Who was the founding member of inhibition? What's the first inhibitory circuit? What's the earliest inhibitory neuron?'

Dr. M:'I'd say it is probably synaptic transmission, and it is also a regulatory function. And I would say also, when it's a synaptic transmission function, it's also regulatory in the sense that a neuron that is inhibited by multiple modulators has to overcome that inhibition so it can participate in a regulatory circuit.'

Dr. B:'Would you say that there is a single neuron that is a perfect example for inhibitory cells? Is there such a perfect example? Is there one neuron that could be called a perfect example? Or is there a family of perfect example neurons?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think there's one that is a perfect. I mean, there are a number of neurons that contribute to synaptic transmission, that contribute to inhibitory synaptic transmission. Of course, you know, the lateral gastric (LG) neuron is part of the STG and is part of synaptic transmission. But it's used not only for synaptic transmission but also to reduce oscillation.'

Dr. M:'I'm going to answer from the biological standpoint because I think, you know, we can, we can always talk about the function. You know, what the function is for inhibitory neurons, and we know that these cells are going to contribute to synaptic transmission. We know that they are going to contribute not just to synaptic transmission, but to synaptic depression. There is a whole suite of other contributions.'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibitory neurons are not essential. For example, you and I, we have inhibitory neurons that can be very strongly activated. Inhibition is a normal part of neural activity, but some neurons use it in ways that are totally inappropriate. So the idea that you need to have a tonic inhibitory drive to a neuron to make it perform a particular function is absolutely wrong. So, the function of inhibition depends on its context, and what its properties.'

Dr. B:'So, when you are in a neural syntax and you are looking at how information is organized, it is essential for you to look at how information is processed. Now, when you go back to the idea that inhibition is a fundamental brain mechanism, it is a fundamental brain function, and you would say that it is essential for neuronal operations that is a completely different idea.'

Dr. M:'Oh, it is not essential, that is right. So, for example, there are neurons in the brain that have properties that are different, and the properties of other neurons are different, and yet they are different neurons. So in that sense, it is important to realize that there are neurons in a brain that have properties, that are different but are neurons. Because neurons are neurons, right. That's one of the important ideas about neurons. So, neurons are neurons.'

Dr. B:'And how is inhibition used to affect neuronal operations? What is the mechanism? And, for example, are inhibition-induced processes different from other kinds of inhibitory processes? What are the differences? And what kind of mechanisms could be involved? What are the potential mechanisms? What are the mechanisms? What are some of the potential mechanisms? In this case, what are the mechanisms? And what are some of the possible mechanisms? Are there any other mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons have a number of roles. They're often important in stabilizing network activity. They're important in regulating the duration of network bursts. They're important as negative amplifiers in network excitability. And also the inhibition itself is a very important component in synaptic transmission. It's responsible for post-transmitter changes in synaptic transmission. So, the presence of inhibitory neurons makes it possible to alter synaptic transmission.'
Dr. B:'In which direction should we look?'

Dr. M:'Well, if we're interested in the function of a neuron, we can do many different things. I think the two are complementary. And we should look both at what the function of a brain neuron might be, and also how a cell or a network is itself functioning.'
Dr. B:'Could you give an example for a neuron which is specifically involved in one function or another, and also what that function is?'

Dr. M:'Okay, so as a general rule, when you find a neuron that is specifically involved in a functional task, there's a strong indication that that neuron is doing it because its evolutionarily related, genetically, to other neurons that are doing it. And therefore, you can make some predictions about what its function is going to be and how it's going to behave.'
Dr. B:'Is that the case? Are there neurons that are specifically involved in one role or the other?'

Dr. M:'And there are certainly neurons that are involved in a specific role. In my mind, I think most neuronal circuits are involved in a number of different tasks. And, you know, when you think about a network, like a network is not really a static entity. Like neurons and networks change their properties over time, and over time the roles of these neurons change.'

Dr. B:'So you can use the example of the hippocampus, which we know very well about how it works. And what it does in the sense of processing and storing information. And then the second thing is the role of inhibition in that process. So, in the hippocampus, in particular, that process is critical because inhibition and activity, activity alone would simply be very inefficient. Because in order for an excitatory action to be carried out, you need to have inhibition.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely.'
Dr. M:'To have inhibition.'

Dr. B:'That's right. And so, it's very important that there's inhibition. I'm not asking you to write a paper, but it's important that we understand what we're talking about. We're not saying that this is an issue. I'm just asking you to consider, that inhibition is a fundamental thing that needs to be understood. Because it's, it's an extremely important piece of function in a very important piece of architecture.'

Dr. M:'I think the best example is the pyloric neurons in the pyloric circuit in the pacemaker group of the pyloric network. And what happens when the pacemaker group becomes active is that they initiate the pacemaker rhythm, which gives rise to the pyloric rhythm that gives rise to the entire nervous system. It's very important to understand how the pacemaker neurons are able to generate the pyloric rhythms that give rise to the entire brain.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons? Well, what about positive-reinforcing neurons?'
Dr. B:'Inhibition is a positive-reinforcers in the brain, what about excitatory neurons? Do not forget inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. M:'The role of inhibitory neurons is to release substances that act on neuromodulatory systems and other circuits.'
Dr. B:'What do these substances do?'

Dr. M:'Well, this is really interesting. We don't really know why inhibitory neurons fire, but they fire because there are modulatory projections from higher-order neurons onto them, and they fire, and they release substances that then act on the networks that they control, either to excite or to inhibit.' So, this is a process that we don't really understand yet. It's not a simple process. I mean, it's been studied.'
Dr. B:'I agree. So if this is a process we don't understand, why is it so important? I mean, it seems like it's a big unsolved mystery.'

Dr. M:'It's a mystery. Right. I mean, what we know is it seems to be important for neural coding and also for other functions, like memory formation and synaptic transmission. So, I mean, there are all kinds of important processes that don't really get worked out in the normal course of working on the brain. I mean, we study the brain for decades, we find out that neurons and circuits of neurons and circuits of circuits are important for cognitive functions, for memory formation and synaptic connections.'

Dr. B:'But it still appears to be a mystery why these networks fire. It's not just like, it's, uh, a, uh, a kind of a big, mysterious box, and we say, oh, uh, we know that in this area, it makes a difference in this area. And then it's done. We know it. Then it's solved.'

Dr. B:'How are the inhibitory circuits controlled? Does anyone know? Is it in any way controlled by brain rhythms? Are there any rhythms in the brain that are controlled by inhibitory systems? Or are the inhibitory systems controlled by some brain rhythms? I would like to know.'

Dr. M:'Oh no, no. The neurons that release the substances are controlled by modulatory neurons. They can be controlled by neurons that are in the brain or they can be controlled by descending neurons that send descending inputs to the brain. So, in other words, if you want to control the neurons that release the neuropeptides, the neurons that release these substances, there are descending projection neurons that release substances that act in the brain.'

Dr. B:'Does anyone know what these substances are? What these neuropeptides are? What these neuromodulators are? What these descending neurons are? Can you please give us a quick summary? I'm asking because I'm trying to build up my understanding.'

Dr. M:'Yeah. I mean, these are peptides and neurotransmitters. So, these are amines and neurohormones. So these are small molecule substances that bind to receptors. So, these have quite high affinity for some of these sites. Some of them have quite high affinity, and these substances will bind to a variety of receptor sites, so it's important to know which one it's going to bind to. Because then you want to release it in certain contexts.'

Dr. B:'Is the inhibition controlled by brain rhythms, in any way? What are brain rhythms that are being controlled by inhibition? In other words, is there a rhythm in the brain that is being controlled by inhibitory neurotransmission?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't know. I have read papers that have demonstrated that these neurons are rhythmic, because they have to release this stuff that they've got that has to reach its target. But we're working on understanding how the rhythm of these neurons interacts with the modulation of these neurons that are controlling the rhythms, that are controlling these rhythms.'

Dr. B:'What are brain rhythms that can be controlled by inhibition? Is there one? What are the oscillations that are being controlled? Is there a particular brain state that can be affected by inhibition? In the hippocampus, in the neocortex, in the thalamus? Do they have special names? Do they have any special name that they're being controlled? Is this a known process that has been studied?'

Dr. M:'We're studying how the neurons that produce the rhythmic motor patterns that control the heart and the muscles and the nerves of the heart, we're studying how those rhythmic neurons are affected by neuromodulators. We're studying how those neurons are affected by drugs that can act on neurons that produce neurotransmitters and hormones and affect other systems. So, it's studying how the motor patterns that are produced by rhythmic neurons are controlled, how rhythmic neurons are regulated.'

Dr. B:'Can we get an example, let's say in the hippocampus, which is, of course, a very well understood brain area? Can we get a sample, and show how inhibition of neurons in this area can impact neuronal activity? So, lets say the hippocampus as an example. Can we get a sampling from the hippocampal neurons that can be affected?'
Dr. B:'Do we know that?'

Dr. M:'I think we do. Let me explain how we think about the role of inhibition in the nervous system. When you think about how neural networks work, we often think about a large circuit and the activity of one cell is quite different than the activity of another. When a cell fires tonically for long periods of time, as opposed to firing irregularly or bursting, for example, it becomes a pacemaker.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the pacemaker?'

Dr. M:'We know that a lot of these inhibitory substances that have been shown to be produced from these inhibitory neurons, they also have other actions, because they've been shown to block action potential generation. Inhibitory neuron substances can cause the voltage-dependent channels that are in the membrane to move from one activation potential to a different potential.'
Dr. B:'What is the function?'

Dr. M:'There are a few studies, which are relatively good, that suggest that some of the same substances that come from these inhibitory neuron and that you can measure in these neurons may actually have other roles.'
Dr. B:'Are there are studies that are excellent and there are studies that have mixed results that have been reviewed?'

Dr. M:'Yes. That has been the problem. So that you know, there are very, very good studies of these substances from these neurons that also have shown that they act as an inhibitory transmitter, they act as an aminergic transmitter, they act like a neurotoxin, they act like an antioxidant, they act like they're protective against oxidative damage. You know, there are all kinds of things that they can do that are different from just, you know, inhibiting action potential generation.'
Dr. B:'How could inhibiting action potentials have beneficial effects that do not occur with inhibiting neurotransmission? It would be nice if you could give some examples that are more detailed.'
Dr. M:'Right, so that's another one of the potential mechanisms that the inhibitory neuron has. It can change the membrane potential and then alter the activity of the neuron.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are part of the normal circuit that generates rhythmic motor patterns. Some of them control muscle contraction, and some control neuronal circuits. There are many different inhibitory neurons with multiple different targets.'
Dr. B:'So there are many different types of inhibitory neurons that can exert an impact on their targets?'
Dr. M:'Yes, well, and so neurons can respond to multiple neuromodulators. So we have these multiple pathways, and each neuron in a circuit can respond to multiple modulators.'
Dr. B:'Could a single inhibitory neuron exert a large impact on its targets in the same way that a single pyramidal neuron can? I'm thinking in terms of synaptic connectivity and firing rates.'

Dr. M:'Well I don't think a single neuron can exert a large influence. I mean the question of synaptic connectivity and the influence of an inhibitory neuron on its target is an interesting question because it's not clear how much synapses it is receiving. So if you're talking about a single neuron you're talking about one synapse. So you can't think that a single neuron is the same as a pyramidal cell. But that is a key part of the argument that we're making.'
Dr. B:'Are there any neurons that have such powerful connectivity to their targets that they can? How about pyramidal cells?'

Dr. M:'They have two or three synaptic connections, but they have many, many inputs and many many more output synapses. So you might be able to think of a single neuron and say well it doesn't make sense that it would make any connections, but many neurons can respond to neuromodulation. And so the problem with understanding how an inhibitory neuron might exert a large influence on its target is the difficulty that we face is understanding how much synapses there are.'
Dr. B:'Where in the brain is inhibitory activity? How do we know where inhibitory neurons are?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons have two functions. They inhibit the amplitude of a burst; they can cause an increase in frequency of the oscillation. Also they can have a more complicated, nonlinear effect on the amplitude and frequency of the burst in response to a stimulus, and it's very complicated to study.'
Dr. B:'Why is it so difficult to study? You can look at it as a purely mathematical exercise.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for example of the hippocampus? Do inhibitory neurons have a role in hippocampal function?'

Dr. M:'The hippocampus has two inhibitory inputs that can play a role. One of the inputs is the inhibitory neuron from the cardiac ganglion, and the other is the inhibition from the cardiac ganglia. These inhibitory neurons both have the same action potential waveform, they both fire the same voltage. So the first thing to ask is what is the waveform of the action potential? Is it different in the two neurons? Is it different between the two neurons?'

Dr. B:'Is it different? I don't know. If it is, there must be something that explains why the inhibition is so different. What is the explanation? What does the neuron use to measure inhibition? Does it use a single channel? Do we know if it uses a single channel? Does it use two different channels? What is the input that brings about inhibition? Does it work with a single channel? Or does it have multiple channels?'

Dr. M:'It does have multiple channels. The cardiac ganglion has two neurons that fire the same voltage, the STG and the PDG. There are two or three different channels, I don't remember the exact number. They have multiple channels. It uses both channels and multiple neurons. There are two neurons that fire in the same group. They have very similar, identical voltage waveforms, but they have two different conductances, and they have multiple different voltage-gated channels.'
Dr. B:'Does the neuron show up in the slice preparations? Do you see the neuron in the slice?'

Dr. M:'We see the neuron in each of the slice preparations, and we see the different actions of the neurons. One of the things we discovered in the cardiac ganglions of the heart is that there are multiple neurons with different waveforms that fire the same voltage in different frequencies, and this is the only way to understand the frequency response of the hippocampus. The only way to understand it is by finding multiple neurons with similar waveforms.'
Dr. B:'What is the difference between principal cells and interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Principal cells are the cells that project to the larger structures, the ganglia and the muscle. It is known that principal cells are the cells of action potential generation. Interneurons are cells that have a neuromodulator action. They send chemical signaling to the circuit. Interneuron projection cells are the cells we study.'
Dr. B:'Which type of cells are inhibitory interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibitory interneuron projection cells, also known as sensory cells, are the cells that can receive stimuli. They can receive a variety of stimuli, such as electrical, chemical, and visual, and their projection cells can either project to the brain or the muscle.'

Dr. M:'The principal cells are the large neurons that contain most of the voltage-gated ion channels in the cell body. The neurons that have most of the voltage gated conductance are called the major neurons, and they are the principal cells. These are the main drivers of the activity.'
Dr. B:'What would be a very simple but useful experiment to study this function?'
Dr. M:'One would be to construct an oscillator that would use a given inhibitory input and show that it increased the frequency of the oscillator.'
Dr. B:'What is the importance of timing? What are the implications of inhibition, in general, on brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'So what you can study is the dynamics of networks. We can study the dynamics of circuits of neurons that are part of the central nervous system, such as in the STG, or in the nervous system of a higher-order animal, like a mammal, or a human being. So what you're going to do is you're going to study the dynamics of networks, and you're going to use experimental methods to study how the dynamics of networks is shaped by neuromodulation.'
Dr. B:'How important is brain structure? Do neurons in different brain regions have different functions? Do they respond differentially to stimuli?'

Dr. M:'Different neurons might have different responses, so that's one of the reasons why it's important to be able to access brain sections, and to be able to look at multiple brain sections, and be able to look deep into the brain is you're going be looking at neurons and networks of neurons that are each individually doing something, that are all acting together to give you the complex brain function.'

Dr. B:'I would suggest that they are there to provide a context for the activity of excitatory cells, which is important for the brain. In other words, there is always inhibition. What I mean is that without inhibition, there would be no inhibition, there would not be any, but we could not do anything else.'

Dr. M:'I wouldn't agree with that, because there is also inhibition in single excitatory neurons. In single neurons, a single excitatory neuron can have inhibitory interactions with other neurons. So, it is not simply one neuron, but two neurons. It is a circuit that can be formed.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is an important factor in making brain rhythms, which is a necessary requirement for cognition. The rhythms in the brain occur in two different ways: one is when there is a strong input from the body, and when the input comes from a very small number of neurons, the brain responds with very high frequency oscillation, which is very short in duration.'

Dr. M:'Like a pyloric circuit in a nervous system, that is, like the pyloric circuit. When there are very few cells or very small circuits, it can respond to a transient input with the frequency of a pyloric rhythm.'

Dr. B:'There is a fundamental difference between the brain's response to very few neurons and to very large numbers of neurons, because the latter group of neurons can give rise to very long lasting oscillations. But there is also a fundamental difference between a small number of neurons and a large number of neurons that, too, can give rise to the generation of long-lasting oscillations, even when the brain receives its inputs very irregularly.'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, a few hundred or a few thousand neurons can be responsible for generating the rhythmic bursts of excitation. If you go back to some of the previous papers I think that, you know, you talk about a thousand neurons. I mean, if you have a thousand neurons, then you have enough numbers that each of these neurons is going to receive enough excitation to elicit a spike from at least one neuron, and so the network can work.'
Dr. B:'When you say the stimulus, we can assume that you mean external perturbations or some stimulus that comes to the brain.'

Dr. M:'Okay, right. So when we talk about the stimulus, we mean external stimuli that might come to the brain.' You know, like, for example, there are the sensory systems in animals, and the sensory system comes to the brain, and you know it's, there's a large number of sensory neurons, so it's not entirely external, but these sensory neurons will also be inhibited.'

Dr. B:'How would you expect that to happen? For example, how does a brain respond to the, to a natural stimulus? Is that what we call a native input that causes a native response? What's that stimulus? What's the stimulus? In what sense is the native stimulus? So what's the stimulus in the brain? Is it the native stimulus? Is it the natural stimulus, or is it the sensory input? Is it the internal stimulus?'

Dr. M:'Well, it could be any of the stimuli that you would be aware of. The stimulus could be some chemical substance that comes into the brain, or the stimulus could be some other kind of sensory input, a visual input or auditory input that is a stimulus that comes into the eye or the ear, and we have to be aware of that. I mean, you know, we talk about the animal that eats.'

Dr. B:'It eats? So you have to be aware that you are aware. So in that sense, this stimulus would be a different stimulus. So the stimulus would be that you are aware of that stimulus and its consequences, and the stimulus would be a signal that comes into the head and affects the brain. So there's no difference. The only thing that is different is that you are aware that it comes to the brain. You could call that a native stimulus and the stimulus as the external stimuli.'

Dr. M:'Sure, and so I mean, and if we think about a neuron that just starts firing and if you think about, like, say we're talking about an isolated neuron that just starts to fire, and it starts firing and it starts firing, so we have to be, we have to be careful about that. So what we do is, what we do is we, as we study the brain, we study these individual neurons.'
Dr. B:'So the response is not to the stimulus but to a set of inhibitory neurons that have an effect on the response.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that's the stimulus, and when it comes to the brain it can have multiple effects.'

Dr. M:'A lot of work has gone into understanding how synaptic inhibition shapes network output. The simple answer, which I have always argued and which is so obvious that it might not be necessary to argue, is that the inhibition of a given cell depends on which other cell(s) that are active, and the strength of the synaptic inhibition of the active cell will depend on how strong the synaptic inhibition of all other cells.'
Dr. B:'How do we measure synaptic strength? Is it quantitative or qualitative, like a thermodynamic change?'

Dr. M:'I'm not going to discuss that much more because I think if you're interested in understanding network dynamics you're going to spend a good deal of time reading about synaptic strength, but I'm assuming that you know that synaptic strengths are quantified by synaptic potential recordings with dynamic clamp and that they will be graded.'

Dr. B:'I'm really not sure what my answer is to this question, but the synaptic strength measurement is a great start because we know what is being measured. What is the function of the neuron? What is the function? What is its function? Do we have a clear idea about its functions or can we look at some of these experiments to get some clues?'
Dr. M:'Well, they help us, you know, to sort out how much stuff is going on in the brain, and which neurons are doing what.'
Dr. B:'They do more than that.'

Dr. B:'Right. So I was just wondering, is the function of neuronal networks the same? Is it still, like, to be a brain, to do this and that? Or is it actually to do something else, that's not what we are interested in, or not exactly what you want to do? Is that the new goal of the brain? Or will it still, eventually, try to do what it always did? Or are there new goals for the brain?'
Dr. M:'There are a bunch of different things that you could do, right?'

Dr. B:'Yeah. What is the function of this? What is the function? Do we want to make this go away? Or maybe to build on it and modify it? Or just try to change its dynamics. What is the meaning? I want to go back to the brain, to understand what this means, and what that means. What is the neural syntax? It's a bit like the way we have to talk, right? Like this, right?'
Dr. B:'So there is no special function? What are the functions that they do? What is the function of neurons? What is the basic function of a neuron?'

Dr. M:'Oh yeah. Well, you know, they are not just sort of, you know, firing at each other and making a circuit. There is something more to it. They also help us to sort out how our brains are working, to sort out what neurons are firing together. How much information is coming in, how it is being processed, and, you know, so I think, I think this is one of those, like, we just got to figure out how brain works.'

Dr. B:'What is the function? What is the role of inhibitory neurons in the brain? What is the main role of inhibitory interneurons in the brain? The, the primary role? What is their function? The, the, the primary role?'

Dr. M:'Yes. Well, there is, you know, there is one kind of primary role, but I think the more important role is, you know how the brain works. There is a function to them, right? The function, they are part of circuit. So they, you know, the brain is really a circuit, and, you do need circuits for the brain to work. Right? But we also need to figure out how the circuit works.'

Dr. M:'I think I would say it is to, you know, help you sort out how much activity is going on in your brain, and which of your neurons are doing what. So, for example, if I am trying to do a calculation, like doing a calculation, you know, because you are always trying to work with, and work with numbers, and try to figure out how to do calculations, you know, or how to do something with numbers.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. I mean, I'm looking at the brain in a different way, though. I'm looking at a particular aspect of it as an inputoutputoutput? function. I'm looking in particular, you know, at how we take in information, and we send out information, and, and I'm trying to figure out how we do that.'
Dr. M:'I don't know that.'
Dr. B:'Oh, OK. Do you have any ideas?'
Dr. M:'Sure, I have a million ideas but no one listens to me.'
Dr. B:'Well, you know, I can make you my listener.'

Dr. B:'I'm glad that you can't get rid of it. So here's an idea. Inhibitory cells have a bunch of ion channels that allow them to control the excitability of principal cells. This ion channel can also open and close, so that if you are inhibitory neurons you can control the open probability of the channel and it allows the principal cells to fire. There are many more inhibitory cells than principal cells.'

Dr. B:'That's easy. It is to constrain activity of principal cells, in which case inhibition is a necessary condition. For example, neurons in the hippocampus are interconnected through inhibitory synapses, and a single layer of pyramidal cells is controlled by only a small set of neurons called interneurons. They can provide the needed inhibition to the pyramidal neurons, thus effectively controlling the firing of the principal cells.'
Dr. M:'OK, how does that happen?'
Dr. B:'We are going to give you an answer, but the answers are coming from other people and not directly from me. So here are the conditions, you're the excitatory pyramidal neurons.'
Dr. M:'So then, is your answer that the interneurons provide inhibition to the pyramids?'

Dr. B:'No, that's not the case. Interneurons do not provide inhibition to the principal cells. The pyramidal cells are in the middle and have the necessary energy, and they are driven by inhibition. If you look at the excitability map in the brain, pyramidal cells have high excitability. They are very active and do a lot of things in the brain. They have very low synaptic inhibition, which is in fact what drives the principal cells.'

Dr. M:'It can be either to activate a certain cell type or to constrain that cell type. So, it is an intrinsic property. It is a property that a neuron has as a consequence of evolution, in terms of its connectivity, that it has the ability to inhibit other cells.'

Dr. B:'And that ability can be a useful function in terms of maintaining a stable, consistent pattern in the absence of an outside influence. But there are other mechanisms that are used to inhibit, which can be useful too. For example, in the hippocampus, the major inhibitory cell types are inhibitory interneurons, and their main function is to limit the activity of pyramidal neurons. And I can call them as the "pacemaker" of the hippocampus.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, so that can be useful. There is a mechanism that allows the pacemaker cells to inhibit other cells in the network, but that doesn't make them necessarily a control mechanism. You can have control mechanisms in networks as well, and that is, as I call it, a second level of control, a mechanism that is responsible for controlling the activation of other neurons in the network, as well as regulating that network itself. And I think it is quite different.'
Dr. B:'But you know, how much of the world's knowledge could be lost if they didn't exist?'

Dr. B:'It seems to be a critical element, but what is it? The function of inhibitory interneurons in the hippocampus is to control the timing of pyramidal cells. In other words, they provide precision timing and synchronization of pyramidal cell spikes. What is the function of inhibition in other structures? In particular, in prefrontal cortex and the amygdala, where they inhibit pyramidal cells, the function is to determine whether or not to inhibit.'

Dr. M:'And it seems to be used for other functions. The function of inhibition in prefrontal cortex is to determine whether to inhibit. And in the amygdala, it seems to be very important for determining whether to inhibit or to excite. So, it seems to me that in most networks, when it comes to the function of inhibition, you'd want to know what is the function of the inhibition.'

Dr. B:'So, I don't know that. I would just be surprised if inhibition is the only function. That's just my guess. But there is no doubt that inhibition is extremely important. It's just a question whether it's the only function. What are the other functions? And the reason I ask is because there are other functions that interneurons can perform. There are many types of interneurons.'
Dr. M:'If I had to guess, I'd guess the amygdala does inhibit pyramidal cell activity. In general, a tonic inhibition might be required to keep pyramidal cells in the appropriate place.'

Dr. B:'You're wrong. For example, in visual cortex, inhibitory neurons are the key players of synchronizing pyramidal cells activity. In the hippocampus, they prevent excitation of pyramidal neurons by CA3 inputs. What is the role of inhibitory neurons in the neocortex? I don't know.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is a basic process of neurobiology. What is the function of inhibition? Is it good or bad? Does it make things more complicated or simpler? If you can say, oh, I'm going to stop all inhibitory neurons, they're going to make a mess, it's going to make a really big difference.'
Dr. M:'It may, it may, it may.'

Dr. B:'Or would it just cause problems of its own? Maybe we don't need inhibition, or maybe we shouldn't try to stop it. Or if you have to pick one of the two, let's say one of the sides, it's better to just try to understand how it works, or the other one is just a disaster. What is the best way to use inhibition, if that's what the main job is, to understand, to find out how inhibition works?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are plenty of papers on inhibitory neurons. I mean, we know that some neurons inhibit other neurons, and that is really important for behavior, for motor neurons, sensory neurons. Some neurons inhibit other neurons. That's well studied, and a lot of papers on that. We've also looked at the importance of some inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'I think so. We have done a number of studies on interneurons. What is it like to work with them? Do they have interesting quirks that we can see, do we have a handle on how they work? Are they the same as principal cells, or what? What is the story that can be told, and what can be understood with inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. M:'Well, inhibition is kind of a double-edged sword.'

Dr. B:'What is the function? I mean, how can I help? Inhibitory neurons have many different functions: inhibition can be a pro-cess or it can be a result or an outcome. So it has a dual role, it can either be the cause or it can be the effect. What is the effect? And what is the cause? It's really the same.'
Dr. B:'Double-edged, double-edged sword, well, maybe there are better, better words to express the same idea.'
Dr. M:'Yes, right.'

Dr. B:'And I'm going to start with this. I think that the function of inhibition is to simplify the brain to make it a little bit more manageable. In a sense, inhibition serves to make things a little bit less complicated or complicated, and then a little bit more complicated. The double-edge of inhibition is a good example. It's a double-edged thing. And I'm going to look at some of those things, which are the simplest and more complicated things that you are thinking about.'
Dr. M:'Right, right.'

Dr. B:'Now, one of those things is that simple is that it is a function of some complicated stuff, which is that inhibition works in harmony with all parts of the brain. Now, this is one of the many ways in which inhibition can work for a function.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'There is another way that inhibition can work. And this is the way that we are going to look at it. We are going to look and see what is the best strategy for inhibition to function well. Now, there are many ways in which to do it. The reason why I would like to talk about inhibition and inhibition-based oscillations is because it works for the brains best.'
Dr. B:'They are not the only excitatory neurons.'
Dr. M:'No, but their excitation is amplified by a series of feedbacks.'
Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons can also receive input from other inhibitory cells and respond in the same way as other neurons.'

Dr. M:'It turns out that there are a lot of different functions for inhibitory neurons, that depends on what other neurons do. It is also important that in the nervous system, there are many, many different types of inhibitory neurons that can do different things. That is important in development, as well as in disease, because in many different systems, these inhibitory neurons can be targeted to achieve different outcomes.'
Dr. B:'Are there some examples from development? Do you have an example that we might consider? If you have one that we could consider, please share it with the audience.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that inhibition plays? What happens if you get rid of inhibition? What happens when you suppress these inhibitory cells? What happens when they are activated?'

Dr. M:'So I think it is important, when you study inhibitory neurons, you ask the question: 'what do you want to happen when you suppress these neurons? What happens when these neurons are not inhibited?' Because that will tell you, or the answer might be that, 'when you don't put those neurons in there, they are useless.' If you want to study something that is a bit more complicated, then you can take the same approach as you do with neurons that are excitatory.'

Dr. B:'Do we know what happens when you get rid of these inhibitory cells in the cortex, for example, if the activity of pyramidal cells is increased? Are we able to answer that? We don't have the capability to directly answer those questions. But in the hippocampus, or in the cerebral cortex, we can study what happens when inhibitory cells are not inhibited.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, that is interesting. I mean, I know that if you don't suppress the pyramidal cell activity in the cortex, then these neurons just go away and their function is basically destroyed. Because it is like it will no longer be regulated, and it doesn't really do much, because it is not regulated, like you can see this.'

Dr. B:'In the hippocampus, or the cerebral cortex, or other areas that have a well understood inhibitory network, we can find what happens when those inhibitory cells are inhibited. In the hippocampus, the hippocampus, there is theta oscillations, and there are many things that happen during theta oscillations that are not happening when those inhibitory neurons are inhibited. This is what happens when inhibitions are activated. So, this is the main function of inhibition.'

Dr. M:'Mmmhmm, that is interesting because, you know, I had a different function before I worked on this. I worked in neurophysiology, and the idea that we used to think about it, is that the purpose of inhibition was to keep the neurons in a safe zone where the oscillator can make decisions about where to travel to find food, where to feed.'

Dr. M:'That is the way that I am trying to think about it, and I like to think about how does the brain work, how neurons work in general, in general. So, I think that is the way that we think about this, that the neuron is the sort of starting point to thinking about the brain. So, what are all these processes that allow you to do things like memory, attention? How does the brain function?'

Dr. B:'So it turns out that there is no shortage of different types of inhibition in the brain. In the hippocampus, in the entorhinal cortex, in the prefrontal cortex, in the basal ganglia, in the amygdala, in the subiculum. And so on, so on. The different types of inhibition can do very different things. And those different things are what we would like to study. It is very interesting. I want to know how inhibitory neurons work.'
Dr. M:'It's a very important component of studying neural networks, because you will be studying circuits with hundreds and thousands of neurons that all have different kinds of properties.'

Dr. B:'I'm not interested in wiring or inhibition per se, but in the function of inhibition. It's a question that is very relevant to understanding how the brain works. And it is the function that is the very interesting aspect of inhibition, and how you make that function disappear in the context of neural networks. And I have a particular, uh, interest in the inhibitory neurons that are responsible for suppressing pyramidal cells in the hippocampus and in prefrontal cortex, for example.'
Dr. B:'So how many different ways can inhibitory neurons do things? What is the function of GABAergic interneurons?'

Dr. M:'There are multiple functions of GABAergic inter-neurons. The important function of GABAergic neurons is to create the right balance between the excitatory and inhibitory drive in the brain. The brain doesn't need both excitatory and GABAergic drive, it can just use GABA if GABA is present. It does not need both.'
Dr. B:'What is the function, if any, of inhibitory interneurons in the hippocampus? Is there a specific function for inhibitory interneuron types in the hippocampus?'

Dr. M:'I don't know, I don't think there is. The function of interneurons is to produce the right balance in the network. I would not rule out a specific function of individual interneuron types. They may well have distinct functions that we don't know about.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the inhibitory network as a whole?'

Dr. M:'Well, the inhibitory network plays a very important role in many different processes, because it can be targeted and can be controlled by modulators. So there are many different ways to modify the behavior of the system. It plays an important role in development, of course, because we see this with different types of inhibitors. Inhibitory neurons play an important role in regulating the behavior of the network.'

Dr. B:'How do we think about their functions and the interactions between excitatory and inhibitory cells? Do we consider them to be separate networks or is there any reason to consider them separate, or can we consider them as a network and try to understand how those mechanisms interact?'

Dr. M:'When we first started thinking about neural activity in the nervous system it was thought that neurons were 'cell types' that could be measured by their morphology and their electrophysiological properties. You think about neuronal 'types' as a metaphor for trying to understand the function of a particular neuron. And the function of a neuron was determined by its properties, so it was thought that every neuron had its own distinct properties that would determine its unique functions.'

Dr. B:'But, in reality, no one knows what a neuron is, what is a neuron? The only thing that we have been able to reliably determine is that when neurons are active they do a thing. We know this because we have seen it repeatedly. But the thing that they do has a wide distribution.'

Dr. M:'Yes, the distributions that you see are a consequence of intrinsic properties. So one of the functions of the neural activity is to show you when you are doing things, you are not doing it correctly, you need to learn to do it properly. So that gives you a very good indication about the behavior of a neuron, because you can compare it with your neighbors.'

Dr. B:'I agree with this idea that a lot of different processes are under the control of intrinsic activity. It is the nature of neurons to respond to the activity that they receive. This is a result of their biology. This has been a topic in several books and I can't go into all of them. But in this book there is a particular focus on how to see the function in terms of the interactions between excitation and inhibition.'

Dr. M:'I have always thought that when you think about the brain, you think about the nervous system as having a set of neurons that respond to each other, they interact. But in most of our brains, there is not that. So you can get away with just having a neuron that responds to itself and does its own thing. But you also need to respond to other neurons.'

Dr. M:'And so our thought process was, well, we know that neurons have properties that are unique to each of them. So that they have their own unique properties and that they will respond to modulators in a very different way. And also because of the fact that many neurons can coexist. So there are neurons that will be coexpressed together as part of a network, and these neurons will respond to neuromodulators in a coexpressed fashion.'

Dr. M:'Well, they're really important. They control the balance between, as it was put in a recent study, the slow and fast, the weak and the strong, so that there can be more of the weak and more of the strong at the same time.'
Dr. B:'What is the importance of the short-term? plasticity mechanisms that take place in these inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. M:'So what I think is important about synaptic inhibition and synaptic transmission is the effect it can have on network performance, which may or may not be immediate, and the other thing that it can do is that it can set up longer-term mechanisms that can change the dynamics of the network. You know, as you grow and develop, there can be changes, alterations of synaptic strengths that may be useful for changing the dynamics of the circuits, and these changes can be seen in changes of synaptic strengths.'
Dr. B:'That's a good, easy answer, but what is the function of inhibition that actually gives rise to it?'

Dr. M:'It's like the function of a relay system. The relay system, for example, is part of an electrical circuit. When the circuit is activated, the relay system kicks off, and it can release a neurotransmitter onto a target neuron, which is the one that sends the final action potential into the circuit, so that the final action potential is generated from the target neuron and not from the relay system itself.'

Dr. B:'This is a very interesting question, but how would you answer it? Why would it be important? Do we not have enough knowledge? How many pieces and pieces there are in the brain, and what is their function? Can you answer me these questions? The reason that I asked you these questions, because I asked the question to both you and Marder recently in our, um, in our book.'

Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons inhibit other neurons. For example, in the stomatogastric nervous system, the pacemaker neurons fire with the pyloric rhythm, and the PY neurons fire with the gastric mill rhythm.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons are part of the cortex. What is the function of cortex? And this is the brain. And this is the spinal cord. Inhibitory neurons have a special relationship with excitatory neurons. The relationship is called inhibitory.'
Dr. M:'Excitatory neurons excite inhibitory neurons and inhibit excitatory neurons'.'
Dr. B:'The cortex is made up of excitatory neurons and inhibitory neurons'.'

Dr. M:'The cortex is a network of excitatory and inhibitory neurons. Inhibitory connections are important for maintaining connectivity. Excitatory neurons connect with each other and to neurons in the cortex via inhibitory neurons. For example the pyloric pacemaker neuron, it will fire with the anterior gastric mill and posterior gastric mill neurons, but it will inhibit the lateral pyloric, ventral ventricular, and medial gastric mill neurons because it has inhibitory connections to them.'

Dr. B:'Cortex contains two different types of principal cells, excitatory pyramidal cells and inhibitory interneurons. Pyramidal cells, in addition to their specialized connections, are connected to each other by reciprocal and highly extensive local excitatory connections and by more distant reciprocal connections, but the ratio of local and distant excitatory connections varies from structure to structure.'

Dr. M:'As you go from a cell to a neuron, there's local excitatory inputs, but more distant excitatory inputs. There are synaptic inputs in all directions, and so you have to be very careful in making the local excitatory versus the more distant connections. The interneuron's local excitatories come from multiple sources. So, for example, the lateral pylar neuron has local excitatory and more distant excitator connections.'
Dr. B:'In contrast, the neurons in the basal ganglia, especially the thalamus, have local inhibitory connections only.'
Dr. B:'In contrast, in the cerebral cortex, the neurons of the PYR group do not discharge on the theta cycle but only a few PYR are active at any given moment.'
Dr. M:'They're not active in a pacemaker, but the entire PYR group is active in the cerebral cortex.'
Dr. B:'But you can say the same thing for the CA3 cells. They fire on theta, and their activity is coupled to the theta cycle by a few CA1 pyramidal cells that are active in a pacemakers role.'

Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons have many functions. Inhibitory neurons are also responsible for regulating the balance of excitatory and inhibitory currents. Some neurons are only inhibitory neurons. Some neurons are dual-inhibitory, that is they have both excitatory and/or inhibitory inputs. Some neurons are inhibitory neurons during some stages of their life cycle and other neurons are excitatory neurons.'

Dr. B:'If inhibitory neurons are responsible for regulating the strength of neuronal connections, how does that happen? Is it something that occurs during development or is it something that happens during learning?'

Dr. M:'It is something that occurs during normal development. We see that neurons that are not inhibitory develop in a way that they are able to increase the strength of their connections, and that also increases their firing rate. In contrast, inhibitory neurons can maintain a low firing rate while keeping a stable and strong synaptic connection. The strength of the synaptic connection, and the ability to regulate it, is one of the key features of the phenotype of the neuron.'
Dr. B:'Is it fair to say that the connection between inhibition and learning is not well understood? I mean, how do we make progress on this problem?'

Dr. M:'There is a process by which neurons can be regulated by many modulators at a given time. One of the fascinating things that has been shown over many years, is that neurons have multiple levels of regulation. That is, there are different pathways by which neurons can control synaptic and electrical coupling, and then there are different mechanisms by which the activity of the neurons can be regulated.'
Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons that are active during theta oscillations can control the gain and timing of pyramidal cells. What role do interneurons play in these processes?'

Dr. M:'This is a fascinating topic because it was known that inhibitory neuron activity can control the gain of the pyloric circuit. And then a few years ago we discovered that in certain types of cells, inhibitory activity during the theta oscillation can control the phase of the pylorus during gastric mill formation. It turned out to be crucial.'
Dr. B:'Can we go on to other things like that? Are there other types of interneurons that could be regulated in this manner?'
Dr. B:' What are the functions of pyramidal neurons?'

Dr. M:' Pyramidal neurons are excitotoxic, so they excite other neurons by releasing glutamate, the glutamate ion is a strong excitatory transmitter that activates voltage-dependent ion channels, and is excitable by many, many, many electrical synapses. So pyramidal neurons excite each other and excite other neurons. So pyrami-noids can excite and they can inhibit and they can produce complex patterns of activity.'
Dr. B:' So is the goal of excitation and inhibition the same? Is that all they do?'
Dr. B:' How many different kinds of neurons can we identify?'

Dr. M:' There are tens of millions of neurons in the brain. So there are tens of millions, maybe hundreds of millions neurons in the brain that we have identified that we know about. So many, many neurons have been studied. So many neurons that we know about are distinct from one another, for example the three neurons that are responsible for the pacemaker network in the pylorus and the five neurons that fire at that particular frequency, those are all distinct and they all fire at the same frequency.'
Dr. B:' So there's just no way that there will ever be a list of all the different neuron types. So what makes up the list is the fact that each neuron has a distinct name.'

Dr. B:' Let me start with a few examples that might help illustrate what you are trying to say, which is that I don't want to make assumptions. Let me first ask you a question: Are inhibitory neurons and networks different in their organization than excitatory neurons?'
Dr. M:' No. All neurons and network neurons, excitatory and inhibsory, all neurons and network neurons use the same transmitter. It's the only way that they are connected.'

Dr. B:' Can we say that in the entire universe only a few percent of neurons are inhibitory? For ex-ample, I am a big fan of the brain of the locust. Its inhibitory circuit is very large and very powerful. I would even say it is the most inhibitory circuit in the entire known universe.'

Dr. M:' But that's not what it evolved to do. The entire purpose of the inhibitory network was to regulate the rhythmic firing of the gastric mill and gastric mill oscillators which generate the gastric mill rhythms of the pyloric network. The gastric mill rhythm plays a role in chewing of food.'

Dr. B:' So is it possible that there are other functions of inhibitory neurons? Are there other functions that are not well understood and could be studied with the proper level of scientific scrutiny? And are there neurons that have not yet been identified which are inhibitory neurons but that, for example, may be responsible for gamma rhythms, which are not understood and could be investigated?'

Dr. M:'I think there are some other properties of inhibitory neurons, one of them is a property that you and I do not understand is called 'antagonist suppression' which refers to the fact that in a given circuit, a cell that inhibits another cell in that circuit also acts to inhibit that target cell from excitatory drive to its target neurons. So in our nervous systems, there is an ongoing exchange of feedback between excitatory neurons and inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'In fact, it is not only the brain, it is the entire system. Now, how many inhibitory neurons there are is not well understood. In fact, a neuron that is in an inhibitory network can be depolarized and excited by some inputs and inhibited by others, or activated and inhibited by others. The output of the inhibitory neuron can be the inhibition of any neuron. So in terms of the functional properties of inhibitory neuron, how many of them are there?'

Dr. M:'I think that you are making the point. I think that this is a great illustration. So one point that we make in some of our papers is that when you look at an individual neuron and you look at the intrinsic properties of the cells, and you look at their connectivity, then that gives you the constraints that they must obey as they develop, as they grow, because you can't build a new neuron without knowing how many neurons it is going to interact with.'

Dr. B:'I agree that inhibitory circuits are very well protected by inhibitory neurons, but it is still not clear why it is so special for inhibitory neurons to protect their circuitry, to protect the population, but to protect the individual cells? The neurons in the locust brain are also inhibitory, right?'
Dr. M:'There is this whole series of papers that we have been doing for a long time that show that you can build circuits that you can build networks that have properties that you don't want.'
Dr. B:'What is the best way to understand how inhibitory neurons work together in networks?'

Dr. M:'In general, a complex neuronal circuit involves many neurons that are not necessarily active at the same times. In general, neurons that are not active at the same time or same place interact with each other with inhibitory neurons, and this interaction is very important. It means that they need to be active in a very specific phase of the network.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible to tell from the brain whether a neuron is inhibitory or excitatory? How should one determine what is inhibitory and what is excitatory?'

Dr. M:'This is a very good question. In general, inhibitory neurons are not identified in the brain with any certainty. In general, excitatory neurons are. In some systems, there are excitatory and excitatory neurons that are the same. In some systems there are excitons that are the same as each other. In some systems it is possible to identify excitons with a high degree of confidence.'

Dr. B:'In the neocortex, is it possible to tell what is inhibitory from an electrode, without testing for some markers? For example, is it possible for a neuron in the hippocampus to be a neurogliaform? What about an interneuron in the hippocampus? What markers should be tested for? What markers are used in the lab?'

Dr. M:'The function of inhibitory neural neurons is to regulate the frequency of oscillatory networks by adjusting the time course of synaptic transmission, which is dependent on synaptic transmission rate and the amount of neurotransmitter released. The main problem is, the rate of synaptic transmission is not a fixed property of a neuron, so the adjustment of the synaptic transmission rate is a very complicated problem. When the transmission rate changes, then the amplitude of the synaptic potential decreases.'

Dr. B:'What about spike transmission probability? That does not change with rate of excitatory transmission. In other words, what is the role of inhibitory neurons? Do they do anything else? What are their physiological functions?'

Dr. M:'Right. So it is important to study synaptic transmission, because one can think about spike transmission rate, one can think about synaptic transmission rates, and we are interested in synaptic transmission rates in the pyloric circuit because they are important because that is where we found the pyloric neurons, where we found the PD and PY neurons, so that is where we saw synaptic transmission occur first and that is where we think that synaptic transmission is likely to have the most influence.'

Dr. M:'In this context, the role of inhibitatory neurons is to regulate a number of physiological processes, including synaptic transmission. The main physiological role of the inhibitory neurons is to regulate synaptic transmission via the synaptic potential, and that involves a number of different mechanisms. One mechanism is to provide synaptic depression to inhibit synaptic transmission, by means of synaptic current ( I syn ) and via presynaptic release of some sort of current. And then you have a time course of synaptic depression.'

Dr. B:'How about inhibition of synaptic transmission? How do inhibitory neurons work? Do they have a fixed number of terminals? What are the advantages and disadvantages of inhibition of synaptic transmission, and what are the mechanisms that inhibitory cells regulate? What is the difference between inhibition and suppression? What is the mechanism of synaptic depression? What is the physiological role of inhibition of synaptic potential? What is the role of inhibition in preventing long-term potentiation, and what are their molecular mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'Well, in this case, the physiological role is regulation of synaptic transmission. The physiological role is regulation. We know there are some inhibitory neurons in the central pattern generating network of the spiking pyloric circuits, that have terminal end structures. They're known to be important for synaptic transmission in the network, and are very rich in ion channel genes. So, it is important to regulate synaptic transmission.'

Dr. B:'Now, what is the mechanism of regulation? How does inhibition of synaptic transmission work? What is the importance of inhibition of synaptic transmissions? Is inhibition of synaptic transmission more important than the other forms of inhibition? Do inhibitory neurons have special molecular properties that enable them to do this? What are their molecular mechanisms? How does inhibition work, and what are its molecular mechanisms?'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are neurons that can either excite the target neuron or inhibit it.'
Dr. B:'Is it an active process or it just occurs in a passive way?'
Dr. M:'Both, it can happen in either way.'
Dr. B:'What are the mechanisms that allow these active processes to occur?'

Dr. M:'We are still trying to find them, but the first one that is in place is the passive inhibition that comes from the inhibitory neuron firing a neurotransmitter that is released from its presynaptic membrane to postsynaptic membrane of the target neuron and that inhibits its action potential generation. So that is what happens first, but then there is active generation of action potentials and active release of transmitters, and there are active modulatory circuits.'
Dr. M:'The mechanism is that the same voltage-dependent currents can activate both excitation and inhibition, and it depends on the timing of the release of the neurotransmitter.'
Dr. B:'What are inhibitory neurotransmitters?'
Dr. M:'Neurotransmitters are substances released from neurons that either excite or inhibit target cells in the nervous system.'
Dr. B:'What does it mean to excite or inhibit? Does the action potential have a meaning in the absence of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'The excitatory action potentials are the ones that tell you, the target neuron is going to be activated, and that action potential will have a tonic firing rate. We don't need that. We don't want that. We want spikes that are triggered by other spikes.'
Dr. B:'Do inhibitory neurons use different methods to generate the same function?'

Dr. M:'Inefficacy in generating action potentials is one of the features that we've been studying for many years. In the past we've seen a number of different ways of generating action potentials, such as by releasing a neurohormone that has a synaptic action at a presynaptic site and then using that as a feedback mechanism to trigger excitation at a postsynaptic site, as well as many other kinds of ways.'
Dr. B:'Is there a way of generating the same result in terms of activity by using different mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'No, not that we've studied. I mean, we can do a variety of things with the neurons we have, but what we try to do is to find a simple way to make it do the simple job it was supposed to do. And so there are many ways to achieve that.'

Dr. B:'And it would be a simple job if it is a feedforward, or a feedback circuit. For example, if we had just a few interconnected inhibitory neurons, what would we expect to see? What would we expect to observe? What would we actually see? Is there a simple, small circuit which would generate the exact same pattern in terms of activation in a small number of inhibitory neurons? Or is there a circuit that would generate that pattern using a large number of inhibitory cells?'
Dr. M:'So, the function of the inhibitory neurons in terms of their synaptic relationships is going to be different.'

Dr. B:'I have the following question: What are the differences between inhibitory neurons of the hippocampus and the neocortex, that are similar and different? Is there a common function that they all perform? Or, is it a special function for each group of inhibitory neurons in a given region? And, what are the differences between interneurons in different brain regions that are similar? And what are the differences, which are different, that are similar? Is there a function that they all accomplish?'

Dr. M:'I think, if we really get into the details of these individual neurons, and look at all the synaptic connections, we find that there are many different sets of synaptic connections that produce a given function. That is to say that the circuit that produces a specific behavior, or a specific cognitive function has a number of sets of synaptic connections, and different sets of synaptic connection strength.'
Dr. B:'So, what is the main role of the brain and, more precisely, what is the function of GABAergic neurons?'
Dr. M:'The role of GABAergic neurons is to inhibit the target neuron, to decrease its output, to increase the excitability of the target neuron.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are used for regulating synaptic transmission. If you put a neuron into a pacemaker role you have to have some inhibitory neuron because the membrane potential of the cell is going to be a signal to the rest of the circuit.'
Dr. B:'So the main function of inhibitory cells is to regulate the balance between excitation and inhibition in principal cells and to keep the circuit stable.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, the primary function of the inhibitory neurons is to regulate synaptic transmission, but the secondary function of the inhibitor neurons is to regulate the oscillations in the pyloric circuit and to determine when a pacemaker neuron is firing and when a passive neuron is firing.'

Dr. M:'What they are is not the question. They are important for regulating neural circuits, and one of their functions is to give a sort of synaptic filtering that allows circuits to be more complex and to function correctly in the face of environmental perturbations. So, what we are trying to understand is the fundamental organization of neural circuitry, not just the function of the components of neural circuitry.'

Dr. B:'What is the function that an excitatory neuron would have? I mean, what function would an excitatory pyramidal cell do? Obviously, excitation is the fundamental mode of operation. If you look at neural circuits, you see that, when you are driving a car and the brakes fail, what comes up is an excitatory loop and the excitatory neuron does the same thing as you have brakes, it gets more excitation.'

Dr. M:'Exactly. So, that is one of the main roles of excitatory neurons. One of the other roles of excitative neurons is to provide feedback to the system, and that's particularly important for circuits with multiple neurons, so that you can have feedback to the system so that you can understand how the network is responding, whether it is producing an expected output or it is responding to environmental perturbations.'

Dr. B:'I mean, that's a pretty good argument for excitatory neurons, but it is not an argument for their function. What is their function, for example, if the input to the pyramidal neuron is inversely related to the activity of the pyramidal cell? What if there are no pyramidal neurons in the circuit? What is the function of the interneuron? Is there a function of the inhibitory circuit? Is it there?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think so. But you know what I'm just suggesting, if you think of the model that I'm suggesting, which is that this is a model of a neuron that does not have any kind of intrinsic voltage–dependent properties that it can have a number of conductance types. I'm suggesting that you can have these different conductances. For example, if you have potassium conductance you can have Kd conductance as well.'

Dr. B:'And potassium conductance is a sodium conductance, and sodium conductance is potassium conductance, so potassium conductance is inversely related with sodium conductance. So, we can get in a couple of conductances. What would the membrane potential be? What would be the input? What is the output? Let me just give you some examples. The simplest circuit is just an input-output function. It's a very simple example that is very easy to understand.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think that's a really good point. I mean, if the inputs to the interneuron are related to the inhibition of the pyramic cells and the activation of the anterior ganglia cells, you would think that the function of the circuit would be to generate rhythmic excitation of these neurons. So, we are trying to establish the general principles of neural circuitry and how neurons might be organized into networks.'

Dr. B:'One of the things that we have been trying to do is to understand how neurons connect to each other. I mean, a few studies have been done, but what are the general principles of the mechanisms? So if I give you a billion neurons, how many of them would you need to have for connectivity? And what is the probability that I would get a billion neurons that are connected to each other? I'm wondering about the theoretical upper limit that might be the most probable.'

Dr. M:'Oh, that's a really important question, because it turns out that neurons in a network can be organized into modules, and there are several of these neural cell types that can be distributed around. In the stomatogastric ganglion, there are five distinct types of neurons that are connected, each other, and to neurons in the brain. And if you think about how these neurons are connected, it is by synaptic connections, not by electrical connections.'

Dr. B:'So, what is the probability? Let's say a billion neurons. How many synapses would I have to have for a billion neurons? What is the probability that you could have a billion synapses? Is it impossible? Are there certain limitations? What limitations might there be? We would like to know what the limitations might be. Are there a maximum limit that could be the theoretical limit, or is it highly dependent on the circuit?'

Dr. M:'You know, I really think this depends on the particular circuitry, and I think it will depend on how much you can tolerate having a neuron that is weak or silent or that you can't measure reliably. So, you know, like you wouldn't want a very weak neuron if you can't measure it. And it depends on how many synapses you can tolerate that may have to be relatively weak, so I think this is just an issue that we have to learn about.'

Dr. M:'Well, first of all, the excitatory neurons are also important to control neuronal oscillation, and to keep neurons from bursting. We do know that many of the neuron oscillation are important for neural network function, so the excitatory pyramids, the excitory neurons are important for maintaining stable neural circuits. The excitatory pyrams are important for excitability.'

Dr. B:'I have a hard time getting excited. I mean, when I am driving through traffic and suddenly realize that the brakes are on, then I start to get excited, but that is a long time after it actually happens. So, when I am in a conversation and somebody is talking about some excitatory neuron, what excitatory neuron?'
Dr. B:'I understand that inhibition is important in terms of neuronal stability. But what would it do?'
Dr. M:'Inhibitions are important for a whole lot of other things, but particularly for regulation of circuits.'

Dr. B:'Oh, for a very important and fundamental reason. If you know, it's a simple thing, I will ask you a simple question, and the answer is very important. The brain is like a car. You can control the car. But if you control the brakes, there is only two options. You push the brakes, or you are in the middle of a traffic jam.'

Dr. M:'That's right, because the brake can only do one thing at a time. It can only stop the car from moving, or it can only maintain that equilibrium state where you have no momentum. And that's it.'

Dr. B:'If you want to keep the car in balance, in a particular mode, or a particular state, then you need to control the accelerator and the brakes. But that can do only one thing at a.m. The brakes can only stop the cars movement. And in order to maintain balance, you need to control many different things, and those things are different, and they are not easy to control.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are an important component of neural circuit. There are three of them. Inhibitory neurons are found as part of synaptic and circuit connections, and they can also be part of a network on their own. We're now using these neurons to study the properties of a circuit, to study circuit output. So the function of the inhibitory neurons is to modify network function. We also find them in both synaptic connections and in non-synaptic connections.'
Dr. B:'So their function is to modify network activity by some mechanism.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. M:'They modify the network by inhibiting another network.'
Dr. B:'How do inhibitory neurons inhibit other neurons? What mechanism does the cell use for this?'

Dr. M:'Well it uses a different mechanism to inhibit synaptic connections. In synaptic inhibition, you just have a direct inhibition from the neuron that has the synaptic connection. And the mechanism for that is a synapse from the membrane of the inhibiting neuron to the membrane of the other neuron. In inhibitory neurons you have an inhibition that's direct from a different neuron, but it's indirect by virtue of a different mechanism.'
Dr. B:'Do we know which neuron is being directly inhibited by the inhibitory neuron?'
Dr. B:'How are inhibitory neurons connected to each other?'
Dr. M:'A lot of the time, they're connected by chemical synapses. So they're not connected by circuit, but the same neurons are part of the circuit.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibitory interneurons in network functions? Are they connected by chemical synapse or circuit?'
Dr. B:'Is it possible to study inhibitory neurons without manipulating them and looking at their circuit? What kind of experiments would you do?'
Dr. M:'It's hard to do that, because we don't have tools to look at them, and we don't know whether they're part of a circuit, so we really need to see them and look at them.'
Dr. B:'Are interneurons connected by synapses or other means?'

Dr. M:'They're usually connected by chemical synapse. But there are other interneurons that connect to inhibitory neurons by electrical synapse. So when we first started looking at neural circuits, a long time ago, we found these electrical synapses between different circuit neurons and they proved that there were more than the two circuit neurons that we knew that were part of the pyloric network.'
Dr. B:'Do you have any examples of such a circuit? What is the function of the circuit? And can you give examples of the inhibitory interneurons in the circuit?'
Dr. M:'They can be connected by synapse from one neuron to another, or they can be part of different circuits. They can be part of multiple networks.'
Dr. B:'Are there differences in connectivity, if so, what are they?'

Dr. M:'There are. One is that neurons with different functional properties tend to connect to each other. But there are many reasons why this happens. There are different receptors and different synaptic mechanisms, so there are many reasons it could happen. Another reason that could occur is different types of connectivity, because the properties of the network can also vary, and there may be a different set of properties that gives a different set of connectivity.'
Dr. B:'What would the impact be if the inhibitory neurons are removed?'

Dr. M:'Well, the impact of removal is always a little bit different because we have so many connections between neurons. So if we were to remove one inhibitory neuron, it would take a little bit longer to recover because there is so much feedback into neurons from other neurons. So it would take more time. But, the properties of the neurons themselves might change because we might have a different set of parameters because of the synaptic connections.'

Dr. M:'There is a large body of work that shows that the number and strength of synaptic connections determine how effective a circuit is to function. And the presence of a presynaptic site with multiple synaptic connections can make a circuit more robust. Because you know if you have a single inhibitory synapse that is not strong enough you know if you just add it you know that that weak synapse will not be effective.'
Dr. B:'Okay, can we move on to another question?'

Dr. M:'Oh, interesting.'

Dr. B:'I study how the brain makes sense of the many neuronal messages that is conveyed to the brain. Dr. M:'So it is a fundamental problem that has puzzled all of us. You know because as you say neural coding is a fundamental problem in understanding how information is represented and how it is read out. So how do we decode it?'

Dr. B:'Yeah, I'm also looking at how inhibition works in neural networks. There is very little known about how inhibition works in the brain. Dr. M:'Well that's interesting. The brain is doing something with neural syntax. I don't know that you would know the function of the brain as far as the neural syntax is concerned.'

Dr. B:'Okay. The brain has so many rhythms that could be used for something. That's what you are talking about. What's the brain's use for neural syntax? So I can give you a few examples.
