Dr. M:'What are you thinking about? Because I think it's very interesting that your work on the brain is not going to just be, just to collect facts about how the brain works, but also to understand what the brain can do.'

Dr. B:'I'm going to answer that one in a little bit. I'm going to respond to a few questions that you had asked a couple of months ago, that is, and then we're going to move on and then we're gonna move back and talk about the syntax of inhibition. So the question is, when and what do you look for in brain rhythms that is, in terms of brain rhythms, how do you go about looking for these things?'

Dr. M:'Well, so first of all, there are all kinds of rhythmic activity, you know, different brain regions, and you know, these different rhythms have different features. So they have a different, you know, they have, the frequency is different, but the, the different neurons and the different subsets of neurons that they can fire and when they can be active at different times.'

Dr. B:'And the reason that we look at how these different neurons are activated and, and then, and how the, how the activity, uh, how the patterns are organized is because the syntax of how neuronal activity is organized is very important.'
Dr. M:'Oh, I'm curious about that, I want to see how the syntax of how neurons can be activated. How is it organized.'

Dr. B:'So, the answer is that that's very complicated. There are two things that are responsible for that syntax: inhibitory interneurons and inhibition. So when you are looking at, uh, the syntax of inhibition, then there are just two things that are important: the inhibitory neuron, and the inhibitory action, or inhibition.'
Dr. M:'You mean the inhibitory neuron that is responsible for producing inhibitory action potentials?'

Dr. B:'No, no, no, I'm, I'm talking about inhibitory interneuron activity. Inhibitory interneuronal activity is a product of inhibition, because there are only two things that can inhibit: inhibition and inhibition. It's just the two things. Now, how the inhibitory neuron produces inhibitory action potential is, is another question. But we have to start with inhibition. The second step is inhibition. And the third step is inhibition.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'Now, we have to figure out how the inhibitory interneu-ron produces inhibition. Then we can, then we can figure out how the inhibition produces a response in a postsynaptic neuron, which produces an action potential, which produces an inhibition in the same interneuron. And, and then the inhibition produces another response. And then it works, uh, and it works, uh...'
Dr. M:'The best way to think about it is to ask how does an excitatory neuron know when to become inhibitory? What's the trigger?'

Dr. B:'I have two candidates. The first one is the action potential threshold. We already knew that inhibition can be triggered in different ways, one way is by hyperpolarizing the membrane to below the action potential threshold, and the other one is by reducing the voltage-dependent inhibition, but then the third possibility is to trigger the inhibition by increasing the threshold of the postsynaptic neurons. And of course, there are more options than those three.'

Dr. M:'You're talking about different neurons in a small network. You're talking about neurons that are part of circuits that are completely different from the circuit of neurons that we studied. I mean, we studied a circuit of three neurons, and a circuit of seven neurons. They weren't part of that same circuit of three and seven, but they were still part of it. So when we think about a circuit of a hundred neurons, we can think about that as a circuit of three.'

Dr. B:'And it can go in different ways. It can be triggered by the discharge frequency of the first neuron. It can be initiated by the second neuron. It can come in different ways from many ways, but there is one way that is similar to what you just said, which is that the threshold of the first neuron will make the second neuron into an inhibitory neuron.'

Dr. M:'So, if we think about a neuron that is excitatory, you know, one of your typical neurons that generates action potentials, and a neuron that is more like a bursting neuron, that has its own kind of unique behavior, but still is part of the same network, then the behavior of the network could be dramatically different if these different neurons were not present.'

Dr. B:'Now let me ask a simple question. In your experience, what would be a simple question? I will tell you, let's say the simplest question. How would you know when inhibition will occur? What would be the best measure?'

Dr. M:'Okay. Let me tell you what we found out. If you change the synaptic inputs of a neuron, you find out that the response of that neuron will change, because some of the ion channels, some of the synapses in that neuron will change. So you find out when a neuron will become more inhibitory or more excitable.'

Dr. B:'Okay. But what if the experiment is repeated, but now without the inhibition. What if you just change some of the synapse in the neuron, so that there is only a small increase in excitation? It's not a whole ton of excitation, but there is a small increase in the membrane potential, then what would you expect? Would you expect the same result?'

Dr. B:'So what you're saying is that you have already a test. So this is a test for me as well. So there's a test when a neuron would become more inhibitory. And there is a test when a cell would become more excitable. And they are very useful for us because then we can find out which neurons that are in a circuit, or which neurons would form a circuit, and which ones would not.'
Dr. M:'One of the functions of inhibitory neurons is to keep us from eating our young.'

Dr. M:'When we grow old we have a lot of bad habits, one of them is we forget to eat our young.'
Dr. B:'And how? Why?'
Dr. M:'And the point is to be able to do that, because when we do that we can live a lot longer, we can avoid many diseases.'
Dr. B:'Oh, I see.'
Dr. B:'How do we know this?'
Dr. M:'Because we have the inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. B:'What other functions they have? Do they serve any other functions? If so, do they serve different functions? What function does the hippocampus have, for example?'

Dr. M:'Well, I don't know that, but one of the functions of the hippocampus is to keep us, and not from eating our young, but from eating the animals that we find that live in the sea that we eat.' So it's it's it's very it's it's a kind of it's the ocean. It's it's all this food. And it's all this ocean food.'

Dr. B:'So there are other functions that inhibitory neurons can perform? What other functions? If there are any, do they serve any? Do they have any special functions that are specific to inhibitory neurons? If so, what are those special functions? What are they? Do they serve? Are they special? What are they?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, yeah, because one of the functions that the GABA neurons have is inhibitory, because they inhibit the muscles that move the eye, so they can actually regulate the movement of the eye. And then they also inhibit the muscles that moves the heart, so they can control the muscles that move. And then they inhibit the muscles in the tongue. So they can make you swallow things. So they can help us digest our food.'
Dr. B:'Do they serve other functions that I didn't mention? Is that right? Are they special functions? What is the special function that these inhibitory neurons serve?'

Dr. M:'So there's a special function, for example, the AGR neuron, the AGR neurons are the main neurons that release a substance called Allatostatin. So there's a kind of AGR neuron in each of us. So there is also a distinct neuron, it's a separate neuron, but it's in each of us that releases Allatostatin that helps regulate the food digestion that goes through the stomach and intestines.'
Dr. B:'All right, but what is the special function? Are they unique? Do they have a function that we can't get by without them? Are they special?'
Dr. B:'What is the function for keeping us from eating our very young?'
Dr. M:'I have to say, you were lucky enough not to have that happen.'

Dr. B:'I also wonder what makes an inhibitory neuron? Is it some special wiring or physiological features, or what are the key requirements for the neuron to inhibit its targets? For example, in my brain, the most important thing of all inhibitory neurons is that they are connected to the principal cells through dendrites. However, some neurons in the hippocampus also innervate their target neurons by releasing transmitter molecules.'
Dr. M:'When you do an inhibitory neuron, you can actually end up with neurons that are very different.'
Dr. M:'The function of inhibitory synaptic transmission is to keep us alive long enough to feed, and grow.'
Dr. B:'Where do inhibitory neurons keep us alive? Is it in the stomach?'
Dr. M:'Yes, and also in the eyes. You know you can't see where you're going, you know, if you're blindfolded.'
Dr. M:'Well, it isn't as simple as that. But I think the answer is that they prevent us from eating our brains and eating our very young.'
Dr. B:'I'm not sure where the brain is that the brain would like to eat. Is it the spinal cord? Is it the cerebral cortex? Do they keep us alive at the expense of brain damage?'

Dr. M:'Yes, they do. We do. We lose a large amount of brain matter during development because of this. You know, the function of inhibitory synapses is to keep us from eating our own brains. This is a very good function that keeps us alive.'

Dr. B:'There are only two types of inhibitory synapse: excitatory and inhibitory. It's only a choice. You can't just choose not to inhibit. If you are a neuron, the only thing you can do is inhibit other neurons, or be very silent or go and burst.'

Dr. M:'The function of inhibition is to stop oscillators from oscillating too fast, to inhibit neurons from firing too fast, to stop neurons from firing together, to make the activity of cells more regular, to make the neurons more robust, to make the circuits more reliable. The main problem in brain circuits is that there is often very few feedback to the brain from the outside, and in many cases we just don't know which brain cells to target.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is the default brain pattern. In fact, the word inhibition is an oxymoron because it means that activity is prohibited, but it is just natural in the brain. In fact, inhibition is so ubiquitous that it is the default state of the brain, it is the default mode of operation. So there is a very close relationship between inhibition and oscillations. In fact, there is so much interaction between inhibition and oscillation that it's really hard to think about the brain without inhibition.'
Dr. B:'I agree with you, we're going to have to wait a while. But there are some things that we can do with in the meantime.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, some of the most exciting developments that we are doing now are with respect to new techniques to manipulate the brain in ways that can be used with the new tools that we are building. Dr. B:'So what is the best way to do that, and what is the worst way to do that? In other words, what is the best use? Dr. M:'Oh yeah.'

So pacemaker activity is not just neurons in the brain firing, the pacemaker neurons have a very well defined function, and there are only a few of them. And it's a pacemaker that controls the phase of many brain neurons that depend on it.'

Dr. M:'There are neurons that have a dual role, so they are part of circuits that, in themselves, are regulatory. You have, for example, the LP neuron which is part of the cardiac oscillator network. It is also part of the lateral gastric (LG) motor circuit. So, these neurons are part of networks that are self-regulating. And as a result, as a consequence of the activity, there is a regulatory role to those neurons that are active during normal circuit function.'
Dr. M:'I think it's probably to make the network resilient to fluctuations.'

Dr. B:'What do inhibitory neurons have to do with neuronal syntax? Do they modify a preexisting syntax? I mean, there are ways to connect them to neurons that are active... but I don't see a mechanism.'

Dr. M:'Well, when I'm thinking of what is most important in neurons, it is that they have to do three things. They have to provide sensory input to the organism; they have to drive the neurons of the circuit, and then they have to control the network. So it's really interesting that it should be important to have these kinds of features and capabilities, because most networks can tolerate a lot of changes in the parameters of their network.'
Dr. B:'What is the function, though, of neurons in the brain, that do not communicate by way of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'There are other neurons, that act on other neurons, so it's not all inhibitory neurons. Dr. B:'Is it really the neurons or is it their inhibitory neurons that matter? And if it is the inhibitory neurons, what are they inhibitting? Dr. B:'Why is it difficult to make a neuron inactive? What is the reason? Dr. M:'That is the reason for the problem we have with understanding this circuit is the fact that we are going to have to solve the problem of how many inhibitions and how much modulation there is going to be, but it is not just a problem of inhibiting a particular neuron, because in that case you would use a proctolin or some such neuropeptide. So, we can't just say we don't have any information and we just go blank.'

Dr. B:'So, why do you not have any information? It would be difficult to give a simple answer, but perhaps the reason is that the brain is a circuit and you don't have the information. And then you have to think of the circuit as a system, like the computer, and to learn how things interact. There is only the information that you have to make the brain circuits work, but it is a system and the information is generated by the interactions of components.'

Dr. M:'Well, they're typically used as switches to turn a system on or off. They can, you know, be used to control some aspect of the system, or to cause an oscillator to work with different frequencies. They can even be used to cause some rhythmic pattern to occur in the network. So, they can serve all of these functions.'
Dr. B:'What would the consequences be if inhibitory cells were to malfunction?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons have a role as inhibitors. As in other species, the majority of inhibitory neurons are modulators, and there are several hundred different substances that affect inhibitory neurons. One thing that we are beginning to appreciate about some of these substances is that they also have some important noninhibitory functions as well.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. M:'I don't know that anybody has really worked on this question, but there are several possibilities for these substances. They may inhibit another neuron with a different synaptic connection. One possibility is that they might act as a chemical synapse or chemical synapse to another neuron, or they might act directly onto neurons. The most interesting possibility would be if they might act directly on one neuron to inhibit another neuron, because they have been shown to be able to inhibit neurons of the same type.'
Dr. B:'Is there a way to investigate how inhibitory neurons contribute to cognition, or behavior?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons provide a negative feedback to neurons that are being overactive or that have too much excitation coming through. For example, in the presence of dopamine, which is released by the pyloric network in the STG of the lobster, there is an inhibition of the pyloric rhythm, because the inhibitory neuron 1 (IN1) is inhibited by the presence of dopamine in the circuit. In the absence of dopamine, the pyloric circuit is excitable.'
Dr. B:'What is the function and role of theta oscillations?'

Dr. M:'Theta oscillations arise in response to modulatory inputs from higher-order ganglia in the nervous system, and in the stomatogastric nervous system, which includes the lateral pacemaker. They are important for providing synaptic inhibition and also for synaptic excitation.'

Dr. B:'Who decides to do the experiments and what is the function of the neurons that provide inhibition? How much evidence is needed before action potentials can be generated in inhibitory cells? What is the function of interneurons? Who decides? Who decides to do the experimental research? How much evidence should be gathered in a certain amount of time? Does the brain use a certain amount of evidence to make a decision? What are the criteria that determine which interneurons are to be included?'

Dr. M:'As to who decides, we have three different classes of modulatory neurons: those that have a clear physiological role in the process, those that are more of a theoretical, curiosity-driven, or otherwise non-physiological role, and those that have some physiological role but that play an important role in the network. A few years ago, we discovered that the pyloric circuits of the two lobsters, Homarus americanus and H. americanus, are not identical.'

Dr. B:'Pyloric circuits, consisting of the stomatographus ganglion (STG), are the main circuit in the lobster. What happens to the STG? What is the main function of the circuit? Is there a general function that it performs? Does the STG generate theta oscillations? What is the relationship between the STG and the lateral pacemaker? What is the physiological role of the pylori in the STG?'

Dr. M:'It has a physiological role because the anterior gastric (AG) neurons release gastric mill rhythmically into the stomatogenes and the pyloric (PY) neurons are their receptors. The physiological role is to excite the gastric mill rhythm by sending the inhibitory pacemaker activity from the lateral pyloric (LP) and anterior gastric (OG) neurons via their axons into the gastric mill (GM) and cardiac ganglion (CG) neurons.'

Dr. M:'We often talk about the fact that neurons need to be oscillatory, but that doesn't mean they necessarily need to be synchronous. For example, some of our previous work showed that the pyloric circuits of some invertebrates are capable of generating both theta oscillations and synchronous spiking with the other two pyloric neurons in the circuit, when the network receives theta oscillations. So it's not always a matter of synchronicity.'

Dr. B:'Do we know the role and function of alpha oscillations? What is the role and function in the pyloric area of these two interneurons that we have in theta? It is not clear to me how the pyloric networks of these interneurons are used in theta.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons provide fast, synchronous inhibition and are very important to producing reliable behavior.'
Dr. B:'What is the function they serve?'
Dr. M:'One of them is acting as a safety device to prevent network activity from getting too crazy, too disorganized. So they have a lot of roles to play.'
Dr. B:'Is there a single inhibitory neuron type, or are they different?'
Dr. M:'No, they're quite different.'
Dr. M:'Their function is to maintain stable activity patterns in neurons by maintaining inhibitory drive from an electrically coupled pacemaker neuron.'

Dr. B:'So when the pacemaker neuron is inactive, inhibitory neurons release inhibitory neurotransmitter, which inactivates the postsynaptic neurons and maintains them in an activity pattern that is more resistant to external perturbations.'
Dr. M:'Well that is a good way to describe inhibitory neurons' function because they maintain a relatively stable pattern of activity during most of the time that a neuron is active.'
Dr. B:'Why is it beneficial to have inhibitory neurons at times when the activity of pyramidal cells is high?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitors are essential components of circuit dynamics. For example, they prevent activity from becoming uncoordinated, and they inhibit neural firing if activity is already low, so that the circuit is always at a certain level of activity.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are there so neurons can make themselves distinct from each other by altering their synaptic and intrinsic properties and changing their synaptic connections.'
Dr. B:'What role does inhibition play?'

Dr. M:'The simplest way of saying it is they create a synaptic potential that inhibits the activity of the target cell by acting as a brake or a brake on the network oscillator that is producing the rhythmic bursting. For example, the pacemaker neuron, the PD neuron of the pyloric circuit, is inhibited by lateral Pyloric (LP) and Pyloric Dilator (PY) neurons.'

Dr. M:'They provide a negative feedback signal to the synapse from the receptor to the presynaptic cell. And that negative feedback signal can either be released immediately, or released in the future, depending on the outcome of the previous event.'
Dr. B:'What are the benefits of this mechanism?'

Dr. M:'There are several benefits. For example, if we are in a situation in which we are sensing an incoming negative stimulus, such as a loss of heartbeat or an inability to breathe, it is possible to immediately halt the neural activity and respond to that stimulus. Or if we are sensing a loss of heartbeats, we can immediately go in and stimulate the heart muscle to restore that negative feedback signal to keep that heart pumping.'
Dr. B:'So the inhibitory circuit can act like a stop switch.'
Dr. M:'And you can turn the switch off if you want to. So it can switch the system to a tonic firing mode.'
Dr. B:'What else can the circuit do? What can the inhibitory circuit do?'

Dr. M:'Well I mean, one of the things that it can do is make sure that synaptic conductance is maintained. Right? Because if synaptic conductance is blocked, the synaptic drive of the system will be lost. Because when a synaptic conductance is in effect, there will be a current that is associated with it, and that current will increase and decrease with the strength of the synaptic conductance. Right?'
Dr. B:'And what happens if we increase the synaptic conductance, and the inhibition will be stronger? Because that is the opposite of what we want to happen. We want the inhibition to decrease.'
Dr. M:'We want the inhibition to increase. Right?'

Dr. B:'The inhibition should decrease. Right. Exactly. It should. There is a system in which excitatory synaptic conductance is stronger than inhibition. Now, this system is called the hippocampal region, and it is the first region in the brain that can be considered as a single cell assembly. If you are interested in the function of the hippocampus, you should know about it, and how it functions.'
Dr. M:'How does it function?'
Dr. M:'I mean, so then, the system is going to have to be stable in both directions.'

Dr. B:'That would be the effect of inhibiting the GABAergic neuron. So the function of the inhibitory neurons is that they provide a negative feedback. And that is why inhibition is a natural control mechanism.'
Dr. M:'One, to inhibit other neurons. Right? Because that's how neurons communicate.'

Dr. B:'No, that's not how they communicate. That's a bit like saying, "Well, a car is like a librarian, except with a radio." The librarian is a bit like a car, but they have more than just one function. The difference between the librarian and the car is that you can do many things in your car that you cannot do in the library.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'So, what happens in the brain when you have inhibitory neurons? If you have a few inhibitory cells, like five percent of neurons in the brain, then a fraction of the neurons will be inhibited. This is what inhibitory neurons do. They inhibit neurons. There are no inhibitory neurons that just sit and do nothing. They send their output, as we would call them inhibitory terminals, out in the brain and inhibit the remaining neurons.'
Dr. M:'That's right.'

Dr. B:'We can call them "buzzing cells," or some other term. They do a bit more than just inhibitory. They are not just inhibiting neurons but affecting the neurons in a way that is not directly related to their direct targets. In fact, you can call them "reader cells." They are not really interested in what comes in or what comes out, or how many neurons they control.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely.'

Dr. B:'But the brain always tries to understand the outside world. In other words, the brain always interprets. This can be called  "action-potential coupling", or  "neural syntax", or something like that. They are looking for the patterns of the inputs and how they would influence their target neurons to achieve their desired goal. This is also what inhibitory neurons are interested in. This is their main goal.'

Dr. M:'I agree. I think it's a fascinating point that these cells can influence the neurons that they directly target as well. These are neurons that have direct targets like the stomach. These are neurons with direct targets like the heart and all these other nerves. This is a part of the function of inhibitory neurons. They can control neurons that they do not directly influence.'

Dr. B:'The output of the inhibitory terminals is that inhibitory neurons are the only source of inhibition in the brain. The activity of inhibition depends on the excitatory input to the inhibitory cell. In this case, the source of excitation is excitatory neurons that provide the excitatory inputs to the inhibitory neuron, but there are many other sources as well. In fact, it's a lot like a car with a radio.'
Dr. M:'Well, you can do many different things with it, but I think the important point is that there are different functions.'

Dr. B:'Okay, then, let me explain. When you drive to work or go to school, the radio is turned off or you are not interested in what they are talking about. That's where your function comes into the picture. Now, if you were, then I would expect you to use that function, and you use that function very, very well. It's only because I have no interest in what they are saying that I don't bother to listen to the radio.'

Dr. M:'So, the difference between the lnager and the car, as we all know, is that you can read in your car, but you can't read in the library. So, it's not like, you know, reading in the car is something that will always be there, that you can't do in the library. It's only temporary.'

Dr. B:'So if I say, okay, here is the librarian. And she can do many things that the car cannot do, then she will still be a librarian, right? Even if she could have an oscillation in her brain, she would still be a lnager, right? Because there are many different functions, right? The librarian has one function, but the car has many functions, right? That's the way that we divide it up.'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. B:'And it's up to you to find the car that will do that, right?'
Dr. B:'Okay, but what's the function of their inhibition? Inhibition is always used to achieve something. What is the function of inhibition?'
Dr. B:'What is the function, or output of inhibitory interneurons?'
Dr. M:'Well, if you have two neurons in a circuit, one of them will be inhibited by the other one. So they're inhibiting each other.'
Dr. B:'And how does that happen?'
Dr. M:'When the two neurons fire together, they both fire tonically.'

Dr. B:'Is there a function to this? So is there a function to inhibiting? What's the function of the inhibition? It's the same function as in the firing pattern of the two neurons, but now, the output of the inhibition, it's not a firing pattern, but in fact it's zero, which is the inhibition, which is zero, but they both fire together at the same time, right? What's the output? What is the output of inhibiting?'

Dr. M:'Because they're in an inhibitory circuit. If you're in a circuit where you can't move, your axon can't break, your synapses can't fall off, your interneurons can't fall off. They can be inhibited from the outside by an antagonist neuron.'
Dr. B:'Which means that when two neurons are placed in an inhibitory system, they will inhibit each other. So what is the function of inhibitory inter-neurons?'

Dr. M:'Well, one function of inhibitory cells, is to slow the transmission of information to the next neuron. When you get more neurons firing with the same pattern as an inhibitory neuron, the subsequent neuron that is activated is slower to respond and the next neuron that is activated will be slowed.'

Dr. B:'Okay, but what if the activity of the first neuron is very strong, such that it activates several inhibitory neurons? What's the consequences? What if the second neuron responds with a strong activity? If it happens that, due to inhibition, the third neuron is also suppressed, the third neuron responds with a low discharge. And so on. What if the last neuron responds? What happens to the first? How many inhibitory neurons would be required to achieve a silencing effect?'

Dr. M:'The first neuron fires and keeps firing and sends out information. The second neuron also fires and also keeps firing and its information is suppressed because it is too small. Then the third neuron fires and also keeps shooting out information. So the neurons just fire alternatingly and thus, if all the neurons were the same size, you would not be able to see which neuron was active and which neuron was suppressed. So, this is part of the reason why I think these neurons are designed to be small.'

Dr. B:'I would like to ask you about another important function of inhibitory neuron, which is to coordinate the timing of neurons to the phase of theta oscillations. What is the function of gamma cells? In this case, what is the function of this type of neurons?'

Dr. M:'You know, these neurons also are designed to be very small, because they also have important functions. So, the function of the gamma neuron is to generate a very small electrical burst in one phase of the theta cycle. So, this neuron plays a role in phase maintenance, but it also plays a role in synchronizing the activity of the other theta phase neurons with the correct timing.'

Dr. M:'And this is something that has puzzled us for a long time. You know, we've done a lot of work on networks. We've worked on networks that have a lot of inhibitory cells. We've worked networks that have very few. And it always puzzled us that this would be the result of inhibition of the first neuron. And I think it's a lesson about the interaction of complex networks and how you can get surprising effects from simple network dynamics. So it could be a good lesson.'

Dr. M:'Inhibition is a common regulator of neuronal activity, so it's important to understand the mechanisms by which this occurs and to what extent it is regulated. One of the ways it's regulated is by presynaptic inhibition of the target neuron that releases presynaptic inhibitory transmitter.'
Dr. B:'What is a'synapse'?'

Dr. M:'A synapse is a voltage-gated potassium current that flows preferentially into one neuron from another when the presynaptic neuron is depolarized.  A synaptic current has a long half-life, so that it flows out of the presynaptic cell after it is activated by hyperpolarization and contributes to the long-lasting post-inhibitory rebound that occurs after a neuron has been inhibited for some period of time.'

Dr. M:'The synapse between a and b is a synaptic gap that's part of the circuit that the neurons belong to. The strength of this synaptic gap depends on a variety of underlying parameters and processes. Some of those underlying parameters are intrinsic to a single neuron, and some of those are determined by the synaptic network.'
Dr. B:'How can a single neuron affect its targets?'

Dr. M:'It can be quite simple, it can be complicated. The basic mechanism is that a cell can have voltage-dependent conductances for its electrical excitability. It can also have ion channel type currents with fixed conductances, so it can have a set of fixed channel currents. A neuron can express a set of channels that can be differentially regulated in various tissues.'
Dr. B:'Can a neuron become a neuron? What would it take? What's the magic? Can a neuron become a new neuron?'

Dr. M:'When you have a neuronal circuit that has several neurons, the circuit output depends on the pattern of activity of each neuron in the circuit. If you don't use the whole circuit, you don't know how to tune its behavior. For example, the nervous system of a frog has several neurons, and there are different versions of the pyloric circuit. In one version, there are five neurons that belong to a single ganglion.'

Dr. M:'It depends on whether a neuron has synaptic targets to different targets or whether it's a single-projection neuron or multi-projection neuron. So you have to look at what it has targets and what kind of synapse it has. The simplest possible case is a single-projector neuron with synaptic connections with multiple targets.'
Dr. B:'So this case is simple, but how would a single-project neuron work in the brain?'

Dr. M:'Well, this neuron would be a projection neuron that would project to one target, and a second target and a third target. But the other neurons would receive inputs from this neuron and from this synapse and also from the synapse that the neuron has to the target it projects to. So you have these three-dimensional combinations of parameters.'

Dr. M:'Neurons can be quite different in terms of their intrinsic properties, and they can also be different in their connectivity and their synaptic structure, and therefore can be different in terms of how they can interact with their targets. That also means that they can change their output. That also means they can change their connectivity. So, one of the mechanisms of regulation is via synaptic and neurohormonal mechanisms.'

Dr. B:'I was wondering, in general, how the brain is organized? What are the key features that make it so good? Do you have a picture of this? Is there a general picture? Are there a few key features? I was interested in how information is organized within the brain, rather than looking at how the brain generates it. It seems like the brain is organized to produce behavior. Is there any way to talk about the brain without talking about the behavior?'
Dr. B:'Are there any synapses with known mechanisms that are not known to the neuroscientists? If so, what are they?'

Dr. M:'Yes, there are lots of known mechanisms, as far as synaptic transmission, that are very well understood. In the past we've studied and identified different types of synaptic transmission mechanisms. We've found multiple, distinct synapse transmission mechanisms within a single neuron, which is a finding that we never anticipated. So, there are also mechanisms that are part of a synaptic network that are not obvious from an examination of the isolated synapse. These are things that we're learning and understanding.'

Dr. M:'Well, some of those synaptic connections are studied in other animals, including flies and crabs. The synaptic connections in the stomatogastric ganglion of the lobster are studied as part of this ongoing study of the mechanisms by which neuromodulation enables animals to survive in the ocean. So the synaptic connections are studied and described in crabs and other species. Some of these synaptic connections are very different in different species. Some of them have been studied using similar but not identical preparations.'

Dr. B:'Okay. Now you have an example where inhibitory neurons are directly and effectively inhibited by another population of inhibitory neurons, which is an example where inhibition is important. And we understand inhibition is important at a number of levels. How do you know that inhibition is critical at this level? If there is no inhibitory control, what is the function of the target neurons? What is the function of this population of inhibitory cells?'
Dr. M:'Well, they're not inhibited at the same level, but they influence at different levels. So they have to be at different levels in the network to regulate different network activity.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is an important factor that is not often used to help guide a mechanistic description of network function in neural networks. Yet, it is a potential tool for understanding neural syntax and its potential role in neural syntax as well as cognitive function.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are essential for the function of circuits. For example, a tonic inhibitory synaptic input from an inhibitory neuron can generate a stable oscillatory behavior of a motor circuit that is independent of external inputs, and also prevents the generation of tonically active spikes in the network that could otherwise block the network from firing its normal bursts of spikes. Thus, inhibitory neurons are essential to a functional network.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that excitatory neurons perform?'

Dr. M:'This is an interesting question. Because there are two opposite mechanisms that can be employed. For example, in the case of a neuron that is part of a sensory circuit where it is only meant to receive inhibitory synaptic input. For example, suppose you have a circuit in which there is a sensor that receives excitatory synaptic input that is only meant to release a certain chemical in response to a given stimulus.'
Dr. B:'How do these inputs interact in that circuit? What is the function that inhibition performs in this circuit?'

Dr. M:'Well, one of the reasons is, first of all, is because the neuron that released the excitatory synaptic potential has no way to inhibit that neuron that released the chemical. Secondly, because it's the same neuron. That means that all the synaptic potentials that are generated as part of the excitatory synapses are themselves excitatory.'

Dr. B:'So now we have a circuit where excitatory input acts in a different way in two different parts of the circuit. The first one is the sensor itself, the second one is a motor. What is the function inhibitory input performs? Does this circuit work? If not, what's the point of it? How can we make it work, and how do we know that what we did in one part of the circuit is effective?'

Dr. M:'So the answer to that is, again, because the two neurons are the same neuron, there is no way to inhibit it, there's no way to inhibit these two cells. It's not a circuit in which inhibition is a key function. So it's kind of like, the first function is to generate excitatory synaptic current. The second function is to inhibit. And the third function is to generate inhibitory synaptic current. And then it has a fourth function to inhibit.'

Dr. B:'I've got a circuit. So now, we have a mechanism for inhibition. So what is the function that inhibitory input performs in this circuit? Does this circuit actually work? If not what is the point of it, and how do you know that what you did in one part...'

Dr. M:'So, in the example I used, this circuit was meant to release a chemical when something was present in the environment. So, it's meant to produce something, and its output will be different when different input patterns are used to excite it. So, this circuit does not need inhibitory synaptic inputs to be functional. This circuit could work as a single neuron.'

Dr. B:'Now, the two opposite mechanisms are there to be studied because both of them serve the same purpose. That is, to serve something. But, this was a very interesting question, because I want to know what would the functions be that inhibition performs in the circuit. Is this circuit useful? If so, why do we have inhibitory synaptic inputs in the circuit? Is the function inhibition performing there a different type of function than excitatory input? Is this circuit useful for what we want?'

Dr. M:'Well, for example, when you want to control the activity of muscle in the legs of the  Drosophila, when you want to make the gastric mill muscle contract you have to electrically stimulate the pacemaker neuron, the LG neuron, and then that activates the pacemaker neurons that activate the muscles that move the gastric mill.'

Dr. B:'Okay. But the function is not to move that leg. It's the inhibition of other neurons. And inhibition is the key, but it is an abstract thing. It is not a leg movement, it's an inhibition that prevents the other neurons from contracting that leg muscle.'

Dr. M:'Yes, yes. It's like you want to relax the muscles of the stomach. And when you inhibit the LG neuron, you release the pacemaker neurons, which activate the muscles to relax and release gastric mill muscle contraction.'

Dr. B:'Then it is like an inhibition-induced relaxation. And that is what we call homeostatic function of inhibitory neuron. It's just like a tension-relaxation balance mechanism that regulates the movement of the leg.'
Dr. M:'You're saying this is kind of like an automatic relaxation mechanism that sets that balance, that sets that regulation of gastric mill contraction.'

Dr. M:'Right, right. But it's important. You see, the key to understanding how neural circuit work is not to get distracted by the details of how the cells are wired in the nervous system. I mean, you can get distracted because you think that there are little cell types that are 'wired' by themselves. We do not believe that the neurons in the brain are 'wired' as you think of it.'

Dr. M:'Well, that's a good question. So, we all know that there are many neurons that are inhibitory because their transmitter phenotype is appropriate for producing inhibitory effects. For example, if you have a neuron that releases dopamine, it is inhibiting another neuron in its environment by virtue of its transmitter phenotype, which will produce inhibitory effects.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of these inhibitory cells?'

Dr. M:'So, the answer is in the second part. I mean, you can think of a number of ways in which a neuron could be inhibitory. It could have one type of transmitter, like most neurons have many. It could release serotonin and thus be inhibiting another neuron. It could release dopamine. It could release multiple transmitters like a neuron in the crustacean STG or a neuron in the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'What is the function? So the function of these cells is to make connections between neurons that are connected to each other through excitatory connections, or that are connected to a third type of neuron, which is not excitatory but inhibitory, or inhibitory interneuron. This is done by the inhibition they offer.'
Dr. M:'Well, they have different functions.'
Dr. B:'Why?'
Dr. M:'Because they activate different ion channels, and so they produce different effects in the membrane.'
Dr. B:'Yeah, they can be very useful in some contexts.'
Dr. B:'Tell me about the different classes.'

Dr. M:'Oh yeah, well, the first class is excitatory. There are two subclasses of excitatory neurons. One of them is fast excitatory, the second is slow excitatory neurons and there is a third class of excitatory neuron that is inhibitory but very weak. There are two classes of inhibitory neurons. One is excitatory-inhibitory, the other is excitatory excitatory.'
Dr. B:'Now, how is it possible to tell which is which? The inhibitory action can be masked.'

Dr. M:'Right and the masking process depends on the duration of the time that the neuron is active. So, the fast excitatory neuron produces an excitatory-to-inhibitory transduction for a long time, whereas the inhibitory neurons and the slow excitatory neuron produce for a very short time.'
Dr. B:'So, are the neuronal mechanisms that can do this very similar to the mechanisms that are used to segregate speech in phonemes?'

Dr. M:'Yes, because in terms of the neural circuitry that produces this, it is absolutely the same. So, what they call the phonemes or the segmentation of speech into words, words, you know, so it's very similar, it's exactly the same and it also depends on the type of neuron, so it's different in the sense that it also depends on whether you are working with excitatory neurons or inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. B:'And this is what you call 'neural syntax' is this mechanism of segmenting neural messages, this is the fundamental organization, and it is done by brain rhythms.'

Dr. M:'There are different classes of inhibitory neurons, for example, inhibitory neurons that release a single transmitter, such as the fast inhibitory modulatory neuron, IH, that releases serotonin. Inhibitory neurons can be different types of inhibitory neurons that release different transmitters, and they can be neurons that release no transmitters, because they can also be silent neurons.'
Dr. B:'Tell us about inhibitory neurons, and why they are important.'
Dr. M:'The function of inhibitory synapses is to ensure network stability.'
Dr. B:'How do they stabilize networks?'
Dr. M:'They stabilize network output by controlling the times of the spikes.'

Dr. B:'But it's a bit like when you are in the middle of a conversation and someone cuts it short and asks you, 'What is the real function of inhibitory interneurons?' You say, "I don't know" and the other person says, "Okay. Then I'm going to tell you. The function of inhibitory cells is to ensure network safety. And you are going to say, "I didn't know that.'
Dr. M:'By balancing the number of presynaptic neurons and the strength of their synapses.'
Dr. B:'What would the role of a network in which inhibitory neurons were eliminated?'

Dr. B:'Why is there a gap between synaptic plasticity and inhibitory plasticity? What is missing? What is not happening? What is not being utilized? What are the potential implications of the missing circuit mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'It is important to understand the underlying rules that allow neurons to change their firing patterns, because the rules are the same for neurons with different intrinsic properties. In other words, the rules for inhibitory and synaptic transmission are the same for all neurons. The important thing is to have a rule that makes neurons more or less likely to fire in a certain way, because they need to maintain their core function as neurons. It would not be useful to have a neuron firing randomly at all times.'
Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons produce synaptic depression and inhibit other cells.'
Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons in the hippocampus, for example, fire together in an organized manner, and they discharge at theta frequency.'
Dr. M:'Yes. It's a rhythmic burst. But that rhythm comes from the brain. There's a rhythm going on, and the brain is generating this rhythmic activity.'
Dr. B:'How did that happen? Inhibitory neurons can be recruited by afferent drive, right? They are interconnected by reciprocal inhibitory connections with each other.'

Dr. M:'Oh, yes. They are all electrically coupled to each other, and each one of them fires when the other is silent. So the frequency of the firing of the electrically coupled neurons is determined by the time of the activity of one of the other cells. The oscillatory neurons are all oscillators, and they fire at a defined phase of their activity, which determines the phase of the oscillators firing in the network.'

Dr. M:'Well, the synaptic connections between these neurons are not simple. Inhibitory connections can be reciprocal. The synaptic connections in the pyloric circuit of the crab, for example, are bidirectional. They're going in both directions.'
Dr. B:'But there is no feedback in this system. The inhibitory neurons have to release something.'

Dr. M:'That's correct. So, in this case, these neurons were activated by two kinds of stimuli. The first stimulus was the synaptic release that came from the synaptic connections between the four neurons that are in the circuit. And then also by an extrinsic factor because the neurons are activated by changes in the pylorus rhythm, which was a very strong stimulus to excite all four neurons.'

Dr. B:'So that's a good argument. But it's a special wiring, that's needed to have this reciprocal inhibitory connectivity. There is no such thing as the default wiring of the brain. It depends on what you're looking at and what you're asking about. There is no "default wiring", or there's no "default activity" or nothing like that. The default state of a circuit is to do nothing. A circuit is just waiting to be used, it's in an active state.'

Dr. M:'Well, I suppose the primary function of the inhibitory neuron is to inhibit. It is usually the first neuron to fire in the network, and as soon as the first neuron fires, the subsequent neurons fire too. It also activates a cascade of further oscillators. One of the examples is when I was working on a model of a pyloric network for which we found the optimal balance between activation of the anterior/pyloric dilator and lateral posterior (LP) neurons.'
Dr. B:'And who is the ideal inhibitory neuron?'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are there to slow down the rhythm.'
Dr. B:'How many neurons in the brain are inhibitory?'
Dr. M:'I'm saying it's one or two, but it depends on the species.'
Dr. B:'Do neurons in other parts of the brain share this role?'
Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely. They all share that role.'
Dr. B:'But there are more than one neuron type in the brain, right?'
Dr. M:'Absolutely.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, and I don't know if you heard yesterday but the first paper was published today on the functional role of the neuron in the eye. The role of the neuron is so variable, that is the problem. It has so many functions. It's important, because if you start to ask, how many cells can be inhibited by a single neuron, well then you're going to have to ask, what is the function of these other cells, how are they interacting with one another?'
Dr. B:'So I would like to ask you what is the role of inhibitory neurons? I mean, what are their main functions? Do they serve the same role or different roles, or is it a spectrum?'
Dr. M:'I don't know. There are probably at least 10 different neurons.'

Dr. B:'That is not a big number. How many cells are inhibitory? In my view, the brain should be viewed as a self-stabilized system with only a handful of principal cells. The inhibition is a major player. In the hippocampus, inhibition is only a small part of the total activity and a very complex system, but it does a great job.'
Dr. M:'There's many hundreds, it changes throughout development.'
Dr. B:'There is a minimum of inhibition necessary for the brain to function?'

Dr. M:'It's one of those old 'why doesn't it look like this?' questions, which I think should have been answered a long time ago. The answer is quite simple. When you think about the function of inhibitors, you have to ask the first question, "What's your model of action?" Because the first thing you need to ask yourself is: how are you going to affect the network, and by that I mean what are you going to change in the behavior of the network?'

Dr. B:'You said "the behavior of the network". What do you mean by behavior of the network? What is it? What are the rules? What are the algorithms? What are the instructions? There are only a few things in the brain that can change its dynamics. Those are excitatory inputs and inhibitory inputs. What are the rest? There are only two things that can affect neuronal activity. Excitation and inhibition.'

Dr. M:'Okay. Well, maybe you should have asked this question 10 years ago. At that time, when you were thinking about what the function of inhibitors would be, it probably would have been the same. However, now the problem is that there are a lot of different models of what a functional inhibitor might be. That's the first question: what you want to do with the network, how you're going to affect it?'

Dr. B:'And what kind of things are going to be affecting the network? In the simplest case, inhibition should reduce the excitatory effect. We can have inhibition that reduces synaptic efficacy, or inhibitory neurons should decrease their rate of release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. We can have inactivity of pyramidal cells, which is the default state of the network. Then we have inhibition that affects synaptic transmission, the transmission of neurotransmitter glutamate.'

Dr. M:'You know what I'm thinking about right now are these inhibitory neurons and inhibitory circuits. There was a study on the role of inhibition in the nervous system. When you first read these studies they make it sound like it's so easy to see the role of inhibition because you look at a neuron that's inhibitory and you think, oh this is going to inhibit other cells from firing because it's always being inhibited. And then you find this is not always true.'
Dr. B:'Well, of course it is not. Because, it's not about inhibition but about the excitatory neurons. And the inhibition comes from the inhibition of the excitatory cells.'

Dr. B:'So what is the actual function of inhibition? So what is inhibition? What is inhibition? Inhibition, if you were to call it inhibition, inhibition is the process that prevents other neurons from firing. I don't have the exact numbers, but, I would say in the hippocampus, the numbers are high enough that I have to work hard to avoid inhibition. In the thalamus, the numbers are not so high.'
Dr. M:'I work with many small neurons that are inhibited by larger neurons. So the number of cells inhibited by large cells is not very high in this model.'
Dr. B:'In the cortex, that's exactly the case, but the number of cells whose activity is inhibited by larger cells is not very large, and I have to work harder to avoid inhibition.'

Dr. M:'So what happens when a cell becomes inhibited? What happens? It's like when you take a neuron like the LPG neuron, when you take this neuron you make it inhibitory, then it becomes hyperpolarized, it goes to a lower membrane potential, and then it hyperpolarizes.'

Dr. B:'And then when you put it back in the network, this cell inhibits other neurons. So this is a role of inhibition in this model. It prevents firing from other neurons. The fact that it hyperpolarises the neuron is the reason it inhibits them. This is the role of inhibition.'

Dr. M:'But what is the function of inhibition? It's like what do they all do? You're just sitting there talking about a different cell, because cells are always active, and then suddenly I look over at you, and you're like, ah, right, I understand now, right, that's what you're thinking about right now.'
Dr. B:'What is the function? What are all inhibitory neurons doing? The inhibitory cell is going to inhibit its targets.'

Dr. M:'No. Not necessarily. Like you know, neurons in the retina are inhibitory to neurons in the retina because they can't be seen. So, neurons can also be inhibitory to each other. There are different kinds of inhibition.'

Dr. B:'Well, the important thing about inhibitory neurons is that they are connected together so that you can have a network in which inhibition is always operating. In the brain, inhibitory neurons are always connected by inhibition, whether it's an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSPs) or an inhibitory postinhibitory potential (IPSPs). Inhibitory neurons are never isolated. In fact, this is the case in most cortical networks, and this is what is very good for me.'

Dr. M:'Why is that? What is it good for? Because if you just make a network in which only one neuron is active, you're just creating a circuit that's going to make all of its neurons more or less fire with every other cell, and then you're never going to get the network to work properly.'
Dr. B:'So if you just have a single inhibitory cell, then the rest of the neurons are going to have no inhibition, right? And this is the same case as you said for neurons in the retina.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. M:'So it has to be, when it inhibits its targets, it has to do so in a manner that's compatible with what it's supposed to be doing because otherwise it would be a really weird neuron that you wouldn't want to have in your nervous system. It wouldn't work in any way.'

Dr. B:'No, so what is it actually doing, if you had to say that, I'm going to figure out what inhibition is and I'm going to make it a better neuron in a sense that it will actually change a little bit in its action. So what is it doing? Well, for a good inhibition, it has to have two things. One is that the inhibition should actually change the firing probability of the target neurons in a short amount of time.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, and second is that the inhibitory neuron should have a target that it is really interested in. That is going to be the most difficult thing to do, right? To find these right targets.'

Dr. B:'Yeah, but the interesting thing is that even these target neurons can be inhibitory, so you don't want to have a target that is, you know, completely independent. And this is what we have to learn. This is what it's like to actually get to the heart of the problem. And it's really complicated and it requires you to think about it for a long, long time. So when you get to the end of the time, there is a simple explanation.'

Dr. B:'But there is a function for inhibition. One way of thinking about it is the neurons that are inhibited have been trained in various ways, they've been given other functions in the brain. They're trained to respond to something else. That training has happened as a result of their interactions with other neurons. And these trained neurons are inhibited, so that their activity is limited, restricted, and they can fire for a limited amount of time at their target neurons.'
Dr. M:'So you can't just think about each individual cell and just focus on the individual cell. So that's where I'm focusing my efforts.'

Dr. B:'And there is the other function that inhibition provides. Inhibition is the process that allows the cells that are doing other things in the brain to act in isolation, or they have their own domain. So inhibition allows them to act, without their brain affecting, but in the case of the hippocampus, the most important domain of the hippocampus is the inhibition of the pyramidal cells from other pyramidal cells. Now this is not a simple task.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'And what's true for some neurons is false for others. So this is not what is inhibition in some neurons is that they inhibit others and they can also excite them. But this is inhibition. This is inhibition that helps the neurons with which they inhibit each other to fire at different times and in different ways. And this is inhibition, right? Inhibition in this case is inhibition of inhibition. In other words, inhibition in this case is a feedback inhibition.'

Dr. M:'Yes. And the other example would be that, you know, I would just like to call them the feedback neurons, the feedback neurons, because we had these cells that were excitatory neurons and we were able to take some of those neurons and actually turn them into inhibitory neurons and that's a big step. And I remember when we were doing that we were like, I was like, oh my god, there's an example here, we can use this for other things.'

Dr. B:'Well, the next question is whether they have a special function? So it would be a very important thing if we know that inhibition in these interneuron types have a special function. Inhibition in interneurons is very important and there's nothing special about it.'
Dr. M:'I know but it also allows the neurons that are the targets of inhibition to be tonically inhibited.'

Dr. M:'Well, so you can see this gets complicated quickly and it gets complicated quickly because what they found, and this is actually very interesting, they found that the role of inhibition varies across neurons. So I'm going to tell you about a study about the role of inhibition. So this study was done by two investigators, it was a team, it was two different investigators. I know you're familiar with this study. This was done on the pyloric circuit of the crab.'

Dr. B:'In the crab circuit it's actually called the pyloric pattern. And it's an incredibly beautiful circuit. It's very simple, and it's an incredibly important circuit. And in this case, when you looked at inhibition, when you looked specifically at inhibition, inhibition and inhibition and inhibition, these are these terms that are often used, but they're not really there.'

Dr. M:'So inhibition is like the yin of the equation, you could think of it like. Inhibition is the dark side. Like, you look at a pendulum, right? You know, a pendulum oscillator. Like, the point, you see the point of the pendulum, right. So if you have a pendulum oscillating you know, just going up and down.'

Dr. B:'So I'm talking about something more specific. I'm talking about the inhibition in this case, right? So in this case we have inhibition, the only inhibitory neurons in the circuit are GABAergic interneurons. And these are interneurons that target inhibitory neurons. These are inhibitory neurons. The other inhibitory neurons in this circuit are inhibitory interneurons, and they also target inhibitory neurons, and so on and so on.'

Dr. M:'And in this case, one of these interneurons is called CbAST5. It's a GABAergic interneuron that was actually found in the central pattern generating circuit of the crab. It targets and it activates and it actually excites an inhibitory neuron. The CbAST5 itself is very excitable, but its activation of this other neuron causes the CbAST5 to become silent. It makes it quiet.'

Dr. B:'And so there are only two inhibitory neurons, which have been shown to be excited by the CbAST6. And this neuron is called CbAS6. It's an inhibitory neuron that also targets and activates and inhibits the interneuron that activates the CbAST8, and so on, and so on.'

Dr. M:'Right. So it's like there's two sides to this. Like, okay, let's say, when you talk about a neuron being inhibited, let's say an action potential. Right? An action potential is a specific spike.'

Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons release chemical transmitters that activate one or more of the other neurons in the circuit. The activation of the next neuron is inhibited by the first, and the inhibitory input is released from the second neuron that activates the first.'
Dr. B:'Why are these functions important?'

Dr. M:'Well, this is one of the most fundamental principles of how neurons are connected to each other. So, in a network of neurons, they're each connected in some way to multiple other neurons, but there are some neurons that have a very important role, and they have to be inhibitory and not excitatory.'
Dr. B:'Now, what is the function of the GABAergic inhibitory system? Why is it so special?'
Dr. M:'There are multiple functions of GABAergic systems.'
Dr. M:'This is very important because this is not the way that I had been trained. I had been trained to think that each neuron is responsible for a single kind of function.'
Dr. B:'But when you look at the brain, it's so complicated and complex that you can't be surprised that there are functions that a neuron does not have to have.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, it's because we are evolving biological organisms, and as an organism we need a variety of neurons to be available to the rest of the organism. Now, there are many, many different neuron types. There are neurons that fire fast, there are neurons that fire slow, there are different neurons for every kind of behavior. So we need to make sure that there are enough neurons available to all of the tasks that we need to perform.'
Dr. B:'And there's a lot of competition for a finite number of neurons between different kinds of neurons.'
Dr. B:' What is the difference between GABAergic interneurons and pyramidal cells?'

Dr. M:'  Pyramidal cells are large neurons that span the entire width of the stomatogastric nerve and then project into the nervous system. They are not small neurons like GABAergic interneuron, which are small cells that project into the stomatotopic ganglion where the three ganglia are located.'

Dr. B:'Now this is an example that illustrates an important function of inhibitory cells. This second cell that is activated by the first cell that inhibits the second one has a similar function, in fact, it is the same function and the second cell is only an example of inhibition of a neuron by a single inhibitory cell.'
Dr. M:'Oh yeah.'
Dr. M:'So there are examples of similar functions between different neurons that arise from this inhibition of a single neuron by a single other neuron.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of these inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. M:'These neurons are important because they have many different functions in the brain. These neurons are the ones that activate many different muscles in the body.'

Dr. B:' Now, here's an example. Now, I'm a little more aware of this circuit than you are. So I can do this a little bit better than you can. Dr. M:' Exactly, right.'

Dr. B:' So this is what happens when the activity has been maintained. So if you increase the activity of the neuron that is in the center of the square, it will disinhibit the neurons in the other corners.'

Dr. B:' The only way to maintain constant output is if both inhibitory neurons fire at approximately the same rate, then this circuit would have constant output, which we call stability. So there are only two possibilities. So it will either be inhibited, or it will be excited. So inhibition is not only a way of regulating the activity of the other cells, but it's also a way of maintaining a constant output.'

Dr. M:' Exactly, so this gives rise to a question, or it gives rise to a hypothesis: that the regulation of network activity is so important, and that neurons must be regulated, because if a neuron fired for a very long time, it would not be able to control the other neurons in the network.'

Dr. M:'The question is how the neurons themselves develop into neurons with the ability to be meaning-making. Dr. M:' We think it has to be a good balance between all of the different components of the brain. One of the key things about the brain is the many different kinds of neurons that there are. That includes neurons of the nervous system, neurons of the cardiac system, neurons of muscles, sensory neurons, neurons that innervate neurons.'

Dr. M:'Well, first of all, I think the question is how you can represent any set of stimuli in any pattern of neural activity, and that's a problem. Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. M:' The inhibitory neurons that you're talking about, the first step is identifying that it's an inhibitory neuron. It either activates a circuit or does something completely different. Dr. M:'When a nerve impulse arrives from the  pyloric circuit and the corresponding neuron (the  pyloric dilator) gets activated, then these cells inhibit other neurons in the same circuit that could interfere with processing of the original impulse.'
Dr. B:'Is this a simple circuit with only two types of neurons?'
Dr. M:'No.'
Dr. B:'How many different kinds of neurons can there be in the hippocampus? Could I add some to the circuit?'
Dr. B:'Why are inhibitory neurons the key element in the hippocampus?'

Dr. M:'The hippocampal network of cells that we study (and which I talk about in my books) depends on the proper and robust activation of the pacemaker cells (the two Pyloric Dilator (PD) neurons) that are responsible for initiating a rhythmic sequence of firing. The pacemaker cells are the first to fire after the onset of a strong enough synaptic drive. In the intact brain, these pacemaker cells are themselves inhibited by the other cells in the network.'
Dr. B:'Can you explain the relationship between excitation and inhibition in the hippocampal CA1 region? What is the function of the GABAergic neurons in this region? How do they function?'

Dr. M:'In my books (and on the internet), I write about it quite extensively in terms of the functional role of GABA in this network. But the simplest answer is the pacemaker neurons that fire at a certain rate. Because of their characteristic and relatively fast rhythms, the pacemaker neurons are inhibited to fire at a different rate that is slower than their original rhythm, and that will produce a slower rhythm in the network. And they are the first to go.'

Dr. B:'How does inhibition work? If we have a network in which there is excitation, in addition to inhibition, how does the system move forward? Do the inhibition or excitation act alone? Are these mechanisms ever studied experimentally?'

Dr. M:'We know that a great deal of inhibition occurs, at least in some neurons, in some animals. We do not know exactly how much inhibition is needed, nor exactly how it changes across species, over development, and between brain regions.'

Dr. M:'I suppose that, well, maybe the function is to provide for the synchronization of neurons that are part of a network. Dr. M:'They are modulators, I suppose.'

Dr. M:'Well, the gamma frequency oscillations are there because of the function that the neuron has as part of the circuit. So, for example, in the cardiac system, these neurons are essential to the function of the cardiac system. So these oscillations are there for a reason.'

Dr. M:'Oh that's a good question. What is the function of the inhibitory neurons? Well the function of the inhibition itself is to stop the ongoing action of the cell because the cell itself stops firing as soon as it is inhibited. And the function of the neurons themselves is to fire or not to fire. It's not that they're doing any sort of active processing. It's just that they don't fire themselves.'

Dr. B:'Inhibition can be a pretty effective mechanism at stopping neuronal activity, and it can be exploited as a strategy to synchronize neurons. Dr. M:'Well, I've always found it very fascinating to think that inhibitory neurons have multiple functions. Inhibitory neurons are really interesting in terms of circuit design, because we've observed that some neurons can act as either a pacemaker or an inhibitory hub for multiple circuits.'

Dr. M:'I think their advantages are multiple. One advantage is that they are not a static component of a circuit. They can be turned on and off, and they can change their electrical properties. Another advantage is that they can generate voltage signals over a large dynamic range.'
Dr. B:'Are there any functions they don't have? Anything they can't do?'

Dr. M:'No, but I'm curious that, because a lot of experiments that people are doing today involve the use of inhibitory neurons with the idea of silencing specific cells of a network that are behaving inappropriately, because often people are trying to do a control function.'

Dr. B:'Control function is one of the oldest. How about something else? Perhaps, say, a new form of memory, or language. Dr. M:'Inhibition of presynaptic terminals.'

Dr. M:'When the presynaptic terminal is excitable, there is a constant activity-dependent inhibition, because of the feedback from postsynaptic neurons. But when a terminal is not excitable, it's not excitable because it's not able to generate activity in response to postsynaptic activity.'
Dr. B:'Are inhibitory neurons necessary for the proper functioning of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Not necessarily. When you're talking about a small circuit of neurons, it's like a relay team that gets their signals from one station, and they relay them to another station. But it's not like a relay team in which all the relay stations are controlled by the same team, because it's not. There are neurons that are inhibitory and not excitatory. There are neurons, for example, that have a different voltage dependence from the other neurons.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible that the two types of neurons can work together, or not?'
Dr. B:'How does inhibition lead to an enhancement of neuronal output?'
Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibition in brain rhythms?'
Dr. M:'The inhibition is a consequence of the activity of the neurons because the neuron produces a constant current.'
Dr. M:'I believe that inhibitory neurons have an important function in maintaining the homeostasis of neuronal network performance.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are neurons that normally provide negative feedback to the network in which they function. This means that they inhibit other neurons in that network from acting in certain ways. For example, when you eat dinner, you don't want to also eat your breakfast, so your stomach needs to be able to inhibit the gastric mill rhythm from bursting when you are eating breakfast.'

Dr. B:'How can inhibitory neurons influence the timing of neuron firing in principal cells? How are they connected to the principal cells? How do they affect spike timing? Does inhibition affect the way neurons communicate with each other? What is their role in brain dynamics? Why do we need the rhythm to be strong enough that we can have inhibition? What are the advantages of inhibition? And finally, what is the function of gamma oscillations? What is the function of interneuronal networks in general?'

Dr. M:'There are advantages to inhibitions. There are advantages to it, because when you need to do something and you need to do it fast, and you need to inhibit somebody else so that they don't get in your way and maybe they don't distract you while you are doing a complicated thing, you can.'

Dr. B:'What are the advantages of GABA? Does inhibition allow the principal cells to function independently? Are inhibitory cells more sensitive to stimuli? What are the effects of inhibition? Is inhibition a key component of brain rhythms? Do we need inhibition? What are they doing in the network? What are the consequences of inhibition for a well functioning network? Why do we have oscillations in the network that are so slow that only the inhibitory neurons can be modulated?'

Dr. M:'I don't think that it's the function of inhibiting that is the problem but the function of regulating, to balance the strength of the rhythmic patterns that you might be trying to achieve. So that's the advantage of inhibiting. In the absence of inhibition, the pyloric rhythm would be much more complicated. The strength of the synaptic input from the gamma oscillator to the pyloric network would change.'
Dr. M:'Well, I guess you could say that they act like switches, but switches that can be switched either way.'
Dr. M:'Inhibition is not a function but it is a mechanism of the nervous system that allows networks to be stable'.'
Dr. B:'What do the neurons of the inhibitory family? Are they special?'

Dr. M:'No, not special. There are many different kinds of neurons, but they do have a set of properties that they have because they have a set of functions. We don't want to say that the different neurons are special, but they do give a set of functions that allows networks to remain stable'.'
Dr. B:'Can the properties of the inhibitory neuron family evolve? What are the constraints?'

Dr. M:'Yes, because these neurons are used for controlling networks. As I was saying, they are important components of networks. There are many kinds of neurons in the nervous system, and they each have their place. In fact, the brain has been made up of many kinds of neurons, because every brain has different networks that must be functional. So neurons have their place and they do have a function.'
Dr. B:'How do you mean when we say 'function?' How do you think the function of inhibitory neurons would be understood, and can be understood, if you don't know their mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'I don't know their mechanism, but that would be the first thing that would come to my mind. I would think, like in other systems, there would be multiple components that would be used. We don't have to be too precise because there's multiple components of a network that will be used. I mean, the fact that the cells are so small and the circuits are made up of multiple cells, doesn't mean that they're not important.'
Dr. B:'Is there a general classification scheme of inhibitory neurons? I mean, one can come up with hundreds of ways of dividing inhibitory neurons into classes. What's the best scheme, and why?'

Dr. M:'That is a good question. I think it is possible to come up with a scheme that will give you an idea of the role of these neurons and their function, but there is a great deal of variability. There are many, many different kinds of inhibitory neurons. There are many other types of neurons, but this is really the most important type because neurons have their own properties, and we are going to look at a few of those properties.'

Dr. M:'I'm wondering how it is determined how many neurons there are. I'm wondering how it's determined. What we do is we say, ok. Dr. B:'The function of the neuron is to be an inhibition, and to inhibit other neurons. And the reason why it's there is because if it didn't do that, the brain would be a chaos. We have to keep things within certain limits.'
Dr. M:'And so it's like a kind of a gatekeeper, you know.'
Dr. B:'A good description, yes, but the reason it doesn't have any intrinsic functions is because it's all done by inhibition.'
Dr. M:'But you see, it doesn't have to work that way.'

Dr. B:'You see, you can have it work the way it should work if you have some mechanisms in place.
