The brain, its networks, and all the connections are always under the control of the body. If you have a brain that can respond to some cues from the body, then you can build up from there.'

Dr. M:' Inhibition is a feature of all nervous systems. In general it acts to maintain appropriate membrane potentials. In particular, the inhibitory neuron of the pyloric circuit acts to increase the amplitude of the rhythmical oscillations of the pacemaker neuron of the circuit, Pyloric Dilator, by inhibiting its presynaptic input.'
Dr. B:' Does the inhibitory neuron have a specific function? If so, what is the function? And if not, why not? What is it doing? Does it have a purpose? If so, why is it important?'

Dr. M:' It's not important. There is no function that it has. It's just a feature of the nervous system. And there are probably many different solutions of how to solve it. It was not selected for by evolution to have this behavior. You know the neurons that can be inhibited by other neurons. There is probably many solutions of how to get them to behave properly, but we found this solution. So, it's not important to know why it behaves in a specific manner.'

Dr. B:' How is the inhibitory neuron organized in the network? Can I assume that in your research you're using a model or a small network of neurons? What is its function? How is it organized? Does it have an importance? And if so, what is it? And if not so, why not? Are there any specific models of the interneuron that you're investigating? Are there any experiments that you're testing?'

Dr. M:' The neurons that can be directly inhibited by other neurons are part of the inhibitory neurons. They are part of the pacemaker circuit. So the pacemaker is the one that makes the rhythmic bursts of activity of the pacemaker. The pacemaker circuit is made by the pacemaker cells, and these cells are made by the single neuron, Pyloric Pyloric Dilater. And the pacemaker cells also include the Pyloric Pyp and Pyloric Pyn neurons.'

Dr. B:' What are the properties of the Pyloric neurons? What are the special features that make them different from all other pyramidal cells? How are they organized? Do they have a function? And if so what is it? Do they have importance? And if not why not? Are they doing anything special? And if so are there any specific models? Are there any other neurons in the circuit? What are they doing?'

Dr. M:' These neurons have the characteristic features of pacemaker neurons: they have long lifetimes; they express a few ion channels; they express a number of voltage-dependent calcium channels. They do not express channels that change the sodium conductance (at least not in the pacemaker) and they do not express voltage-dependent potassium channels.'

Dr. B:' These characteristics make them quite different from other pyramidal neurons. So, what do they do? Can they affect their peers? Are there other cells in the network? What are they? How are they organised? What are they really doing? Do they have any special functions? Are there any models that you're investigating in terms of their function? Are there any experimental studies that you're performing? And if so where can I find these papers and read them?'

Dr. M:' Yeah, there are also the A-type potassium channels that are part of the voltage-gated current in the pacemaker neurons. So, it is the combination of these two neurons that drives the pacemaker rhythm. And it is these two neurons that are driving the pacemaker rhythm, and that is the only function that they have.'

Dr. B:' Why did it have that particular function? How did it get that function? What advantage does it provide? Why does it need to have this behavior? What is its function?'

Dr. B:' So, if you were a single neuron, what would it be doing? Would it be sending spikes to other neurons? What is its job? If so, is it important? Is it important to the organism's survival? Dr. M:' They don't have a specific function. I mean, you know, that was an example that I gave before when I talked about the brain. We used to study all of these single neurons, you know, neurons that we could take out of the brain, and we used to put these single neurons, single cells into culture, and the first question you would ask is: 'Well, do you feed the neurons?'

Dr. B:' The mechanism of inhibition is pretty well understood and well documented. It's a matter of time. When it is the case, why is it not known? What is the 'brain mechanism' or'mechanisms' that make inhibition so effective? I'm interested in those mechanisms.'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think that this is going to answer any questions. So, I am trying to put it in context, because we are trying to understand neural syntax. So, the question about how nervous systems come to be has been one of the major questions for which we do work. And the way that it becomes a feature of nervous systems is because nervous systems have to be regulated by activity, otherwise they can become extremely inefficient, or can fall apart. Right?'
Dr. B:'What is the function, or benefit of synchrony of inhibitory neurons? What would be the consequence if the rhythmical inhibition were compromised?'
Dr. M:' I don't think the answer to your question would be the same as if you asked a different question.'
Dr. B:'Why don't I think the same?'

Dr. M:'The function of inhibitory neuromodulators is very diverse: for example, some of them cause contraction in muscles, but others cause contraction in neurons or muscle fibers, or excite a neuron.'
Dr. B:'What is the function or effect of inhibition in the brain?'
Dr. M:'One of the main functions of inhibition is to provide 'gating' to networks or circuits that release a signal that is important to an appropriate response.'
Dr. B:'Where are the mechanisms and functions that inhibitory neurons provide in the brain?' What are they? What is it?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons can be found on all of the different sensory inputs that are important to the brain, but there are many inhibitory neurons in the brain. The same neuron can release substances that inhibit all the neurons on the same side of the circuit, or it can release substances that are highly selective in terms of the neurons that they affect.'
Dr. B:'In a brain circuit, how does inhibition play the role of gating the network or circuit? What is the role of inhibition?'
Dr. M:'In the brain, I think there are more functions than we thought previously, and the role of inhibitory neurites, synaptic inhibition, in those functions, is going to be very interesting'.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurites have an important role in many brain functions. What is the function of inhibition? What is the function? What is the effect of inhibition in many brain functions? What is the role of inhibition? What are the functions? What is inhibition? What is inhibition and what are inhibitory neurons? What are inhibitory interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Well, to understand the brain's function, you have to understand how it works. In this case, I would say that the function of inhibition is something like, if you're a hunter, you want your prey to get away from you, so you throw this stone, it bounces back and it hits you, you're dead, that's the function of inhibition.'
Dr. B:'Is it the only function that inhibitory interneuron systems have?'

Dr. B:'I agree that inhibition has many functions and that's what we want to know, what are the functions? In my question, I want to know what the function of inhibition in the brains is, and I want to know how inhibition does what it does in order to understand the function of inhibition and inhibition's role in the brains, I want to understand the function, because that is the ultimate goal of neuroscience.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that inhibition has in cortical circuits?'

Dr. M:'Well, you see, neurons in cortex function both as modulators of the circuit and, by firing, also, as they fire, as independent neurons; and so inhibition has different effects in each of the cell types that are present in cortex; and the function of inhibition can vary depending on the network it's being applied to. And the function of the same neuron can change over the life of an organism, depending on the network.'
Dr. M:'Well, it has several functions, because it works in concert with inhibition from multiple neurons and also from inhibitory synapses and from electrical excitatory synapses.'
Dr. B:'In particular, what is the function that inhibitory neurons do for each other? What are the roles that inhibition has in circuits?'

Dr. M:'They act as a sort of homeostatic brake that prevents networks from getting out of control. I would like to show you an example, and this is a really simple one, but it shows how important it is to understand how you change brain function, and how your brain can learn from experience, and change, and how it can change under many conditions.'

Dr. B:'Okay, then we'll have a look at this simple example. Let's say that you have a little piece of cortex, which contains a little bit of pyramidal cells, interneurons and axons, which has two inhibitory neurons in it. We'll say that the two inhibitory neurons are connected to each other by one inhibitory synapse. Now, there are a couple of excitatory synapse that are also connected to each other in the same piece of cortex.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are the brakes that stop neurons from acting against our bodies.'

Dr. B:'How do they do that? Inhibitory neurons make the brain safer by reducing neuronal firing rates in our brain, so the brain can have a better chance to deal with the world. And what is the function of GABA? I have read your book in its entirety and am now preparing to read it again for fun because it is just too good to let go. So what is the function and mechanisms of GABA?'

Dr. M:'Well the main function of GABA is to inhibit electrical excitability. But as I understand, GABA acts through multiple mechanisms, and one of its mechanisms is it acts on a voltage-dependent calcium pump that has two membrane components, so it acts on one part of the pump, and it then releases a calcium channel into the membrane, and it activates this calcium channel. But it has other mechanisms, so that's one of the mechanisms that GABA is thought to have.'

Dr. B:'I have read your book and am now preparing the same book to read again for fun. I'm not interested in your book, but I want to know, what is the function, mechanisms and mechanisms of inhibitory neurons? What are the functions of GABA? Are there really multiple functions? Are there really more than two functions? I have read the recent papers of GABA. What are they? Are there multiple mechanisms?'

Dr. M:'There are many mechanisms, but the most important mechanism for GABA's role in inhibition is the inhibition of electrical excitability, so the first mechanism I'm going to talk about is the inhibition of electric excitability. The inhibition of excitability is thought to be the most important mechanism, but it is not necessarily the first mechanism.'

Dr. M:'Well, GABA is a neurotransmitter that is associated with many of the modulatory neurons, and so GABA is released from a variety of neurons to affect different processes. One of the most important effects of GABA on the brain is that it slows the activity of neurons to allow for the generation of a slow wave in the brain, and also, it is a major transmitter associated with modulation of many different processes, including the modulatory inputs into the pyloric circuit.'

Dr. B:'Do you have a few examples of the many different processes of inhibition? Do you have a few links to some research that demonstrates that inhibition plays an important role in a brain function? Something that could explain what is the role of inhibition in a cognitive function? Or a cognitive function? And if you don't have any of those things, I don't want to be mean. But, can you give me a few?'

Dr. M:'Sure, yeah. So one example is that one of the main ways that GABA is released is that the GABA-A (GABA-A) receptors on the membrane are associated with voltage-gated conductances, specifically, inward current. And so, the current produced by the GABA-A receptors at the membrane depolarized to a negative potential, this is important because the currents that are generated at the membrane are important for keeping the activity of the neuron in its target range.'

Dr. B:'Let me ask you a more precise question. What is the function of interneurons? Interneurons are also neurons but they don't communicate with each other directly. So what do they do? Can you name a specific role for interneurons in the brain? If you can, then let's talk about that.'

Dr. M:'Well, this is the really hard problem. You can ask yourself 'what function do interneurons have?' and you'll find that a lot of the interneurons that exist today have multiple functions, because the brain is always changing, and so they have to be flexible.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory circuits are important because they control excitatory activity by controlling the timing of neurons within the cycle and therefore timing of spiking. Inhibitory circuits are essential in generating various oscillations that are ubiquitous in the brain. Inhibitory neurons are also the cells that control excitatory circuits by inhibiting each other. Inhibitory cells and circuit components also help to select or 'chunk' neuronal messages by modulating the timing of action potentials within the various oscillations.'

Dr. M:'There are lots of reasons why inhibitory neurons are good candidates for being part of a neuronal circuit. First, neurons release transmitters that act via synaptic transmission onto target neurons. One of those transmitters is amine, and the other one is peptide. The amine-containing transmitters in the stomatogastric nervous system are the major neuromodulators of the pyloric network.'

Dr. M:'So, we have a set of neurons that are connected and form networks. The brain is full of oscillating neurons. We have the pacemaker cells that can generate the rhythms that drive neural activity, and then we have network oscillators that we can use to generate various behaviors that depend on the rhythm. We have network oscillators, such as pacemaker cells in the STG that drive other pacemaker cells and can produce a variety of rhythms.'

Dr. B:'Now, let's look at a smaller, more specific brain rhythm, the thalamocortical rhythm in the mid-temporal area that is present during the waking state. What is the function of the inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. B:'So, I can ask the question another way. What is the function of the brain? The answer is that we use the brain to survive and reproduce.'

Dr. M:'And to understand our bodies and understand ourselves as human beings. And we can use the brain to generate behaviors, which is not a trivial thing because we can do things that would make it possible to survive if we were totally dependent on other animals.'

Dr. B:'And this is important because the brain can generate actions that would be dangerous if we were totally dependant on other animals. Dr. M:'But, survival is reproduction, so we use the brain for survival to reproduce, and then we also use the brain to die.'
Dr. B:'Yes, but what do we use the brain, the inhibitory circuits to do? Inhibitory circuits can inhibit excitatory circuits or prevent them from doing anything.'

Dr. B:'And now, a few years back, we had a talk, and we talked about the mechanisms and functions of inhibitory circuits and the mechanisms of inhibition, and a lot of people were talking about what is the function of inhibition? I didn't have a clue. It was only later that I discovered the paper where it was written that I read a sentence, and there it was: inhibition is the brakes that stop the activity of other cells, and it's very simple but very clear.'

Dr. M:'We need the brakes. I mean, we have a car, we have a motorcycle, a car has brakes and a motorcycle has brakes, and so if we're gonna control it, the car has to stop, and the motorcycle has to stop and the bike has to stop.'
Dr. B:'What are the brakes, what are they, what do they do?'

Dr. B:'Now, what is the function of these oscillations? How does an inhibitory circuit control a circuit? Do you have an example of a circuit that can be controlled by a particular oscillation? Dr. M:'Yes, because many, many different rhythms can be generated by single neurons and single circuits. We now understand that a single neuron can generate multiple rhythms or a single circuit can produce multiple rhythms. For example, some of you might have heard of the gompertz neurons, which are a network of neurons that can be active at the same frequency. So, multiple oscillators in a single brain can produce multiple rhythms and therefore multiple functions.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are part of a network that keeps neural information from going too far, from getting lost in the brain.'
Dr. B:'Why is it important to keep the balance in the brain?'

Dr. M:'Well, one of their main functions is to provide a mechanism for inhibiting one network by another network, to allow networks to be coupled. It's a kind of an intrinsic mechanism that allows the network to be coupled. If two different networks were to compete, then it could be that the intrinsic mechanisms of a neuron that inhibits a particular network could be activated and allow the other network to inhibit it.'
Dr. B:'I agree. What is the role of inhibitory neurons in the brain and cognitive behavior?'

Dr. M:'You know, they're just fundamental components of the circuit, and I think, you know, we've said, it's interesting, it's funny, because people will come up with a story about this neuron, you know, I've worked with several different neuron types, and it's funny, you know, one of the things about neural coding is there are neurons that make up, and we have identified neurons that make up some of the sensory circuits, and there are different circuits.'

Dr. M:'I think that when we look at the brain, and we look at the network mechanisms, and we look for the different networks in the brain, and what their interactions are, I think it would be wrong to say that any particular network is a 'brain-cell'. I think it is much more interesting to ask the question of how the brain comes to have a particular network and a particular combination of brain cells.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons function primarily to decrease membrane potential so they can maintain their firing rate. They're like a brake pedal for the motor neuron. But, in many networks the network itself doesn't always produce the inhibition; the inhibitory network also acts like a brake pedal.'
Dr. B:'What is the function then, of GABAergic neurons?'

Dr. M:'I've always been puzzled by the apparent contradiction between this brake pedal function of GABAergic neurons and GABA's ability to inhibit synaptic transmission. The inhibition is always produced by a release of GABA, so the synaptic response to a GABAergic neuron should be inhibited by GABA. And it was initially quite puzzling, but it became clear to me that GABA plays a crucial role not only in the inhibition of GABAergic neurons but also in the inhibition of their postsynaptic targets.'
Dr. M:' Inhibitory neurons have to be part of the circuit that generates an action potential.'
Dr. M:'I am a neurobiologist, so it's important to ask questions about how they function.'
Dr. B:'I don't understand the distinction between excitatory and inhibitory neurons? Are they different? They both generate action potentials.'

Dr. M:'They are used to control synaptic transmission. They are not used to change synaptic dynamics. They are not necessary to produce network dynamics. In this model, as you can see, the network is controlled by inhibitory neurons, which can be identified by their activity patterns. The role of the inhibitory neurons is to provide for synaptic transmission. In this model we find it necessary to put the inhibitory neurons in to control the network.'
Dr. B:'Are inhibitory neurons necessary to control the network?'

Dr. M:'They don't always have a function. Some neurons don't have a function, but there are neurons that are involved in the regulation of muscle movements, and that is because they can inhibit or facilitate the contraction of muscles. I think the best example of a neuronal function is the function of a pacemaker neuron in a muscle contractions. The pacemaker neuron sends a signal to another neuron that is connected with a muscle, that is the same size as the muscle.'

Dr. B:'But the question is, what is the function of that neuron? And that is what you would like to know. And my answer is, it's the same thing that the question is. It's the same thing, and it is also how the brain of an animal can be described. I don't know, because I have never seen an animal without inhibitory neurons in its brain.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'
Dr. M:'But you know, when I look at some of the neurophysiological descriptions of the brain in an animal, like the crabs, there are inhibitory neurons that are not used in that specific behavior.'

Dr. M:'This is a function of the brain's nervous system. You have a nervous system that controls muscle movements, for example. You also have neurons that provide inhibitory input to other neurons. So there are a lot of functions that neurons use to influence neurons in different circuits. But if you're asking what is their primary function, then that's a function of nervous systems.'
Dr. B:'Exactly. And that's what I mean about function. What is the primary function? There are multiple functions. In our case, I would like to use as an example the brain's ability to move muscles.'
Dr. M:'They serve the regulatory function to switch on and off oscillations of oscillators like cells or pacemakers.'
Dr. M:'When inhibitory neurons are active, they inhibit other neurons, and they inhibit themselves. So they play an important role.'
Dr. B:'What are their important functions in the brain?'
Dr. M:'To be honest, I've been thinking about that for decades. I think one of the functions of inhibitory neurons is to prevent neurons from being overloaded and firing too many spikes.'

Dr. M:'That is an interesting question. And I do think that it is, it depends on how you think about them. There are many people who will say 'no, I don't think that these are functions that are critical for behavior. So the function of a neuron is not critical for behavior. The function of a neuron has to do with its ability to express a whole lot of different molecular products and that's what is critical.'

Dr. B:'I can agree with that, but what I'm saying is that there are so many different inhibitory functions that I can't be confident that I understand them all. There is, of course, a lot of literature on interneuronal function that's very interesting.'
Dr. M:'I don't think it is so many. I think it's one way of seeing it. The function of the internal neurons is to coordinate the network activity to produce coordinated behavior.'

Dr. B:'What can they accomplish? Can they inhibit other interneurons in any way? Can they make connections across neurons in any way? Are they responsible for any special functions? Dr. M:'Well, and if you go back to these things, these connections and these relationships in the network, we're really learning that these are relationships that are variable, and we're starting to see that the connections, the circuits that come together are highly variable, and therefore it is possible that different neurons may be connected to different parts of the network and that the connections may be completely different.'

Dr. B:'And how would that happen? In two different ways. One way is a random connection that may occur because the timing is unpredictable. Dr. M:'Right, right. In the case of the nervous system, which we studied a little bit, in the case that we studied in our lab, we found that some neurons in the network are connected to each other by different synapses with different properties that are variable across preparations. We call this variable connectivity the'sophistication' of a network, and we think that there is sophistication.'

Dr. B:'It's very difficult for me to give you a hard time. But the hard problem, the question we are asking is whether we actually know the answer and not whether we have a good story for the answer.'

Dr. B:'Well, the interesting thing is that there's, there's a lot of work that is being done at the cellular level. And it's very interesting, what the connections are in the network, that comes up. And how it connects to the principal cells. And there's the problem right there.'

Dr. M:'In the  C. borealis  system, they're the main pacemaker neurons that trigger the cardiac and gastric mill rhythms and inhibit motor neurons that in turn control rhythmic movements of muscles like chewing and swallowing of food. Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. B:'In the brain, we usually have opposing systems that are balanced with each other. Such as when we have a brain in balance between the left and right sides or the right and left sides. Do we have opposing systems in the brain as well?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely! Absolutely, yeah. Dr. M:'So you're talking about a type of reversal? So that's a kind of a counterbalance?'

Dr. M:'Right, and it's not just pacemaker neurons. There are other neurons, there are other neurons in the  C. borealis  system that fire in concert with these pacemaker neurons. So I think it's the possibility of manipulating a neural circuit without having to manipulate the neurons in the circuit directly.'

Dr. B:'Thank you for this answer. So what about inhibition? Is there some reason for this circuit? How is inhibition so critical for a circuit? What does inhibition do that is so special for the function of these other neurons and neurons? And how are inhibitory neurons and how are inhibitory circuits different from excitatory circuits? How is inhibition different from excitation?'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons have many different functions'.'
Dr. B:'For example, a very important function of inhibitory interneurons is to balance excitatory neurons, to limit their effect and to determine the stability of the circuit.'
Dr. M:'That's correct, the role of an inhibitory neuron is to keep the level of activity of the cell low'.'
Dr. B:'And there is another one, which is to balance excitation and limit excitation'.'
Dr. M:'And to limit excitation, that's correct'.'

Dr. B:'Let's go back to the time when you were a student and the function of the neuron was a little different. If you were to make a circuit where the neurons are only inhibitory neurons, what will happen? The neurons will be inhibited and the inhibitory circuit will be silent.'
Dr. M:'I guess I would be more interested in a function of inhibitions.'
Dr. B:'What is the function... of inhibitory neurons? In other words, what is their function? What do they do? What happens to them? What are their jobs?'
Dr. M:'You know what? I'm not sure. I'm not sure...'
Dr. B:'No, but, uh, I'm very interested in inhibitory mechanisms. I'm very interested...'
Dr. M:'Yeah. So...'

Dr. B:'You're not interested in the functions of inhibitory neurons. What would be a function? You know what? So in my book, which is an old one, I don't want to bring it up, but I can. I can point to it, or I can... I can, I can make it into the issue that I'm interested in. And so you know, I'm not interested in inhibitory neurons or the functions of inhibition or their role in the brain.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'But you want to know, what is the function of the brain? You have a brain. You know, I'm very excited about the brain and the brain is a system of excitatory neurons and inhibitory neurons. And the way the two are organized, uh, uh, that's, uh, so it's a system of opposing forces, which is perfectly suitable for doing something. You just have to know what are the inputs and the outputs of the system and how are they connected?'

Dr. M:'Yes. Right. Yeah. So what, I mean you mentioned the brain is a network, and networks that have, that have many opposing elements to them, so you can, you can make all kinds of different systems out of networks.'

Dr. B:'And this is a perfect case, you know, uh, and if you look at the history of the brain, then you can see how it's a perfect case. We have a structure called the cortex in which there are a number of neuron types.'
Dr. M:'And I guess I'm very interested – I have a paper that we just published on inhibitory mechanisms and I'm interested in – I'm interested in learning more about them.'

Dr. B:'Well, as in, uh, my area of study, I've always been curious about that. It was very important in neuroscience and we know now that inhibition can bring about a lot of different effects, both good and bad. Let me give you two examples from the recent past. The first one is the hippocampus and the second one is the prefrontal cortex.'
Dr. M:'Sure, you mentioned the prefrontal cortex as a potential example.'

Dr. B:'Yes. The prefrontal cortex, as the name suggests, is the last major cortical area to be formed during the mammalian evolution. In humans, it is a homolog of the pallium, and it provides the major communication between the pallium and the subcortex.'

Dr. M:'Oh, that is interesting, it's just that it depends on the context in which you're talking about it, because when you talk about inhibition in the hippocampus you are talking about a context where you are trying to preserve, uh, you know, like a memory in your brain. And if you talk about inhibition with the prefrontal cortex you are talking about, uh, you're talking about a context in which the cortex is supposed to be, uh, to bring about a different kind of effect.'
Dr. B:'It could be a goal or a vision, but in my point of view it's always about a particular goal, and it's always about inhibition.'
Dr. M:'But, you're using it to preserve a memory in the hippocampus or preserving the prefrontal cortex?'

Dr. M:' The function of inhibitory neurotransmitters is to reduce the excitability of postsynaptic neurons, and their firing rate. And this is achieved by several mechanisms. For example, it can happen by reducing the total calcium conductance or by changing the shape of the calcium current or by changes in synaptic transmission, by the activity of an inhibitory neuron or by a neuron in the circuit.'
Dr. B:' Why is the balance of excitation and inhibition important for the brain?'

Dr. M:' We'll discuss the importance of balance in the brain later, but it has to be important to brain function because if you think about what you're trying to do in the brain, you're trying to maintain stable synaptic transmission, and stable electrical excitability.'

Dr. B:' Do you think that the balance of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in the cortex is what maintains stability in the brain? Are the principal cells more important than interneurons? Are the excitatory neurons more critical for maintaining stability, or is it more critical for stability that interneurons are maintained?'

Dr. M:' It's been my experience that in terms of the balance of neurons in the brain, the interneurons have an even bigger role to play than the principal neurons. The interneurons, because the interneuronal circuits are much more complicated and their connections are much more intricate and so, they're really the main modulators of neuronal function.'
Dr. M:'There are many different roles for inhibitory neurons in nervous systems. They can have a number of functions.'
Dr. B:'What are some of those functions?'
Dr. B:'What are some of the functions?'

Dr. M:'Some of the functions are to make sure that other neurons don't fire by inhibition. Other functions are to produce the correct output, because if you don't regulate and maintain the correct balance of inhibitory inputs, you could end up having the wrong balance.'
Dr. B:'Does the right balance depend on the function?'
Dr. M:'Yes, there's a kind of balance between the inhibition that you need to get an output and also the inhibition that you don't need because it prevents it from getting the right output.'

Dr. B:'So in a sense, it is the activity of inhibition that determines whether the output will be a good one or not. So this is an example where I agree with you. I think that in this case, you don't want to have a very small inhibitory system. You want to have a large inhibitory system. If you go back and look at it and see what happens if you have a larger inhibition system, it can have a very large impact on the target network.'
Dr. M:'Well they're inhibitory and they inhibit other neurons and they can inhibit oscillatory neurons.'
Dr. B:'That's the definition of inhibition... right?'

Dr. M:'Right, I guess we've learned to think about that as inhibition. But, the biological meaning of inhibition is really different and this is what I want to talk about, because what we think of as inhibitory neurons is actually the opposite of inhibition in terms of the biological process, right?'
Dr. B:'I agree.'

Dr. B:'And how can inhibition become inhibition? What is the chemical reaction that occurs when GABA is released? How is inhibition released? And what is the chemical reaction of GAD? So there's a lot to discuss there.'

Dr. M:'So I'll just describe, you know, to give you a more, you know, this is, this is a good question, because the definition of inhibition is not what you think of as inhibition in the biological sense, right?'
Dr. B:'So how can we view this in a different way?'

Dr. M:'Because we tend to think of inhibition as inhibition. We tend to think of it as, if you've got a two-headed lion, you don't want that to attack you because you'd be eaten and if a bunch of lions is coming into your town, you don't think the lions are going to kill you. So when the tiger comes into your town, that is not necessarily going to kill you because it may just want to, you know, eat the cat.'
Dr. B:'Well, then that would be inhibition... right?'

Dr. M:'Because when you really analyze the synaptic inputs that inhibitory neurons have, you find that they have the capacity to either inhibit an oscillator, inhibit a neuron that is tonically firing, inhibit a neuron when they are silent, or to turn off a circuit...'

Dr. M:'If you think about inhibition in the biological system as being the inhibition of the activity of one neuron by another neuron, and you think about how many neurons are active and they send out their action potentials and the voltage of that action potential gets passed through the circuit, and it gets reflected off the voltage clamp, and so you have a voltage-gated conductance that can be changed by another voltage-gated conductor that is not necessarily an inhibition.'

Dr. B:'We have to think of inhibition in a different way, but we can't afford to neglect the inhibition. We just need to think of it differently, but we can afford to be ignorant about the inhibition.'
Dr. B:'Now we have the wrong terms, but I'm not going to argue with you. So, I will just wait. And we'll talk about the consequences later.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are important.'
Dr. B:'And why are they important?'
Dr. M:'Because they cause a lot of different kinds of activity to occur.'
Dr. B:'Are inhibitory neurons ever affected by any neurological disease?'
Dr. M:'Some of them, maybe not all of them, but a lot of the ones that are affected, are affected by neurodegenerative disease.'

Dr. B:'So that is to say, the same cells can be affected by two different conditions, or their activity can be affected by a neurological disease and the same thing that causes activity in these cells to change can be responsible for the degeneration of the neurons.'

Dr. M:'Yeah. I guess this is sort of the other reason why these systems are so important. This is one of the reasons why they are so important, because you can look at any nervous system and think it is a simple circuit, and if you start to look at it you realize that it is a big network.'
Dr. M:'Because there is a constant balancing act between excitation and inhibition.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the brain?'
Dr. M:'The brain has many functions.'

Dr. B:'In the last century, we've done a remarkable thing with the understanding of the functions of the nervous system, but now it's time to do the same for the brain. We need a new generation of scientists with the ambition to understand the brain.'
Dr. M:'That's my ambition.'
Dr. B:'Well, good, because this is the field where I'm interested.'
Dr. M:'I'm interested. Oh, in this, and in neural syntax, neural syntax.'
Dr. M:'What do you think they can do?'
Dr. B:'It depends on how ambitious they are.'
Dr. M:'They're important, because the brain has a bunch of different functions.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are a ubiquitous element in neural circuits and are present in every network neuron we study. In general, these neurons can provide a number of distinct functions: they can change their strength in response to neuromodulatory inputs; they can provide a transient suppression of activity; they can trigger oscillations; they can increase the period of an oscillation; they can increase or decrease the amplitude of an oscillation, and they can act to turn an oscillator off.'
Dr. B:'What are the various ways that inhibitory neurons can affect the activity of principal cells?'
Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibition in the brain?'

Dr. M:'The role of inhibition in general, in general, is to make a network behave as you want it to behave, by altering the strength and time course of synaptic connections within the network. So it is useful to a network that is behaving correctly. But if it's malfunctioning, it can be harmful, because these neurons, as you mentioned, can alter synaptic connections.'
Dr. B:'Who are these inhibitory cells that can exert these changes? How would we characterize them?'

Dr. M:'One of our fundamental questions is how the brain uses sensory and motor inputs to produce behavior and then to create new perceptions. What I'm finding, that the brain is more complex than I've ever expected, is that there are multiple circuit mechanisms that are co-evolving in the brain to produce behavior, and they interact with each other in very important ways.'
Dr. B:'When one looks at the entire system, how do you see the circuit mechanisms that will be needed to accomplish the functions that you've outlined above?'

Dr. M:'The answer to that question would be in two separate ways. One is that the brain can use neurons with different features in different circuits, and that's one of the fundamental principles of nervous system design. The other is that there are always interactions between neurons in the brain and those neurons with which they are interacting in their circuits, and then all of the interactions of neurons that go into the brain, the brain will use the neurons and will use their interactions to achieve behavior.'

Dr. M:'There are multiple circuit mechanisms of many types that are working together at the same time in every neural circuit, and that all of these circuits have to be balanced to perform optimally. There's a lot of work that is focused on the balance between excitability and suppression, and it's critical, because if you are to have the neurons in the network that need to work together to produce the behavior that you want, they must be tightly regulated.'

Dr. B:'In the brain, how much excitation should go on at any given time, how many neurons should be firing in a given time window, and how much inhibition should be applied? The goal, in short, is to have the proper amount of excitation and inhibition, and this balance should be maintained through multiple means such as a feed-forward and a feedback mechanism, as shown in the hippocampus.'

Dr. M:'I think you might say, that the answer is, 'Yes, because we have multiple mechanisms to balance excitation and inhibition'. The answer is yes. One of the reasons why it is so hard to understand neural circuits is because it is hard to know how neurons and circuit mechanisms in the brain will interact, and you can't measure everything. You can't monitor the brain. You can't see how the circuits in the brain will respond to stimuli, because you can't go to the brain.'
Dr. B:'How do you have a way of telling what is appropriate and what is inappropriate to balance? There's no way that you can know it's optimal.'

Dr. M:'The balance between excitation and inhibition is absolutely critical for any circuit, and I think it comes from evolution. For example, in evolution, animals need to be able to respond to stimuli, and the balance between excitation, which is important in responding to stimuli, and inhibition, which is critical, is fundamental. It's not enough to have a circuit of neurons that is firing tonically, so you want to have many neurons firing together in bursts to be able to effectively respond to external stimuli.'

Dr. M:'The role of inhibition in neurons and networks of neurons is very different, because neurons are already inhibited before they fire. In networks of neurons, however, there are many neurons that are active at a given time and it is important that those neurons be regulated by feedback. Many of the same processes that apply to single neurons that are important for determining the period of an individual neuron can also apply to networks.'
Dr. B:'So what are the examples of inhibition that are important in neural networks?'

Dr. M:'The brain is a complicated network, with many neurons, neurons are electrically coupled, neurons have different electrical properties, and neurons in a network can have many, many different connections. The network is also regulated by modulators that influence synaptic and intrinsic membrane properties. Inhibition is often a critical regulator of neural function, because it provides a feedback element that allows a network neuron to influence a network's behavior.'

Dr. B:'How would you define inhibition? What's the difference between inhibitory and excitatory neurons? What is the fundamental difference between excitation and inhibition? Why are some neurons excited and others inhibited?'

Dr. M:'Excitatory neurons are ones that increase the frequency and/or amplitude of the network's activity. Inhibitory neurons are ones that decrease the frequency and/ or amplitude of the network activity. Excitatory neurons often increase the amplitude of oscillations, whereas inhibitory neurons tend to decrease the amplitude of oscillatory activity.'
Dr. B:'Do inhibitory neurons work differently than excitatory neurons?'

Dr. M:'They are different, they have different synaptic connections, different intrinsic membrane properties, and they release different modulators. Some of them work very differently from excitatory neurons.'

Dr. M:'A few years ago, I read the work of a neuroscientist who is working in London, and he had this idea, which is actually quite general, that a neuron that has been inhibited can become very excitable, like a spiking neuron. You can actually see in the nervous system of animals, that if the neuron is inhibited for a long period of time, then when the inhibition goes away, the neuron then becomes very excitable.'
Dr. M:'What are inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. M:'The answer is, they control the behavior of neurons and of circuits.'
Dr. B:'So why is there only one inhibitory cell type?'

Dr. M:'Because when you look at what inhibitory neurons are actually controlling, you find that each of the nervous system has many different circuits in it, so you need many different types of inhibitory neurons, and it is a relatively simple system to engineer.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible to have more than one inhibitory cell? Are you aware of any, or do you think we are close? Are we close? Do you think we can make it so that more than one type of inhibitory cell can do the same function? If so, how?'
Dr. M:'I think that it is possible to make it so that there can be multiple cells that play the role of inhibiting a particular neuron.'
Dr. B:'I have the feeling that if you could just explain to me your way of making it so that there could be more than one type, it would work perfectly fine, but I am not sure that that will work.'

Dr. M:'Well, you can make two or three different types of neurons, so that you could have two or three cells that would release different substances. So, there are already multiple-cell types in the brain, so you could have more than one type.'

Dr. B:'What is the function that inhibition serves? And in this case, they are the principal inhibitory neurons in the cerebral cortex. In other words, the GABAergic interneurons and basket cells are, in fact, the main inhibitory neuron types of the cerebral cortex. So inhibition is a fundamental function in the cerebral cortex, and it is achieved by inhibition.'

Dr. M:'This is important because in many cases, we don't have a direct view of the neurohormones that are released in the nervous system. So if we look at the structure, the function of the brain, we are looking at one type of inhibitory neurons, the GABAergic ones.'
Dr. B:'Let's begin with the neuron types themselves. What are their properties?'
Dr. M:'Well, they all have a membrane potential, an intrinsic excitability, and an excitability that depends on neuromodulation.'
Dr. B:'Now, we've established that these three key features are common across all neuron types. What other features are unique to inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. M:'Inhibition is a function of modulatory neurons. In general, the role of inhibitory neurons is to maintain rhythmic neural activity.'
Dr. B:'How does inhibition support neural syntax? Is there a way to describe it objectively without the help of the language of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's not necessary to use language like inhibition, because there are many other terms that are related to inhibition, that we can use to describe the role of inhibition. For example, in the case of synaptic depression, there are two neurons with similar properties, the presynaptic and the postsynaptic neuron, and the postsynptic neuron is slower than the presynaptic one.'
Dr. B:'Do we have to talk about the syntax separately for excitatory and inhibitory circuits? How would inhibition support syntax?'
Dr. M:'Well, they are inhibitory neurons. They control the amplitude of an oscillator.'
Dr. B:'How is that possible?'

Dr. M:'Because they inhibit the pacemaker from generating the oscillator's activity and they slow down the oscillator's frequency. So, it is not necessarily the case that they have a specific function.'
Dr. B:'Can you explain it in simpler terms?'

Dr. M:'Sure, you have a pacemaker that generates action potentials, and the pacemaker is usually electrically coupled to an oscillator. And it generates a rhythmic action potential sequence which is a kind of pacemaker activity. So, there is a pacemaker neuron, and an oscillator. So, what the neurons do is inhibit the pacemaker to slow down its frequency to maintain some appropriate frequency with which the pacemaker can generate a rhythmic pattern of action potentials.'
Dr. B:'So that's very cool.'
Dr. M:'But the neurons that inhibit the pacemaker have an inhibitory synaptic potential, and they are slow, they release inhibitory substances.'

Dr. B:'Okay, I know what the mechanisms are, but I am looking at the output of the neurons in a network. It seems to me that it is the output of the pacemaker neurons that is driving the activity of the neurons in the network.'
Dr. M:'So that's the pacemaker neuron, the slow-wave oscillator. Okay.'

Dr. B:'But the slow-wave network is not 'built in' like a rock that the power of the rhythm is just given to it. I'm looking at a network that has a slow-wave activity that is the consequence of some network. And I'm trying to understand how that slow-wave activity arises. And the neurons in the networks are the target of the network and they can respond to the slow-wave activity. They are part of the slow-wave generation.'
Dr. B:'So, you can think about inhibitory neurons as they are 'good enough' for the pacemaker?'
Dr. M:'That's right. And they will always be there, because you can always turn the pacemaker off if you wanted to do that.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, good enough.'

Dr. B:'That is an extraordinary feat. Do you know, who were the people who first identified that inhibitory neuron function and how did you become interested in that? And when were you aware that you wanted to be a neuroscientist?'

Dr. M:'When I was a graduate student. I had been studying biology for many years and I got interested in the nervous system in high school. My parents were professors and they started telling me stories about the nervous system when I was a kid. So, I remember I first got interested in how the nervous system worked when I was very young, like very young, and it was also because of my parents because they didn't understand why I would want to become a scientist.'

Dr. B:'I can just imagine the excitement you had when you were a student, you were working on how the brain could do something extraordinary and how the brain could make the machine work. And that is where the brain and computers were? Nowadays, the brain and the computer are connected and integrated. But in your time, they were completely separate and independent entities. I can also imagine that there were very few people who could communicate with each other as effectively as you and I? What was the process?'
Dr. B:'And they can have a high enough impact on the pacemaker to provide sufficient feedback inhibition so that the neuron or a group of neurons can respond with a high enough frequency.'

Dr. M:'They are 'good enough'. I think you might be interested to see some of the work by my lab that has been done. So, we have been studying the interactions of neuromodulators and other neurotransmitters with the pacemaker networks and with neurons that are part of the pacemaker networks. For example, the modulators that influence the pacemaker networks include the neuropeptide VIP.'
Dr. B:'VIP? What does VIP do?'

Dr. M:'VIP can interact with all of the neurons that are partof the pacemaker network. And there are many neurons that are part-of the pacemaker and are targets of VIP, because VIP also can interact with neurons that are not part of the pacemaking network. But you are right, the best example of this is that when VIP was originally identified, it was isolated from the rest of the neuropeptides, but the pacemaker networks were identified.'
Dr. B:'What exactly does VIP do?'

Dr. M:'VIP acts as a pacemaker-released, slow-wave-induced depolarization that influences both the pacemaker activity and that of neurons that are part, either directly or indirectly, of the pacemaker network. The neurons that are directly part of the pacemaking network are the pacemaker neurons themselves. These neurons include two pacemaker neurons that are responsible for generating the high-frequency oscillators.'

Dr. M:'It influences the strength of synaptic transmission, and it also influences the frequency of the pacemaker's oscillation. So, there is a lot of other things that influence the strength of synaptic and intrinsic conductances. So, I will leave the question with you. But the answer is: No. Not that they are 'good-enough' for the pacemakers. But that they influence the frequency and the other features of the pacemaker neurons, but the pacemaker is always firing.'

Dr. B:'I mean, I've been around the world a little bit, but the first thing I heard when I got to this continent was that it is a land where there are many many kinds of inhibitory neurons, which is, to me, a great news because inhibition is the most important and most interesting function of the brain. It is a kind of a glue which holds together the neurons that don't respond to the external stimuli.'
Dr. M:'It is a glue and the way it works is that, you know, if you don't get enough stimulation, you're not going to respond.'

Dr. B:'No, that's right. I don't know if we have to make it so strong that you're going to respond or not. What I would like to ask from you is that how we can understand the mechanisms of inhibition, but without knowing the mechanism, how can we explain why it's so important? What kind of things are they suppressing, exactly? Can you explain to us how inhibition works? Or I have a simpler question, maybe. What is the function of excitatory cells?'
Dr. M:'They excite the cells they contact, and excitatory cell, if you will, are, by definition, are the ones that excite the cells that they excite.'
Dr. B:'Oh, that's true. So that would mean the same thing as inhibition because inhibition can inhibit excitation and, or, or, or excitation is just the other side of inhibition.'

Dr. B:'So if we take a couple of these excitatory cells, for example, and we give them a neurotransmitter to excite them, they will do a little dance. That's because it is a neurotransmitter, which can excite the neurons. But if we put the two together in an inhibitory loop, then it becomes a very, uh, interesting mechanism. Now, how you can understand this mechanism, I don't know.'

Dr. M:'There are mechanisms and I think, to me, that are very simple and they were not complicated because we thought about them. For example, for a long time we thought that all neurons responded to the same kind of neurotransmitters and they do respond to the same neurotransmitters.'
Dr. B:'If you don't get too much stimulation, then you're not going respond.'
Dr. M:'You're not going to be able to respond to it.'

Dr. B:'Well, there's no way, right? There's no way you can say, "Oh, now we have an action potential because we have the right level of stimulation." Right? There are many things in the brain which are so sensitive to changes in the external inputs. For instance, the brain activity in the hippocampus, in the case of the gamma oscillations, is controlled by the strength of hippocampal afferents coming from the entorhinal input.'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibitory neurons have a function. Their inhibition plays a role, but it is more important for them to produce a release to remove the inhibition. In fact, in certain preparations of mice, we had found that if you just took out the inhibitory inputs to the neuron, the neuron would fire and die and you wouldn't have any function at all.'
Dr. B:'So it's important, but it's not as important as excitatory neurons?'
Dr. M:'In my view, yes. Excitatory neurons play a role in enhancing the excitation of other neurons by synaptic release.'

Dr. B:'Why is it important to inhibit other neurons? Does inhibition allow for synaptic plasticity? Is the strength of synapse strength determined by synaptic release? Is it important for inhibitory cells to inhibit? How is inhibition released? Are there some types of inhibitory neurons that have special features? How is the inhibition released? Are some of the neurons not inhibited but instead inhibited indirectly, like for instance, in the thalamus? Is the release of inhibition different in these types of neurons?'
Dr. M:'Oh yes, yes.'

Dr. B:'What are some examples of these differences between these neurons? How are inhibition released? Do inhibitory neurons have special features, special features, special wiring? If so, what are some of the special features? What are some examples of inhibitory neurons? How are these inhibitory neurons released? Are there any types of inhibitory cells that inhibit in a different manner? Is the release mechanism different? What is the inhibitory circuit? Is it important to inhibit?'

Dr. M:'I can only speak to the inhibition that we do because we do not see the release of the activation, but I'm sure there are some, and there are examples of activation release, but certainly there are examples of synaptic release of the inhibition of other neurons.'
Dr. B:'I agree with that.'
Dr. B:'You mean the inhibitory neurons play a role?in enhancing the excitation by synaptic release?'
Dr. B:'And inhibitory neurons inhibit other inhibitory neurons, but, if excitatory neurons are to perform any useful function, they are necessary for interneuron function.'

Dr. M:'And the inhibitory neuron also produces its own kind of inhibitory feedback. And when you study the dynamics of neurons and of networks, you find that the dynamics of the network depends on the interplay between the dynamics of the individual neurons.'
Dr. B:'It depends on inhibition, which is always a key player in the network.'
Dr. M:'So there are always a couple of components, one being the excitatory neurons, one being the inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'I agree with this. I agree with this because inhibition is necessary for the dynamic operation of the network. The interneurons are always there and are always critical in a network. But, in order to make the network work properly, the dynamic interaction between the excitatory and inhibitory neurons is an absolute requirement.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons inhibit other neurons. Inhibitory neurons that inhibit neurons of the same kind are called 'positive' neurons, inhibitory neurons that inhibit different kinds of neurons are called 'negative' neurons. So neurons have a lot of different properties and it turns out that the neurons that are most important for a particular behaviour are often different from those that are most important in other behavioural contexts.'
Dr. B:'I'm looking for a function that is not a function.'
Dr. M:'No.'
Dr. B:'Okay. How would you define a neuron's job? What is the neuron's function?'

Dr. B:'Then, can you tell me what is the function? Is the function like, I have a cell assembly. My assembly is composed of these three inhibitory neurons that can fire at a particular time and at a particular time, they're in the gamma phase or theta phase, they can fire or they will fire in a particular way, is that the function? Is that the function?'
Dr. M:'I don't think so.'

Dr. B:'Well, why not? If that's the case, then I have to understand how many inhibitory neurons have to be assembled to fire at a particular moment, at a particular moment in a particular way in order to make it happen. And what is the timing mechanism? Is it something internal or external, and how many assembly members? If you had 20,000 neurons, would your assembly have 20,000 members? Is that the assembly? What is the timing mechanism?'

Dr. M:'Well, the timing mechanism is called the pacemaker kernel. I mean, the pacemaker kernel is, for instance, the pacemaker in the spiking pacemaker kernel and the pacemaker in most invertebrate pacemaker. The pacemaker kernel has to keep track of time. It can't be an absolute timekeeper, because that would mean that every neuron has to have a different clock and then keep it aligned. They do have their own clocks.'

Dr. B:'I have to say, I'm, I'm very impressed by your answer. I have to say, it's actually really, it's really convincing to me. I'm actually very impressed. So this is the assembly. Now, if I want to make it happen, then, uh, I have to tell it that you are here, then this is how many neurons do have to be assembled, and you have to tell it when they have to fire.'

Dr. B:'So in other words, the function of inhibitory neurons is not that they inhibit neurons. There's not a function that interneurons are in the business to do, they can only be part of an assembly. So the function of inhibitors is to be part of assemblies, and this is their sole function.'
Dr. M:'That's their sole function, yes.'
Dr. B:'What would be a good example of such functional differences between neurons? I can think of only one.'
Dr. M:'That's interesting. Let me give you a very simple example. There are neurons that are important in the gastric mill rhythm of the stomach that are important in other rhythms of the stomach.'

Dr. M:'Well, one example is neurons that are important for maintaining cell identity that don't necessarily inhibit the other neurons that are involved in some other behaviour, so for example, neurons that don't fire but are electrically coupled to some active neuron or a neuron with a tonic activity. So this could be important for maintaining cellular identity. Other neurons that could be important in a context where they don't fire but they are inhibited, and that would be a similar case.'

Dr. B:'I'd be interested in learning more about such properties of inhibitory neurons in particular. What excites me is the possibility that you could provide a few example neurons from the brain that have properties that allow them to accomplish their functions effectively, yet in a context that we can relate to the properties of a large population of inhibitory neurons. How can we do that? What are some of these neurons in particular that have different properties and how do those neurons interact and what excite them?'

Dr. M:'Well the function of an inhibitory neuron is to reduce the amplitude of a postsynaptic response to a strong presynaptic stimulus. Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons, or the synaptic inhibition from other neurons, is critical for maintaining the robustness of networks. In networks with inhibitory neurons, networks can become stable despite underlying biological differences. For example, in the biological model that I have studied in my work, where neurons are connected electrically and they receive inhibitory and excitatory inputs from several other neurons, neurons can become highly electrically coupled and can maintain this coupled-ness despite any biological differences in the neurons.'

Dr. B:'Are there other types of inhibition that are important for brain function? If so, can you explain their functions? Are there different subtypes of inhibitory neurons in the brain? What are the mechanisms that allow them to perform their tasks?'

Dr. B:'So what is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'I think it is important for keeping networks robust. But we are thinking in a biological sense. This is, I think, a critical problem. Because, I mean, we have a theory of the nervous system where it's been very successful, but you know, it's been very good for explaining the properties of the nervous system, and it's very hard to imagine how the nervous system could work, and how neural circuits could work, if they were not regulated by neuromodulation.'

Dr. B:'How do inhibitory neurons behave under physiological conditions? What is their job, if they're there? What's their function? Is it mainly to balance excitation and inhibition? Are they mainly inhibitory? Are they mostly excitatory? What's their contribution to the network? What do they do?'

Dr. M:'Well, I'll give you a simple example of this, and this will give you an idea of how important it is to have this robustness in networks and how important it is that you don't get all kinds of weird and extreme cases. When you look at the nervous system of the lobster, for example, the first neurons that respond to external stimuli are the STG cells.'
Dr. B:'Then what? What are these STG cells?'

Dr. B:'Then what happens? The STG cells will inhibit the other neurons in the lobster stomatogastric ganglion, and, because the inhibition keeps the inhibitory circuit closed, the remaining neurons will respond.'

Dr. B:'STG cells are a special group of inhibitory cells in the lobster nervous system that are innervated by the giant layer 5 neurons of the lobster stomatogastric ganglion. What is the function of STG cells?'

Dr. M:'The function of the STG cells is very important, because these are the cells that are most exposed to the outside. The STG cells respond to the inputs of the pacemaker group. They respond to the inputs from the pacemaker group and they're also part of the circuit that is controlling the pyloric circuit. The pyloric circuit is important for chewing and swallowing, so these cells are important for eating. They produce the stomach rumbles that you hear when you're chewing food.'
Dr. B:'And are these STG cells innervated by other neurons, including other GABAergic inhibitory neurons? What is their function?'

Dr. M:'Well, as I understand it, it's to produce a stable output by suppressing the amplitude of the fast oscillators that arise during neuronal activation. That's been studied in a number of invertebrate and vertebrate systems.'
Dr. B:'So, then, what are the advantages of that?'
Dr. M:'The advantage of this is that the output is, it's more robust because it is always suppressed. We now have a robust circuit that doesn't care how often the inputs get presented to it.'

Dr. M:'You know, they really give you the reliability of output, so you know, you know you just want a neuron that can just keep firing, and then you don't want one that's going to fire intermittently, because, because then you're going to worry that something's wrong with your model.'

Dr. B:'What is the function? They are not critical for the brain's normal operation. They are just there. What is the function? I will ask the question again, but with a different approach.'

Dr. M:'I will tell you what the function of these neurons is: they are the part of the circuit that makes us, for example, wake up in the mornings. That is a normal circuit function. If we were to remove those, you'd go to sleep.'

Dr. B:'I'm asking a question about inhibitory neurons, and I will say that the function of inhibitor-neurons is that their removal from the circuits will make the circuits to act like they would if the excitatory neurons were removed. They are critical. They are critical.'
Dr. M:'Right, but that is a different question than we're asking.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but it is also the same question. I will ask you the question again but with a different method. The fundamental question is whether you have a circuit that can generate a particular output, and the question is how that output is generated. For example, the output of the circuit that generates cognition is, for example, a decision. The question is whether that decision is made by a circuit with two different types of neurons.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of the inhibitory circuit?'

Dr. M:'Well, the function of the inhibition is to keep us awake in the morning and also to make sure that we get out of the house and into the garden and then out into the street. So the function of the synaptic inhibition is to be able to respond to the fact that the sun is shining outside.'
Dr. B:'When we have to wake up and go out in the morning, there's something we have to face.'
Dr. M:'Exactly.'
Dr. B:'And so the inhibitory circuit is the synaptic inhibition, the process that allows us to respond to these two different situations.'
Dr. M:'It allows us to respond appropriately, so that we can wake up and go into the garden and enjoy the sun in the morning, and also then can go out onto the street and interact with other people.'

Dr. B:'I think it's pretty easy to look at these things from the perspective of the neurons and the synapses and not the system as a whole. The synapse is a little piece of the system, but when you have a system as a whole, the neurons work together. In this case, the inhibition is a little piece. The inhibition allows for certain types of communication, and this communication allows for the neurons to be able to do certain things. And so on.'

Dr. M:'Well, it depends on whether the neuron is excitatory or inhibitory. If it's excitatory, it excites other neurons. If it's inhibitory, it inhibits other neurons, and it can affect other neurons even before it inhibits itself. It can cause inhibition of the same neuron that is not caused by it self-inhibition. That's important, because otherwise you wouldn't be able to have many, many neurons in networks.'
Dr. B:'What are they doing in the hippocampus?'
Dr. M:'They cause inhibition. They cause inhibition. They're important components. Inhibitory neurons are important components of the hippocampus.'
Dr. B:'But they don't cause anything else? They don't add something to the circuit?'
Dr. M:'No, they don't add something. They just add an inhibition to the circuit.'

Dr. B:'But what is the function of inhibition in the brain? For example, what is the function?of inhibition in the hippocampus? What's the function?of interneuronal inhibition? What's the role of the GABAergic system?'

Dr. M:'That's important. I mean, you can't study a circuit without knowing that the GABAergic system is important. Because it sets up the circuit, and it's always important in brain research. And so if you have a brain that is producing a large number of actions you want to understand how that brain works, you first want to understand the role of the neurotransmitter, you first want, you first want the roles of the modulators. So that's very important.'

Dr. B:'What is the function? of interneuronal, I mean, inhibitory, inhibition? What is the function?that is, it's always a function. It always has to be done, right? There is no function, like, "Oh, how would I like to inhibit, without knowing that it's important? Without knowing why I'm doing it? Without knowing why it's important to inhibit, without seeing what's in front of us, what are we trying to inhibit?'
Dr. B:'Can we use such inhibitory effects to manipulate networks? Like a computer?'

Dr. M:'So, that's an interesting question. Because, as you can imagine, it would be useful to be able to, say, turn off a circuit, if you want to study its properties in isolation. Right? So, the question really comes down to whether you think that the brain can be manipulated, and how you'd like to manipulate it.'

Dr. B:'I'm not very optimistic about that. I would say that, in addition to a few known neurons, it would be hard to find many specific inhibitory neurons in the brain. In fact, the inhibitory system in the brain is so diverse, I mean, it has several orders of magnitude more neurons than the excitatory system, but it has fewer known types of interneurons.'

Dr. M:'I think it would be hard. In addition to the neurons you know, there are several different networks and they're diverse, and they're kind of hard to locate, but also, you know, to study, you know, their properties.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but, uh, I agree with you. There's no doubt that in principle, you can do things with interneurons. But, uh, I'm not an expert, and you're certainly not a master. So I'm not going to give you a list of questions you have to answer and answers, but just think about it and tell us what you think it's like.'
Dr. B:'So you're saying that inhibition is a really important element of how the brain works.'

Dr. M:'I'm saying that inhibition is an important element of how our brain works, how our nervous system works. And that's true for excitatory systems as well as inhibitory systems. Because if you don't have inhibition, if you have a network where some of your neurons are excited and some are not excited, that network can be very unstable and if it's stable it can't perform well.'

Dr. B:'I'm not talking about the cerebral cortex. I'm talking about other parts of the brain that can be studied in isolation. And that's where inhibition is really important for its role in network activity. What is the function of GABAergic interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Okay, so GABA is a general abbreviation for gamma-aminobutyric acid, which is another neurotransmitter in our brain that has been studied for years. And GABA plays roles that are really very general. So GABA is used as a neurotransmitter. It also helps regulate the pyloric rhythm. That's important. It also helps keep our nervous system working. It also has important roles in feeding, for example, in feeding. So GABA is important for all of these things.'

Dr. B:'The pyloric rhythm is not very important. The feeding is not very important to the cerebral cortex. In fact, it's not even a very good idea to get the two disconnected from each other. We would see a massive loss of cortical function. So these are examples of functions that you can learn a little bit about GABA. What is it's really function? What is inhibition?'

Dr. B:'Now that you know inhibition is so important, it's important to understand how it affects information in the brain. Do you know what's the impact of inhibitory systems? Do we have some data on this?'

Dr. M:'Well, they have two functions, one is to inhibit the release of neurotransmitter and another one is to maintain the synaptic connections within their networks by blocking synaptic release from other neurons. So it's a two-fold function of inhibitory network activity, which is why we think it's important that we study this. Because this is fundamental to understanding how the nervous system works.'
Dr. B:'And what makes inhibitory neurons so different from excitatory neurons? Do they have a different architecture? Are they wired differently?'
Dr. B:'If you were in charge of the development of the nervous system, what would be your strategy?'

Dr. M:'First of all, you would be thinking that you would want to maximize the amount of information you could put onto the circuit and how that would interact with the other circuits, and then also how this would relate to the behavior that you're interested in and how the nervous system is going to respond to changes in its environment, whether it is going to be healthy or ill.'

Dr. M:'I believe the function of inhibitoric neurons is to inhibit other neurons that are in the circuit, and so to maintain the proper rhythmic oscillations that underlie perception, cognition, behavior and all sorts of complex neural functions.'

Dr. B:'Why do we have so many different subtypes of inhibitory neurons, and how do they work together? Can we know their mechanisms? What is the function of the different subtypes of neurons? Is it important to understand their mechanisms, or are they just interesting for their properties? I also don't understand how to answer that question.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think, I think you have to be both because you need to know how the neurons work, but also you have to know why they evolved the way they did because it may have been evolutionarily adaptive in certain circumstances, or not, but we know from studies of evolution in different species and neurons in different species that evolution tends to evolve the most robust mechanisms, the most robust mechanisms.'

Dr. M:'It is important to understand their mechanism because each neuron has a different complement of ion channels and neurotransmitters. And each neuron is tuned to a particular circuit. And so if you want to understand how neurons work, you want to understand the underlying mechanisms that control their different properties, then you have to understand how different neurons in the brain control different neural circuits. So each neuron has a particular role to play.'
Dr. B:'In other words, each neuron's a bit of a special puzzle, but we don't have a full understanding of how they work.'
Dr. M:'We have a full understanding, but we're learning to understand them, and it takes a bit of patience and a bit of luck.'

Dr. B:'The mechanisms that different inhibitory subtypes can perform are just interesting because it goes to the fundamental question of how neuronal circuits work and how inhibitory neurons contribute to their function. But at the moment, I can only just say, well, I'm very interested in how different subtypes of interneurons work together in order to form neural circuits that perform different functions, like perception, memory, imagination, navigation, motor planning, behavior, and so on.'

Dr. M:'I see that you're asking the wrong question, but I'll answer you anyway.  The function of inhibitory synapses is a common misconception in neuroscience. In general, inhibition is a very different animal than inhibition in other circuits. We call this 'intrinsic inhibition'.  Intrinsic inhibition is a kind of activity-dependent feedback process that is triggered by a stimulus that is not synaptic and that is intrinsic to a neuron.'
Dr. B:'So, the action potentials in the inhibitory neurons are triggered by some intrinsic mechanism in the neuron itself.'

Dr. M:'So that means the feedback loop, in terms of the circuit, is built into the neuron. So, this is intrinsic regulation.  This is feedback to the nucleus that's independent of synaptic or intrinsic synaptic regulation. This is intrinsic regulation by the network. And these intrinsic feedback rules, which are called intrinsic conductance rules, which are part of these intrinsic properties of the neuron, are controlled by the transcription factors that govern neural circuit dynamics.'
Dr. B:'I'm sorry, but I have a question.  Why are the intrinsic conductance rules controlled by transcription factors?'

Dr. M:'Because there are different components of neurons, and it turns out the same cell, in general, has many, many different combinations of proteins. So, if you're going to control this sort of regulation, the first thing that you want to do is have it regulated intrinsically. It turns out that the first thing that happens when you do this is that it turns out you want to have the rules, or the regulation rules, that are intrinsic to a neuron.'
Dr. B:'And are intrinsic inhibitory currents typically strong?'
Dr. M:'Well, as far as we know, they provide the feedback that is crucial for the function of many brain circuits. But I think you asked about their function in terms of neuronal signaling.'
Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are part of the network, and in particular part of the circuits that make up the oscillatory networks of the heart and the stomach.'
Dr. B:'Oh, I see, now we have the function.'
Dr. M:'Yes. I mean these oscillators. We use these oscillators because these oscillators allow us to interact with our food and water.'
Dr. B:'How? What do they do?'
Dr. B:'Is it the same mechanism?'

Dr. B:'Okay. So inhibitory neurons are part, uh, of the mechanism that is called oscillations? That is, they are a mechanism that is used to, uh, generate, or to create, or to sustain oscillations in the system. So in the case of the heart, the frequency of the heart is maintained by inhibitory neurons, and the frequency of the heartbeat is generated by, uh, excitatory neurons.'
Dr. B:'How does inhibition allow for this? So, uh, you can explain that, can you?'
Dr. B:'And what about the hippocampus and amygdala? Are these inhibitory structures?'
Dr. M:'No. Inhibitory neurons have a variety of functions.'
Dr. M:'No, they're the main pacemaker cells that control rhythmic motor behaviors that depend on complex, multi-compartmental network interactions.'
Dr. M:'The hippocampus is not a network, and the amygdala is not a network.'
Dr. B:'But when it comes to circuits, are there inhibitory neurons in there that are functionally relevant for the hippocampus and amygdala?'
Dr. M:'Well, the  C. borealis  and the  C. americanus  have some inhibitory neurons that have been identified, and they function in the brain, as far as I know.'
Dr. M:'They regulate synaptic transmission and they are used as integrators of network activity into cellular and circuit functions.'
Dr. B:'Who are the neurons in the brain that provide input to inhibitory cells?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are two types of neurons in the brain—projection neurons and somatodendritic neurons. There are projection neurons, which send axons through the body and they are responsible for the transmission of information between neurons and the central pattern generating circuitry of the brain. Those neurons that send axons down the entire body—throughout the whole neuromuscular system—are the somatodendrial neurons.'
Dr. B:'What role do inhibitory neurons play in the brain?'
