Dr. M:'In the brain, the largest part of the brain, they have many roles. Some of the functions of inhibitory neurons are fairly well documented. For example, a good part of the work of the Marder lab is to do with neurons that are used for modulating synaptic transmission, and neurons that are used as integrators of network activity into higher-order network function.'
Dr. B:'How about principal cells? What do they do? What is their function?'

Dr. B:'Now, is it possible to predict how long it will take to answer those questions? Are there some examples where the process of discovery has been relatively fast and efficient? What were those findings? What have been some of the questions asked that were answered by these processes of discovery? How long does it take to find some of the answers? Are there some specific examples? How many years or decades or decades did it take for you to solve some of these questions?'
Dr. M:'In mammals, this is mostly done by inhibitory projection neurons that are used to regulate synaptic transmission, but also by several other kinds of neurons.'

Dr. B:'In the hippocampus, are there specialized cell types that selectively innervate a particular class of neurons? I'm asking about interneurons, which are the primary target of hippocampal pyramidal cells. I'm not asking about the pyramidal cells, because pyramidal cells also innervate each other, but how do they innervate their primary targets?'

Dr. M:'Yes, that's a good question, because as you go up the neuroaxis, pyramidal cells are only a subset of the neurons that provide feedback to them, and there are several neuron types that provide inhibitory feedback to pyramidal cells.'

Dr. M:'Well, their function is to release a variety of substances that in turn influence other cells, either by activating receptors on those other cells or by influencing the release of neurotransmitters from those other cells. It is often a very complicated network of interacting neurons because there can be multiple inhibitory inputs to the same cell and multiple modulatory neurons acting together. And they can influence a variety of circuits.'

Dr. B:'I've always wondered why neurons have dendritic spines and axons that go to other neurons that are considered inhibitory. I have a hard time visualizing inhibition as anything but a complex, and inhibitory neurons are very expensive to construct, as are excitatory neurons. What do inhibitory neurons do?'

Dr. M:'A lot of work has been done on the function of the dendrites, and there's a great deal of evidence that the dendrites are crucial. In particular, it is thought that it's the dendrites that are responsible for a variety of inhibitory inputs, including local dendritic inhibition, and that the dendritic spinoes and axons themselves are important in activating the local inhibitory potential.'

Dr. M:'Well, first, in terms of the central pattern generating networks, the main function of the inhibition is to generate the inhibitory components of the central pattern, so they can get out of the bursting cell group and release neurotransmitter to other cells. So, the important thing to think about is the importance of inhibition to allow a small neural circuit to work, and so that the inhibitory component of the central pattern generation becomes an important aspect of the central pattern generator.'
Dr. B:'I'm sorry. Did you just say something? Sorry. I wasn't listening.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'What is the difference between a single neuron, which can produce only an action potential, and the central pattern generator which is a set of neurons that produce the inhibitory neurotransmitter?'
Dr. M:'They are the same thing, so there are a couple of different components of the brain that have a function of producing this inhibitory effect that we see in this set of neurons.'
Dr. B:'And the importance of inhibition is that it allows a neural circuit to work. What is the importance of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, the importance of the inhibitory component is that it is the inhibition, or the inhibition, or a function of inhibition, that allows a circuit to work, to work. The function of inhibition is to allow a circuit to work.'
Dr. B:'So, what is the function of excitatory neurons? Are they also central pattern generators or pattern generators?'

Dr. M:'They are not central pattern generators. They are not pattern generators. So, they have functions that are similar to the functions of central pattern generators, because their excitatory components have the function to bring in current, to drive an action potential. So, they are, they can drive action potentials, but they don't have the central pattern generating function.'

Dr. B:'Do these inhibitory functions have important functions? Or are they there just so we have a framework for thinking about the central pattern generator, which, of course, has to be much more central and more elaborate than just excitatory? Do they have important functions? Do they have a function? Are they there just so they have a framework for how we think about the central pattern generating network?'
Dr. M:'Oh, they have, of course, they are central pattern generators, but their excitatory component is not central pattern generating.'

Dr. B:'Are they excitatory pattern generators, or pattern generators, because they also release neurotransmitter to their target neurons? Are they similar to interneurons? Do they have similar effects? Are they similar? Do they have identical effects, similar to, uh, the central pattern generators, interneurons, because of the inhibitory effects they exert? Are they similar because of the inhibitative effects they exert?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons, it is not clear that they perform a very specific function. They do release substances, but I think they probably just increase the release of those substances by the neuron that is receiving the inhibitory signal. I do believe they are important because they control the release of substances by the neurons that they are inhibiting, so they make them release more substances. But it is not clear if they are essential for the function that their circuit is performing.'
Dr. B:'How about excitatory cells? What is their function?'

Dr. M:'I am not sure that excitatory cells have been well studied. They produce an increased in the release of substances but it is not clear they are necessary for that increase. It is clear that excitatory neurons are important because it is very difficult to understand how neural activity is generated in response to neuromodulatory inputs.'

Dr. M:'I guess it is similar, but I think excitatory cells are very important because they have to provide the excitation to stimulate some cell, and some of the cells that they excite do respond to excitation, so it is important that excitatory cells respond to their excitation.'

Dr. B:'What is the function or role of neuromodulatory cells? Are they essential for the function of inhibitary or excitatory neurons? What is their role in the circuit? Are they responsible for, for example, controlling the release of substances from inhibitory or excitatory cells, or are they not important for this? Are they, for example, essential for the circuit that inhibitory neurons are doing? What is their importance in this circuit?'

Dr. M:'So in this sense, you have to keep in mind that neural circuits are not just made up of neurons with different kinds of intrinsic properties. There are neurons that have intrinsic excitability, neurons that have intrinsic inhibitory capacity. There are neurons with intrinsic excitability that are not electrically coupled and that have no interaction with the other cells. There are neurons, like neurons, that are intrinsically inhibited, and therefore require inhibitory cells to provide inhibitory drive to them.'
Dr. B:'Is it important that inhibitory and excitatory neurons receive different types of information, or is that just the way the brain is organized?'

Dr. B:'What is the function that their neurons perform? There is not a very good definition of what their circuit does. It's not clear what they are for. I don't have a good answer, but it seems to me it is a very important question. I have no idea.'

Dr. M:'You know, I have a very similar comment, although in a different domain. It is not clear what these neurons do because you don't know if they're there to regulate the release of transmitters or if they just increase the release or the level of release of the transmitters that they're regulating. It is not very clear.'

Dr. M:'Well, if you go back to the earliest studies, it seems to me that they were trying to find neurons with activity that matched what they saw in the intact animal. So, in the case of the STG, for example, the pyloric circuit, we were able to study the pyloric network, the network, or the network that produces pyloric rhythms, and we studied the stomatogastric ganglion, which produces the pyloric rhythms.'

Dr. B:'If we find a network that produces a particular rhythmic output in a particular form, we find that network and study it, right? So we can say that there is a network that produces oscillation or a network that produces the pylotic rhythm or whatever it is, but the point is to say what kind of function the network does.'

Dr. B:'So, I don't understand how the inhibitory neurons in the STG control the output of that network. I don't know how they are integrated or if they are integrated by some neurons in the network. If you go back to studies from the beginning of the 20th century, it seems to be that they were trying mainly to find neurons that had rhythmic activity that matched what those were trying to match, but that's not a very good answer. I don't understand.'
Dr. M:'So, it might be the only answer that we have is to say, it was to try to find neurons with similar activity.'

Dr. B:'It's not clear how the inhibitory neuron in the STG will integrate with these other inhibitory neurons that surround the STG. It's not how they are integrated into a circuit. And, we didn't really know how much they are integrated into the network. We know that they are there, but we don't know how important they are. So, that's a very important point.'

Dr. M:'Well, you see, you have to know the function of the circuit that you are trying to understand. Because it's easy to see a single neuron and say it's either going to be up or down, but not how is this neuron going to respond to perturbations? And we really don't know, until we understand that circuit how this cell will behave.'

Dr. B:'How it is going to respond? If I am going to use this as a metaphor, this is the neuron that is sending an inhibitory message to the neuron that is going to send a spike. We don't know what its circuit will do in response to a perturbation. What we have to know is how the circuit will behave. If you look at the function of inhibitons in the hippocampus, and they work with inhibition and excitation, this is what they do.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that excitatory neurons have?'

Dr. M:'It is not clear if excitatory neurons are essential for the generation of oscillation. I think excitatory neurons do play some role, because neurons can receive excitatory inputs, and if these inputs are removed, it can be extremely difficult to produce a rhythmic pattern of activity in the neural circuit.'
Dr. B:'How many types of inhibitory neurons are there? How many inhibitory types can there be? Can we say with certainty that one will turn out to be essential for the function of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Yes, the brain is very robust to changes in the synaptic network. We have seen that if we knock out the dopamine receptor and all of a sudden we have an extreme phenotype in which people become vegetative or die. If we add dopamine we can recover some kind of homeostatic control of the system. We have seen the same thing with serotonin.'
Dr. B:'Is it safe to say that if a single neuron is stimulated at random, what happens in the network?'
Dr. M:'They are there because of synaptic connectivity, because neurons can be inhibited by the other neurons in their circuit.'
Dr. B:'And if you take the whole network, the inhibition provides stability so that the network can be modified by inputs, and this is how networks are built in biology.'
Dr. M:'Exactly.'

Dr. B:'But this is not what we want. The reason for this is that there is no need for inhibitory neurons when there is no need to build a circuit. I want to build a circuit so that you can use inhibition as a tool to build a circuit.'
Dr. M:'Exactly. So they are really a kind of a regulator of neuronal connectivity and the way that circuits are generated in biology.'

Dr. M:'And that's also why we think of the nervous system as being extremely sensitive to neuromodulators. For example, if you put the neuromodulatory systems onto a noninhibiting neuron, you might get something that looks like it's very sensitive to neuromarkers, but it's not actually sensitive to neuromuscular stimulation because the neuron will go to the ground before it reacts to the neuromodulation.'
Dr. M:'We can modify networks to meet our needs, if we modify the inputs that our network is receiving.'
Dr. B:'In other words, the function of the inhibitory system is to serve the function of the principal cells that are embedded in it.'
Dr. M:'Yes, to keep the activity, to keep the cells in a particular configuration, so that the network has the appropriate function.'

Dr. B:'You have to understand that the principal cells in the network, and this is the same for every known biological function of neurons, are embedded in inhibitory activity. In every layer of the brain, and at every synaptic level, inhibition has a special function, but this function depends on the principal cells' input and output patterns.'
Dr. M:'They function to inhibit oscillatory neurons that fire at the wrong phase of a circuit.'
Dr. B:'Exactly.'
Dr. M:'I mean, how do we function if the neurons that we use as inhibitory neurons are firing at the wrong phase? Or the wrong rhythm?'

Dr. B:'Right, the reason why you're asking this question is because you're interested in how inhibition and interneurons interact in the context of brain rhythms. In fact, one of the oldest, oldest, oldest questions of neuroscience has been "What function do inhibitory cells perform?" And we have different answers depending on what part of the brain we are talking about.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, and if we're talking about central pattern-generating systems, as we have been, we would say that they serve to stabilize the frequencies of neural oscillators. But if we're talking peripheral pattern generating systems, we would say they have a role in providing a fixed frequency to the pacemaker system. Or if we're talking brain regions, we would say it's essential for maintaining a functional circuit, and if you're talking about synapses, we would say synaptic integration.'
Dr. B:'So it seems that the function is what we need to know the function for, right, and the answer to your question is in understanding the mechanisms that make those functions possible, right?'
Dr. B:'Is there an example? What would be an example for the wrong phase?'
Dr. M:'Like, in a pacemaker that fires at the wrong phase, that might not be a function.'
Dr. B:'How would you test for this? If you have a brain pacemaker that fires randomly, what would be the effect of inhibition of those cells?'
Dr. M:'You'd test for this by injecting some inhibitory substance and measuring the effect that inhibition has on these other oscillators.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons have been known since the beginning of neuroscience. They are the key players of the inhibitory circuit and have been described in everything from the brainstem to the cerebellum.'
Dr. M:'You have described them in the brainstem, yes, in the brainstem they are the key players.'

Dr. B:'I am not a neuroscientist, but even as a non-neuroscientist, it is clear how they do that: they suppress the activity of oscillatory neurons. This is what they do. Now in the cerebellum, where there are only neurons that have oscillations, those neurons are the key players in the inhibitory circuit.'

Dr. M:'When we think about synaptic inhibition, that is a kind of passive function of the neuron, and it is a way of changing behavior. So, for example, synaptic inhibition can prevent the firing of neurons during a critical period of activity, during the gastric mill rhythm, when it's important to have a gastric mill rhythm.'

Dr. B:'These functions were discovered in the hippocamal nucleus, the first neurophysiological research lab in the United States. It was a place that many people thought was the seat of the cerebral cortex but the hippocampus, because of the prominent oscillations that were there, because it was such an important rhythm. It was there that the first descriptions of interneurons were made.'
Dr. M:'Well, that is the case. That is right.'
Dr. M:'But these interneuron populations were not well studied until much later.'

Dr. B:'The first studies were done by the Hungarian scientist, Endre Grastyn. He was the first to record from the hippocampal interneurons in the anesthetized cat and studied their activity during sleep, immobility, or slow-wave sleep. What I've always wondered about is how he could tell the interneurons from the principal cells.'
Dr. B:'But they also function to regulate timing of oscillations in the network, as is observed in the thalamocortical system.'

Dr. M:'I mean, you know, you can think of them like, you can think about the neurotransmitters, which are inhibitory, and that function is to inhibit firing. That's the role that they play. I mean, their activity is to stop firing. They don't fire when it's appropriate, and I've never seen any evidence that they really can, um, fire when they are needed.'

Dr. B:'Do they really? I mean, I don't think that we have, uh, good evidence that they can fire, but, uh, the mechanism is really, you know, there are a lot of experiments. We have good evidence that inhibitory cells can communicate with the principal cells. That's, uh, one of the many functions. In fact, there are, there are many studies that suggest that inhibition is one of the key factors in the generation of different brain rhythms and functions.'
Dr. M:'It is.'

Dr. B:'Can we find out what these neurons really do? Do we know what they do? I mean, do we know how they, uh, stop the action potentials? Do we know how they affect synaptic strength? Do we know the physiological mechanisms? What are these? We have some evidence that inhibitory neurons in fact can affect the synaptic strength and function of principal cells. We have some evidence, but, but we don't have good evidence.'
Dr. M:'But why would they even be there, if you have to inhibit other neurons to, to produce different behaviors?'

Dr. M:'We're not trying to figure out whether they're inhibitory, whether they're excitatory, or what they're doing. We're trying to understand how neurons work and how their electrical properties are controlled, how their synaptic and intrinsic properties are controlled.'
Dr. B:'We are interested in how synaptic input affects firing patterns of neurons. What would be the ideal synaptic input? What would be the optimal firing pattern of a cortical pyramidal cell?'
Dr. M:'Well, inhibitory neurons are those neurons that control other neurons, other cells.'
Dr. B:'Where is the inhibition coming from? How are they controlled?'
Dr. M:'They can be controlled by a single cell, or by multiple cells.'
Dr. B:'Are the inhibition signals from the same cell, or are they independent of each other?'
Dr. M:'Each one has a distinct function.'

Dr. B:'How do they interact with each other in time? Is there a temporal order in which these cells are activated? Are there cell types with different temporal relationships to each other? How are they embedded in the circuitry?'

Dr. M:'I'll tell you the function of an inhibitory neuron is to turn off the network that is going to be activated by it and you won't activate the network, and you won't excite other network elements. So, if you want to build an oscillator, and if you want to produce oscillations, you don't want excitable cells because you're going to excite other cells. So, the function of inhibitions is to turn off networks.'
Dr. B:'What are the functions of inhibitory neurons in the brain? For example, what are the roles of GABAergic inhibitory neurons in cortical circuits? And in brain rhythms?'
Dr. M:'When you study the nervous system, inhibitory neurons are a huge puzzle to us because they have to do so much more than excite neurons.'
Dr. B:'Can you tell us a little bit about that, please?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think that that would be fair, I don't even know how many of them there are in the crab, it might be 20 to 25 or 30 or something like that, we know that there are at least four to five of them in the crab and some of them seem to be in the same network.'
Dr. B:'Okay, that's what I was asking. What's the function of inhibitry neurons? And how big is that network?'
Dr. M:'This network is enormous, it's huge, it's probably three, four, five, six times bigger than the entire nervous system, and it consists of a lot of different components.'
Dr. B:'And inhibitory neurons are very important in that?'

Dr. M:'Yeah. I mean, it is a massive network and neurons from different groups are co-transmitted to some degree, so you know, inhibitory neurons release a lot of different transmitters, and one is probably important and one is probably not important.'
Dr. B:'I'm interested in the wiring system, how does a neuron connect to the next neuron?'

Dr. M:'And then the next neuron connects to the next neuron and then the next neuron and this kind of goes on all the way down the nervous system, I mean if you look at a neuron and you look at the different kinds of synapses that are going on it's not just one neuron but many different neurons are being influenced and we know that neurons that connect in the same network can interact with each other and that neurons that connect to different networks can interact with each another.'
Dr. B:'How many neurons are there in the brain, do we know?'

Dr. B:'Why is it important for inhibitory cells to do more than excite principal cells? What is the most important thing they do? I don't want to talk about my own research for too long so I'll ask my question first, and then you can address it.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So we do not know the function of inhibition. We know that it can be the maintenance of synchrony, it can be the modulation of excitability, it can be a synaptic inhibition and it can be intrinsic inhibition.'
Dr. B:'The function of the inhibition should be known?'

Dr. M:'There are a lot of ways that these neurons may contribute to an overall function, and many of the experiments that we do depend on inhibitory synapses to some extent, and therefore it is a hard problem to solve.'
Dr. B:'Is there a big gap between the computational problems that inhibitory neurons have to address, and the understanding of how they actually do that? What is that gap?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that gap is enormous.'
Dr. B:'I would like to hear about it in your view.'

Dr. M:'Sure, well there's a lot to say on it. We're still learning how the brain works. We're still very much learning how different types of neurons work and how their connections and how different neuronal networks function, and so, it's not something we've cracked, but we're working on it, and it's part of neuroscience as we're working on developing new tools, experimental tools, and tools to study the brain.'

Dr. B:'And what are the most important problems to be addressed? Is there some list of things that would most need to be addressed? What would the ideal situation be? What is that ideal? What do you think?'

Dr. B:'So what we're trying to understand is how the neurons of the hippocampus, or any other structure, function as a network. So that is the thing, and what is the gap between the problem and the solution?'

Dr. B:'But there are many things to learn, and many people to talk about that gap and work towards a solution. What should be the top priorities, and what should be the top priority, and what can we accomplish in a few years? What are the top priorities? Can you tell us about those priorities? In other words, what do you need to learn? What do you need to understand? In other words what are the top priorities for neuroscientists?'
Dr. M:'Oh, the top priority is understanding how neurons and circuits do the things that they do, how they interact to produce behavior, how they interact with each other to produce behavior.'
Dr. B:'Okay. That is what we are talking about here, right? In other words the top priority is to understand how cells do the things that cells do. What do they do? What does that mean?'

Dr. M:'Well, it means understanding all the aspects of cell physiology, because the different neurons and their circuits are regulated by different sets of parameters, and you have to know how they are regulated, because it turns out that they are regulated by different combinations of modulators. So one of the things that has come up is there's been more focus on this side of things than the other side of things, which is the side of the biology where we are doing experiments to find new ways to monitor cellular physiology.'

Dr. B:'Now, the thing to be understood is how the things in the brain are organized, and how they interact with one another. This is a very complicated topic, and one that requires a combination of computational methods and experimental techniques to really understand. Can you give an example of an interesting thing to be explained or explained? Let's say, if I want to understand how neurons and circuits interact, then the first thing that I have to learn is how neurons and circuits are organized.'

Dr. M:'OK, neurons and circuits are distributed across the animal. It is the task of the biologists who study animals to find out how distributed they are, and that's the first thing that they have to do is find out how they're distributed, find out the number of neurons or circuit elements that they have. Find out how their circuits are organized. Find out how they're structured, and what their properties are. Do you want to know how their circuits are structured?'

Dr. B:'Yes, that's what we call the connectivity. It's a set of relations that binds one to the next. A set of relations that connects one to the next is the thing to be explained. Now, the first thing to be understood in neurobiology is how neurons and circuit elements are organized, and what their physical properties are. And this is a complicated topic.'
Dr. M:'And how does that change over time as the animal grows, as they are active, as they are developing, as they're growing, as they're getting older, as they age?'

Dr. M:'I think there are a lot of gaps and we're only beginning to address that. We really only started trying to understand the computational problems that these neurons have to address when we started thinking about these problems in the context of a more general problem of understanding the role of inhibition in the nervous system and the brain. So this is only relatively recently that we started to think about what might be the function of the inhibition.'

Dr. B:'So the inhibition is a general problem, which is the problem of how to control the output neurons, or inhibitory neurons. And as a general problem, it is actually much easier to think about that than the specific computational problems that these specific neurons have to face. We may not have to consider every single neuron, but for a neuron, it may seem to be more practical to figure out how to activate it in a particular way rather than in another way, depending on the goal of the network.'

Dr. M:'To inhibit the voltage of other neurons that are electrically coupled to them. It's like in the cardiac system; the cardiac ganglion neurons are all electrically coupled, and one of the ganglia neurons inhibits all of the other cells, which are electrically coupled. So, for all the oscillators in the cardiac ganglions to behave appropriately, the inhibition needs to be delivered. It also enables the oscillator to control other oscillators that are electrically connected.'
Dr. B:'What are some of the consequences of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'The most important one is that the inhibition can be quite long-lived. In the cardiac system, for example, the cardiac ganglionic neurons can fire for hundreds of milliseconds, so they need to be inhibited as long as the system is active, and they are firing.'
Dr. B:'How long is long inhibition?'
Dr. B:'Are there some things that inhibitory neurons do that aren't being considered enough? What are some of those things that inhibitory cells do that we're not considering?'
Dr. B:'How can an inhibitory neuron communicate with other inhibitory cells? I mean, let's say in a small group. What would the neuronal code be? What should be the synaptic strengths?'

Dr. M:'It would be different for different groups of neurons, because every neuron will have different kinds of ion channel types. But a general principle, is that the synaptic strengths should be asymmetrical, and that the inhibition should be the stronger one.'

Dr. B:'I'm trying to put in a few more words in here, but, uh, I'm struggling with the concept of this inhibition. I'm just not understanding what inhibition actually is, uh, and what is this inhibition? How are you suppressing something? And then this inhibition needs to have its impact, and in a small group of neurons, and so on.'
Dr. M:'So it's a bit like a control center for the system, a kind of a coordinator between the electrical and chemical components of the network, because they all feed back to the same oscillator.'

Dr. M:'I think they're part of a network of network neurons that's involved in the timing of various brain rhythms and is therefore functionally important. But as far as how they are used as a regulatory mechanism, that's just something that needs to be studied. I think it is important that they be studied. But it is also important to study the network as a whole. So there is no one set of rules, it's very complex.'
Dr. B:'How important is it to understand how inhibitory neurons work? What is their function? What is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's difficult to answer that question because it depends on the type of neuron. I mean, there are neurons that are inhibitory, neurons that release substances and so forth. There are neurons that have very little inhibitory action. But it's also the case that you know neurons that do different things with inhibition, depending on the network in which they're participating. So we're going to have to look at each neuron, each circuit as a separate entity.'

Dr. M:'This is a good question because there are some neurons that play an inhibitory role in a neural circuit, but they don't have any particular intrinsic electrophysiological property, such as being depolarized, but the function of these neurons is to inhibit other neurons in the circuit because they are in a different neuron group.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of the various inhibitory neurons in controlling the excitability and oscillation properties of principal cells?'

Dr. M:'The important role of inhibitory neurons in control of the excitability of their targets is probably the most general one. The neurons that inhibit and activate the principal cells are probably the first to interact with the other neurons and neurons in the circuit and to determine what the excitability properties are. Because the neuron that has the most direct interaction with the other neurons in the network has the greatest influence on the properties of the network.'

Dr. B:'Is there any particular neuron type that is the best suited to this job? In other words, what makes this neuron a special inhibitory partner? Why is it the best? What are its advantages? What are its disadvantages? Does this neuron have special wiring or special biophysical properties? What is its role? What is it's contribution? In short, what is it's function?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are probably as many possible answers to this question as there are different neurons, each with different sets of properties. I think the important point is that neurons need to inhibit other neurons. In some animals, the neurons that inhibit the principal neurons are probably identical, because they can inhibit other neurons at the same time. In some animals the neurons that are most likely to be involved in inhibition of the principal neurons are neurons with different properties.'

Dr. B:'This is the case in the hippocampus. The inhibitory neurons, such as basket cells and chandelier cells, are also inhibitory of other principal cells in the hippocampus. In the prefrontal cortex, different types of inhibitory neurons are involved in different functions, and they may be different in the prefrontal cortex. There is a special type of inhibition of the principal cells in the cortex, which is inhibition of inhibition. This is the case of inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. M:'The key to understanding how networks of neurons can produce behavior is to understand how neurons with similar characteristics can behave in a different way, and in particular the difference between inhibitory neurons and inhibitory neurons. To get a sense of the role of the different neuron types, we have now a number of neurons with very similar phenotypes that we study in our laboratory and others, but have very different underlying electrophysiological properties.'
Dr. B:'How many different neuron types can be identified in the mammalian brain? In other words, how many cell types do we have?'

Dr. M:'In the general brain, there are three or four neuron types that are likely to be present, including the pacemaker cells that we study, but there are likely to be many different cell types that are present in a brain region, and this could be more or less than four. So this is a very active area of study. One thing that is going on right now is that we have begun to study the cell-type variability in both invertebrates and mammals.'

Dr. B:'Do we know for sure what makes up a neuronal circuit? And do we have a list of neuron types that we can study? If so, what are some of those neurons? What are the key neuron types that are present? What is the main function of these neurons? What is the difference between excitatory and inhibitory neurons? What is their primary wiring? What is the role of these various neurotransmitters and neurotransmitters in the various cell types?'

Dr. M:'You're asking, 'What are the roles of the different neuron populations?' And so this is a central theme that we have been studying over the past decade. When you look back in the early '90s, we were interested in how the brain would be reconfigured in response to neuromodulators and substances, and this was a very active area for us.'

Dr. B:'Now, what do we know about how brain circuits are formed, and what are their primary functions? What would you say are the most important cell types? What are the important wiring? What is their role? What is the contribution of these various neurotransmittters and neurotransmitter systems in the various neuron types?'
Dr. M:'I'm a little hesitant to jump too far back.'

Dr. B:'Then the question is, how many different neuron types have been identified? And the answer is that we don't know. But we can be more specific. We have been trying to answer these questions for the past several years. I'm just asking you what are the neuron types? What is the key neuron types? What are the main functions? What are the roles of these various neurotrans transmitters and neurotransmitter? What are the role of inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. B:'If there is no difference, why do we have so many different inhibitory neuron types? And what is the advantage of having so many inhibitory neurons in the brain? Is it simply so that when some excitatory neurons fire, the inhibition that they produce is much weaker than when there is only one type of inhibitory cell?'

Dr. M:'That is a very good question, and it is one that we have been looking at. So what you are looking at is how the brain can be flexible. So for example, we had a study a few years ago that showed that there are neurons that change in function as a consequence of aging, as a consequence of changes in activity, and other changes, and we don't really understand the mechanisms by which neurons can change in this way.'

Dr. B:'And what would be the advantage of neurons that change their firing patterns? What function would that serve? How would that be useful? So, what you are asking is that why there are so many different types of interneurons? Well, we have been discussing that issue recently.'

Dr. M:'So, the excitability properties are controlled by the intrinsic properties of the neurons, of course, but there is a number of inhibitory factors that come from the extrinsic network to the neuron and the neuron has a number of membrane conductances that influence the activity of the neuron and the strength of the synapse and the amplitude of the slow wave oscillation.'
Dr. M:'I don't know yet, but my work on the nervous system shows that they must have a function.'
Dr. B:'How is that? Are inhibitory neurons connected to the nervous system?'

Dr. M:'No, they are not connected to the nervous systems. But we know that the nervous systems are very modulatory and that they can change their responses to neuromodulators, and the inhibitory neurons are the target for these neuromodulators.'

Dr. B:'What are some of the neurochemicals that have some impact on the function of inhibitories? If you know the names of these neurochemicals and their mechanism that they have, would you be able to tell us what that is?'

Dr. M:'Well, my work on neural development shows that the inhibition that comes with development is very different from the inhibition that comes at maturity, when the nervous system has reached its mature strength, so that the inhibition has a different mechanism.'
Dr. B:'What are the most important functions of neuromodulators? Is it about sleep? Is it about learning? Is it about movement? What about brain rhythms? Do they play a major role in brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Well, yes, they do play a major role. So I think that the neuromodulators in the brain have been studied enough in the past, and we know that they can produce sleep, so that has been studied. And we know that some neuromodulators can cause changes in learning, and that some can cause changes in movement. And we know in the nervous system that neurons can be activated in different ways and can behave in different ways.'

Dr. B:'And that is why it's important to understand the brain rhythms. That is why it's very important to understand how these neuromodulatory cells interact with these brain rhythms, but that's what you mean by the question that has a particular reference to the brain rhythms, that's why it's important? Is it about memory? Is it about planning? Is it about emotion? What about imagination? What about creativity? What about sleep?'
Dr. M:'Sleep? All of those! All of those. All of those.'

Dr. M:'So, these are all important aspects of the brain, and I think, so, you know, when you are doing neuroscience you are trying to understand how the brain works in all of these different domains. And I think the fact that some of these are very difficult to study, especially when you have to study brain circuits or you have to study neurons in isolation, right?'

Dr. B:'Is there something that we have to look forward to when we have to use the methods that you just mentioned? Like, is there something that you're really looking forward to? And so on and so on, or are you looking forward to anything in particular that you would like to research? What I mean is, if you just told us a little bit about what you'd like to study, and what you're looking forward to, or, you know, anything, we're all very curious.'
Dr. B:'Let me ask you a question. What is the function of the neuron in the hippocampus?'
Dr. M:'It is a pacemaker neuron.'
Dr. B:'And where are the principal neurons?'
Dr. M:'Principal neurons are in the stomach, so that is a muscle of the stomach.'
Dr. B:'Where are the principal neurons that provide a feed-back loop to the pyramidal cell?'
Dr. M:'They are in the small intestine.'
Dr. M:'the pyloric network must have a function, but the function must be so well hidden that we do not know it'.'
Dr. B:'But why should we be interested in inhibitory neurons? What function can they do? How can they assist in solving the problem of how the brain is organized?'
Dr. M:'So my work shows that inhibitory neurons play a role in creating circuit dynamics that can help to solve that problem.'
Dr. B:'How do they do that? What kind of mechanisms are involved?'
Dr. M:'Well, that's an interesting question because it's one of the areas that we want to work on.'

Dr. M:'There are two functions of inhibitory neurons. One is that the inhibitory neurons that we've studied in previous work with pacemaker neurons, that have been studied by many people, their function is to inhibit, to activate other networks. So, we've shown that inhibitory neurons have this important function. But the second function is this synaptic inhibition. So, the neurons that we've looked at that have their inhibitory inputs are these inhibitory neurons that are responsible for synaptic inhibition.'
Dr. B:'Why did you choose to study these inhibitory neurons, and how have you looked at them in the past?'

Dr. M:'Well, this is a tough question because we don't really know, and there are models that have been built. For example, the pyloric rhythm in the brain is a pacemaker in the pacemaker neurons, and the pacemaker neurons inhibit other pacemaker neurons, thus creating rhythmic pyloric activity in the pyloric network. And the pacemaker neurons also inhibit neurons that control other muscles that are used in chewing or eating food.'
Dr. B:'But, how does it end?'
Dr. B:'And what about the activity of interneurons? Are they just a kind of noise that the brain can overcome, or are they critical for the stability of other rhythms?'

Dr. M:'They are important for the stability of all the rhythms, actually, because they create all the feedback circuits, you know, for example, when an invertebrate muscle contracts, it also contracts other muscles around it, and thus the contraction and the feedback can be monitored. And they're also important for generating all kinds of electrical and chemical responses in the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'Well, what are some of the other functions they play in the brain? Do we know the physiological functions that they perform? Or are we only just assuming what they're doing, based on the evidence we have? And we use the term, 'noise,' is that correct? So the term that we use, noise, is that a fair assessment of the evidence we have?'

Dr. M:'No, it's not fair to say that, because these neurons are very important for maintaining all the rhythms. So in that sense, you know, they do have to function. We don't really know what they're doing most of the time, but we know that they're very important for keeping everything intact.'

Dr. B:'Do we know that what we're trying to maintain is critical for brain performance? Do we know what the critical function is? And how does the brain control these functions? Or are we just assuming what the function is without actually looking at the evidence and seeing what happens when we remove the noise? And how does it look? What does it look like? What are the things we have to look at? And how does that affect brain performance?'

Dr. M:'Well, I mean, for example, one of the things we have seen is that many invertebrate circuits, even with neurons that have very different frequencies, they still produce a very consistent behavioral output that is very important for the ability of the animals to navigate through their environments. So even in this case, we know that these neurons are important for maintaining neural circuit stability in behavior.'

Dr. B:'And do we know how they affect behavior? So this is a question that you're also asking about is that this is the question you would like to have answered? And how does this work? What is the role of these neurons and how are they controlled? What is the function of these neurons? And how do we know that these are not just some neurons whose sole function is to keep the brain alive and stable? So how do we know?'
Dr. M:'I think you've heard, you've heard many, many studies that show that the brain is dynamic, that it can be rewired.'
Dr. M:' Inhibition is not just inhibitory, but has a very specific and unique role to play in many neuronal networks.'
Dr. B:' What is it? What is the function?'

Dr. M:' It's a function to inhibit other oscillators. They're not all alike. It's not a global function, like a pacemaker. It's not meant to inhibit every other oscillator, but it's meant to be inhibited by one particular oscillator. It has to be inhibited by the same oscillator.'

Dr. M:' One of the things that you learn in biology is that each neuron type has a very unique set of intrinsic properties, that may be different from other neurons. The same neuron type may have different intrinsic properties in different animals. The same neuron might be different between two different animals of the same type, and the same neuron may have different intrinsic property in different animals.'
Dr. B:' How does this differ from other networks?'
Dr. M:' What is the unique role?'

Dr. B:' So there are two different forms of inhibition, a form that you could call as the 'feedback loop' inhibition and another type called 'feedforward inhibition', which has two distinct roles in neuronal networks. The feedforward type of inhibition is critical for the generation of oscillations. It is a special kind of inhibition that is often referred to as the perisomatic type of inhibition. The function of perisomatic inhibition is to reduce the output spiking activity of the neurons.'
Dr. B:' What is the unique contribution of inhibition?'
Dr. M:' To inhibit, you need to have a set of neurons that are inhibitory neurons and to have a mechanism to inhibit the rest of the network by which you are influenced.'
Dr. B:' In addition to neurons and their activity, what other ingredients do you have in a circuit? Can you name three items that can form a circuit?'
Dr. M:' Circuits have many components, including neuromodulators, neurohormones, hormones, growth factors, cytokines, chemokines, and the rest of it.'
Dr. B:' Inhibition is a fundamental mechanism in all mammalian cortical circuits.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons, it's a really good question. Inhibitory neurons play an important role in suppressing and regulating different kinds of neural networks. And you see it in many different kinds of nervous systems, and then, it's also true in invertebrates, in mice, and also it's been shown in, you know, in rats, as well as in primates as well.'
Dr. B:'Now, in the brain, where do inhibitory neurons act?'
Dr. B:'I'd be happy to see how this is done in the brain, in a simple brain circuit.'

Dr. M:'We have many, many different neurons and we have many, many neurons that are inhibitory neurons. We have neurons that are inhibitatory neurons. The one you're familiar with is the inhibitory neuron that produces the pacemaker potential. And you know, and then we have inhibitory neurons that do not participate in the pacemaker potential, but that are there because there is a circuit that requires them to be inhibitory to certain neurons, and also inhibitory to some neurons.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory cells have been a central part of the brain for a long time. For example, inhibition was already present in the brain when mammals were still in the egg, when the embryos were only a tadpole shape. And then in the spinal cord of fish larvae, and so on, there are very large numbers of inhibitory neurons. The first inhibitory neuron in the neocortex of rodents was discovered in the 1920s by Ramn y Cajal in Barcelona, Spain.'

Dr. M:'Well, one is that they can provide inhibitory feedback to the central oscillator neurons to maintain the timing of the cycle, for example. So, one of the most exciting things is to watch the effects of manipulating neurons because one always thinks about neurons, they're always just the first neurons that come to mind, but the amazing thing about neurons is the interactions that they have with other neurons, with other circuits and their effects are also really fascinating'.'

Dr. B:'I'm looking for a mechanism, a physiological explanation that might explain this mechanism of inhibition or its effects in the brain, but so far there are really just a couple of interesting examples of neurons that are inhibited by certain chemical substances.'

Dr. M:'You know, one example is dopamine is inhibited by dopamine neuron ( DAN ) because dopamine neuron can take up dopamine by action potentials. And in response to that inhibition, dopamine neuron can then release it back into the synaptic space.'
Dr. B:'There's one example, but in my research, I'm looking for mechanisms of inhibitory effects in the brain.'

Dr. M:'But I'm thinking, well, you know, it's important to understand that neurons are not the only targets for neuromodulatory activity. Neurons are targets for neurohormones from other neurons, from neurohormonal peptides, from hormonal substances, from other neurons, it's neurons in the neurohormone family.'

Dr. B:'It would be a good idea to list some of those. So in our case, I would be willing to go on to any level of inhibition, from the single inhibitory neuron, the network of inhibitory neurons, the circuit of inhibitory neurons. But, what would be the appropriate level of inhibition? Do we know that? Is there some sort of classification?'

Dr. M:'So, my current understanding of the function of inhibit neurons, because I've thought about the function of inhibitors and when I was at school in France, the teacher always said, we should always remember that there are three different kinds of neurons. One is the hyperpolarizing, hyperpolarizing neurons. The other two are depolarizing neurons, that have the opposite properties to the hyperpolarization.'
Dr. M:'Well, if we look at these inhibitory neurons, they play a role in setting the membrane potential of the targets that they activate to hyperpolarize.'
Dr. B:'Okay. So if a target of an interneuron is excited, it would hyperpolarize that target?'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'And then that would be one example where that target would be inhibited.'

Dr. M:'Right. And the other role of an inhibitory neuron would be to allow targets to hyperpolarate more quickly than they would if it were excitable targets that would continuously excite. So in a sense it's a function of a neuron to hyperpolarizate targets as quickly as possible.'
Dr. M:'Right, so these are two different roles for inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'That is my definition. That is my definition of the function of interneurons in the brain. The role of the inhibitory neurons is to keep the principal cells in the brain's optimal operating range, which, as I mentioned, is the target membrane potential at the soma of principal cells. And they are also responsible for the maintenance of the excitability of their principal cells. They do a good job at that.'
Dr. M:'Yes. If a target of an inhibition neuron is excitable and if the inhibitory neuron has multiple inputs, then it would hyperpoltarize the multiple targets that it could activate.'

Dr. B:'Can we put these questions into context? The context being that when these questions were first being asked, the target cell populations were already excited. What is the goal of the inhibition? What is the function of inhibition? In a very early work of yours, you discussed a few things. The first of which was the role of interneurons and their role in setting the target membrane potentials of target pyramidal cells.'
Dr. M:'That's right.'

Dr. B:'The second of those things you discussed was that inhibition is a way of controlling or limiting the activity of target neurons at the right time in the right manner. The third one, and I think the most important one, is that the effect of interneuronal activity depends on the dynamic properties of the target neuron. In particular, the interneuron's input-output relation, as well as its excitatory-inhibitory balance. The goal of the inhibition is to achieve something.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'All right. And now we have some information on inhibition, it's a fundamental player in circuit functioning. So what is the mechanism by which an inhibitory neuron can hyperpolarize its target?'

Dr. M:'Ah, well, we now have some work on the mechanism by which inhibition can hyperpolarise its targets, and it turns out that this is due to the action of some very unusual and interesting transmitter, a transmitter called the inhibitory transmitter.'

Dr. B:'This inhibitory transmitter allows its target to be hyperpolarised, but the effect, the effect of this transmitter, this inhibitory neurotransmitter is not well understood. And it is very hard to identify and separate the effect of that inhibitory neurotransmitter from its network effects and physiological mechanisms, but if you just say, 'Well, what is the mechanism? How would this inhibitory transmitter actually do it?'

Dr. M:'So the inhibitory transmitter turns out to be a chemical transmitter, it is produced by a distinct neuron from the STG, which is located in the  Panterus pacificus  (spiny lobster), as well as by some crustacean ganglia, the STG, and the olfactory neurons in the STG. And the STG is a ganglion at the base of the neuropil, which is responsible for controlling neuronal networks.'

Dr. B:'Now, it's a very unusual mechanism, in fact, but not so unusual that we can't say, well, it could be the same mechanism by which inhibition would hyperpolarise their target. Now we're talking about mechanisms, and it turns on to be a mechanism very similar to that which is responsible for generating gamma, a very high frequency oscillation, which is a major player in neural syntax.'
Dr. M:'Yes, yes, yes, so that when the next neuron that activates the interneuron starts firing, it will be a hyperpolarized neuron.'
Dr. B:'And what is the role of interneurons in that setting, and what is the role in that setting of the target neuron? Is it inhibitory? Is it inhibitoric? Is it inhibitoretic?'
Dr. M:'I think we just look at a neuron, we are saying the target is the neuron itself.'

Dr. M:'It depends, if the interneuron is activating it, it can be an inhibitory neuron, or it can be an inhibitor. So if it's an inhibitor, the target neuron is not going to fire. If it is an inhibitory neuron itself, it's going to be inhibited, or it's going to hyperpolarized. So the inhibitory interneurons are the ones that control the inhibition.'

Dr. B:'Right. And what if the activity of the targets is a periodic oscillation? It would be natural for inhibition to interfere with the activity of the target neurons and set them back to baseline. But there are other ways to inhibit neurons. The most widely used method is through neurotransmission. I'm not sure what you're working on in the inhibitory system. So maybe you could tell us more about your research.'

Dr. M:'So, I use the term 'inhibition' rather loosely. We usually don't inhibit an entire neuronal network or an entire neuronal circuit, we usually inhibit the activity of a small number of neurons. So if I say the network I'm working on has 10 neurons, the small networks with 10 or 20 neurons, and one of the neurons is going to be inhibited, and then it would set the membrane potential of that inhibited neuron back to baseline, so the inhibition would be removed.'
Dr. B:'So you're a very specific example of the term 'inhibitory neurons.' So let me ask the question differently. Are you the only class of inhibitory neuron that you work on?'

Dr. M:'No. I mean, there are numerous other classes of inhibition. So there are other classes of neurons that have been studied for their role as inhibitory neurons. But we typically focus on only one. You know, if we were to do a full model of the nervous system we would probably have 10-15 classes of inhibition that we would be able to look at. But we try to focus on only one.'
Dr. B:'But are you sure that you're working on the right class? Are you sure that you work on the right inhibitory neuron?'

Dr. M:'No, no, and most of the networks I've worked on are not so small. So when we were working on the stomatogastric circuit, we were working on a circuit that had dozens of neurons, maybe tens or even hundreds, and they're not all necessarily inhibitory. There was a small population of neurons that were inhibitory and a larger population that were not.'
Dr. B:'But in that network, when you were working on a small network, it's pretty much always in the inhibitory neuron system.'
Dr. B:'So in other words, you are inhibiting neurons that are in a rhythmic activity, but in a time-dependent manner.'

Dr. M:'That's correct. And in addition to inhibition, we do excitation also. The most important role that neurons play is excitation. And when we talk about rhythmic behavior, then it's important to know what that means.'

Dr. M:'Exactly, so there is a mechanism that allows this to be dynamically regulated. So, the dynamics of regulation of the frequency of activity is something you would not normally think of in a neuron, but the dynamics of regulation is a critical thing because neurons are oscillators and they have to work properly for any given task.'

Dr. B:'And, the mechanisms by which this is accomplished are not well understood, and it seems like an area where you and I might be able to find common ground. It is not as clear in inhibitory circuits as in excitatory circuits. It is not well understood how inhibitory neurons and interneurons are controlled in different ways. And so this is where you and I could possibly find a common ground. Do we have anything in common with regard to how these systems are controlled?'

Dr. M:'Okay. Yeah. Well, actually, the most important and interesting questions that we study is about inhibitory synaptic transmission, and about synaptic transmission in general, in small neuronal networks, but how synaptic transmission is regulated. So, we study a small network, it's a circuit of neurons, three neurons, and then they're part of a larger network.'

Dr. B:'I like small networks. They're simple enough to allow us to see how the components interact. So, in a circuit of five neurons, we can investigate how inhibitory postsynaptic potentials change the membrane potential of their targets. And these are two types of interneurons, the perisomatic and the dendrite-targeting interneurons.'

Dr. M:'Yes. So we have three inhibitory neurons, and then there's a fourth one, a large synaptic input, and so we study how the synaptic input is regulated, and how it modulates, and also how the individual synaptic inputs and then all the components in the circuit interact. So, I study the regulation of synaptic transmission.'

Dr. B:'Oh, yeah. And what's the goal of this research? What are you trying to understand? What are you hoping to learn? How do these components interact? How do they work? What are the important questions you're trying to answer?'
Dr. M:'We're trying to understand how neurons and small networks work. It's hard to say, you know, how much you know about how neurons and small network systems work.'

Dr. B:'So if the network is aperiodic, then inhibition would not have a much to do with it, in a way. So, what are the physiological mechanisms that allow the inhibition to affect the activity of these neurons? What is the role of inhibition in this network? How is the network set to hyperpolarized? So, this is the big question.'
Dr. M:'The big question is how synaptic transmission is modulated in networks.'

Dr. B:'What if inhibitory transmission is an oscillation. And what are the mechanisms that allow that? So, there are mechanisms, which is very important, and this is where the work is done. So it's very important to look at this in an experimentally way, or with experiments and try to work out the mechanisms. So that's the kind of thing we do in our laboratory. So we look at the mechanism of inhibition in small neuronal networks.'

Dr. B:'What is the contribution of gamma frequency activity to hippocampal inhibitory neurons? Do they contribute to the generation of spikes or synaptic currents? Are there other functional contributions of theta, delta and fast and slow oscillations, and other brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Well, you'd ask about synaptic transmission first, but for most invertebrates, it appears that they use a small number of different inhibitory neurons for a variety of different inhibitory purposes. But in some species, the number of distinct inhibitory neurons is very high, as it is in humans, and those inhibitory neurons play very specific roles.'
Dr. B:'What's a good example?'

Dr. M:'I can think of one. We had some colleagues in Brazil who discovered the function of a different neuron to the  C. borealis  nervous system. They found that some neurons that were not thought to be synaptic transmitters, were involved in the control of the pyloric rhythm. They found that they had a number of different chemical substances that were secreted onto the soma of the pylor neurons, and they were very important.'
Dr. B:'Can you tell me the name of this inhibitory neuron?'

Dr. M:'If you're talking about humans, well, we use two different inhibitory neurotransmitters for inhibition of muscles. We use two different neurotransmitters for the inhibition of neurons, such as dopamine and serotonin. We use two neurotransmitters for inhibiting different types of cells in the brain, and so on. So it's not that one neurotransmitter is used for inhibition of different kinds of cells, but a variety of different neurotransmitters are used for inhibition.'
Dr. B:'So it's all about the specificity?'

Dr. B:'Well, I mean, there are some examples in the brain where it appears that GABAergic interneurons are used in a very specific manner, but many of those interneurons may function by inhibiting excitation in other areas. In many cases, their ability to inhibit excitation depends on other interneurons. The GABAergic neurons are always on the periphery, and they are the first to be activated in the early response to excitation.'
Dr. M:'Yes, the earliest response to excitation is always GABAergic.'

Dr. B:'I agree, and those interneuronal roles are much more diverse than in some interneurons in other areas, and in many other areas, the function of interneurons is not clear. I would like to get in touch with your previous students who were the first students in the study of interneuronal functions. What is their current status in the field?'

Dr. M:'I guess many of the same, like most students, they're still doing neuroscience, they're still studying brain systems, and they are also taking on new areas of neuroscience, like studying interneuronal relationships.'

Dr. B:'But in this process, what are the challenges that you have faced? What are the areas of science that you are looking for to bring back, and what are the topics that you are looking to study in the next decades? Where are the questions that you will address? What are your aspirations for the next few decades? I'm assuming that you want to return to your original goal of understanding the neuronal syntax, but what is the practicality of this goal?'
Dr. M:'Well, for the next few years I'm doing a lot of work that is kind of not really in that field, but it's in a general neuroscience area.'

Dr. B:'I mean, there is one case where we see that inhibitory interneurons appear to play a critical role. In the hippocampus, the inhibition that they provide is needed for the orderly sequence of firing in pyramidal neurons, which is thought to underlie the sequence of representations in episodic memory.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, it is quite clear that they are the first activated, the first to become active, and the first to play a role in the earliest response to a change of the neuronal inputs.'

Dr. B:'And when they are activated, the result is a specific inhibition of excitation of the neurons that are the first to respond to input, thus giving rise to a unique temporal order of activity. That's how they may function.'
Dr. B:'And how would it be possible to tell if that is the case for an individual inhibitory neuron?'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibition is very important in the nervous system, in my view. It allows different neurons to be segregated and to keep each other off balance, and it allows a variety of rhythmic behaviors to occur, such as gastric mill rhythms, cardiac muscle contractions, or cardiac muscle contraction. And it's important in allowing neurons to release a variety of substances, as you know, that have many functions. And it's a fundamental mechanism that allows different neurons to behave according to their genetic profile.'

Dr. B:'I understand that inhibition allows for a variety of different rhythms in different parts of the brain, but in the hippocampus, I'm not sure how inhibition would be the key to providing rhythm. I mean, it's not clear to me how inhibition allows for rhythms in the hippocampus. The other mechanism that allows for a rhythm is the interneuron, but what are the mechanisms for inhibition? What is the mechanism for inhibition? What are the mechanisms that allow a neuron to inhibit its own targets?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, well, the neuron that inhibits itself is probably the only neuron that is likely to keep its target off. So it seems to me that the role of inhibition is to keep neurons segregated, to ensure that they're not co-transmitters, to ensure that each cell is only firing in the correct rhythm.'

Dr. B:'Could it also be the case that inhibitory interneurons can synchronize neurons with a high temporal precision? So that, in, for example, a hippocampus-dependent memory task, a hippocampal interneuron might be synchronized in the theta frequency band?'

Dr. M:'So the hippocampus is a place where it's really critical to maintain the appropriate rhythmic patterns of activity in the brain. So that's why, you know, the neurons that are there must be kept segregated and they must be, they must be in the appropriate frequencies and they must be the appropriate length of time apart, so that the appropriate patterns of activity can be produced, so it's very critical that that be done correctly.'

Dr. B:'So the hippocampus has, theta oscillation, gamma oscillation, but not in the theta or gamma range is another mechanism that allows for segregation and synchronizing of neurons. I'm not so sure that inhibition is the key to segregating and synchronizing the hippocampus, but it might be a mechanism that does allow for theta and gamma activity, which is essential for maintaining memory and other cognitive functions, such as, in this case, memory.'

Dr. M:'You see, I think it has a lot of mechanisms. I don't think inhibition is necessarily the mechanism. I think inhibition is a fundamental part of neural network dynamics that allows neurons to regulate each other, and to control the rhythmic behavior of many different networks. We use inhibition in many different ways. We use it to release substances, we use it to regulate the voltage of the membrane, we use it as a control mechanism.'

Dr. B:'What are some ways that we use it? In the hippocampus, we know that inhibition is critical for gamma and epsilon rhythms. We know that inhibition is an important part of the hippocampal network. What are the mechanisms and the mechanisms? What are the molecules and the mechanisms that inhibitory neurons use? Do we know? What are they? What are the molecular mechanisms of the inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So that's the point of our study. We're studying the mechanism of regulation of a network, the mechanisms by which the neurons are regulated. We don't think that it's necessarily a mechanism by which the neurons control each other. We think that neurons may regulate themselves by regulating the expression of a number of different neurotransmitters and ion channels. So we're studying the mechanism by which the networks, the neurons themselves, regulate themselves.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible to inhibit the hippocampus and, in particular, GABAergic inhibitory neurons? Do we know what those neurons are? Do we know how many different inhibitory classes exist? Can we say that, well, we'll get to inhibition, because inhibition is a fundamental mechanism in the brain, and then we'll be able to control the hippocampus by inhibiting them? Is it possible?'

Dr. B:'It's not clear to you how inhibition can regulate neuronal activity in the hippocampus? What mechanism is there? What is the neuronal mechanism to inhibit? How does inhibition work? What is the physiological mechanism? What are the neuronal mechanisms for the hippocampus to inhibit its own activity? I mean, it is just not clear to me what inhibition means.'

Dr. M:'Well, as a matter of principle, they're supposed to be the negative poles of the network that produces excitatory networks. You know, if the excitatory neurons were positive in nature, then the inhibitory neurons would provide a negative signal to make things balance out. But you know, it's kind of like with the wind.'
Dr. B:'I mean, they can't work the way you described them.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, they have to be negative. Otherwise, they don't do anything.'
Dr. B:'But they just can't. They just can't.'

Dr. M:'If you look at an oscillation, you know, the whole process, the whole action potential process, the whole generation process, you know, starts with a little leak, starts with a small gap in a circuit. And then, you know, if the gap is small enough, the voltage will accumulate and then the gap will widen. If the gap is wide enough, then the voltage will escape.'
Dr. B:'And what is their function?'
Dr. M:'So their function is to inhibit. So it's to make things balance. Because you can't just get rid of them; you've got to have negative excitatory neurons. So that's their function.'
Dr. B:'Is that true?'

Dr. M:'Because, otherwise you're going to have these excitatory things all over the place. Otherwise they're just like you're trying to get rid of positive excitatory neurons, and then there'll be positive excitatory things everywhere. So there are limits.'
Dr. B:'But it has to be a negative.'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory neurons are not supposed to have negative feedback. Instead, they work through inhibition of excitatory neurons. And inhibition is a positive force, as you will see later on in this conversation.'
Dr. M:'So, if you think about it, if you're going to inhibit a motor neuron, you're always going to end up with the negative, because when you're doing it you're always getting back a positive.'
Dr. B:'Well, then the reason the wind comes to an even balance is that we need to provide the energy to keep it up.'
Dr. B:'So, I have a question for you. Do you think that the evolution of brain rhythms is simply an inevitable consequence of wiring principles, or is it possible that it serves some purpose?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think it's inevitable at all, because we're learning how to do this, and we're learning how different neurons can connect to each other, and that there are alternative pathways and routes to getting neural signals. So, I think it could be done a different way, but you know, what's interesting is, like we were talking about this earlier, you know, as humans we evolved into bigger brains.'
Dr. M:'Well, you know, we always thought that the function of an inhibitory neuron was to inhibit something.'

Dr. B:'It's actually very different, though. It's very different from other neurons. In fact, other cells can inhibit other cells or inhibit something else, or excite something else, right? What is the function of a cell that inhibits something else? Does it inhibit? Is it inhibitory? Or does it inhibit? What is it?'
Dr. M:'I think I know what the function of an inhibitor is, actually. I think that's one of the functions. I think it's one of the things that a neuron might do.'

Dr. B:'Okay. So, what other functions are the inhibitory cells doing? And can I understand from the function of inhibition what would happen if, you know, if the GABA-A receptors, which are one of the many functions of the inhibitory neurons, were abolished? I mean, it's not realistic, but we can still pretend.'

Dr. M:'But we can also pretend. So the GABA-A receptor function isn't necessary for an inhibitory neuron to produce its inhibitory effect. There are different subtypes of GABA-A receptors. GABA-A receptors are very different from each other, and one of them is not as important as the other, for instance.'
Dr. B:'But recently it has been known that they also produce rhythmic output patterns that we refer to as inhibition.'
Dr. M:'Yes, that was also very surprising, because we thought they were only inhibiting.'
Dr. B:'Now we know they also produce rhythms and have a very complex network in their brain and even in their body.'
Dr. M:'And that's actually been very surprising.'

Dr. B:'In fact, it is the inhibition that they provide that I would like to have a special talk with you about. And that is the importance of the inhibitory system. In fact, you know, if you would like to learn about a recent paper that is doing a really great analysis, you would want to look into the brain at this inhibitory system. I mean, the role of the inhibitory neurotransmitter system has been studied by a large number of different methods.'

Dr. M:'Well, I know that they produce a lot of inhibitory feedback to other neurons that can affect them, but I just wonder if there are any fundamental principles that we understand and then try to build up a model of what those principles are that would be beneficial to everybody.' I mean, you know, what are some of the basic principles that apply to neural circuits, and how these neural circuits work, and maybe even in the more general context of learning.'

Dr. B:'I'm actually not too familiar with the specifics of it. I'm mostly interested in the more general level that you just mentioned. But the principle is simple, if you will: you have a central excitatory circuit, which is basically the hippocampal system, which can excite neurons that in turn give rise to action potentials.'
Dr. M:'The inhibition is the function, it helps us to regulate the network.'
Dr. B:'What is the function? of inhibition?'
Dr. B:'Are we familiar with their physiology?'
Dr. B:'What does the inhibition serve to achieve?'
Dr. M:'It helps to regulate the network activity.'
Dr. B:'Is there any functional difference between pyramidal cells and inhibitory neurons? If so, is it worth the extra step of adding interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Well, pyramidal cells provide the highest current that they can and inhibitory cells are just the ones that are more hyperpolarized than the rest of the cells, and that's because they don't have an outward K +  conductance, they don't have a K +  equilibrium potential, so they're only hyperpolarized relative to the rest of the network.'
Dr. B:'If inhibition is as important as the previous question, then why did nature build only two cell types, inhibitory and pyramidal neurons?'
Dr. M:'Well, pyramidal neurons are pyramidal neurons, and they can generate more action potentials, and then they can also act as inhibitory neurons, and they are in effect inhibitory neurons.'

Dr. B:'I'm sorry to interrupt, but there are so many variables. I mean, what do you expect to learn? What are the most important ones to control, and what is the least important? In other words, is there any way to control the brain activity without controlling any of these many parameters that affect brain activity? And this would still allow the brain activity to do what it's supposed to do, which is to make predictions and to make decisions.'
Dr. M:'That's where it comes to, to achieve a balance, where it allows us to regulate networks by changing and regulating the balance of neurotransmitter, and the strength of synaptic transmission.'
Dr. B:'Does inhibitory neurons provide a different function than excitatory neurons? If so, does it offer advantages for the brain over excitatory neurons?'
Dr. B:'Inhibition is what makes neural syntax so important.'
Dr. M:'It is.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special class of inhibition that you like to work with? Or are you willing to work with all types of inhibition?'
Dr. M:'Well, I am more interested in network dynamics, because that is what drives all our behaviour.'
Dr. B:'Do you have a prediction, what are the most promising directions for understanding the brain?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think my best work was probably done on invertebrates, like crabs and lobsters. So, we were able to study the function of individual neurons, and the roles of the different types of neurons, and the importance of these different modulatory neurons.'
Dr. B:'And these neurons are similar to those in vertebrates? Or they are very different?'

Dr. B:'Inhibition is the most fundamental mechanism of neural coding. Do we have a general concept of what inhibition is? I mean, it's not only inhibition of excitation, but the absence of excitation... I mean, inhibition of inhibition is an important mechanism in the brain as well... I'm not sure that inhibition and excitation have a general concept.'
Dr. M:'Oh, no. I would say excitation is the most important...'
Dr. M:'...because they are a property of networks, not a property of neurons. It's a property of networks.'

Dr. B:'I agree, but we still have to look at how we use and how we understand them in isolation. The fact that inhibition is not only a property of networks does not mean that in isolation it doesn't have a lot of value. In isolation inhibition does not have much value, but when it's in the network it has a lot of value, because it controls the network and it gives us a framework in which to look for the function of networks.'

Dr. M:'Inhibition is a ubiquitous feature of neuronal networks and is an example of evolutionary conservation of an important functional mechanism. It's not the only mechanism for creating inhibition. Inhibition can also be generated by the activation of a hyperpolarization-activated current that depolarizes the membrane from a more hyperpolarized point, a kind of rectification.'
Dr. B:'If this is the case, then what is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'So it's a way of inhibiting voltage excitation from a depolarized to hyperpolarized state. If the excitation is already at a high enough level, the hyperpolarization will just make it increase and increase. So you can see, in general, the main reason for inhibition is to inhibit voltage excitation.'

Dr. B:'Can we put aside the concept of inhibition for a moment, and what we would like to ask is how we can learn anything that we know about the brain if we ignore the effects that inhibition has on excitation?'
Dr. M:'I'm not sure that there's anything to be lost if you put that aside.'
