Dr. B:'But there would be something to be lost if we ignore the fact that inhibition can create a range of responses and inhibition is a mechanism to bring excitation down. I'm asking how we would learn about the brain if that aspect of the brain that is most critical is ignored.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think we would learn about more of the intrinsic mechanisms. We would learn about the intrinsic mechanisms, because that's the most critical aspect of understanding how the brain works. And if you think of your brain like an electronic circuit, that depends on the strength of the connections. So you could imagine putting a really strong hyperpolarizing current in your head. Your head would be like a circuit that was kind of like a short circuit.'

Dr. B:'And then we could learn about your intrinsic properties. Because this is not a long circuit, it would be very weak, but the response would be much more complicated. Now, the reason why that is very important is that in the brain there are multiple systems that are so interlocked that it is not always clear how to draw a line between them.'

Dr. M:'Well, if you look at neurons that have no hyperpolarization potential, there is no way for them to inhibit themselves because they have no synaptic connection. So, in a network with many neurons, the function of inhibitors is often to provide a feedback mechanism to maintain the structure of networks.'
Dr. B:'Is there a particular example that you can illustrate that you can't get away from the feedback inhibition?'
Dr. M:'It is a fundamental feature of how we understand the organization of brain circuits.'

Dr. B:'What is this fundamental feature and what makes it the fundamental feature? What is the essence of this feature? I mean, I want to be able to define this fundamental feature because it is a fundamental feature, but I want to know what is it's fundamental feature. What makes it so fundamental? So, you have a list of mechanisms that are available. The mechanisms that you're able to use are limited by a number of things.'
Dr. B:'What is an example of inhibition that we have observed in the brain?'

Dr. M:'I'm not really sure that we've observed inhibition in the brain but certainly we have observed many different patterns of network activity that suggest that there are different mechanisms at work.'

Dr. M:'Well, if the neuron is producing a hyperpolarizing current it will tend to be pushed further to the left, so that it will not fire in a burst. So it's more likely that it will have to fire in a slow and rhythmic mode to push the membrane far enough to make it hyperpolarized.'
Dr. B:'What is the function, or the use, or advantage of this mechanism?'
Dr. M:'Oh, I think it's essential. I mean, I think that it's fundamental. I don't think that it's just a kind of, you know, by-product of evolution.'

Dr. M:'It can act as a switch for other networks. For example, it's known that a group of invertebrate neurons have a switch, they have a switch for inhibition, that acts like a switch for a different network, the network that produces fast rhythmic bursting.'

Dr. M:'Well, it would be interesting to study this because it would provide insight into how neuromodulators use different mechanisms to achieve their effect on behavior. I mean, I've studied some of this in the context of the activation of voltage-dependent potassium currents. The activation of voltage-gated currents by neuromodulators is one example. In this case, we see a distinct mechanism being used to achieve the same goal, which is the activation of voltage gated currents.'

Dr. B:'In other words, in order to achieve the goal of inhibiting the cell membrane, you have to use a specific mechanism. What are the consequences of the inhibition? In other words, is it possible that inhibition is the key to generating a specific output in terms of a neuron's output?'
Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely. I think it's the key, because it allows for feedback to occur and it allows for neurons to be active.'

Dr. B:'So there are numerous possible consequences for inhibition. I'm going to ask two questions from you. First, are there any potential consequences of inhibition that you find particularly interesting? Second, are there any possible ways in which inhibition may play a role that we haven't covered yet? I'm going to give you the opportunity to address that, and then we'll bring on the audience to respond to the questions.'

Dr. B:'So let me ask you a question that has to do with the evolutionary conservation of inhibition. In order to answer the question, I want to ask you two questions. One is from you: what is the evolutionary conservation of inhibitory neurons? And the second is for everyone to answer this: what are the evolutionary conservation of principal cells? And then I can go on and talk about inhibition. And hopefully you'll answer those questions. And then we can talk about what it means for neural syntax.'

Dr. M:'So the first part of your question is: why do we use inhibition? Because it is the only thing that is universal among all nervous systems. And we use it for all different kinds of reasons. Right?'
Dr. M:'The primary function is inhibition, but also synaptic depression can increase the inhibitory signal at the synapse and so can activate inhibitory pathways.'

Dr. B:'I'm sure that you would agree with the observation that all of our behaviorally relevant neuronal activity takes place within certain frequency bands and that we are not interested in the whole brain, and, in fact, it would not make sense to ask what the function is of, for instance, the whole hippocampus, which is responsible for the behaviors that are being examined.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons can be important in keeping the nervous system stable, and also for producing homeostatic mechanisms. In the sense that they can act as sensors to measure inputs into the brain.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are typically used in the generation of synchronous bursts, and the coordination of multiple neurons within networks requires that neurons can communicate with each other even while they are activated. We see that inhibitory neurons can be used in both synchronization and coordination, but not in all networks.'
Dr. B:'Why does inhibition not work well in some cases?'

Dr. M:'It's interesting that we didn't find any inhibition in the system of the pacemaker neuron. The pacemaker neuron is inhibited directly by the rhythmic action potentials in its network. The pacemaker is also inhibited indirectly by the rhythmic actions potentials in the inhibitory neurons and is, therefore, influenced by the rhythmic activation of the pacemaker neurons. The pacemaker neurons do not produce action potentials but instead have tonic spiking properties.'
Dr. B:'If this is the case, what makes the system so special, and why does it require inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Well, in this case, the pacemaker has been'released from inhibition', as you might say, as the pacemaker neuron has been released from inhibition by the rhythmic depolarizing pulses from the inhibitory neurons. There are two possibilities: either the pacemaker was never activated and never had an inhibitory input or the pacemaker neurons themselves had an intrinsic or synaptic current-rectifying conductance.'

Dr. B:'So the reason it works in the circuit is that the inhibiting action of the inhibitory neurons, while it is very important, does not produce synchrony; that is, it does not make the neurons fire together, which is the main mechanism of synchrony generation. In the case of the pacemaker, the network of cells is synchronized because the action potential is very fast. And this is the main mechanism.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. B:'The problem is that there's no inhibition. The action potentials in the pacemaker neurons, in principle, could be initiated or induced by an action potential in one or more of the other network cells. And then you have the inhibition. So what is the inhibition? The action potential in the pacemaker neuron is very fast. This is the action potential, but when the inhibition is on, the action potential is not initiated.'
Dr. M:' I see that there is another interesting example of a model neuron and how it relates to the synaptic interactions in the network.'
Dr. B:' What would the synaptic interactions be in the network without inhibition?'

Dr. M:' That's a good question. Well, there are two neurons in this model which are inhibitory neurons, and the synaptic connections between the two inhibitory neurons are inhibitory chemical synapses. The other is an electrically passive cell. And there are inhibitory chemical synaptic interactions between the electrically passive cell and the two inhibitory ones.'
Dr. M:' Well, I'm sure they would be there because synaptic interactions are important for neural circuit stability.'
Dr. B:' Are there any differences between the circuit with inhibition and the circuit without inhibition?'

Dr. M:' Yes, I see two different kinds of behaviors: one that is similar in terms of the network as a whole, and one that is very different. This is a model that is very robust against perturbations, and this is also known to occur with biological neurons.'
Dr. B:' And what are the differences between the circuit without inhibition and the circuit with inhibition?'

Dr. M:' This circuit is quite robust to perturbations, because, you know, this is a system that can compensate for a perturbation. You know, if there was a perturbation, you know, the circuit would still produce rhythmic activity.'
Dr. B:' Are inhibitory neurons important for circuit stability?'

Dr. M:' Of course, because when you're getting a circuit that doesn't work right, you know, you want to be able to identify the nodes that are going to fall off of that circuit, so that you can do some work to keep those neurons from falling off.'

Dr. B:' Is inhibition important for circuit stability? It seems to me that you may want to make a case, because it's not just that inhibition is important, but also there are other factors that come into play. What would the circuit be like if there were no inhibition? What would be the synaptic interactions in that case? What would be some of the synaptic interactions if inhibition was removed? What would be, you know, some of the synaptic dynamics that would result? What is your hypothesis?'

Dr. B:' I'm sure that you remember the old discussion about pyramidal cells and inhibitory interneurons? It's a little different now, but it's basically the same. So now the neuron is actually more sensitive to inhibition than to excitation. This is a new era, but the same kind of old questions.'

Dr. M:'Yes, of course. We also see that these neurons are very highly excitable, and this is a part of what gives them a strong influence on the network. So this is a very active part of my work now, in understanding the dynamic properties of these neurons in networks. What role do inhibitory neurons play in network dynamics?'

Dr. B:'So I'd like to add something about the role of interneurons. We're seeing now that inhibition has a very important role in controlling synaptic transmission, that is, the rate of neurotransmitter release. It is very important. I have been studying this for a long time, and I'm seeing now a real breakthrough. I'm a very happy person that my findings in this area are very well-supported.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, well the old questions are the more important ones, because they're still applicable. So when you're doing some experiments with a model neuron like that, you want to make sure that it shows different behaviors. Because it's not just a tool to find out how a network can work. It's also a tool to learn how neurons can function, or how neurons can function together.'

Dr. B:'I'm sure that it's not going to surprise the audience that you're in the audience that you know that there are a lot of different types of inhibition in the brain, but what is a simple description? I mean, one that people can use in a different context would be nice.'

Dr. M:'We tend to call the kind of inhibition, the inhibitory feedback, the feedforward inhibition. So we tend to think about feedback inhibition as something that happens at a later stage, but it's also an intrinsic inhibition. It's like the membrane potential, when you have a strong inward current, when you depolarize your membrane potential, you're also suppressing the potential of your membrane, so it's a feedforward effect.'

Dr. B:'So if you're going to do a simple model neuron, the feedforward inhibitory feedback is what you would want to use. But if you want to study how a neuronal network works, then feedback inhibition, the feedback inhibition, the feedforward-forward inhibition is a very useful way to describe a simple neuron.'

Dr. B:' Well, as you know, it's really hard to make the case of inhibition for network function in the brain, but I'll give it a shot. Inhibition is the most common mechanism for reducing population excitability, it's ubiquitous in neuronal circuits and it affects many more neurons than excitation.'
Dr. M:'Yes, and it's also a good thing, because it helps stabilize circuits in a way.'

Dr. B:' That's right, but in addition to stabilizing the network, inhibition also affects its timing and its probability of firing. Inhibition does not only serve to reduce activity but it also serves to bias the timing of neuronal activity. Inhibition is a dynamic, and in many brain regions its activity and timing is highly precise.'

Dr. M:' Oh yes, there are regions where neurons are inhibited as if by a circuit, so there are areas where these neurons are not active for days but the network is. In fact, the network is the one that is always active, but it's not being inhibited.'

Dr. B:' Exactly, and the network activity of the network is coordinated by these rhythms, but not by inhibition. These are the types of things that we are interested in. Let's go to the next point now.'
Dr. M:'We study them. We study the dynamic, the plasticity of networks.'

Dr. B:' You mean, what is plasticity? And what is dynamic? That is a bit different now, but let's move back to when the networks were already there. What would happen if the system were already there and then we'd have to study it in this way? What would happen, for example, if the hippocampus is already activated? Then we wouldn't need to go through it all and we would be able to make some quick assumptions.'
Dr. M:'Let's move on.'
Dr. M:'Well, this question has been on my mind for years because we have identified many inhibitory neurons and we still do not know the function of these neurons.'

Dr. B:'The best guess I have is that these neurons are responsible for controlling the excitability of principal cells. Therefore, the inhibition serves to maintain the stability of the principal cells and to control the dynamic range of the principal cells within the network. This is what I have been doing with my network model: controlling the firing rates of the principal cells by applying current steps to these inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. M:'That is a good hypothesis. That is the best hypothesis that I can offer right now.'

Dr. B:'I agree. Let me ask a more difficult question, then. Is the function of the excitatory neurons the same or different? I mean, in principle, the same, right? And this is where we have the second part of the answer that I will share with you. If you want to ask a difficult question to someone, you should ask it to yourself.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely, yes, I do.'

Dr. B:'What is the function of these excitatory cells? You have mentioned many inhibitory cells that would be perfect for this job. Is it to add some more inhibition to the network? Or is it to fire the same amount of spikes, just faster? Or is it something completely different? Do we know? Does the brain know? Or does it need to be determined? In other words, is it the primary function of these neurons to contribute spikes to the network, or to inhibit?'

Dr. M:'I think the primary function is to contribute spikes to network activity. We know that these neurons fire spikes, and we know that these neurons can fire spikes and they fire many times per cycle. We also know that these neurons are sensitive to temperature changes. So, you know, I would be very surprised if these neurons have not become temperature sensors.'
Dr. B:'It is a plausible theory.'

Dr. M:'It is a very plausible theory, although I would have to run simulations and see what happens when the voltage is stepped. To show you how it works, I think we need to see the effects of changing the membrane conductances. When we go to an animal, when we are studying an animal or when we study humans, we don't measure the activity of every single neuron or neuron that we measure. We measure the activity of a few neurons or many neurons.'
Dr. B:'So how many neurons would you like to include? Is that 1,000 or 10,000? How many neurons would you include in the network?'

Dr. M:'Let me talk about the other side of the equation. We also know that a major function of a neuron is to release neuromodulatory substances. There are many examples where neuromodulatory processes have been identified and it is obvious that this is an additional function. For example, in the central pattern generating circuits, the pyloric pacemaker neurons, we have identified several neuromodulators that enhance and facilitate the generation of central pattern generators.'

Dr. B:'We also know that these neurotransmitters are capable of affecting other neurons and that their effect depends on time. So, in the central system, the inhibition of the pacemaker neurons is a necessary condition and the release of a neuromodulatory substance is an optional event.'
Dr. M:'And what would be the significance of neuromodulation in this context? Why would it be important to put it there if it's just an optional function?'
Dr. B:'Well, let me ask a more specific question. How many neurons are there in the cortex? And please, no, don't say, 'I'm going to estimate.' That's a terrible estimation.'

Dr. M:'Okay, how many neurons are there? The number of neurons has increased since we started counting neurons. We know there are a variety of neurons that are identified as inhibitory. We know there's some that play roles in regulation.'
Dr. B:'And we know that there are other neurons that have specific functions, which are related to memory and processing sensory inputs. And what is the function of the inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. M:'The function of the inhibitors is regulation, in general. In general they play a regulatory role. I mean, the regulation is a general mechanism that neurons use to control other neurons. The neurons that regulate the regulation have a regulatory role. The neurons that are regulating regulation also have some kind of a regulatory role, but their regulatory roles are not necessarily tied to their inhibitory function.'
Dr. B:'Okay, so the inhibitory neurons don't have any specific functions. What they are doing is they are regulating other neurons, which are called principal cells.'
Dr. M:'Right.'
Dr. M:'No, we know there are many neurons that fire in the cortex, and their number is still unknown.'
Dr. B:'So, let's just start with the number of neurons in the cortex.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, I would like to be able to say how many neurons there are in the cortex, but, that's not possible because we are still working on the function of some of these neurons. We've identified many neurons that we believe fire in the cortex. We still don't know how many neurons there really are, but many, many neurons fire in the cortex.'

Dr. B:'Right. So here's what I want to ask. How many cells are there? If you can say how many cells there are, I'll say how many cells. Let's say there are 20,000 neurons. What is the function of these cells? What is the function? If you can answer that question, then you will know the function of the neurons, because you've answered the question, and the function of a group of neurons is the function of that group.'
Dr. M:'Right. Right. So let me tell you what we've done, and it's not what you might be expecting. We've identified neurons that fire on the cortex of crabs.'

Dr. B:'Well, that's interesting because we have shown that a small circuit can be made to fire with 20,000 neurons in the cortex of a crab. So the first thing we did is we identified a neuron that fires in the cortex, we call it C1a neuron. Then we identified a neuron in the frontal cortex, and we called it C2b neuron. Then we created a small circuit that connected them, and it fired. It fired because it was designed to do so.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'What we have not done is identified the function of the two neurons in this small circuit. So the first step is to find the function of the neuron C1a and neuron C2b. But to find the function, it's not easy. Because it requires looking at the entire circuit, from the very beginning where there are the two neurons, where they synapse. Where they have excitatory and inhibitory synaptic inputs from, where the neurons are connected to each other in the circuit.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'Okay, so let's move forward with what we do know about these neurons.'

Dr. M:'Oh, geez, I was going to say that the number of neurons that fire in this region is unknown, and the number of neurons firing is still unknown, but we do know that it's probably quite a large number.'

Dr. B:'Oh, what are they doing? Are they connected to each other or are they doing their own thing? I know that there are several interneurons. What about the number of pyramidal cells that are connected to each other?'

Dr. B:'Well, this is why we are having a conversation with you tonight. And by the way, I would like to thank the Society for Neuroscience, and particularly the San Francisco chapter for giving us this opportunity to speak with you tonight.'

Dr. M:'I think it's important, because a lot of people think that when you get two neurons that are inhibited by each other, that is going to lead to some kind of a fight, whereas in fact, it does not necessarily lead to some kind off of a fight, it's not that two neurons that are mutually inhibitory can fight each other.'

Dr. B:'Can two neurons have mutually inhibitory effects on each other? For example, when you get a neuron that produces an action potential in a neuron that produces a GABAergic postsynaptic potential in the same neuron, this is considered mutually inhibitory. However, when two neurons are inhibited by each others action potentials, then they can suppress each other, but this is not considered mutually inhibitory, as the interneurons are affected by the action potential as well as the target neurons.'

Dr. M:'Right, okay, so I guess, one example is that you can see this, when you get two inhibitory neurons that are electrically coupled. The two neurons are inhibited electrically by each other. The only way that they can release neurotransmitter to each other is if they release neurotransmitter at different points in time, so that they each get their own portion of the neurotransmitter and can release.'
Dr. B:'But is there a fundamental reason why inhibitory neurons would not just fire spikes randomly?'

Dr. M:'Not necessarily. We don't want to have a bunch of spikes randomly firing. We have to have the inhibition, and we have to have the time that it takes for the system to respond. So, it's important for them to function.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for neurons to not be mutually inhibitory? What is the function of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Well, as far as I'm concerned, you want to avoid mutual inhibition, because you want your neurons to be firing in a coordinated fashion and not, you want to prevent your neurons from firing one at a time.'

Dr. B:'So, so, this seems like the function of inhibition. So it seems like you would be able to make the case that inhibition is necessary to do what you want to do. Is that the case? Is that, is that the case?'

Dr. M:'Yes, so I think that the function of inhibition is actually pretty simple. So we think that we want our neurons to have their own specific patterns of activity that are important for us. So we want the neurons to fire out of a specific pattern of activity.'

Dr. B:'I have a question from a friend who's, who's, who would like to know, uh, if you would be able, uh, you know, uh, you would you be able to comment on that question, uh, how does a single neuron function? Is it like a, is it like a car, is it a car, is is it, is it like anything, is it like it's like a truck? What would it, what would it be?'
Dr. M:'You know, you want, you want to be sure, because, you know, you want to, you want to fire the specific kind of pattern that's needed.'
Dr. B:'You want to make it, you want to make it like a car. Or a truck. Or a computer. And so on. Do you want to comment on that?'

Dr. M:'Well, inhibition is not always the most effective way to control neuronal excitability, in fact, it's not even the most effective way. There are other modulatory neurons that can control neuronal activity.'
Dr. B:'What are they?'

Dr. M:'There are modulators that activate or inhibit a single neuron, that inhibit all the excitatory drive to that neuron, and you want that. But there are modulators that have multiple actions, they can act on multiple neurons at once. There are substances that activate neurons at the level of single cells, there are substances that act on networks of neurons at once.'
Dr. B:'And what are these substances? What are they?'

Dr. M:'Oh, it depends. One of the most obvious examples of this is hormones. Hormones are obviously important to reproduction, but they also regulate many things that are not immediately associated with reproduction. They also regulate muscle contraction, they regulate heart contraction. The heart itself is quite important, you know?'
Dr. B:'Where are those other inhibitory neurons?'
Dr. B:'But when it comes to the brain, these neurons are always first.'

Dr. M:'Right. When we looked at this circuit of inhibition and excitation in the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab (Crab), we found the two excitation and inhibition neurons were co-inhibiting each other. There was a reciprocal inhibition, and this inhibition was critical to maintaining the rhythmic and robust motor patterns. When we blocked the reciprocal inhibition and removed the ability of the neuron to inhibit itself, it immediately lost its rhythmic behavior.'
Dr. B:'Well, what are those modulatory neurons?'

Dr. M:'It is a large set of neurons that release amines and neuropeptides, that can activate different circuits of neurons and can be responsible for regulating the excitability of neurons. Neuromodulatory neurons are able to regulate the excitability of specific neurons through changes in the voltage-dependent properties of ionic channels, and through changes in other cellular features. Neuromuscular reflexes can also be inhibited via modulatory neurons.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible that inhibitory neurons in the hippocampus have special control on other cells that is different from that of excitatory neurons?'

Dr. M:'Certainly. The neuron that controls the rhythmic behavior in the stomach is probably not necessarily inhibited by the neuron that controls the behavior in the mouth. The neuron that influences the muscle movements is probably not inhibited by the neuron responsible for the cardiac activity. So, in fact, there are two neurons that play quite disparate roles, and the roles that these neurons play in the system probably rely on different sets of chemical and electrical properties. And they probably utilize different sets of inputs.'
Dr. B:'But in the hippocampus, the interneuron network is an effective mechanism.'

Dr. M:'The interneuron network? So there are neurons that do that other things? Well, we know that it was a single neuron that did that. So, I think there are a number of neurons that can control neurons.'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are the most important components of circuits in that their inhibitory actions are responsible for generating the temporal structure of circuits. Inhibitory neurons have a role in synaptic transmission and in the modulation of circuits.'

Dr. B:'What are the mechanisms by which excitatory cells communicate with each other? What is the function of interneuron circuits? What are the mechanisms by that inhibitory interneurons affect the activity of excitatory neurons?'

Dr. M:'Excitatory and inhibitory neurons have a functional identity and their actions are complementary. Each neuron in a circuit contributes to the regulation of the circuit by using its own electrical properties or by its actions on other cells. For example, an inhibitory neuron will influence the behavior of a neuron if it alters the properties of that neuron, but a strong excitatory input will usually dominate the circuit.'
Dr. B:'Where does the neuronal code come from?'

Dr. B:'Inhibitory circuits are composed of inhibitory cells and excitatory circuits. In inhibitory circuits, there is no feedback from the inhibitory circuit. In inhibitory neurons, feedback inhibition is weak and often suppressed by the excitatory loop. In inhibitory cells, the inhibitory effect is mediated by the GABA A  receptor. In this mechanism, the effect of a neurotransmitter that binds to the receptor causes a hyperpolarization, and a decrease in excitation.'
Dr. M:'You might say that the function of inhibitors is to make a synaptic circuit, which generates a particular output.'

Dr. B:'The mechanism that enables the output is the excitatory action of the excitatory circuit. The inhibitory circuit has three elements: inhibitory neurons, which receive the output of the excit-atory circuit and act as gatekeepers; a second circuit, composed of the same neurons; and inhibitory interneurons, which act as the output of the circuit and act as'spike attenuators'.'
Dr. M:'To enable the inhibitory output.'

Dr. B:'That is an important aspect of inhibitory circuits. In order to make an inhibitory circuit, inhibitory cells must be interconnected. This is achieved by gap junctions between interneurons. It's also an important mechanism for transmitting inhibitory signals in the gamma frequency range, which is important for synchronizing principal cells, and is critical for providing the necessary strength of inhibition that is necessary to maintain the stability of circuit dynamics.'
Dr. B:'What do we know about the wiring of inhibitory neurons? How many inhibitory cell types are there?'

Dr. M:'As far as we know there is one neuron type that is a general modulator. There are many inhibitory neurons that are regulated by neuropeptides and there are many more that are regulated by neuromodulators that release small amines and small peptides. So there are several subtypes of inhibitory neuron that each have their own individual set of small molecule transmitters. The question is how many subtypes of inhibitors there are in the brain.'

Dr. M:'There are six identified inhibitory neurons that exist in the retina of the crustacean STG. Each of them is responsible for a different subset of the rhythmic circuit movements, like opening the stomach for feeding. We don't know the identity of the neurons that control the rhythmic circuit activity, but these six cell types are responsible for rhythmic patterns of the gastric mill, oesophageal, pyloric, cardiac, and pyloric rhythms.'

Dr. M:'We know, that there are many, many different kinds of inhibition that are going on in the brain. We know, for example, that one kind of inhibition is called long-term inhibition, where the inhibition occurs over seconds or minutes. Another kind of inhibition occurs over hours, days, and weeks. And yet another kind of inhibition is happening on milliseconds scales, and the dynamics of it is completely different.'
Dr. B:'Does the brain have a particular set of inhibitory cells, and if so what are their specific functions?'

Dr. M:'Yes, it does, so you know we think that the neural circuits are not a set of fixed components, but they are variable and their components can change. So you know the neuromodulators can modify the neurons that we call the modulatory neurons, the neuromodulatory projections can come from anywhere.'

Dr. M:'I don't know about wiring, but there are two classes of inhibitory neurons: neurons that fire tonically or intermittently, and oscillatory neurons that fire in a coordinated fashion to produce rhythms. There are neurons that respond to synaptic inputs, and then there are neurons that fire as a consequence of intrinsic membrane currents, and then there's a few other neurons that combine those two. So, yes, there are two types of inhibitory neurons.'
Dr. B:'And, are these types of inhibitory cells wired to each other? Are their axons collinear, or do we have to get there with a micro-drive to examine the wiring?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think they are wired, because it's been shown that their properties, their membrane potentials, their electrical synapses, depend on their wiring. So, I think that all the information that gets transmitted is dependent on the way in which the wiring of the neuron is set up. It is possible that different configurations could have led to different outcomes. We just don't know. We don't know which circuit, in all its complexity, would have developed.'

Dr. B:'If you're in a classroom, and you've a kid that's a little bit older, would it be easy to explain how inhibition is a critical ingredient of circuit function? What do we know about inhibition? How many different types of inhibition exist?'

Dr. M:'There are probably several cell types that are inhibitory, in terms of their voltage-gated conductance pattern and their connectivity. In that sense, their connectivity, they're all alike. The point I'm making is that there are a multitude of cell types that are known to be modulatory neurons and are themselves modulated by substances, and that those substances can alter the properties of those cells and that can change the circuits that they are responsible for generating.'

Dr. B:'Do we know that all inhibitory cells are also'modulatory neurons? Do inhibitory cells affect the activity of pyramidal cells in the same way? Are there mechanisms of inhibitory cell types that are different from pyramidal cells? Inhibitory cells are responsible for the temporal structure of circuit function but do they have other roles?'

Dr. M:'Well, some of the other roles they play, yes. One of the other functions they play is the modulation of circuits. There are neurons, for example, that release acetylcholine that can increase the amplitude of some currents. It can have a number of other functions as well, like increase the amplitude of the membrane current or increase the strength of synapses.'

Dr. M:'There are different types of inhibitory neurons with different wiring patterns. We think of them as sub-types. There are different types of network neurons with the same electrical properties but different wiring patterns. One of the reasons why the field of neural syntax is interesting is because there are different types of circuits, not necessarily different neurons. So one thing to try to do, is to understand the wiring patterns and how they influence the function of the circuits.'
Dr. B:'Which class of inhibitory neurons are wired like this?'
Dr. M:'We know about about four or five different cell types of the inhibitory neurons in the network.'
Dr. B:'How many inhibitory interneuron types exist in the hippocampus and what is the relationship between these interneuron types? What are the inputs to these interneurons?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons provide inhibitory feedback to the central pattern generating networks which produce rhythms like the stomach rhythm, which is part of the pacemaker kernel of the pyloric circuit of the brain, which also contains a few other circuits like the stomatogastric circuit that generate the stomachs, the eyes and the heart of the animal. Those are all part of the pacemaking kernel of the central pattern generating network.'
Dr. B:'But I don't know if the inhibition is just one big kernel, and the entire brain is a giant oscillator. I can see that it is part of a much larger mechanism.'

Dr. M:'It is part of a larger network, but the important thing is that the central pattern generating circuits are highly connected to a variety of other circuits in the animal. They interact, but in all cases, the central pattern generating circuit is responsible for producing a stable rhythmic output that is not dependent on the interaction between the other circuits, but is highly dependent on the properties of the central pattern generator itself, and the properties of the neuron(s) in the central pattern generating group.'

Dr. B:'Then what does the other part of the brain do? I mean, what is the function of the excitatory part? We have to put together two parts that don't communicate with each other and produce an output, but I don't know what the function of that part is, if it is just random activity in the neocortex. What is the function of random activity? We have to answer that question.'

Dr. M:'The role of the neurons is to generate neural activity and to provide synaptic and intrinsic membrane properties to the network. It's a little bit of a conundrum. We know that neurons can respond to neuromodulators and that neurons can be active by themselves, and we know that they can interact with each other. They can interact with many other cells. They can generate a variety of motor patterns in many different ways. But the function of the neurons is really not to do something directly.'

Dr. B:'So then the function of the brain is to transform all these many, many ways of internally generated activity into outputs. What kind of outputs are they making? Are they producing a rhythm? Is it a slow wave sleep oscillation or an alpha wave? Is it a fast wave or a gamma cycle? How are the neurons communicating, and what is the content of the messages? And so on.'
Dr. M:'Inhibition is used for the modulation of the behavior of neurons.'
Dr. B:'Why are there so many different types of inhibitory neurons in the brain?'
Dr. M:'Because the brain needs to be very, very flexible.'

Dr. B:'What advantages does inhibition offer? Why should the brain choose to use inhibition over excitation? Do you believe that inhibition is the most effective way to solve problems? What should be the role of inhibition in brain function?'
Dr. B:'Do there exist any important functions that are not, or cannot be, performed by inhibitory neurons?'

Dr. M:'There are important functions, but they are not directly related to the regulation of synaptic transmission. There are other modulatory inputs to the nervous system. The modulation of synaptic transmission is important for neural circuits. There are many functions that are important for the brain. The brain needs to be flexible. However, the regulation of synaptic strength is also important.'
Dr. B:'Is inhibition important in the brain for its normal function?'
Dr. B:'What is a typical neuron?'
Dr. M:'A neuron is a model of the behavior of an individual cell.'
Dr. B:'How many different types of neurons can there be?'

Dr. B:'When you have a very large population of excitatory neurons, the result is the suppression of the activity of the majority of neurons by inhibiting them. This is the main role of inhibitory neurons. And what is the difference between inhibition and excitation? Inhibition is that activity of the neurons that are responsible for the inhibition are also suppressed and disinhibited, so they are no longer inhibited. This is the key mechanism of inhibition. The main mechanism of inhibition is that of inhibition.'

Dr. M:'There's only one inhibitory neuron, you see, and it controls the activation of a specific kind of synapse in a network. That synapse, the activation of that synapse, is important for the activity of that network.'
Dr. B:'But what is the function of the network? What can that network do for the network?'
Dr. M:'Well, it depends on how the network is configured, what the synaptic connections are.'
Dr. M:'It doesn't really matter, because you can always replace a neuron with another, with a different kind of function.'

Dr. B:'So there are some interneurons that are not part of that specific network, but they are activated by the activity of the network, and they control the activity of other interneurons in that network.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, yeah, and some of the control depends on the level of activity in the network, so they are part of the dynamics of the network.'
Dr. B:'I suppose we can call them regulators. And what is the function of regulators? They can make the neurons in that network to work in a particular manner.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely.'
Dr. B:'And if we understand the rules that govern those interneurons, we can understand the dynamics of that network. That's the process, right?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, the interneurons are regulating the network. They are regulating the network, they control the activation of the specific synapse that they are in, and their own activation, so they can activate themselves, so they can increase their own membrane conductance, and they can release substances that modify the activity of other neurons. So they're very important.'

Dr. M:'Yes, and when neurons get excited, it changes the way they conduct their activity, so they change their synaptic output, or they change their ionic channel expressions, their membrane conductances. And then it changes the activity of the neurons and therefore changes the activity of circuits.'

Dr. B:'Okay, but what is the physiological relevance of this? And the reason why we are discussing this? It seems very interesting that a circuit can work without its constituents, which are the interneurons and the excitatory neurons, but with a different output, but, uh, what I mean is, is that there's a functional difference between the two networks? So it would be interesting to know what is the physiological difference between the two network activities. What is the physiological difference?'

Dr. M:'Well, we have learned a lot from the work of the, of other scientists who have worked with rats and mice to work with the brain, and when you get down to the cellular level, you find that the neuronal networks are formed by different types of neurons. We don't know exactly what each neuron does, we know that each of these neurons has a particular set of synaptic connections, and each neuron has a set of ionic channels on its membrane.'

Dr. B:'And how do these things change when the network is excited? How do these things change? So, uh, so for example, if we can make the neurons that are in that circuit to fire synchronously, for a short period of time, you can say that they work as a unit. Now, this is one example, because when these interneurons fire together, the membrane conductance of the principal cells decreases.'

Dr. M:'Yes, for example, there's the pyloric and gastric mill networks that you find in the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab. There are these two distinct networks that are found within the same neuron, and they're activated by two distinct neuromodulatory inputs that are received by the neuron. And these neurons play a critical role in the generation of gastric mill and pyloric rhythms within the crab.'
Dr. B:'Can we talk a little bit about neural syntax?'

Dr. B:'It is like a pacemaker mechanism, and the result of this is that the neurons in that network are excited and dis-inhibited by the activity of other neurons in that network. And this is how that network works together. And so this is what I'm asking. What is the function of all inhibitory neurons? Is it to allow this network to work together in a particular way, and in that case to stop the network from discharging, or is it to do something else?'
Dr. M:'It is to stop the network discharging, I'm afraid, and there are few examples of where this is the function of an inhibitory neuron.'

Dr. B:'Can you please explain this a little bit more, then, because these are not typical examples that are used in the literature? What is it like when these inhibitory cells stop network discharging? What is their output? What is their effect on other neurons in the network?'

Dr. M:'Well, their effect is that it stops the network from firing, and it actually does produce a tonic discharge in a circuit, because all of these circuits have one, and they can keep firing because they're just continuously, continuously firing. The only difference between the active state of the network and the quiescent state is that all of the active neurons that were firing are turned off during the quiescent states, and are turned on during the active state.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special type of inhibition that works like this? I'm not aware of such a mechanism.'
Dr. M:'Not that I'm aware of.'

Dr. M:'There is a mechanism, the mechanism is that the inhibition of one neuron produces hyperpolarization in the next neuron, so that you have a series of neurons that are inhibited by the activity of one neuron, so they are kind of hyperpolarized. So, this is an example of a special form of inhibition.'
Dr. M:'A number of studies in a number of preparations have shown that inhibition can be a regulator of circuit output, and that neurons can regulate circuit activity.'
Dr. B:'Can you give some examples?'

Dr. B:'Who are they regulating? In which situations? Can they affect the output of a target neuron? If so, how do they affect their target? How do they affect circuit activity? What is the functional difference between inhibition and other physiological types of regulation? What is the advantage of inhibition?'

Dr. M:'Inhibitory neurons are widely distributed throughout the brain and are usually found in multiple cell types in each brain region. They do not normally control target neurons. Inhibition is used as a modulator in many neural circuits. They can either enhance the oscillation frequency of neurons in some networks (e.g., the gastric mill network of the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system), or decrease the oscillation frequency (e.g.'

Dr. B:'Are they special in any way? Are they unique? Can they affect a different way? Do they have special effects? How do they differ from other neurons? What is the effect of inhibition on network activity? Are there any special effects? What is the role of GABAergic interneurons? How does inhibition affect the output of the target neurons?'

Dr. M:'Many inhibitory neurons have properties that distinguish them from their modulator release counterparts. The inhibitory neurons themselves have at least one inhibitory transmitter, they themselves release inhibitory transmitters, and they can alter the properties of target neurons. The role of GABAergic neurons is very complicated, and a lot of studies have focused on its role in the pyloric network of the stomatogasts. In some networks, it is possible to study isolated GABAergic neurons.'

Dr. B:'Which neurons are inhibitory? How do they regulate circuit activity? How do they modify the output of their target neurons? What is their role? What is the difference between GABAergic interneuron and other forms of neurophysiological inhibition? What are the functional differences between inhibition and other types of regulation? How do they interact with their target? What is the influence of the inhibitory neuron on the output of their targets? What is the contribution of inhibition to circuit activity?'

Dr. M:'Excitatory neurons in the stomatogenetic ganglion release a single transmitter, glutamate, but excitatory neurons in other parts of the stomato-gastric nervous system release many additional transmitters (as well as a few that are not identified as excitatory, such as gamma-amino butyric acid).'

Dr. B:'Do inhibitory neurons contribute to the output of their neurons? Are there special effects? What are the mechanisms involved? Are there special mechanisms? Are there any unique effects? How do inhibitory neurons contribute toward network activity? Are they special in any other way? Can they affect their target neurons in a different way? Can they regulate circuit activity in a different manner? Can they have a different effect on the output of target neurons? What are the roles of GABAergic inter-neurons?'

Dr. M:'In general, neurons that release multiple transmitters have complex roles, because they can activate many target neurons, they can excite one or many, and they can influence many processes, or they can influence just one or two.'

Dr. B:'How would you separate inhibitory neurons from the excitatory ones? Is there a reliable way? Are there ways to differentiate GABAergic neurons from excitatory neurons? What are some of these differences? How would you identify inhibitory neurons? What are their roles? How do inhibitORY neurons interact with their target cells? How do they contribute to network activity? Is there a way to identify them in a reliable manner? Is there a specific contribution by inhibition?'

Dr. M:'I think GABAergic interneuron activity is going to be one of the key issues, or areas that we should explore in our experimental neuroscience. GABAergic interneural activity is found in the central nervous system of most animals that have an anterior ganglia, so I think the nervous system of all animals. But it is seen in the nervous system of only some animals. And the extent to which it is found varies widely.'

Dr. B:'Is the role of GABA A  inhibition going to be different from the roles of other physiological mechanisms? In what ways? Is it different? What would we be looking at? Is it more important? Is it less important? What is the mechanism? Is it different from other modulatory mechanisms? What would we expect to find out? What would we like to learn? How would we test this? Are there any implications? How are we going to approach this?'
Dr. M:'Well, I think GABA is going to have to be studied in a variety of animals and brain regions.'

Dr. M:'The GABAergic interneuron of the crustaceon stomatogastic nervous system is one of the most well-studied cells in the animal kingdom. It is responsible for the maintenance of the rhythmic pyloric circuits of the crab, and it is also responsible for the production of the rhythmic gastric mill network that contributes to chewing in the animal.'
Dr. M:'These inhibitory neurons can be regulated to release GABA in specific circuits.'

Dr. M:'We study the dynamics of the pyloric network of the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab  Cancer borealis. We measure the time course of inhibitory synapses in the network and determine their functional significance to the network.'
Dr. B:'How is inhibition critical for circuit activity?'

Dr. M:'Ineutory neurons are one of the most interesting areas, because you're really looking at the function of the neuron and the function of the circuit. Because as we learn more about the molecular details of how neurons work, and how they are controlled by hormones, we learn more about their function. And I think that this is really important, because as we learned in biology, it's important to know the function of a neuron.'

Dr. M:'The inhibition is required to generate the phase of the network; for example, it's required to produce the pyloric rhythm. So, the inhibition is necessary to produce the phase of the pyloric network, because otherwise, the neurons would run completely into the wrong phase relative to the network. So, the phase of the entire network is dependent on the inhibition of the neurons.'

Dr. M:'I don't know what it's called, but I studied inhibitory neuron function in invertebrates, because in invertebrates they have multiple neurons, and if you look at the brain of the lobster, it has multiple neurons, and there are different neurons for sensory information and for motor functions, and there are distinct neurons for different behaviors, and so this allows you to be selective with your motor neurons, and so you can control muscles independently of the other neurons.'
Dr. B:'And that was the first time I thought of inhibitory neurons as a mechanism for brain functions, and the rest of my life, I dedicated to studying inhibitory cells and inhibitory circuits.'

Dr. M:'This was a big mystery for us, because we thought you would have to have some role to play, but when we tried to find out, we were looking for a role and we found an important role, because it turns out that the neurons themselves have an important role in how the circuit works.'
Dr. B: 'What is the function of spontaneous neural activity during development?'

Dr. M:'Oh my goodness. I wish I had thought of this. You know, my father—when I was young I loved going on hikes with my father and when we would be up in the woods or the mountains or forests, and he would be telling stories of his grandfathers who were—who were in the War of 1812 or the War of 1815 or whatever, or the Civil War.'
Dr. B:'Yeah. I mean, how did your father get these stories from his grandfathers? How did he do that?'

Dr. B:'Or the Revolution, or the War of independence in Spain. I mean, it sounds crazy, but what we were doing, or rather, what they were doing is a different thing, but the difference in the brain, right? The brain, the brain, the brain is what? The brain is the brain, it's a physical thing. But, in this case, the brain can have a function.'
Dr. M:'Exactly! Right, so what they did was they developed different systems.'

Dr. B:'That was exactly what we are saying, though, that these oscillations, these self-organizing oscillations are just one system of neural syntax, which are organized by the brain's ability to modify and change the dynamics of this system.'

Dr. M:'Right, well, that would also depend on what kind of inputs were being sent to them. So, if you were studying in Europe, for example, when you would be looking at the brain, you would be looking down at a big slab of gray tissue, you would never know what the brain was doing.'
Dr. M:'One of many.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of gamma oscillations in this process?'
Dr. M:'For that we need to look into the underlying mechanisms.'
Dr. B:'In the simplest case, a single neuron can be driven by two excitatory inputs, such that, when one input is stronger than the other, the neuron fires.'
Dr. M:'Not really. I mean there are other mechanisms at work.'
Dr. M:'I'd like to discuss this more. I know you're quite interested in this.'
Dr. B:'I'd be interested in hearing it from you as well.'

Dr. M:'The answer is obvious.  It provides a substrate for synaptic connectivity and neural circuit development. It is the means to test circuits that are not known to be functional. If there were no neural activity, synaptic connectivity would be impossible. We would not know how many synapses are present or how they are organized. And as the circuit is built it would not be possible to determine which neurons are active and which ones are silent, even though it would be possible to test the functionality of each neuron.'
Dr. M:'The nervous system grows. It gets larger and bigger, but its connectivity doesn't grow proportionally to it, right?'
Dr. B:'Not quite. I mean, what is the function of connectivity?'
Dr. M:'It's really hard to say. It can't all be done in the development phase. It's hard to say.'

Dr. B:'But you say the connectivity of the brain is very important. Do you say that because you know, it will be connected, and you will be able to work it all out later? Or, do you say that because that's the way it is?'

Dr. M:'I guess the function of connectivity is that it's flexible and it's a property of the nervous system. And so there are neuromodulators and other substances that are released from all different kinds of cells in the central nervous system and they can act on many, many neurons. And then if you look at how the circuits function, how the neurons communicate with each other, it's very flexible.'
Dr. B:'Why are the neurons active in the first place? Are they under the control of the brain in any way? Are they independent of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Spontaneous activity during development creates neurons that have a characteristic shape or size; neurons that have a more characteristic shape or size tend to be more efficient. So, it seems to me that the answer is simple. Just use more efficient mechanisms. Just add more neurons, or create neurons with more efficient electrical properties.'
Dr. B:'What is the function or goal of spontaneous activity?'

Dr. M:'For some cells it produces neurons that have characteristic behaviors. For example, neurons in cardiac ganglia can produce a characteristic rhythm in response to a modulatory input. So, it's not just to create a 'random' network of neurons that's going to produce whatever behavior it has to produce; it's to build circuits with specific properties that give rise to a behavior that you want.'
Dr. B:' What role does experience play?'
Dr. M:'The function of a neuronal circuit is to collect information from its cells, to send that information to other cells, to process it, and to respond appropriately to external perturbations.'

Dr. B:'Who controls or decides the outcome? The answer is simple. Because it is simple to add more neurons, to make the neurons with more efficient properties, to add more connections and to create more efficient synapses, or to modify some properties of the neurons and connections, then the answer is simple.'
Dr. M:'We can do all that by modifying the environment that these neurons are subjected to. So, my point is that neurons with a different shape will have a different shape.'
Dr. B:'But who is controlling that? That would be a different kind of answer, and a more complex one.'
Dr. B:'What is the function(s) of spontaneous neural activity in the adult brain? What is the function of the various brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'I was interested in this question. So, many years ago, before we had much good neurochemical data about neuromodulators and neurotransmitters, and how the circuits worked, and how many synapses they had, and how they connected to each other, I read a paper about how the pacemaker kernel of the heart was regulated by the rhythmic activity of the muscles.'

Dr. B:'What is the function for a specific pattern of activity? For example, sleep spindles in the hippocampus. They're very large amplitude, irregular population bursts in the local field potential, and they are extremely prevalent in early development. What function is this? Or spontaneous neural activity at any other time?'

Dr. M:'Well, again, we have a situation that involves complex interactions of various mechanisms that are differentially regulated. So, I think you are going to have to take into account the developmental changes that have gone on, and see if there are regulatory mechanisms that control these mechanisms. So, you might be able to use that as a general principle to get some sense, but it certainly will not be as simple as adding neurons to get the most efficient solution.'

Dr. B:'How do neurons acquire a shape? Are they inborn or do they develop? Or what is the mechanism of change in shape? What is the genetic program that is responsible? What are the rules? So I'll start off with that because it seems to me as a simple way of giving us something to work with. So, what is the genetic program for a neuron? What is the neuronal code? What are the neuronal syntax?'
Dr. M:'Right. So, what we know is that every neuron is very closely related, so is it that the neurons themselves are born with their neuronal morphology? Or do they develop?'

Dr. M:'We're just beginning to understand these function principles. We have ideas about how neurons respond to different stimuli, and we have ideas about how they respond to different patterns of activity. So, this is a work that's in progress. We've learned from studies of animals in the early days of neuroscience, about the importance of being patient with experiments that are going to take many years to solve.'

Dr. M:'Well, if it's a spindle, that would be a very good function for this. I'm not sure why they are present in development. Why they occur as a sort of a common type of activity, not an occasional type of activity. I think the answer might have something to do with how neurons are produced in development.'

Dr. B:'How are they produced? What is the mechanism for producing them? Do they form a self-generated network, or do they rely on an external input, for example, sensory input? How do we know? Are there neurons that are dedicated to produce these events? What is the function of the neuron? What is the job of the neuron? How does the neuron produce its action? What is the action of the neuron?'
Dr. M:'It seems to me it is important. The function of neural activity may not become evident for quite a while after an animal is born.'
Dr. B:'Why is it important?'

Dr. M:'Why are the networks different in the animal? Why are different animals different? Why do they respond differentially to external perturbations? There are different neurons in different animals and different kinds of neurons. So this may require the ability to differentiate, or to discriminate, or to respond to different stimuli.'

Dr. B:'What about genetic? What about a particular protein, for example, in the brain? What happens to it in the absence of external stimuli? Does it become a particular pattern or a different pattern?'
Dr. M:'I don't think that has been worked out either.'

Dr. B:'But there are some fundamental issues. How do the different circuits become different? And are these circuits genetically fixed? How do these circuits interact with each other? Are they self-organizing? If not, can they be affected by external stimuli? And are they ever modified by external stimuli? How are these circuits changed by external stimuli? Can the animal acquire these circuits? Is there a mechanism or an ability to change circuits?'

Dr. M:'But to some extent you may be asking the wrong question because you are looking for an answer that is biologically plausible. I mean, when we first started studying animal-to-animal differences we were told there are different animals with different brains and that this is important because this creates variability, right? So, if you are asking the right questions, you may be going to discover that these differences are critical because if you ask the right questions you may discover that they are important for some fundamental biological principle.'

Dr. B:'So, for example, it turns out that it is very difficult to change the color of a neuron. But if you go to a different brain structure, the hippocampus, it's much easier to change the color. So, it's not only a difference in function, but a difference in function is a change in function. So this is a fundamental difference. And so these differences, whether they are in wiring and the biophysical properties of neurons, are very important, I agree with you.'

Dr. B:'Why do we do the things in our brain which are not immediately useful, like dreaming, sleep, eating and drinking, just to name a few? How about our most creative states, which we call our 'off-line' states? What is the function of those states? And by the way, there are many more states than we have thought about before.'

Dr. M:'There are more states of consciousness than we know. That is correct. And we think that because we are trying to discover the mechanisms underlying some fundamental problems. We are trying to understand what the human brain is, and in particular the human brain has evolved very, very rapidly, and we have thought that we would be able to find the answers for those kinds of problems with a lot of patience.'
Dr. B:'Do you think this is a fruitful approach?'

Dr. M:'Yes. We don't have all the answers, but it's been a good way to think about it, and I don't think that we would have arrived at the answer any other way. So, you know, you try to understand the function of a cell, of a circuit, of a brain, and in the brain we have neurons, and they are called circuit neurons, neurons that are connected in specific sets of neurons.'

Dr. M:'I'm not saying that, but I think it will be useful. The other approach would be to say we need to understand the fundamental mechanisms of neural circuitry and the brain, that the human brain is a very special kind of brain, and we need to understand how human brains have evolved, and by definition, evolution is going to change them.' So that you're going to have to, you know, change a little bit to understand the fundamental principles. We're still working on that.'
Dr. B:'Is the brain the best metaphor for the mind?'

Dr. M:'Well, maybe there are two functions of neural activity, one of the neural circuits that are active in the moment, and then another function for the other parts of the brain. For example, your heart and your muscles might be activated because they are needed to move something in the body, but if that neural circuit doesn't work because it is not receiving its normal electrical input from the nerves, your heart and muscles can't work for themselves.'

Dr. B:'What is the relationship between neural circuits and brain rhythms? Can we say that brain rhythms are responsible for organizing the activity of the neural circuits? In other words, can we say that brain-generated patterns are responsible for the organization of neural activity?'

Dr. M:'I'm not sure we can. But we might be able to say that there are neural circuits that are the only ones that are active in a particular brain-pattern, and then there are other neural circuits that are either active at very low frequency but can be triggered by other brain-patterns at higher frequencies, or that are only part of that network, so they are not active for their entire lifetime.'

Dr. B:'Now, how long is that time period? When we say that brain activity can organize the activity of neural circuits in that short time period, what are we talking about? The time period that has been described by the "slow" oscillation or "hippocampal theta." I'm looking for more answers, but perhaps you can tell me a little bit more about that? And how long is that period of activity? What is the mechanism? What is it?'

Dr. M:'That is a good question, and it is really hard to put in terms that would work in general. And my favorite question is always how long can it take for a neural circuit to make a change in a single neuron or an entire network. How long can that be? And I have come to the conclusion that the answer is either infinity, or it is zero.'

Dr. B:'In other words, you can have a network of neurons that is triggered by a particular brain pattern, but this network can be very large and can have very complex properties. And so if you put a probe in that network of neurons, you will get a very different set of neurons than if you probe the network during a different state.'

Dr. M:'Okay. So what would be your thoughts about the neural circuit in your own brain? So we have these neurons that are, say, the pyloric circuit, and this circuit consists of multiple neurons. We have the pacemaker group, consisting of three different neurons, PY, PY1 and PY2.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but it seems to me that when you are born, you are born with a neural syntax. When you are born, and we are born in time, we have already a neural syntax. Now, there are things that can be called to be learned. What are these things? And how long does it take to acquire these things? What are these things that we have to learn?'
Dr. M:'Well, I don't know. I mean, one is to learn to breathe, for example, to move, and so on. We learn that as a child.'

Dr. B:'There are two aspects of learning. What you do or what you acquire, and there is the process of learning. So, I'd like to know when you have to begin to learn the syntax that is innate? What is that?'

Dr. M:'I'm not sure if I completely understand your question. And I think you want to ask a bit about the role of the brain circuits, which, let's face it, you have been studying for years. And then I have been studying for several years. I was studying how the nervous system of the heart works. So I worked on heart, spinal cord and brain. But the brain was not really the focus of my work. So you are asking me about brain circuits? About brain networks?'

Dr. B:'Exactly. Now, let me give you an example. Suppose that the brain is a tabula rasa system. In a tabula rasa system, what are the fundamental functions of the brain? There are multiple fundamental functions. For example, there are the primary functions of the brain, which are perception, action, and cognition. Of course, the system is going to have some other functions, such as emotions, language, and all these other things.'
Dr. B:'Yeah. I'm asking about the circuits that control brain dynamics in general.'

Dr. B:'I'm a neuroscientist. I'm interested in the brain. So how could you start working on this, without being a neuroscientist? And I think you have the answer to this in your book. It says that you knew about the brain. In fact, it says that you read a paper by Marder and you had already the idea of the brain as a series of rhythms. You already knew about Marder's work in the 1970s.'

Dr. M:'Right, right, right. I had seen some of his work as I was starting graduate school. I had seen his work. But not in detail, in detail. It is a huge topic, because you see, when we think about how the brain works, we think about single neurons, single circuit units, and how these units work. And then there are circuits of neurons that can work together to produce some cognitive or behavioral function.'

Dr. B:'That's how we approach things in science. And I think this is the way that the brain comes to us. I agree. We go from the simple to the complex, or we go from the complex to the simple. Now, what is the fundamental unit of the brain? So here's my answer to that question. There are these rhythms that you describe in your book, that you already knew about.'
Dr. M:'Yes, yes.'

Dr. M:'It depends on the stage of development. During early stages of development, the nervous system is not functional. The neurons are passive with little to no synaptic connections, and they can only express genes.'

Dr. B:'So this is a window of opportunity. What are the conditions? Do these conditions match the current brain states? Or, should we change the conditions to match? In other words, how should I approach this? Or should I look at it differently?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's a little bit different, because at that stage of development, the neurons have a huge influence over each other. For example, during early embryonic stages, the neurons are not necessarily identical. The neurons that are present in the nervous system might be different, but that is a consequence of their own history as cells. And even later in development, during larval stages, the neurons will become functionally distinct in response to ongoing neuromodulation.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibition? Do the right conditions match with the current inhibition? Or should we change the inhibition? In other words should I approach this differently?'

Dr. M:'In the case of larval stages, in most species, the inhibitory neurons are also different. There are multiple neurons that send their inhibitory synaptic inputs to the soma of the neuron. In the case of the lobster, for example, the PD neuron is a separate neuron that sends inhibitory inputs to the somata, but it does not affect the action potential firing in the soma.'

Dr. M:'We are always learning, because when you start looking at how the nervous system is developed, you see that you will always need to change the current state of the nervous system to maintain certain features. That is because during development, the nervous systems always need to change. The only question is, can you maintain certain behaviors or certain features over a lifetime? In other words what is it like in the adult? Can you have a nervous system that is robust to neuromodulation?'
Dr. B:'Is there a single neuron in the brain that is responsible for the generation of a sequence of neuronal messages? If so, what are the conditions? Or, should I look at this differently?'
Dr. M:'I don't know.'

Dr. B:'Well, what is the point of learning the syntax of neural activity if it doesn't have a useful function? We spend most of our life developing a brain and we are born with a brain, but we are born with no function and we spend our time developing a function. What if we go the other way around? What if our brain learns how to generate a syntax that we can use to generate a function? I don't know. What would the brain do?'
Dr. M:'Well, if we were to just do a simple experiment, I'd just ask my patients what the function of their brains is.'
Dr. B:'Yeah, let's do that.'

Dr. M:'And I'd look them in the eye, and I'd say, 'What function of your brains?' So I would say 'How does your brain generate thoughts? What is your brain doing?' And then they'd say, 'Well, I don't know, well, I don't really know how it is.' So, I think we'd all know how we work the brain, and how we produce thoughts.'
Dr. B:'So my brain has syntax and produces thought. I'm an expert in this.'
Dr. M:'No you are, yes.'
Dr. B:'Do you do this? Do you ask your patients what the function is?'

Dr. M:'Yes, and most of the time they don't know, they don't know what it is and they just tell you a number, they tell you a number and then you ask them, you ask them a simple question and you say, 'What is the maximum and minimum numbers that you can do with your fingers?', for example.'
Dr. B:'So the brain will tell you a number.'
Dr. M:'That's all they will tell you.'
Dr. B:'Now, what if you ask them, what is the maximum and what is the minimum, what if you have a brain, right?'
Dr. M:'It's essential for nervous system development.'
Dr. B:'Why is it so critical? I'm curious.'

Dr. M:'Well, you see, because you develop your brain as you develop your nervous system. Your nervous system develops as you grow, you are growing your brain. Your brain is growing as you grow, and it's important that you develop the nervous system as your brain grows and develops. So, there are many brain rhythms that arise from activity in small groups of neurons.'
Dr. M:'Oh it's very important. It's what allows you to control the kind of synaptic interactions that you're gonna have between the neurons as you're growing up.'
Dr. B:'But how would you explain it? What is it good for?'
Dr. M:'I know I don't know. It's good for controlling the kind of synaptic connections that you get.'
Dr. B:'And how do you explain that? What is it? What is its function?'
Dr. M:'Maybe you'll find out.'
Dr. M:'Well that's why I'm saying it's a mystery that we don't completely understand, because it's not in our model. So why does it exist? And, it's very difficult to say.'
Dr. B:'What is the utility of a brain without the brain? I'm just curious because it seems very inefficient.'

Dr. M:'That is a very interesting question. What happens if you don't keep the network, but you can change the parameters that govern its behavior? What happens to the network? It can be used, can be used for different purposes, can be activated, can be activated to produce an activity that is different from that which it is initially intended to produce.'
Dr. B:'What are those possibilities? What would be the functional consequences of a neural network with different parameters?'

Dr. M:'Let's take an example: a small network that is normally silent. If it is kept in a silent state, that can be used as a decoder that will be able to recover lost data or information. You can use it as a recording device or as a control device. This is an example of a neural network that can be kept as is, and it can be turned on and off.'

Dr. M:'There are several functions. There are important functions in the development of the circuits in which the activity is generated. That function has to do with the fact that the networks that are produced in this process will have their properties. One of the points we were trying to make in the paper we've discussed a bit is that these networks that are generated spontaneously have properties that allow them to develop.'

Dr. B:'Why is this important? I'm not necessarily asking you to elaborate on a specific function. Just tell me your answer to the question that I'm asking: What is the function of activity in the brain during development? Is it just to develop the brain? Is it just for building up the brain? Is there a difference? What does it do that isn't just building up? Let's say during development, how does the activity of the circuits contribute to function?'

Dr. M:'Right. Well, I think what happens is the networks that are built up during the development of the brain, are built in a way that is more sensitive to synaptic connectivity and synaptic dynamics than networks that are more mature. As a consequence of that, if a neuromodulator comes along and then changes a network in some way that produces, then it's going to change the activity of the network to reflect that new network.'

Dr. B:'What I'm asking is what is the function of these spontaneous patterns of activity that are generated? What is the function? Is it just development? Or is there a difference? In your words, what does it do that's not just development? What is the activity in the brain that has to do with function?'

Dr. M:'Well, I mean, I think that the point of our paper is really to illustrate that these networks have different properties in a mature brain. The other point, for a mature brain is that it will respond differently to perturbations. As a consequence, the networks that can respond appropriately, if they get perturbed, can maintain stable function.'

Dr. B:'That is important. So the functions that are the focus of this work, the spontaneous patterns of activity, do they serve as a sort of a blueprint for the activity in the adult brain? Are there any particular examples where the network patterns in a developing brain show a function? I'm asking, but just tell me that. What is that function? So, what's that function that the activity patterns that occur during development have? Is it just building up? Is it just growing?'
Dr. B:'So, what are some of these properties?'

Dr. M:'Well, one of the points we wanted to make is that the networks that emerge spontaneously are likely to have some properties that will allow them to be successful in the circuit that they're going to be interacting with.'

Dr. B:'But there is no guarantee that these properties will produce something useful for the brain. Are there any guarantees that any given property will bring about useful circuits for the brain? Is it a random process or, in other words, is it a black-box or a white-box process?'
Dr. M:'I was wondering why we were interested in these studies.'

Dr. M:'There are multiple functions. First, in the developing brain the brain has to generate and maintain enough intrinsic excitability to allow neuromodulators to have an effect on the circuit. In the adult, the modulatory influence on the circuit can be very strong, as well. So, the developmental period in which the neuron has to maintain a certain level of excitability is really important. And then the question is why are these networks developed in the first place? That is the most basic question.'

Dr. B:'Well, it seems there are many functions that could be accomplished by the activity that is generated in the developing brain.
