I guess, one of the things I can say is that the activity that we see in the fetus, in utero, may not necessarily be the same thing that we have to explain and understand as adults, but that's another issue.'

Dr. M:'I think the important thing is that we're going to try to explain the development of circuit function using all of our existing tools, the existing techniques that we're developing in our labs and are using to understand circuit function. In some sense, we're going to make this a little bit of a bridge between what happens during development and the understanding of the brain as we understand it today. So, that will come up when you talk about development.'

Dr. B:'So, let's talk about development. And then we can talk about why the brain functions the way it does. I'm just, I'm, I'm, you know, I'm the moderator here, but I'm the person who has more questions to ask you than you have to answer. That's a joke, but the answer, um, I'm the person to ask you because you are, um, one of the smartest people in this field. I have no doubt about that.'
Dr. B:'I have no idea what you're doing, but that's an interesting idea. I like it.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, I don't know whether I'll be doing this one, either. Because it's an interesting question, but there are lots of questions that might be interesting.'

Dr. B:'It seems like an important topic because it would give us a nice start to work on. I've wondered about how we would go about explaining development to our kids. So, let's start there. I'll start with the issue of why and you'll start with the development.'

Dr. M:'So, development is the most basic function of the developing brain and of the nervous system, of the nervous system. And then, the function that we're trying to understand is the function that the brain produces during development, that the brain develops during development. And this is kind of how we're going to take that question forward and try to look at the brain as it develops, because development is the most mysterious aspect of the brain.'

Dr. B:'What is the function that developing brains are responsible for? The function, of course, that you are asking about is the question about the function. And the function is the same as the function of developed circuits in the mature brain. And this is how we're going through the problem. What is the function that is being produced in developing brains? And how does that connect to the function that is produced in the mature brain?'

Dr. M:'Right. So, you know, development in this sense is going to be a bridge between what is happening in the brain, what is happening in development and then the study of brain function. So, this is kind of going to be a model of what we might see if you were studying how the brain functions as it develops. In some sense.'

Dr. M:'Well, there are two important functions. One, it provides the developmental substrate for neuronal connectivity. Secondly, it provides the basis for neuromodulation during development. Neuromodulation is essential for many of the important biological processes that occur during development, particularly during times when the brain is changing. When neural circuits are changing during development, when neurons are being re-wired during development, then neuromodulation is very important.'

Dr. B:'How is this neuromodulation, which is a development-dependent phenomenon, essential for brain function? And how does this work? Do we have some evidence that it is? If so, how does this help us with the fundamental question of how to understand how spontaneous activity of the brain is utilized to perform functions?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. This is really the first question I would ask you, in a way, because we have learned a lot about how neural circuits work. We have learned a lot of the properties of individual neurons. The neurons and the networks they are part of are changing during development. The networks are changing because neurons change during development, and the circuits are changing because of the way in which neurons are changing.'

Dr. B:'What would the best strategy be for us to understand how development of the brain supports function? Is there one thing that we should be doing to help the field advance, or would that be a foolish strategy? How would I approach this question if you were to ask me?'

Dr. M:'It's critical for establishing connectivity. For example, neurons that have synaptic connections at the embryonic stage will express synaptic receptors that enable them to be properly influenced by the neurotransmitters released by other neurons and other neurons that connect them, and will express the appropriate transcription factors that enable the neuron to express synaptic receptors and synaptic transporters. And so the same neurons that contribute to the establishment of connectivity will then be part of the circuitry that is necessary for ensuring proper behaviour throughout development.'

Dr. B:'If one asks the question a little differently, perhaps the function of spontaneous activity in the brain is to allow it to be developed without having to put a lot of effort on its behalf, and allow it to connect to other brains. Or the function of spontaneous and spontaneous activity is to link the brain with the environment.'

Dr. M:'The function is to be there for the circuit. It allows it to become robust, so it becomes stable. You know, if you're going to live with another person, you don't want to be there when they're going to be angry, because it can create problems.'
Dr. B:'It is an internal process. What is the difference between an internal process and external process? Can you give me a concrete example?'
Dr. M:'Well, when you walk down the street, you don't need to go through this complicated process that allows you to find out when somebody's going to run you over. You know?'

Dr. B:'There is a simple answer to that, isn't there? If you have an internal mechanism that you can build, that can give you an answer as to when is the best time to run. Dr. M:'Oh, well, I don't think the brain can be the only mechanism that decides when you're going to walk down the street. I think you need other mechanisms, too.'
Dr. B:'So what mechanisms do you use for such a process?'
Dr. M:'I think it's called a 'gut instinct'. But what I'm going to do is I'm going to show you a picture, which is the most famous picture that's been published.'
Dr. B:'So you want to create problems for it.'
Dr. M:'Yeah. Right. You want to get it to do things that you don't want it to do.'
Dr. B:'It can make it a weapon, it can make it a threat.'
Dr. M:'You want it to be there in all the right ways.'

Dr. M:'It's not bad enough.'

Dr. M:'No, you want to create a set of conditions in which your behavior is going to be reliable.'

Dr. B:'I'm saying, what's the function of that? That's the function is that it helps it to become stable. You have to work together to keep it stable. You know, what is the function? That's what I'm asking.'

Dr. M:'Right, but I think it's possible that the function is different from one person to another, and you're not going to want that same behavior from two different people, right? That's going to be hard.'

Dr. B:'Exactly. Exactly. So the answer is to be reliable, to be there, that's the function, right? That allows it to become stable, to be there when your behavior is going through certain stages. And so in order to do that, I'm going to be angry. You don't want to get into those situations. And so on. That's the function of it. That's the benefit. And so there are many cases where you want to create things for that reason.'
Dr. M:'You want to be there, because then you can take the control. You know, you can't do anything you want all the time. So you want to be there to control the circuit.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, but it also allows it to be there when you need it.'

Dr. B:'Now, let me ask you about the timing of the responses, because you're talking about neural syntax, and it's hard to predict when the right moment is when I'll get a good answer because this is very broad. How does a system become stable? Is there a good time window? Are there some events that occur at some critical phase in development?'
Dr. B:'And what's the mechanism that allows the brain to do that?'

Dr. M:'I think it's mainly synaptic homeostatic regulation, because you want to have the balance. You don't want to have too much, and you don't want too little, because the neurons can overactivate or overpolarize and give rise to a variety of behaviors that are just not desirable.'
Dr. B:'So the problem is the excessive activity at the right or the left ends of the spectrum, but there is a middle ground, where the brain is able to keep things stable. Is that right?'

Dr. M:'Well, yes. I mean, we think about, you know, if you put neurons on a scale, and say, "Well, they're going to fall at the extremes," like there's going to be too much activity, or there's going to, there's going to too little activity, you know, or, you know, the other way around, like there's going there, or there's not enough.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's a long-standing puzzle, because when you think about these brain circuits, if you think about them in terms of simple electrical networks, a circuit is just a chain of voltage-gated conductances, and if you imagine a voltage-gated channel in one compartment and another in another, you can see that in theory a circuit can be made up of a chain of voltage gated conductances. But the brain doesn't behave like that.'
Dr. B:'How does it behave?'

Dr. M:'It behaves in a very robust way. Because it's got neurons and neurons that do not change with respect to each other. For example, in my lab we do a study of the pyloric circuit, and we take a large group of pyloric neurons.'
Dr. B:'Well, do they have voltage-gated channels? And if so, can they be driven by the neurotransmitter that activates a voltage-gating channel? Are they part of a feed-forward network?'
Dr. B:'What does it do? What's the function of the network?'

Dr. M:'It's been studied for a long time and it's been studied using many different tools, because in the simplest sense, you know, what we study in most systems is a network of cells. You want a cell to be able to go one way and another, and you know, in principle there are many different solutions to that problem.'

Dr. B:'So, what's the best? What is the best mechanism that allows the neuronal circuit to perform this function, and how can it be done? And where's the best location in the brain to do it? And what are the cell types in the brain? And what are their connections and what are their connections to each other? What are their connections to other neurons? What are the neurotransmitters that are involved? What are the types of neurotransmitters that they use?'

Dr. M:'What is the function? Well, we don't know what the function of neural activity is, because it's in the development, it's in the developing. And we think that you and me, when we were kids, we were very active, but we didn't know what it was. We didn't know how it got started, and we didn't know why, you know? And we didn't know, we just played, we played around, we played, we were active.'

Dr. B:'What do we know about the mechanisms, and when it will be known, that will be known, what the function of activity is, in order to be able to assign a function to it, a function that will be useful to us? What do we know about that? Do we know that?'

Dr. M:'The brain grows in a variety of patterns during development. You know that neurons have a number of different roles, and I think a big part of the brain is growing, and I guess this part of the brain develops as the rest of the brain.'
Dr. B:'What are these patterns? Is it a neural syntax?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, so I think maybe what the brain is doing is it is trying to find a balance between what are the different patterns that are necessary to achieve all these different kinds of cognitive functions.'
Dr. B:'How does this balance occur? What are some examples of these balancing mechanisms? What are the functions of spontaneous activity?'

Dr. M:'I think it occurs because if you are developing neurons for example you can tell that if you are developing the cortex of the brain you want neurons that are highly regulated. You want to have neurons that fire reliably, you want to have neurons in which the regulation of their firing occurs so that they can do their functions, but neurons that are regulated also can be flexible and that are adaptable. So, I think I know examples of this in the cortex.'

Dr. M:'I think you just answered it. That's right. And you've been asking this question for about 25 years. What is the function of neural activity during development? And I think you just asked a really simple question. What is the role of activity in development? So, you know, we think of neurons, neurons being active during the formation of circuits, or during development, and all the rest of it. But you asked the question that nobody really asks: What is the role?'

Dr. B:'The role is to be determined by the experimenter. It's in the interest of the experimenter to determine the role of activity. But I think it's a little bit of a mistake to say "the goal of spontaneous activity" is to be determined later. What happens is a function of activity. So, and, uh, the brain is always being active. The brain always is.'

Dr. M:'But, uh, there are different kinds of activity. There's the kind of, what is the rhythmic sort of behavior of the nervous system and brain during all of these different processes. There's the rhythmic behavior of, you know, the rhythm that's in the heart, right? Which is always going to be there. And, and then there are the rhythmic behaviors of the nervous system, that are going to be, are going to be generated.'
Dr. B:'You know, and that's always there. And the only difference is in the timing. And that's where, uh, that's where we come in.'

Dr. B:'Well, that's a hard question, because one can look at it differently. I would say, as a first possibility, that activity is a good thing, because the reason why neural activity is good is because it allows the development of the brain, as I said in the very beginning. So this activity has to be organized somehow so that it does not destroy the ability of the brain to be organized. And what is the minimum level of organization?'
Dr. M:'That's a good one. I mean, and the way in which the activity can be organized is not necessarily easy to understand, and so, how do you organize it?'

Dr. M:'Well, so I guess I would say the minimum level of activity would be just enough so that you didn't destroy the ability of your brain to be flexible enough to be able to change. To be able to change itself. Because if you get to a level of activity, that the brain is totally disrupted. But I would say the brain has to be flexible enough so that it could change itself. And I think the answer is yes.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's been known that animals that display relatively robust rhythms during embryonic development, they tend to grow faster and survive better than animals that display less stable rhythms.'

Dr. M:'When you are young, there are two neurons that are kind of 'hard-wired', neurons that are necessary for the development of the circuits. And then when you get older, you get to have more flexibility in how those circuits are going to be configured because different neurons are going to be activated for different times and for different behaviours. And then, of course, the neurons that are already there, because they need to be there for the development of your circuits, those neurons will be maintained.'
Dr. B:'What are the functions of sleep?'

Dr. M:'One of the functions of sleep is that you have to recharge your batteries. In that sense, you want to be awake when you want to recharge your batteries and be awake when you have to go to work or whatever. And also, we think that sleep plays a role in the development of the nervous system.'
Dr. B:'The brain is a complex system, with complicated dynamics. What are the fundamental rules that govern its operations?'

Dr. M:'Well, there is a series of reports of activity in the developing animal that appears to be necessary for producing the right set of network connections. The idea is that you can change the connectivity of a network by changing its behavior.'
Dr. B:'Well, how do we do that?'

Dr. M:'That is a whole series of experiments. You can do manipulations of a network, and then you can look at the properties of the network, and then, at the properties of its neurons. So I think what you are saying, is that if you think of the brain as being able to change and reconfigure itself, there are lots of experiments in the world that show that you can modify a network of neurons. You can reconfigure circuits. You can do things like changing a network.'
Dr. B:'Are there any other examples?'
Dr. B:'You could modify a network by altering connectivity, or altering the biophysical properties of its neurons.'

Dr. M:'We're not asking what neural function is, we're asking what its role is for learning in evolution. When it comes to neural function, I think the first thing to ask is what a function is. I mean, a function is a definition that we give to a set of equations, you know, a set of equations is just a bunch of numbers. And they might be, you know, they might be arbitrary numbers.'

Dr. M:'Well, in the developing organism there's a kind of a 'crash course' that occurs during early development. The brain is growing all kinds of neurons that are going to be very important during the lifetime of the animal, and neurons that are going be important for the maintenance of homeostatic regulation mechanisms, so that all of these different networks, their behaviors, their properties will be constrained by those of the other networks and that sort of regulation will take place.'

Dr. B:'What is the function that is to be maintained by regulation? And what is the function that, uh, requires regulation? I know that the answer is very complicated to give, and it requires a whole new approach that I do not have, but I do have some ideas about how to try to understand this, and my goal is to convince the reader that the answer is that, uh, there is an important thing to be maintained, that we can understand, that is what the function is.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, exactly.'

Dr. B:'So in terms of, uh, homeostatic regulation and maintenance, what is that? And what is that function? Let me see, let me see here. So let me start with a very obvious example. Let me, let me come in with an example, because then we can, uh, we can start to talk about the, the maintenance part. Uh, so let me, let me start with that.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'I have a second question: How does self-organized activity, or spontane-ously emerging patterns, influence brain development?'

Dr. M:'I think we're seeing, as you see in all biological systems, as they develop, is that neural systems, or neural networks, or circuits, they tend to go through a stage of exploration during development, in which their properties are not constrained to what the underlying mechanism is going to be. So they're finding out, you know, "We can do this. We can do that. Why is this the way it is?" Why are neurons electrically coupled? Why is that?'

Dr. M:'In the case of the gastric mill (GM) and cardiac mill (CM) ganglia, I think it is important to distinguish between the intrinsic properties of the neurons, which are crucial to their function, and the synaptic and hormonal influences that occur during development.'

Dr. B:'Are these things fundamentally different, or are they basically the same? If they are fundamentally different, what is the function of the intrinsic cellular properties? In other words, what are their main function? They could have a different function, but what is the best guess? I mean, it would be the same as the best guess if we are in doubt.'

Dr. M:'There are important differences. I would say one difference is that they are both rhythmically active, so they are in the same category. But another difference is that the gastric mill neuron is part of the gastric- mill network. And the gastric mill network is part of the circuit. So the gastric mill neurons are not isolated neurons that function as individuals. So I don't think it is the same as the gastric mill in terms of the importance of the intrinsic properties.'

Dr. B:'So what is the function that is provided by the intrinsic cellular properties in GMs? In other words what is the function in the brain that is provided by GMs? What is the function in GMs, if any, that is provided by CM neurons? So, what is the answer to the question, which is the function in brain that is provided or supported by these intrinsic cellular properties in the neurons?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think this is a good example. In the first place I don't think there is any single function. But the gastric mill rhythm is essential for chewing and breaking up food. So it is an essential part of cognition. You know, it is a part of the brain. But it is also essential for chewing of food in other animals, so we just don't eat meat. I mean, we don't eat lobster. So that is a function.'

Dr. B:'You are right. I meant the intrinsic firing properties of the neurons. The brain is a closed system with its own self-sustained activity. It does not need any inputs, as long as there are sufficient nutrients in the brain. However, a fundamental problem with this framework is that it leaves out a large fraction of the brain, and even if this is done to include all neurons, it would be difficult to explain how the functions they perform emerge.'

Dr. M:'You are talking about synaptic interactions and hormones. They are all important in development. You need them all. So, in the case of gastric mill (GMC) neurons it is important to understand how these neurons emerge from gastric mill neuron neurons that have already existed for hundreds of millions of years. So the gastric mill neuron is really old. The gastric mill neuron itself was probably even older.'

Dr. B:'Exactly. And this is where the fundamental difference between brain circuits and software circuits comes. I have an example in my lab, a cortical circuit, where this happens. The circuit is made up of interconnected neurons, which can be readily described by just the properties of their connections. But once you know the function of the circuit you can imagine that it is a program that allows the circuit to be able to function. That is, the same circuit can be implemented in different ways that can serve different functions.'

Dr. M:'And that's interesting because when you look at the neural network that exists in the stomach, it's like a software system because there are many many neurons in it. And so we can imagine, as we develop a gastric mill circuit, what the gastric mill circuit would be like as software that we are building. It would be like software that can be built from a few neurons, which are interconnected, and then you could build more complex things with this.'

Dr. M:'This is why we do not really understand how the brain does it, because it's a hard problem to study, particularly in the case of the developing brain. For instance, it is extremely difficult to be sure of what activity of a neuron that is still forming as it is supposed to be developing. I think it is interesting that you have just pointed out that neural systems have their own self-regulating mechanisms to maintain constant activity, and I think that is absolutely the case in the developing brain.'

Dr. B:'Are there neurons that are only active at certain times of the day? If so, how do we understand how they form, because when we look at the development of the brain, we always look at the activity of individual neurons, because they have their own self regulating mechanisms to maintain constant firing activity.'

Dr. M:'Yes. Of course neurons and their electrical properties change as they are stimulated by modulators, such as serotonin or dopamine. There are neurons that change their properties in response to neuromodulation. There are also neurons, as you said, that maintain constant activity as they mature, and I think it's important to distinguish between them.'
Dr. B:'This is an interesting point.'

Dr. M:'So when we go back to your point about the intrinsic properties, the properties of the neurons themselves, there is no way to be sure that a neuron that is not stimulated by the inputs that are put in to it is really going to fire. But it is interesting that it turns out that some neurons that are active in the adult brain can behave completely differently during development.'

Dr. B:'I mean, it's possible that the same neurons have a different type of self-regulation in response to different patterns of activity, but it's also possible that in response to different inputs, these neurons behave differently. For example, it's possible for a specific type of input to induce an increased activity in one type of neuron, whereas other neurons, responding to the same input, are inhibited.'

Dr. M:'I think this is an interesting point, because you could imagine that neurons and neurons would have distinct types of self-regulating capabilities, and the brain may need to be able to cope with changes in input that are occurring over long timescales, or changes in the dynamics of the network.'

Dr. B:'We have to be able to understand how these self-regulating properties arise in the developing brain in order to understand how the self-regulation of the mature brain takes place. If, for instance, the self-regulation arises from genetically controlled changes in gene expression, that would give us clues about how the self-regulatory properties arise in the mature brain.'

Dr. B:'It is important to distinguish, also, between the intrinsic properties and the synaptic and modulatory effects of neurons. The importance of these two functions is that they are often conflated in the discussion of how to proceed in the study of neural networks. If you are talking about the function of synaptic activity, it may be important to distinguish between a simple synaptic effect and a complex one such as long-term potentiation or depression.'

Dr. M:'Long-term Potentiation and Depression, or even complex, long-lasting synaptic interactions, such as those that occur between many GM neurons, or that are involved in the generation of GM rhythms.'
Dr. B:'What is the function? Is it an electrical process that affects synaptic strength or is it a biochemical process that affects the intrinsic properties of neurons?'
Dr. M:'That's a good question.'

Dr. B:'If you are talking about GMs, how are they used? It seems that they are used to communicate with a very large group of neurons, but the GM rhythm is a relatively slow rhythm, and this appears to have been a relatively weak mechanism for communication in the brain. How would you see them? Can you come up with an example? How would they interact with other oscillations? If you are talking, instead, about the CM neurons, is the CM rhythm a good mechanism for communication?'
Dr. M:'No, the CM neurons appear to be used to communicate with the entire body. This is not true for the GM neurons.'

Dr. B:'I suppose that there is a big difference between the frequency of the oscillation and the duration of the postsynaptic effects of long-term potentiation and depression. The long-term potentiating effect lasts for hours, whereas the depression effect is a rapid change of synaptic strength over a period of a few minutes. Is this correct? It would be interesting if we were to know what causes the long-term potenti-ation, but what causes the depression, and we can compare them.'
Dr. M:'For example, we now realize that synaptic depression is important because it allows a neuron to recover from being stimulated at a high frequency.'

Dr. B:'The reason for this is that the synapse will either strengthen or weaken based on whether the neuron receives NMDA receptors or not. As well, NMDA receptors are a well-studied and well-understood family of receptors that are responsible for many, many things in the brain, including synaptic depression. What happens to NMDA receptors when the neuron is stimulated? Does synaptic depression occur or not?'

Dr. M:'It can occur, and the most interesting thing, in a lot of these systems, is that many of the mechanisms that we find are very important for understanding development occur during development itself. This is the case with the NMDA receptor system, because the fact that synaptic depression is seen in the development of neurons of the same type as those in mature animals provides clues about how a neuron can change during development.'
Dr. B:'In my question I was specifically asking about what functions, in particular, are attributed to spontaneous activity of neurons during development.'

Dr. M:'And I think that's a very important point. I mean, if you are looking at the gastric mill and cardiac mill circuits, it's possible to think that they are a very complex network of neurons. Because all of them have multiple roles. So, even the ones that may not be responsible for a behavior at that particular time, may be important for developing and for developing the behavior of an animal.'

Dr. B:'And so there is an important distinction between spontaneous activity in the circuits and the activity of the circuit. I have never heard anyone say that the spontaneous activity in a circuit is important. They all point to the activity of the circuits. And that is important because the activity of the network can be very sensitive to the external stimuli. And these are very powerful signals.'

Dr. B:'In the case when there are other, more complex rhythms, I think it's important to emphasize that, even in the absence of the dominant oscillation, these networks can be controlled by inputs and respond to perturbations.'

Dr. M:'You mean, as in the case of the STNS in C. borealis. This is a relatively simple system, because these animals have relatively few neurons. But they have more than 100 different, well-defined neurons, and some of them, of course, are intrinsic properties. But there are also synaptic and hormonal and neuromodulatory influences that are important to the development of these systems. And all of these have been studied.'

Dr. B:'What is the function and role of intrinsic oscillations? I know you have studied these in many laboratories, and there is not just a "one-for-the-book" answer. But it seems to me that you're looking at it from a broader perspective. What is it's function and role in the brain?'

Dr. M:'There are two answers to your question, I think. First of all, this is the natural state of all nervous systems, and is necessary for neuronal development. So, I think there is a role for these networks in that way. It's like a physiological condition, that when they go back into adulthood, these animals are very well-balanced, and all of their physiological properties are maintained. So, in the absence of a significant perturbation, these networks are stable.'

Dr. B:'But that could also be their function. It could be an important part of their function, their role in the brain. What is the role of the network and its activity in the brain? Again, I want to ask you this question from a broader perspective.'

Dr. M:'That is one answer, which I'm trying to think of. Maybe we're asking the wrong question. Maybe we're not asking, like, "What is the purpose of neurons in the brain?" It's kind of what you've already started, like, "Do we think the brain requires them to be stable? Is that their function?" I guess it might be.'

Dr. B:'We have a few studies in which we see the importance of intrinsic activity, the ability of neurons to act without any synaptic input or hormonal influences. Dr. B:'I am in favor of the brain's ability to function without the presence of external influences.'

Dr. M:'I believe that, yeah, that it is very important, that all animals develop in a kind of a natural context. Dr. B:'Yes, yes, so what we do know is that there is a time that these things are already available, a time when these things are already there, in the brain, but you don't know how they're organized, because it is in an undifferentiated brain state.'
Dr. M:'So you mean that the brain can have neurons that are different from each other, and that they're different in their properties or in the pattern of the interactions among them?'

Dr. B:'So I'm going to have to disagree with this, because this was the point that I was going to make, that the ability of the brain to respond in a natural context is a product of our evolutionary history as a brain-based species.'
Dr. B:'It is important to understand the physiological, biophysical, developmental basis of oscillations that are related to cognitive function.'

Dr. M:'What we are trying to understand is how different circuits come together, how they are regulated during development, how they are affected by changes in the environment, and to what extent these networks and the underlying synaptic and circuit elements may be plastic.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible to summarize your position on the role of oscillations? Is it possible to summarize the role of oscillatory activity in the developing brain? How would it look like, and how would you summarize it, and what would you be able to explain to a curious person? What is the goal of this line of inquiry?'

Dr. M:'We are asking how networks that have specific circuit properties are regulated during development so that they become mature, functional, reliable systems. We're trying to understand how information is read out of the networks and how the underlying network elements are regulated, how network properties are regulated, how networks are regulated, and how the properties of a network are regulated during development.'
Dr. M:'You mean before we get our sensory organs and get into the world?'

Dr. B:'Yeah. I mean, it's a really fascinating question. And I think it's a really interesting question to answer. And it's a really hard question to answer. But I'm curious to hear your view on this. I'm really curious to hear your point of view and see if you can maybe point out some studies that you feel particularly interesting. But first of all, we have to figure out, which are the mechanisms of development.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, that's a really interesting one. I remember, this is back, this is back in the day when we used to talk about developmental plasticity. And you know, developmental plasticity, because developmental plasticity was the thing that, you know, you can do what you like, and you can be born a boy and you can be a girl. And I think we thought that was sort of important.'
Dr. B:'I would be very curious to hear your thoughts on that.'

Dr. M:'Right. I mean, I think it was a very important question. I think the answer is: it is important that we develop in this world. And I think the answer for me is that when we're children, we don't necessarily develop as we're supposed to. We don't necessarily develop in a certain way. So, we have to develop the ability to be with our family. And to interact with our friends.'

Dr. B:'That's a really interesting point of view. I'd like to hear more from you on that. What kind of a perspective are you taking? I'm really curious, I'm really curious as to your point of view. Do you want more? Do you want less?'

Dr. M:'It's an interesting question because you look at, you know, you look at this nervous system. It's incredibly complex. They're not really neurons that are specific to a neuron or specific to a circuit.'

Dr. B:'Okay. But we have to answer the question about what is the function of that biological activity? And in the case of the brain, I'm talking about the spontaneous activity of cortical networks. Dr. M:'Exactly.'

Dr. B:'Yes, you can call it pre-sensory activity. What kind of brain activity takes place in that critical period of development? What I am looking for, and what I want to know about, is what takes place in the waking brain in the absence of a sensory input or an overt action.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's fundamental to generating behaviour. But the other function, which I think we all would agree is the most important function is to generate cognitive flexibility.'
Dr. B:'So, is this the role of the brain? I mean, that's what my question is.'
Dr. M:'I don't think we know the function of the brain yet.'

Dr. B:'Well, if you do your research in mice, then, it gives you some answers, right? We can ask what we're asking is, is the function of the activity that's going on in a network. In fact, it is, in a way, even more flexible than the network generated by a hard-wired brain.'
Dr. M:'So, you're saying that the brain doesn't need to be flexible, it just needs to be stable over a long period? It can be a long period of times.'

Dr. M:'This is one of the reasons that this conversation is a little bit interesting because you're asking the question of how the brain develops, but how it functions at later times in life. Because, for example, I do neuroscience with people who are young people, they do not know the meaning of life. They don't know whether they're going to live happily ever after, whether they're going have a long, healthy life. They have no idea. You know, it's a funny question.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but I think that's where the brain is most important for developing, so that it can adapt to different things in later life, but that it can also generate behaviour in order to get by. And if that's your question, then that's one that we can approach. Is there a role in the brain of spontaneous activity in early life? It's interesting. I mean, there's just no such thing in the brain as a function.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'I think that's what we should have to focus on, and it seems so important to me that in the brain there is no such thing as a function or function, but instead there is always the possibility to adapt to situations. I mean, I think that's what the brain is always adapting to, and what happens is it makes a lot of noise and then it can adapt to that noise. It can adapt to that, right?'

Dr. M:'Exactly, it has to be generated. I think it's just a good question. You know, is it that the brain just sits there, and does its own thing, and doesn't do any special jobs, but it kind of creates these different functions for itself?'
Dr. B:'Okay, but it doesn't do anything in the world, right? It can't help us, and it can't give us anything.'
Dr. M:'No, I think it can generate behaviour, it can generate cognition. You know, because we're going to be using our brains to ask you questions.'

Dr. B:'Exactly. And there's no way that you can generate a function without doing something, right. It's very simple. It's very very simple. What is the difference? There is no difference in my brain without the activity of my brain. It's not an argument for anything, but it's simple. What are we trying to achieve? And this is where I'm very skeptical, because there is a problem.'

Dr. B:'So the brain doesn't do things just because it has a natural tendency to do them. There's a critical period that, when these things are under my control and can be altered, I'm in a better position to understand the function of it. Can you tell us a little bit about this? What does it look like? I mean, you have a very special career here. In a sense, you're a scientist like no one else.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, I feel like a scientist, and it's funny that you're talking about this, because I feel like a neuroscientist and I feel like a general scientist at the same time.'
Dr. M:'That is a really good question.'

Dr. B:'I'm gonna go with a question that's probably easy to answer, though. What is the function of the hippocampus? The hippocampus is a piece of cortex whose neurons can encode a particular type of information, which we call episodic memories, that cannot be encoded in the neocortex. The hippocampus in itself can be conceived as a large associative network. It is a circuit of circuits. It can have many functions and it can do it in two different ways.'
Dr. M:'A circuit of circuits is a very good analogy.'

Dr. B:'So what is the hippocampus good for? We have two functions of the hippocampus: it encodes and decodes the episodic memories and it generates the hippocampal theta oscillations that coordinate the encoding and decoding functions. In the hippocampus, this function is carried by theta oscillations. Theta oscillations are a product of a consortium of oscillations that includes theta at 9 hertz, slow gamma at 40 hertz and fast gamma at 60 hertz.'
Dr. M:'Which is very fast. Yeah, which is different from the other oscillations in the nervous system.'

Dr. M:' Well, the first function of the nervous system is to help us survive.' The first function of the brain, of course, is to help us control and survive. So, I think if you look at what is needed for survival, you'd want to make sure the activity of the nervous system, the brain and the spinal cord was appropriate. The function of the nervous systems is to allow us to control, regulate, and be robust.'
Dr. B:'And, how would the brain do that?'

Dr. B:' What if you are wrong? What if, for instance, my nervous system's activity is not robust enough? Or the system has to be strong, but the brain is weak? How do you explain such an observation?'

Dr. M:' You know, it's a very hard question because we know so many people who have gone to extreme extremes with their nervous systems because of neuromodulation.' And, I mean, this whole idea of being able to regulate yourself during your lifetime is an amazing thing.'

Dr. M:'During development is the moment of maturation that occurs as the nervous system undergoes the process of neurite growth and connectivity. At this point, neuronal processes grow long enough so that their intrinsic properties can become important, and you also add synaptic interactions. We don't have a precise definition of maturation, because we can only measure the responses of animals to specific stimuli.'

Dr. M:'When you're small, you're not paying much attention to things, but your brains are working all the time to keep you alive. So you see activity, but you don't know it's different from what it is when you're big.'

Dr. B:'But at some point you do know that something is going on. That's when your first thought is that somebody is looking at the screen, or that there is someone else in your brain who is talking to you.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's a kind of—it's a kind of mystery. Because you know, I think a mystery about the brain is that you know we know that neurons, neurons have their own intrinsic properties. We know that different neurons in a circuit might be specialized for a particular function. But it's also, as you know, neurons can have multiple identities and they can participate in different, uh, networks and participate in circuits with other neurons that are, uh, part of different networks.'
Dr. M:'So at some point you begin to understand that that might not be necessary.'
Dr. B:'Right. And the time when you first realize that, well, I'm the one who's talking is not a big event, but the big event is when you wake up.'
Dr. M:'Yeah. Yeah. But that first big event that you wake up is when you realize it's me that's talking.'

Dr. B:'Now, when I was a child, my parents, they had a radio. The radio is a piece of junk, but it was fun to turn the knob, press the button, and hear the operator. I had to put up with those annoying buzzing noises, but at the same time it was fun. It could be useful, or it could be dangerous, but I thought it would be fun to turn it on, or to turn it off. It was very different.'
Dr. M:'Well, yeah.'

Dr. M:'There are at least two important functions of spontaneous neural activity in developing brain. One is to ensure that the network and circuit develop appropriately. The second is to maintain the circuit at its desired functional level after the individual has reached maturity. That is very important, because, for example, we have a very strong tendency to overproduce muscle cells. If we stop the contraction of muscle cells, we are going to die.'

Dr. B:'I have a question for you. What happens in the brain when a particular part of the brain goes silent? It seems to me that it is very important to understand how the brain's response to the input is modified when a particular set of cells or a set of neural circuits goes silent. How does this response to input change?'

Dr. M:'Yes, that is very important. I am not sure that we know the answer to that question yet. I am guessing that neurons and circuits can go silent if they fail to fire, if the axonal processes or synaptic processes fail to transmit enough information, or if there is just not enough space for the neurons to fire, as well as other possibilities. There are many possibilities.'

Dr. B:'What is the reason for such a possibility? How is this caused? I mean, I have read a few experiments in recent years that seem to indicate that when the activity of one set of neurons is disrupted, the remaining cells respond with increased excitability. How do they know that the activity of the cells that are firing is somehow connected to their own activity? How can they make this relationship?'

Dr. M:'Well, it is possible that there are some underlying regulatory mechanisms that are responsible for this, that tell the neurons that it is important to respond appropriately to a given perturbation. I don't know how that regulation mechanism works.'

Dr. B:'It is very important. It is an interesting question that can be addressed. How will it be addressed? What would be the way forward to understand this? I mean, are there any studies that are already on this topic, where one can see the experimental results, the results? I have seen very few studies on this topic. There are very few studies in which they actually asked this question.'

Dr. M:'It is interesting that it occurs in both sensory systems and motor systems. What you do is you create a set of parameters that allow the nervous system to respond to environmental perturbations. And what you get is an animal that is able to respond to changes in temperature and food availability as its nervous system matures.'
Dr. B:'So it is a kind of a "self-correcting" process that allows the organism to evaluate changes in the environment, and then move in the appropriate direction.'
Dr. M:'So that is how you get a kind of homeostatic control process.'
Dr. B:'Is that the reason that the brain can't disengage from the environment too often?'
Dr. M:'It's one of the features of neural development that is often overlooked, but it's important.'
Dr. B:'When is it important? For example, during brain development?'
Dr. M:'Well, for example, if you have a developing network, that network is in a state of a constant state of homeostatic regulation that it can't really be altered in the final product.'
Dr. B:'The network is just a 'container' into which the growing brain inserts its new circuits. How does it stay a 'container' or'structure' for the brain?'

Dr. M:'Exactly! This is a very big point. We've known for years that during development neurons and networks develop synaptic connections at a rate that is significantly faster than their ability to use those connections. This means that when a neuron or network is removed from a developing brain, it needs to be able to reintegrate and function in the brain of the final product. So that's the answer to your question. This is a problem that comes up with most of the models that we have.'

Dr. B:'There's another issue that is often ignored that is, what is the function of these neuronal syntax structures? Are they useful for something? And if so, what happens if they are damaged? What would the brain do? We have no idea.'

Dr. B:'In my laboratory, we started out with these ideas from early on, which have persisted until today, that synaptic circuits are a fundamental property of the brain and that the brain's ability to change its wiring is an essential part of brain development. These two things had to be confronted, because one would like to understand the origin and nature of these circuit connections and how they can become dynamic and how they can be reconfigured to meet a specific goal.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, the problem is that when you start looking at development of, like neurons and circuits, and neurons, and they get established into the brain. Then that network is already established and it's just developing its own regulatory patterns in terms of, like neurons, and it can't be altered. So, the only place where you can change regulation of these neurons is from some other component of the network.'

Dr. B:'And the only component is some other neuron or glia, which can be altered by some other component, but what happens to be the other component? The two parts of the network, or the two sides of the brain, are really never ever ever ever disconnected. They are constantly intertwined. And the way they are linked is not by some physical interconnect, but it's actually by a mechanism that allows for constant and rapid communication.'
Dr. M:'So that is how it can keep the structure, but how can it maintain structure when there are always ongoing changes and development and growth?'

Dr. B:'But this is what I mean when you say it's a state of constant regulation. There are some states that are hard to get out of because you have to go through a long process of trying to get out of those states, and some are really just there forever, but it takes a very long time to get out of them.'

Dr. B:'What is this? I mean, it's a question that has an answer to be given to every single one of us, every single time we wake up in the morning. Every single time, every single time, this question is raised, it has an answer. But I want to know from the neuroscientists what is it?'

Dr. M:'I'm really interested in this. The nervous system has a number of features which I'm interested in understanding. It's a complex system of interacting neurons with their connections that change over development. I'm interested in how the interactions between neurons and the synaptic connections change over development and how we can study that. The nervous system is highly modulated, so the question then becomes how do you manipulate the activity of the nervous system to change the function of neurons?'

Dr. B:'Are there different ways to manipulate the activity of neurons? Is there one way to manipulate neurons? Are there different ways to make neurons fire? I have a different question. What is the function of the firing patterns of neurons during development? What is the function and mechanism of neuronal syntax, which is the mechanism by which neural information is organized? How do neurons segment information? What is the mechanism of communication between neurons in the brain?'

Dr. B:'Let me take an example. In early development, the activity of a neuronal assembly in the hippocampus is organized by two major oscillations: theta and sharp wave ripples. How does that evolve? I think the answer is the same, how do you do it? Well, there are different ways of doing it.'

Dr. M:'So what you're interested in is how a set of neurons change over development, how networks change over development. And that's really what the main thing that I'm interested in, is just understanding how neurons and networks change over development.'

Dr. B:'You're right. And the way that you manipulate neuronal activity at any particular point of development would be the same, so to speak, the same way in the brain. What happens when you put your finger on a target region and you manipulate the activity there at a particular point in development? That is the question.'

Dr. M:'That would be fascinating. I like to think about how neurons and networks develop as well, because I think the way that we think about how neurons develop is different from the way that we thought about how circuits develop. Like, it's sort of analogous to how a person learns to walk and then learns to walk well, so in your case it's like a person who walks well when they first walk is different from a person who walks poorly at the age of two.'

Dr. B:'Yes, that's true. And in fact, there are many people who are born into a culture and acquire some skills, but there are many others who have difficulty acquiring those skills. It's not only a biological difference. In fact, it's not biological at all. It's cultural. It's also a social one.'
Dr. B:'In other words, the question you ask is: what is the function of that activity?'
Dr. M:'The function is to develop. The function is to develop the nervous system. It's to develop the motor system. It's not to study a particular neuron that exists.'

Dr. B:'But, what we want to understand is how it works, how it works and what happens when it works in a particular way. So my answer is how do you manipulate it? How do you manipulate that activity, that activity of those neurons? Well, how do you manipulate synaptic connections? That is the key. How do you manipulate those connections? Well, the key is how do you do that? What are the methods? I mean, that's what you want to understand.'

Dr. B:'The function of a set of neurons is to change the activity of that set of neurons, right? In this case, change the activity of a set of pyramidal cells in the hippocampus so that they produce activity that is organized in time by a certain oscillation. So, the function is change the activity of the set of neurons, and I want to understand how that change occurs.'

Dr. M:'Well, that is a very interesting question because you mentioned the hippocampi and the way that that is modulated. I've also been interested in how nervous systems respond to modulatory inputs and how neurons can be regulated by their actions as the nervous system matures and it can be interesting to see how they become regulated during development.'

Dr. B:'We talked about the hippocampus in that previous question, but let me talk about the cerebellum as well. It's a simple brain, but there are some things that we don't understand about the cerebellar system. It's important to understand how that system works to understand how the cerebellum functions, but it has been a bit difficult. What are the fundamental features of this system that are so important? It seems to be a very complex system with a lot of connectivity.'

Dr. M:'The cerebellum is the most complicated part of the nervous system, and the one that most people don't think about. It's a very complex circuit with a lot of components that interact to produce the different functions of the cerebellum. It's important because it's used for coordinating muscle movements and posture. It's used for many different things.'
Dr. M:'You can't necessarily control the oscillation of neurons in a given circuit.'
Dr. B:'What is the relationship between the development of network dynamics and the emergence of cognitive function?'

Dr. M:'Well, the development of cognition depends on a number of factors, and I think some of the best work is done on this is on  Homo sapiens. Our brains and nervous systems have been evolving for millions of years. We are a very ancient species. You can go back, probably, maybe half a million years ago and look at a picture of, say, a baboon in the rainforest and see that the brain in that baboon has developed into a human-sized brain.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's quite complex. As we develop, our neurons change. And if you want to understand how neurons develop, you must first understand their history, their developmental history. So for example, during development, if a neuron has always existed, if it's been active from the beginning, it will always express particular types of ion channel densities, and will always exhibit a certain electrophysiological characteristic.'
Dr. B:'So what are the conditions that determine whether it should change? What is the developmental rule that it follows?'
Dr. M:'So it has to do with its environment.'
Dr. B:'Does it change with experience? Does it matter what experiences a neuron encounters during development?'

Dr. M:'So this is quite different from neurons in the adult, and the nervous systems of many animals, and of some animals, the nervous systems of developing animals, such as mice or chicks. So there are many, many developmental rules that govern how neurons change.'
Dr. B:'How many? What is the rule book?'

Dr. B:'And in the mouse brain, for example, these are the brain structures that are involved in language. And how are they involved in language? What is the role of language in the development of those brain areas? And there are many, numerous studies that are done in the development of these structures.'
Dr. B:'Then why would it change if it never experienced the world?'

Dr. M:'When neurons are developing, they need to be 'wired' so that they can properly fire and transmit the necessary information for development. In some cases, neural activity must be blocked during development, but, as these neurons are usually silent, it is not a significant restriction. Thus, spontaneous neural activity is a necessary component of development, but it's not the only one, it's not an important component.'
Dr. B:'What is the most important role of this activity?'

Dr. M:'The most important role of neural activity is to promote the development of the nervous system. For example, when we look at neuromodulation, we know that neuromodulation is necessary during development, because we need to activate the circuit during development and then the network needs to be activated to produce the appropriate behavior. So, the most important role is to promote the growth of the nervous system to generate appropriate behavior.'

Dr. M:'Well, there are many different, distinct functions that can arise from neural activity during development. We use neural activity to teach the nervous system. To teach itself how to make different synaptic connections. To learn to respond to sensory input, for example.'

Dr. B:'Is there a developmental time window, for example, that the activity during which can induce these functions? If so, then what is the window of opportunity to observe these activities? For instance, is it preplay, and that is what happens prior to birth? Is it consolidation, in which neural activity occurs later in development, as would happen in an adult brain? Or is it during the development of the brain in the embryo? How would these events unfold?'

Dr. M:'You're asking me to speculate a bit about brain development, and it's a speculation that we're never going to know for sure. But I guess we can talk about two of the main questions you might ask. One is that if you take brain regions, for example, the anterior part of the brain contains many neurons that project into the foregut and make muscle movements.'

Dr. B:'And the posterior part of the brain has the motor areas and the eye muscles, which is where these projections occur. So I would argue, is there a window that you would say would be an appropriate time to begin to look at what's happening to this system, which is the same system as in the anterior part of brain, and say, OK, this activity in the brain is going to be important for motor control or movement.'
Dr. M:'Right. So you're going to be interested in how neurons are able to learn to function as neurons and then how the neuronal network is able to function as a network.'

Dr. B:'Now, if this is a critical function, then how does the brain do this? What happens in development to make this a critical function? And the other question is that if you look at the brain, in particular the hippocampus and cortex, and the functions that emerge, such as learning and memory, and these processes in general, and how do they unfold? Is it just that things are happening all the time, in a continuous flow?'

Dr. M:'So, it's all of the above, and there are different functions that are used throughout development. For example, if we look at the retina, we see that at first, all cells and all processes in the retina are small, and grow in a kind of a spiking fashion until they're big enough to generate reliable information. Then, they grow linearly, and continue to grow, and that allows the circuits to grow. So, it's all three of the above.'

Dr. B:'So, what I would say is that the question you should ask, as a neuroscientist, is what is the function of all of this activity during development, and how does it occur? Because if you go to the other side of the problem, and you say, what is the goal? What is the function of this network, the neural syntax, in the brain?'

Dr. M:'The role of synaptic inhibition is the dominant role during development, because, initially, the neural circuits were very much smaller and the inhibitory inputs were also more abundant and they had to be tonically inhibited by multiple neurons or by a single neuron at a low frequency. Thus, initially the neural network was very small and it could be inhibited at low frequencies. And that is critical, because the network can't be damaged if it is not activated.'

Dr. B:'Why is it critical? In your book, you mention that when the brain is exposed to high-frequency oscillations at birth, they can induce seizures that is not true for adults or premature babies that are not exposed to such high-frequency oscillation. If a few months after this manipulation, I ask you, "What are the functional consequences of such manipulation? What is the function of these high-frequency oscillators?'
Dr. M:'They are not critical during development.'

Dr. M:'Well, that's a good question. In the first instance, the function of the electrical activity is for the development of the neuromuscular circuits. And then as you move on up the levels of organization, the function of that activity is to facilitate the development of the neurons and the interactions between neurons.'
Dr. B:'Is it important to understand what is the importance of spontaneous activity as opposed to some externally applied electrical activity?'

Dr. M:'I guess in the first instance, yes it's important to understand the role that neural activity has in the development of a nervous system. And it also provides an interesting clue to how a nervous system develops in a normal fashion, because a nervous system needs to be robust in the way it responds to environmental perturbations. But then as you go up higher in the way that neural systems develop, it's important to get a sense of why they work the way they do.'

Dr. B:'So, why spontaneous neural activity is important for that is something that we are trying to understand as well. So, I mean, how is it important? What is the impact on neural activity? What's the role that spontaneous activity has? And then we can go from there.'

Dr. M:'And I'm actually studying this in the crab. In the lobster, we have similar oscillators in both systems, the crabs and the lobster. But what the lobster is doing in the lobster, the lobsters, is very different. Because the lobsters have three or more active neuromuscular networks, each with their own synaptic connections. And in the lobsters, each network has a distinct function.'

Dr. B:'And so, in the lobster, they can flexibly engage in a large number of combinations. In fact, it's much more of a combinatorial code than in the crab. And I think what we are trying to figure out is how each of those circuits could operate, and then how they could flexibly activate or disengage from one another to support a larger function. And then, how would it be possible to disengage from that larger network activity?'

Dr. M:'That's right, because as you start going higher and higher up in the nervous system, the neurons become more specialised. So, there is still going to be a core set of neurons that will be activated in most animals in response to all of the inputs coming from all the sensory systems. But then there is going to be many, many neurons that can be activated as a result of a certain environmental perturbation.'

Dr. B:'Yes, and they can be activated in a very similar manner. And so what's important is to figure out how those neurons, or any subset of neurons, would interact with each other to support a function, and then how those circuits would respond to environmental inputs. And then what it would be possible to do is disengage from that activity to make a new circuit for the lobsters needs.'
Dr. M:'I started working in the nervous system when the activity was tonic.'
Dr. B:'What was that like?'

Dr. M:'The first time I went into a cell that was the first time I encountered a nervous system, and it was the stomatogastric nervous system. There was a single neuron, and it was firing. You know, it was firing over and over again and just continuously firing. It was firing, like a drum. And then you know, as you learn, this becomes quite fascinating.'
Dr. B:'How did you find yourself doing it?'

Dr. M:'Well, it was because I started graduate school at the University of Michigan when there was a group of neurophysiologists that were doing studies of the stomatogenic nervous system, which is where I started. So, one of the first people that we hired was a neurophysiologist, who was working on the stomatogenus. The only job he did was to take the nerves that connect the muscles to the brain off, to study their properties.'
Dr. B:'And where were you studying at the University ofMichigan?'
Dr. M:'Graduate student.'

Dr. M:'It is very early on, before the onset of functional motor circuits, during embryonic development, and it is during the first phase of neuronal development when there is the greatest period of growth. We know that the earliest phases of neural development occur in the early stages of embryonic development, so that is really a phase of rapid growth and the largest number of neurons that you will see.'
Dr. B:'The question really is how that network state interacts with the physical world.'

Dr. M:'The interactions between neural activity and the physical world are really important, because they are the first step in the development of all motor circuits and other circuits. But the importance of the question that we're interested in is not only the first phase of development, but the development of networks that will govern cognitive functions that we're interested now.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that we're looking for, the 'what' that's being sent to the brain, so to speak?'

Dr. M:'Yeah. So, if we look at the neural syntax and how the neural circuits are put together, there are three levels, and the first level of that is the network that we've discussed before, the first level is the circuitry of the neurons and their relationships to each other and to their connections. The second level is the interactions between neural cells and circuits and the mechanisms by which these cells, these neurons and circuit neurons, the circuits control behavior.'

Dr. M:'The spontaneous neural activity during early development is crucial, because at the time of initial neuromodulation, there is relatively little other modulatory innervation. At first the neurons may fire irregularly, but after the initial neuromodulatory drive to the system, the neurons start firing regularly in a stereotyped manner, allowing the system to be regulated later on, when more inputs are available.'
Dr. B:'Is this activity a random occurrence or does it have a defined function?'
Dr. M:'If it is randomly occurring then the function of neural activity during development is just random noise.'
Dr. B:'I wonder, do you consider it to be an important random event, or is it not important? If you take a look at some data, do you consider that activity to be random or not?'

Dr. M:'It does, and the function is that the activity of these neurons creates an environment in which the activity of the neurons can be controlled. As the neurons are active they build connections that increase their period of firing. They release a variety of hormones and neurotransmitters, which act on the neurons in the circuit. The system, the circuits, is thus a self-regulating network, with a number of feedback mechanisms.'
Dr. B:'Do these self-regulating circuits create a "good enough" solution for neuronal circuits?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's not a solution. In fact, it would be a nightmare to design a self-regulatory mechanism to generate behavior in response to sensory input, because sensory information would immediately be rejected. A good enough solution is something that produces behavior in response to a sensory input that is close to the behavior that would occur under a given set of environmental conditions.'

Dr. M:'Well, when it happens after development starts, it's probably a way to restore some kind of equilibrium for the network activity. So, maybe at the same level of activity it's important that the activity occur.'
Dr. B:'I mean, that seems like a pretty good answer, but is there more to it? I mean, I've read the recent literature, and I'm not sure I understand what's going on...'
Dr. M:'What's going on with the recent literature? Tell me, do you mean about the network activity?'

Dr. B:'No. The recent literature, and that's all that I mean. But, you know, I'm not, I'm not trying to say, well, it's very, it's very important, but the things in the past, the current findings, the current data, are not sufficient to answer this question. I'm not saying, well, I'm asking for some new data. But it would be nice to see what's going on. It's a pretty interesting question.'

Dr. B:'Yeah. Yeah, yeah. It's a good question. I mean, it seems like the answer is pretty straight-forward, but then again, it depends on the kind of question. So for instance, in a recent paper I read about the role of gamma oscillations in plasticity, I'm not sure what the role of spontaneous network activity is in that. And I'm not sure whether that's a function of gamma oscillations, or something that is there to be exploited.'

Dr. M:'You know, because this is one of the big areas where I really have no experience with. But I'm curious... You know, you look at these data showing that neural activity is always present in some kind of fluctuating range. Right? And then you wonder whether it's important for neural development. Right? So, whether it's important that some neural activity be always present. Right?'

Dr. B:'If I'm asking this question from a slightly different direction, what is the function of brain activity during development? I mean, there seems to be a consensus that it's a 'protomap' that helps guide the growth of neural circuits. So, that would be a first thing. So is there a second thing? I mean, we're all aware that during development neural activity is not always present, but it's not clear whether it's important or not that the activity is always present.'
Dr. M:'I mean, it could be.'

Dr. B:'What if it's just the other way around? Is it important that activity in the brain be present? And what would be the consequences of it? And what could be the consequences of this if you want to build some kind of hypothetical function? But I'm not sure it could be very fruitful. So, but then, and I want to be clear, in no way is this a criticism of the development of the brain.'

Dr. M:'It's just a question. You know, we have a tendency to think that, like, we're sort of building this, you know, hardwired, you know, the brain is going to be built and it's going to have a specific set of behaviors, and everything's going to be, you know, just kind of...'

Dr. B:'The only thing we have to be aware of is that the brain is made up of a lot of competing dynamics, and it's not one or the other. I'm a firm believer that there are, but the way that these dynamics interact is constantly changing. It's never fixed. It's always, always changing. I'm a great believer of dynamic interaction, and it has a lot to do with language, as it does.'

Dr. M:'So I guess, you know, the thing that strikes me is that these models that you're describing are, like, the brain has a job and the job is to produce neural activity, right? So these models are going to be, if they are models of neurons, they're going to be bursting neurons, right?'

Dr. B:'No, but I'm saying, what would be the function of bursting? Is the brain an information receiver or information generator? And there are at least two functions that can be done by bursting. And the first one is called pattern completion and the second one is called gain modulation. And both of these functions seem to be very helpful. So if it's the other way around, I'm just, I'm asking whether there are functions for the other way around.'

Dr. M:'Like gain modulation. I mean, gain modulation, that's a really interesting idea because you can, you can gain information by modulating the gain, the amplitude, of a neuron, right? Right, and it doesn't seem to me that the brain would function well if it was missing the normal, normal gain modulation.'

Dr. B:'So, so that's the first point, right? If you want to build a function, it would be very useful for the brain to be able to increase the gain of a cell, right? So this is what I want. For example, what would happen if you removed gain modulation?'

Dr. B:'So this is why I'm so fond of your work, is that it makes the brain so that it can do something that it couldn't do before the intervention. Like, before, in many cases, all of these models are built using synaptic connectivity and a very simple network.'

Dr. M:'No, what's going on is you've got this kind of nonlinearity that's been identified in the neuronal circuits. You know, like how they can produce a variety of motor patterns. Dr. B:'Oh, okay, and I guess that's what's going on in the cortex, right?'

Dr. B:'So, I would just want to know what you think is the role of spontaneous activity in developing neural activity. Is it important? How should it be handled? Dr. M:'I guess I could try and speculate about it. I think there's maybe a lot of reasons that we don't understand that it is necessary for neural activity to be regulated. And you've got a couple of them that I think might be relevant to this. One, because neurons are subject to damage and there's a constant turnover of neural units, so, when you're a neuron, you've got to know when your turn will come.'

Dr. B:'But then, it's already in your body, so you can have your own rhythm. So I don't know. The second reason is that if you don't have a rhythm and there's no goal for it, there's no way to do anything. And so that's the kind of critical thing about it, so that's maybe more relevant to the timing issue and to the question of the role of spontaneous neural activity.'

Dr. M:'That's the most mysterious part of it, and most intriguing part. Why, first of all, should the neural networks that develop during embryonic and childhood develop in the way that they do, instead of following a simple rule that is determined during the embryonic or early childhood and then that determines how the network develops for the rest of the lifetime?'
Dr. B:'Why not just follow the simple rule? What are the rules of self-organization?'

Dr. M:'Because it doesn't necessarily follow the simple rule. We don't know if there are rules of self-organized network development, and I suspect that there are. That there are rules is not in any sense guaranteed by the fact that we're born into the world, so the answer to that question is not automatic and is likely to involve an active developmental process.'

Dr. B:'What is it? What is the developmental process? We know that self-organization is in the brain's best interest in the sense that it minimizes costs, but we don't have an idea as to what those costs are.'

Dr. M:'We're not even really good at describing the mechanisms by which neurons make the connections that they do, and whether or not there are rules governing network development, the mechanisms by which synaptic strengths are regulated.'

Dr. B:'And what do the mechanisms have to do with the wiring? If it's wired in a specific way, it's likely to produce the same dynamics and patterns as long as the wiring is intact. And that may be the case here. But we don't know that it is. We don't even know what the cost is of the wiring.'

Dr. B:'That sounds like a very serious problem. How long can we continue to talk about this problem without a breakthrough? We've been working on the problem of neurodevelopmental processes and neural syntax for more than a century, yet we have no real answers.'

Dr. B:'The most important question is, of course, what are the consequences of these networks? If you know what kind of consequences, then you know what happens when the networks are created, what happens when the connections are made in a particular direction, what happens when they're formed in a particular way, and the consequences that would follow from that. If you know the consequences, then you can ask a very relevant question: what are the consequences? What are the consequences of self-organized neural networks?'

Dr. B:'So it seems to me that the function of self-organized activity is not to generate random noise but to establish a dynamic that will support the selection and construction of circuits which eventually become the basis for efficient and accurate computation, and the emergence of cognitive behaviors such as memory and planning.
