Dr. M:'Well, I think, that depends on the species. So, for example, in the case of human beings, for whom the nervous system has developed in the most complex manner, they are capable of quite a remarkable range of behaviors and complex cognition. And yet, they can maintain relatively stable patterns of activity during times when their body temperature fluctuates, when they're swimming in the ocean.'
Dr. B:'I can't see a purpose to activity during sleep and waking, when they're not going to be doing anything.'

Dr. M:'I think you're asking the wrong question. The wrong question is not why is there activity during waking and sleep? The wrong question is why don't we all just wake up at 6am, and then sit around all day? Why are there many hours during the day that people are wandering around the streets and shops, and they're thinking about things? That's the wrong question. I think your answer to that question can be a little bit more specific and not so general.'
Dr. B:'Because the reason why we wake up at 6 o'clock is because it's so nice and so good, that even when I wake up early, the experience is still pretty good.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's hard to imagine that a simple rule would produce this variability. So that's an interesting point. The rules of self-regulation are hard to imagine, because we know that many rules could produce different kinds of behavior. We know, for example, that many different rules could produce the same behavior, and yet we see that these rules do not. So that's very mysterious.'

Dr. B:'What if it is not mysterious? What if it's known and can be explained? Do we have any clues? Can we look at these rhythms and see which ones, for example, are responsible for the brain's ability to control its ability to control the spinal cord?'

Dr. M:'So one could imagine that the network could be regulated in a manner that ensures that it follows the correct rules of self-regulating behavior, but it might be regulated by external perturbations, or by neuromodulators. So one could imagine that these rules are a kind of set of conditions that have to be fulfilled, for self-organization, and that this set of conditions might be changed by environmental factors. So, you know, that could be regulated, that kind of thing.'

Dr. B:'I am going to try to answer your question with a question of my own. I'm going to pose a question to you that's a bit more direct. Dr. M:'Ahh, well that's a good question, because I think it's really hard to distinguish between the two, how much of this is just genetic?'
Dr. B:'And how much is it environmental or experi-mental?'
Dr. M:'Well, that is a really great question that we don't know the answer to.'

Dr. M:' The function of neural activity during development depends on the intrinsic properties of the neurons themselves. Early neural activity during development can be inhibitory or excitatory. Neurons are formed during development, and then the properties of the neurons can become relatively fixed because they can receive constant inhibitory and excitatory synaptic inputs from the rest of the network during development and then these properties become relatively fixed, even if the properties of the individual neurons can be different.'

Dr. M:'Well, this has been discussed many times because you're right, they're just going to be firing all the time. But it's also the way in which they change, and it's the way in which new network patterns are formed.'

Dr. B:'There's also, I'm aware of the fact that these are different questions. I mean, it doesn't matter how one would ask the question, but I'm interested in how to address that question, because, in fact, this is a real-world issue that is very challenging in the, in the sense that we have to answer this question, not because it's easy but because it really is challenging.'

Dr. M:'The other side of it is, is when you think about neurons and neurons and networks, the neurons are the fundamental building blocks of our nervous systems. They're the fundamental building blocks. Of all our systems. They have a ton of intrinsic properties and synaptic properties.'

Dr. M:'You know, and then it becomes a problem for us because when you start thinking about neurons and their properties, you start thinking about how they're built, right. Dr. B:'So there are two challenges here. One is to understand the mechanisms that builds up intrinsic properties of neurons. Dr. B:'What does that mean? For example, synapse-dependent plasticity.'

Dr. B:'How do the various aspects of synapse-dependent synaptic plasticity change in response to various brain states?'

Dr. B:'Which are the functions? What are the consequences of synaptic transmission and the role of spontaneous activity?'

So it learns how to express itself in many different ways, you know so to some extent, the neurons have to be able to express themselves, as well.'

Dr. B:'And this is one example. But what are the other functions? There are so many functions that can be taken. What are some examples? What are the functions that have to be taken care of? Dr. M:'Yes, well that's true, but to think about the function of the brain when it's developing, when you are forming your first synapses as an infant, it's interesting. Because, so it learns how to form itself, and that's what you call a developmental change.'

Dr. M:'Some of the parameters. Some of the parameters, as we try to understand the changes that occur in a brain from childhood to adulthood, as the neurons and circuits change.'

Dr. M:'Well, because all animals have unique electrical, chemical, and histamine inputs, and all these inputs are changing during development.'

Dr. M:'Because it's crucial for development. And we are also studying how development might alter synaptic transmission.'

Dr. B:'And what are the changes that take place during development? Is there a specific time when the changes occur? What are some of the changes that occur, please? Dr. M:'I've spent most of my career looking at a particular kind of neural activity. What you may not realize is that the first phase of neuronal development is very chaotic and there are many different processes going on at once, and they're all kind of jumbling around and trying to learn what they're supposed to be.'
Dr. B:'Do they get to pick any of them?'
Dr. M:'They can choose, and they can choose, and the neurons can choose from an extensive menu of choices, that's the way it is.'
Dr. B:'How long does it take for the brain to get to choose?'

Dr. M:'That's an excellent question and I think the answer is there are not that many genes that are responsible for neuronal function, and therefore you have to be able to have enough time to sort out what's important, and there's a series of events, that are all happening, and the neural activity is really quite different from neuron to neuron and the synaptic connections of the neurons are changing all the time.'
Dr. M:'A lot of work has been done that shows that neural activity during development influences circuit performance when neurons are part of a functioning network.'

Dr. B:'What are these neurons doing when they are part of a network? What are their intrinsic rhythms doing? What is the relationship between their intrinsic patterns and their collective behavior as a network?'

Dr. M:'Well, first of all, what the intrinsic rhythms are doing when the network is not active is not clear. But if you look at the results of this work that I've done and you look at the findings in the neuropeptide work that you've done, you start asking the question, "Okay, how do these neurons change and develop?" The fact is, is that neurons, neurons, neurons have to develop, they have to change.'

Dr. B:'But in the case of the self-generated patterns, how are they changed? What is the interaction between the self-generated oscillations and the neural firing? Can the network make use of self-generated activity or is it an internal clock? Or is it a mixture of these things? Is it a network oscillator, or is it a network oscillation? How is it interacting? Is it in balance, or is it oscillating in the wrong way?'

Dr. M:'So when we started talking about the dynamics of small networks we started talking about neurons and then we started talking about synaptic interactions. We started talking about all kinds of biological networks. The way neurons work, the way synapses work is important because that affects all kinds of networks.'
Dr. B:'Who are the neural networks and what are the networks that they are part of?'

Dr. M:'For example, if the neural network is the pyloric rhythm, the cardiac network that drives heartbeat, if you turn off this network, the heartbeat is very much reduced, and it will stay reduced as long as the pyloric network is disconnected.'
Dr. B:'What is the connection between spontaneous activity and the various rhythms of the brain?'
Dr. B:'What is the neural syntax that governs this network activity?'
Dr. M:'We don't know, that is what we study.'
Dr. M:'I think this syntax is different from the neural syntax of a circuit that is already active.'

Dr. B:'How does the brain generate that syntax? What are the principles that govern the generation of that syntax? We know the syntax that it is, but it's difficult to figure out how the brain generates that syntax.'

Dr. M:'You know the brain is very dynamic and it's easy to find neurons that have been activated a long time, but it's more difficult to find neurons that are always activated, that are part of a tonic circuit, and they are in a constant mode. So, I think it's quite hard to figure out how that process of generating this syntax is regulated.'

Dr. M:'Well, it turns out that you need to have different neural patterns for development that you need to learn, because you have to learn how to use your circuits correctly for development. So it's like there are two phases in development. In the first phase, when you're growing up, you're developing a ton of neural circuits that are kind of 'good enough' to be functional.'

Dr. B:'And then when you get older, you have to really learn how to make those circuits behave correctly in an appropriate manner. And this is where, uh, the activity of the brain is so important. I mean, this is where activity of the brain becomes a big part of the neurosyntax that controls circuit behavior. And if you learn these patterns at a young age, then you will use your circuits in a better way in the future.'

Dr. M:'And so I work with this group of people who come to us with problems, and we find out that what their problem is, it's not really a problem with a biological network or with the circuits that they're using. Their problem is with the brain, with the neurons, with the synapses, and the circuits of neurons that control cognition. That we're trying to teach people to think properly.'
Dr. M:'One of the functions is to build circuits for generating rhythmic motor patterns that are responsible for rhythmic behavior in general.'

Dr. B:'But you can learn all kinds of movements and all kinds of things without doing it with a brain; you can do them all, all right? Dr. M:'Oh well, it's very easy because the synaptic connections, I mean, for example, they're different. For example, you could start with the rhythmic motor pattern for chewing and then move to rhythmic motor patterns for chewing and moving your teeth around. And then you could move to rhythmic jaw movements that would create movement of your mouth around, around, around. And then then you can move to rhythmic chewing movements of your mouth around food.'

Dr. B:'It would not be so different if I learned those movements by a computer with the ability to generate neural syntax. So, for example, you have a very limited number of patterns that could be represented by a machine, just like only so many different kinds of moves that you can do. And then with a bit of training you can learn how to do those patterns perfectly, just like in your brain.'
Dr. M:'If the brain is silent, it's not functioning.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of spontaneous activity in the development of brain networks?'

Dr. M:'Oh, gosh, I don't know. I think that is a big question. I think that there is some speculation, that neurons that are active during development, might, might be important in development, but I am not really sure. But I think that neurons active during development might play some role in the development of the system, and then might also play a role in how the system responds to the world. So, that is one of the interesting questions that is raised.'

Dr. B:'What's the role of spontaneous activity during development? Do these circuits grow on their own, or do we need to provide them something else for them to do, which is why they are so good at doing some things? Or is there a point when the circuits are set up and ready, and then the spontaneous activity will be the things that they do, and we can see what happens? What are the conditions for that?'

Dr. M:'I think that there are conditions. I think that you need to have neurons that have a role. I mean, if the neurons that are active are responsible for, say, maintaining stability, or if the neurons that do the most important computations are always active, or if the most active neurons during development are always active, then I think that those neurons will be responsible for maintaining function.'

Dr. B:'Would you be able to give an example? Would you, uh, just give an example of what you mean by, uh, maintaining stability, keeping the network stable, maintaining function? What would be an example of a task that the brain has to do when it's ready to do it?'

Dr. M:'Um, I think that, for example, I was looking at it and it says that, um, that neurons that were active during development, like pyloric network neurons, have been found to have different behaviors in the adult. Like the neurons that are responsible for generating the fast pyloric rhythms have been found to be slow in the adult.'

Dr. M:'We don't know yet. I mean, we understand now that when neurons develop, they first undergo massive channel-closing inactivation of different channels. And they do that in an appropriate way. For example, the development of the gastric mill network is dependent on ion channel-closing to occur. But the expression of the ion channel genes that are responsible for ion channel-closes changes during development. For example, my colleague Dr.'
Dr. B:'Paul. Paul is my postdoctoral fellow.'
Dr. M:'Yes, Paul.'

Dr. B:'Paul, that is actually one question. In addition to that question, what are the major questions that we can address in the next 30 years? The two major issues, to my mind, are the mechanism of cortical circuit-formation and the mechanisms of neural syntax.'

Dr. M:'Yes, well, it's actually one of my interests. As a scientist, as we say, and so I think we have many years to go to find out a lot more about how the brain really works. And of course there is going to be an enormous amount of interest in the mechanism by which neuronal circuits develop. I think that will be interesting for some years to come.'

Dr. B:'And what do we think is the state of the field right now? What should we be focusing on? What are our most promising leads? What are our best questions that we can ask and work towards? What are our broadest questions? What are the most exciting questions?'

Dr. B:'I agree with that and I would also add that the reason why spontaneous activity is so important during development is because it is during development that the initial neuronal activity arises. That is when the neuronal network is in its simplest form, but then it becomes very complex and interesting at the right time, when the brain is in its development. In that phase, there is no need for external influences. That is when I don't need to do much. I have all the resources and energy of the brain.'

Dr. M:'The function of spontaneous neural firing during development is that during development the neuron has to be properly developed, so that the firing frequency that is present is appropriate for the neuron's task. The neuron is also developing its synapses, and this also depends on the firing frequency of the other cells in the network. There are models that show that you can have a slow neuron that has a slow synaptic drive, and still be functional as a neuron, because of homeostatic mechanisms.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for slow activity?'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, there are two main functions. One is to allow the neuron to be properly developed and to have its synapses be appropriately regulated. In addition to this, the slow rate of spike production is a mechanism that can help in the homeostatic regulation of synaptic strength, synaptic strength is regulated by a number of mechanisms. In addition to that, the slow rate is important for the regulation of membrane currents, so that the electrical activity in the cell is maintained at a fixed amplitude.'

Dr. B:'Could you give an example from studies in the developing brain of how this is achieved? Could you give us some examples of the role of the slow rate of firing in the regulation of synapses in the developing brain? If you are able to give us an example from the developing brain, what is the role of slow spiking in the regulation of synaptic strength? What is the role of the low firing rate in the regulation of membrane conductance?'

Dr. M:'So, this is why I think we are starting to get models that show you can get homeostasis, and these models can have a wide variety of firing rates. The way homeostasis works in these models is that they rely on a set of feedback sensors that are located throughout the system, and that send back information to the brain, or to the brain can send back information that feeds into those sensors, that are located throughout of the entire system.'
Dr. B:'How can the sensors feed back information?'
Dr. B:'Why is the fast-firing group more functional? What is the fast-spiking group doing?'

Dr. M:'Well, we can't predict how different animals will develop, but we can see that there are differences in the types of network activity that occur during development. The functional outcome depends on the interactions of all of the cell types that have different membrane properties, different synaptic drive properties, and different intrinsic properties. It is the interaction between the different properties of the different cell types that determines whether the network performs a particular function.'
Dr. B:'What is the best example of that interaction? Can you illustrate that interaction by giving me an example?'

Dr. B:'Do the different aspects of development have their own mechanisms? What are the mechanisms for the development of spontaneous activity? What are the self-organized patterns that allow for the spontaneous activity to develop? What are the neurochemical mechanisms that allow for self-organized activity?'

Dr. M:'So it depends on the details of the intrinsic properties of each of the neurons, as well as the synaptic connections between those neurons. The different neurons also have different developmental and physiological processes that influence their development, and then all of the factors that influence the interaction between these different kinds of neurons come into play and they all have to work together for functional brain output. So that's one of the things we're thinking about. There is no general answer. It will vary by individual.'

Dr. B:'In the course of evolution, how did we get here? How did the brain evolve? What was the first brain? When was the first brain formed? Do we have a guess, and what is the date? Dr. B:'I'm also interested in how to learn how to read a novel environment, in addition to the standard training of the rat, because this would be a big advance in the rat's abilities to understand how to solve a problem. Dr. M:'So this is a very good question because it touches on an interesting problem. One of the things that we know that the rats will learn very fast is the ability to go from one compartment to another by going down the ramp. We can test them at that. Dr. B:'So how does it come that if you are tested for three days and then a week and then three weeks, the animals have this ability? But I just want to make sure that the animals are behaving well and that they are not getting frustrated or bored.'

Dr. B:'What are the first things that the rat learns? Are there any data that you've used that shows that the first thing that the rat learns is that if you will turn your head around and go down the ramp, that will lead to another chamber.'

Dr. B:'Are there any data sets you've used to test the effect that learning this behavior has on the firing rate of neurons? Are there any data set you've used that would explain how learning this behavior leads to a particular level of neuronal activity? Are there any ways in which learning this behavior leads in a particular direction of neuronal activity?'

Dr. M:'One thing I did, because the animals that we study were quite different, they would typically have to be in a large open space, with little food in their stomachs. So we have to provide them with food, but we also have to provide the water that they need. So there was a little bit of food on the ground, so they could find that and eat that, and the water they need, so that they could drink.'

Dr. M:'I guess it's an adaptation that comes from the fact that it is an important part of the developing brain. I mean, if you were to imagine a developing neuron that was silent all the time, then you would not be able to make many useful connections between different parts of the brain.'
Dr. B:'No, but I mean, the interesting thing about that is, how does it start? What causes activity to start? I don't know, I'm really trying to understand, I don't know.'

Dr. M:'So what we're interested in is understanding how the nervous system develops. So the nervous system develops in an evolutionary sense, and it's not until you start talking about evolutionary processes and how things come about that you're able to find out how important a role the nervous system plays in an evolutionary sense. That's why I started the evolution of the nervous system, because I was interested in understanding how nervous systems change.'

Dr. B:'Okay, and why is it important? What's so special about these sequences? Is it good for the brain that the activity goes this way and not the other way? Is it good that the brain creates some sequences that are important? Or is it good that the sequences are not important?'

Dr. M:'It's both. So, it's important for the brain because it gives rise to many important functions. So, you would not be here today if it were not for spontaneous neural activity and rhythmic activity. And at the same time, I think it is interesting that the brain makes some choices about what rhythm to use when it is developing, because some rhythms are more useful for some neurons than others.'
Dr. B:'What do you mean by that?'

Dr. B:'So if you were to ask me, "What is the function that sequences have in the brain?" Is it good for brain? Or is it just there for, "Why is it a good idea to have a neural system with this?" Is it good that there is a system that creates some sequences that help the brain in some way? Or is it more, "What are the consequences for the brain that this sequences happen to have?'

Dr. M:'So, I guess the answer to your question is it is good for the brain. But at the same time I think it is also important that this activity is not only good for the brain but it's also important that there are certain rhythms that are very important, so that this is regulated by other neurons, because, again, you're looking at the evolution of the nervous system.'

Dr. M:'Well, I think it depends on the circuit, so you are asking me to speculate. But in general, I think that neurons that are silent would probably have different kinds of activity, because different kinds of networks need different kinds of activity in different contexts. So I don't think that the fact that the brain is generating some sequences, or some rhythmic patterns is necessarily bad for it.'

Dr. B:'But what you mean by that is it's a little like a computer system, where you have a few hard-wired elements and you connect them. And I can say,  "Let's see what happens when you plug in a couple of chips." Or if I have a few chips, and I can build a computer. I know that those are just a few hard-wiring elements. What would happen if I plugged in a million?'
Dr. M:'A million is just an extreme example. Right?'
Dr. B:'What would be the function of such connections?'

Dr. M:'So basically, what you're doing is you're learning how to get information from many different brain regions and combine it into a single brain region. Like if you're trying to learn how to walk and how to feed yourself or how to read and to think. Those things happen through a kind of network activity because your whole brain is involved.'
Dr. B:'How would you teach the brain how to do those things?'

Dr. M:'Well, you would basically do a lot of the kinds of things that we've learned how to do in a lot of experimental models of the nervous system. You would teach it to learn how to behave and how to be smart. You would teach him to solve problems, to read, to understand. The kind of general education that a person would receive.'

Dr. B:'So I can say that, but I want to ask, what if it's the case that the developing brain is not able to acquire many important connections, but it does so in a way that the brain at the adult stage is able to make a lot of important connections...'
Dr. M:'Well, it could be different...'

Dr. M:'I think the function of neural activity during development is very important. When we're talking about neural activity during development, we're thinking about the normal development of neural systems.'

Dr. M:' Spontaneous neural activity is critical in shaping neural circuitry and circuits for function and homeostasis. As neurons and networks change, neural activity is also critical in maintaining the appropriate behaviour of the nervous system. This is important because changes in neural activity can come about from multiple underlying changes that occur during development. That's why we're interested in understanding the mechanisms of homeostatic regulation of neural activity in general, and neural activity in specific neurons and networks in the developing animal.'

Dr. B:'What can we do to understand homeostatic regulation? Can we find a simple solution to that problem? Can we find all neurons with an input to control their activity? Can we find some neurons in the brain that fire continuously in a reliable manner that we can use for that? Can we find neurons in the brain whose activity is not regulated and thus they can fire with the ability to spike or fire?'

Dr. M:'Well, in some animals, we can do this, and in many animals we can't do this. In other words, there are animals that, because they're highly sensory-coupled, they really do need to be regulated so that they can be appropriate to their surroundings. Other animals are highly modulatory, or they're more dependent on the environmental cues for regulation of their activity, so they're not sensory-coupling.'
Dr. B:'Is there ever a time when it makes sense to say 'Oh, this is a brain where homeostatic regulation is necessary?' How should we investigate this?'

Dr. M:'I would say most of the time we're interested in the adult animal. That's really the primary reason we're interested in studying homeostatic regulation and understanding the mechanisms that we've identified in homeostatic regulation in adult animals. However, you know, one of the exciting things that we're seeing is that we can understand homeostatic mechanisms that govern neuronal morphology, and that govern neural circuits that are very important for regulating the behaviour of the adult animal.'

Dr. B:'Are there any particular types of activity that we can look for in neurons and networks to understand homeostasis? I'm particularly interested in what we've already identified as the role of neural activity in learning and memory, for example. What activity can we look for in neural circuits that will give us insights into how we might work out a homeostatic mechanism to maintain neural activity?'
Dr. M:'Well, it is one of the first roles it plays is providing the feedback from the system to the central pattern generating circuitry that then goes out onto the system.'
Dr. B:'But what is it? What is it? What's the system? What is the feedback? What is the central pattern generator? What is the pattern generating network?'

Dr. B:'How is the feedback achieved in developing systems? In addition, what is the role of spontaneous activity in the wiring of the system that creates the feedback loop and what determines the direction of this feedback loop?'

Dr. M:'The brain has two systems. There is a descending system from the central pattern generating circuits to all of the muscles, and the anterior ganglia, as well as the posterior ganglia, but all the anterior ganglia are fused. This descending system is modulated from the central pattern generator circuits. The modulators come in and act via descending pathways on the central pattern generating networks that produce neural rhythms.'
Dr. B:'Can you give an example of how this is mediated?'

Dr. B:'Is there any evidence that spontaneous activity during development is important? What are some of the early processes that we are missing because we are not studying the brains rhythms, and what are some of the later ones that are important?'

Dr. B:'So it's a bit like a GPS, you can get a directional signal for a given direction or even an arbitrary direction and you can navigate your way to that point. What makes this so great is that it does not require any sensory input. It just takes a self-generated mechanism in the brain that's responsible for generating a spatial output and you can send it to the appropriate body part, which then moves the appropriate muscles and such.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that's right.'
Dr. B:'What would be a nice example of what is this feedback?'

Dr. M:' Well, for example, when the central pattern generating circuit is not activated, it has to send something out, it has to let the muscles around the animal get into place so that the muscles that allow the animal to feed can move, and that then is used to provide feedback to the central pattern generator that then creates the gastric mill patterns.'
Dr. B:'Is that what is the feedback in case of neural syntax?'

Dr. M:'No, I don't think that the feedback in neural syntax is going to be that. In terms of the feedback, it is not going to be that the central pattern generator is going to be able to send a message out and say, "Hey, my muscles are in place". So, I'm going to let these muscles contract now.'

Dr. B:'And what is the feedback, if you would like to call it that, then? I mean, let me ask you a question. So in case of neural networks, do we need a central pattern generator? So in case of the brain, we have a central pattern generator, right? And what is that? So what is the feedback?'
Dr. B:'What would happen if the central pattern generating and feedback circuitry was disrupted?'
Dr. M:'I would be unable to produce rhythmic behavior.'
Dr. B:'Why does that?happen?'

Dr. M:'Because the central pattern generating network is not 'hard wired' into the brain but is rather modulated and regulated by neuromodulators, including the pyloric dilator (PD), which comes from the lateral PY neuron. There is one PD neuron that comes into the system from the anterior ganglion (AG) that then goes to the STG that then is transmitted to the other PY neurons via descending axons.'

Dr. B:'So that central pattern generating circuitry is in the central nervous system. So, in the context of the brain, what is this? What is this? What are the parts of the central pattern generating circuit that are in the central nervous?system? The central pattern generating circuit consists of the central pattern generators (CPGs), the motor-sensory pathways, and a large network of interneurons that act as a 'gate' or'switch' in the brain.'
Dr. M:'You are talking about the central pattern generating circuits.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but it is important to understand what I'm talking about. It's not, you know, what I'm doing is something like a central pattern generating circuit. I'm not a central pattern generating expert. It's about the parts of the CPG, which are all neurons in the central pattern generating system, that are in the brain, or what is the central pattern generating? What are the central pattern generating parts that are in the network that are in the Central pattern generating system.'
Dr. B:'How does this activity relate to the neuronal syntax or the segmentation of neural codes?'
Dr. M:'Yes, we have discovered that by studying the changes in the network as the system develops that that is a critical part of the system.'
Dr. M:'So that, that the synaptic inputs and the synaptic interactions between neurons can be coordinated to produce rhythmic movements, to move animals.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of the intrinsic oscillations in this process?'
Dr. M:'Well, we have discovered a very special role, is that some of these networks have these spontaneous oscillations, these networks are not hard-wired.'
Dr. B:'What is their role?'
Dr. B:'When do these rhythms arise and how do they become self-organized?'

Dr. M:'They occur at first. The early stages are quite well known from experiments done in the past on a number of different types of animals. The early stages of a developing embryo are when all of the processes that we think of as the 'hard-wired parts' are not yet developed. The developing embryo starts producing rhythmic activity, and then as the 'hardware' of the brain begins to develop, and as it does so, the activity is more robust.'
Dr. B:'What is the importance of this self-organized activity?'
Dr. M:'They can be genetically engineered.'
Dr. B:'I'm talking about the developmental periods here.'
Dr. M:'That's when they're built.'
Dr. B:'What is the mechanism, please, please explain it for our listeners.'
Dr. M:'We've been asking ourselves that for years. We still don't know the mechanisms that are involved in these rhythms.'

Dr. B:'Do we know how many mechanisms are involved? It seems that there are several levels of mechanisms. What is the minimum, please? What is the first level? What is the second level? What is another level? What is a fourth level?'
Dr. B:'Are they part of the hardware or are they part of a software program?'
Dr. M:'Part of the hardware, they are part of a software.'
Dr. B:'Is it all the same code that makes up these rhythms? What is the code? How does the code arise? Where do the rules come from?'

Dr. M:'Well, it has a code, it has code, but the rules are part of the brain and part of the brain's memory and that's not entirely different from what a computer does. For example, the computer code for your favorite word processor may be very, very different from the code that you use to write a program to do mathematical analysis. You know, it depends on how you choose to write code.'

Dr. B:'So the code may be fundamentally different? But it is based on a syntax, and the syntax of the brain is fundamentally the same. Is it fundamentally the same? It's a bit like that, but a bit more technical. It's not that the syntax is fundamentally the same or that the syntax is fundamental but, it is that both syntaxes may share a similar core that is different between the syntaxes.'
Dr. B:'What is the function that these oscillations serve?'

Dr. M:'There is quite extensive theory about this, about how you can make some behavior occur by controlling these networks. I would say that it is the major mechanism by which neurons influence each other and neurons influence their environment.'
Dr. B:'Do they serve a role in neural syntax? Can they be exploited in the way that they are exploited in the brain?'

Dr. M:'Certainly. The brain has evolved to do certain things. It's evolved to be able to learn certain things, to recognize faces. If you can design things that can do that, that can be useful. That's part of the way it works. That can be exploited to make sense of the world.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible that the ability to read from the brain or control the brains activity or use it to affect the brains activity could be used to control the brains output? For instance, to make the animal do things that aren't in its genetic blueprint, but things that would be useful in the context of the environment it is in?'

Dr. M:'I think it is possible, because in general the brain has evolved to be flexible, to be flexible, because the environment changes. We have many examples of evolution, and so the brain has evolved, and the brain has evolved in response to the environments that animals have been in, but the brain has evolved over generations and generations to respond to changes in the environment, to respond to changes. It is a very powerful mechanism that is built into the brain. It is built into every neuron.'
Dr. M:'I think that they are a basic mechanism by which neurons can communicate with each other. I don't think that they are just a way by which neurons can be different and do their own thing.'
Dr. B:'Do they occur when the brain is disengaged from its environment? That is, how do they occur? What is the function of these rhythms?'
Dr. M:'Oh, we are trying to find out.'
Dr. B:'Are they formed after birth?'

Dr. M:'No, they are formed during early development, during the first few days, during the first week, during the first month. The first few weeks, in this case, of early development. It is this, this special role of neural activity, this spontaneous neural activity, that makes the developing nervous system able to regulate itself. We need a regulatory system to make sure the networks are functional.'
Dr. B:'What can these networks do that they cannot do in the absence of a network-driven mechanism?'

Dr. M:'Oh, they can do many things. But, you know, if you don't have an oscillator, you can't have a brain. Or if you have only one neuron, you can't get a nervous system. So, we're developing models of the development of nervous systems, which are based on the biological data.'
Dr. B:'Is it critical that the networks have oscillations or not? How can we make a network with only some neurons without a mechanism for oscillations?'

Dr. M:' Well, I think, probably mostly the development of the nervous system itself, to create all the neurons, to grow all of the connections, to establish all of the circuits that we'll use when we're adults. And it's just—it's an important feature of neural development.'
Dr. B:'So what are the advantages of spontaneous activity? Or the potential benefits? Let's say in terms of memory or creativity, because this is the thing that really concerns me.'

Dr. M:'As I was going to say earlier, the first two or three years of a baby's life, his or her brain has been very, very active, and the first several years of development are very active. So, the question is: What is the function of the spontaneous activity during these first several years of life?' Because all the circuits are reconfigured as the baby's brain develops, and the brain is very plastic. So, the brain is changing during this first year of life.'
Dr. B:'But what is the point of it? Why is it important? Can't we have a blank slate to start from? What is the function?'
Dr. M:'Yeah. Well, that is the question.'

Dr. B:'In other words, there's no answer right now. There's nothing in the brain, nothing in the brain. No synaptic connections, no wiring, no, and so on. It's, in fact, the blank slate. And then, we can start the process of learning. And then, when I was a student, I thought that was a very interesting thing.'
Dr. M:'So, we are learning.'
Dr. B:'Exactly. And we have learned a lot. So, let me be more specific. Let me be more specific.'
Dr. M:'Okay, sure. Go ahead.'

Dr. B:'How would you like to see a neural syntax? Now, you said that we are going to go through a list of things that we can discuss. And, so, I think we might look at some things that are in the brain that you've already started with.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. So, for example, we might look at the central pattern generator. You know, the pacemaker in the brain. The pacemaker in the central pattern generator, the pacemaker might produce rhythmic electrical activity, and that's important for maintaining a certain set of properties of the pacemaker cells that allows it to generate rhythmic bursts.'

Dr. B:'So, I'm not a neurologist, but as a neuroscientist, what is the most important function that we have to understand? Because it seems to me that this is what is at stake. What is at stake? We've got to understand what is going on in the brain. Because if you take it from the perspective of a neuronal network, this is what's at stake.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, it's the first question. So, first question is, why is it important? What is the point of these patterns of activity? Why is it not important if all of the circuits have been 'built' already?' Why is it important that the circuit is'reconfigured'?' Why is it 'taught'? Why is it important to know? Because, it doesn't matter how we are all wired, as long as we are 'wired' correctly.'

Dr. B:'Is there an important function we have to understand to understand how it all works? I mean, there is a function that you have to understand in order to understand how it works. So is there a function that we have not yet explained that has to be understood? Like, I don't have to explain that to you. It seems like you are already the person who knows how to explain how the brain works, right?'

Dr. B:'Can we have a blank paper and start from scratch? What is the, the function of those patterns of activity? If you take the perspective of a single neuron, this is what is going on. This is what is at stakes. So, the second question is, what is the point, or what's the function of these patterns? What is the 'point'? There are many possible explanations. What is the 'function' of a neural pattern? That's the second question.'

Dr. M:'It is, it is very important. I have spent a lot of time talking about the evolution of the brain. In the evolutionary sense, a nervous system has to change. You cannot have a central pattern generator without the ability to change. You can't have a central pattern, the central pattern generator.'

Dr. M:'I suppose it's necessary to have it to build circuits and to develop synapses. And, so, there are different levels of neural activity and we don't really know whether it is necessary for every cell, for every neuron to have that low level of neural activity, or if some of the neurons may be very active and some neurons may be very passive. But, this is an ongoing issue in neuroscience research. There is still no consensus on what the function of this is.'

Dr. B:'How do you know how to assign the appropriate function? What is a critical function? What is the most important function? What do you want to look at? What is the function of a network? And, so on. We have to get back to the brain, how we can find these brain mechanisms that are critical to cognition. But, it's hard. There are a lot of variables and a lot of factors that come into it. I mean, we have to consider all of them.'

Dr. B:'And what is the function of inhibition? What is the function of the interneuron network? What is the meaning of this particular network? This is a network, right, that's constantly active at the very low level, with a critical role in many brain operations. And so that's a fascinating thing, that when inhibition is turned on or off, the network activity goes up or down. What are the effects of these drugs? What are the effects? What are the mechanisms of these drugs?'

Dr. M:'Well, if you think about the effects of these kind of drugs, like if you think about a drug like a morphine, or like if you think of the effects of a morphine, morphine will have effects on all of these different systems. It will decrease pain in your body. So it's kind of like a painkiller. So that will decrease pain. It will decrease nausea and vomiting. It will decrease sweating, will decrease spiking.'

Dr. M:'There are two things that are known, one is that the neurons that are born, in terms of size, are fairly large neurons, like the big sensory neurons and the motor neurons. And then there are the small neurons and the neurons that give rise to the circuits that govern muscle contraction or the contraction of the heart or the contraction of muscles of the mouth.'
Dr. B:'The size of the neurons is important, right? How big is a neuron?'

Dr. M:'Well, the first thing is that you know in principle the neurons that are small in principle may be useful in some other way, because if the large neurons are doing something that you don't want, you can change your circuitry. So you have to decide that when you do develop a circuit that is going to operate in some given way whether it's useful in some other sense. You may want it to have some feature that you find useful.'
Dr. B:'What happens to the neurons that are not the right size? What happens to the neurons when you have to eliminate them, because that happens in the course of development, right?'

Dr. M:'You can actually grow some of the neurons. If you make the circuits with neurons that have a larger, more robust phenotype you can grow them up. And so you can actually control the size of some neurons. But there are also some neurons that are so small, the size of a neuron or the size of a synapse, or the size of an action potential that it's really not possible to build a circuit with them.'

Dr. M:'Well, this is probably the most important question. You see in this case, this is because in this case, we can observe how these neurons develop in the first place. The first thing you learn about a neuron is it has some activity and some time over the lifetime of a neuron you learn that this activity is very important to it. This is the first thing you learn, I mean, the most important thing to you, because it allows you to study the development of the neuron.'
Dr. B:'So, how does this lead to the second thing you learn about the neuron, which is the firing patterns of the neurons?'

Dr. M:'If you think of neurons in developing animals, they fire action potentials all of the time, but as they develop, the activity decreases, and that activity is important in producing the mature phenotype. We use these neurons to help regulate cell number and to produce the mature phenotype. There are other roles for that kind of activity, too.'

Dr. B:'It's a paradox that one can think about development in two ways. The first is that it is a natural progression from earlier stages to more complex ones. Or, the second way is that it is an orderly sequence of events that can be driven by the inputs that will give rise to the mature phenotype. I'm not sure which one is right.'

Dr. M:'The right answer depends on which kind of systems you're working on. If you're studying, say, an invertebrate brain, a crab brain, the role of neural activity is very different than the role of the brain in an animal that is learning to speak or understand complex language. The roles are different. But what we're discovering is that the systems, as they develop, they don't become a different system but they become specialized.'

Dr. B:'In my lab, we have a program called "neural syntax" where we have the tools to examine how neural information is segmented by various brain rhythms, and we're using those tools to identify the functions that are carried out in the development of the systems. It's a novel approach that I call "neural syntax".'

Dr. B:'I'm asking about the development of the brain. What is the function of neuronal activity during development? What is the purpose of neural activity during development? Because, what happens during development is critical for what happens when the brain is in an adult form.'
Dr. B:'Are there examples from the developing brain that we can use to illustrate how spontaneous activity affects the outcome? How does spontaneous activity develop in the developing brain?'

Dr. M:'You know, the example that comes to mind, and this has come to my mind a lot as a scientist working in the early years of molecular biology when we were trying to understand how the cell types were produced is the example of this, because there were many years of studies that led to the identification of these cell types, but we had no clue as to how many of these different cell types might be produced.'
Dr. B:'But if we had the knowledge that these were the sequences, how would that have changed your studies, in retrospect?'

Dr. M:'Yes, well, if we had the sequence, we might have been able to see in retrospect the cell types that would arise. So I don't think that we would have been in that dark, but that kind of illustrates how the activity changes during development.'

Dr. B:'So there are a couple of things that are very important. I'm thinking about how we use these cells in the mature brain. I'm not thinking about how we make these cells in a dish. I'm not talking about the mechanisms of those neurons. I'm asking how you use these cells in a brain. If you have a good idea what would be beneficial, what would be effective, how do you use these cells, what are the mechanisms?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, yeah, so first of all, the fact that they are present, and that they're there and they can be studied.'

Dr. M:'I think it's a matter of homeostatic regulation. The brain regulates itself during development to generate a circuit of activity patterns that are appropriate for that animal. The regulatory mechanisms are really important because the brain is a plastic organ and it's plasticity that enables these homeostatic mechanisms to be built into the system is really important.'

Dr. B:'If you look at the brain at a very fundamental level, there is only a limited number of brain functions. There are only a limited number the various sensory and motor actions that can be generated. The brain has the potential to generate all of the sensory and motor actions there is in the environment. All the sensory and motor behaviors that could be done by the brain, or any other system, have already been done. It's impossible to invent something new in biology or physics.'

Dr. M:'It is essential for maintaining neural connectivity between neurons. This is because, as the neurons develop, the synaptic connectivity and the intrinsic properties of their neurons become interdependent. This is especially important in the case of neurons that receive multiple inhibitory inputs. So there are multiple ways in which activity can modify the synaptic interactions and the intrinsic properties. It also produces developmental changes in synaptic dynamics and also can be essential for other functional processes. There are multiple roles that activity can play in developmental processes and during development.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special role of gamma oscillations in this process? If there is, please, go into the details. It would be very important.'
Dr. M:'Yes, I've been reading about this in an old book called the Developmental Consequences of the Pyloric Circuit in the STG.'

Dr. B:'Please, go ahead. Please, go ahead. There are many different ways in which activity in local circuits can affect the connectivity, synaptic strength, and intrinsic properties of the neurons. We are just interested, here, in the effects of activity on gamma oscillations. The reason why it is so critical is because, as discussed, it can have a major impact on connectivity and the intrinsic membrane properties of the cells.'
Dr. M:'So it can be very critical to be able to have, when one cell is changing, a feedback to the rest of the circuit so that the circuit can accommodate to the change.'

Dr. B:'There are two possible ways in which activity of a single cell can affect its peers. The first one is through a synapse that connects between the two cells. So this is, for example, the case of the STG circuit and the way the SPG circuit works. Now, the second case is when there are no such synapses, but the activity can affect the properties of the cell membrane. So for example, the way the neocortex functions.'
Dr. M:'And the way the retina functions.'

Dr. B:'So, that's a nice example because in the neocortex it is a single cell that affects the membrane properties of its target neurons. So for example in the hippocampus, the activity of a single place cell can affect the synaptic efficacy of its target pyramidal cells and inhibitory interneurons, and that will also, therefore, change the firing patterns of the neurons in the circuit.'
Dr. M:'But not necessarily the total number of pyramidal cells. Right.'

Dr. B:'And the same is true for all other circuits. But the thing is, if you, for example, are trying to have a conversation about, say, sleep in a single neuron, then you need to know how it affects the neurons that are, and in the case of the hippocampus, how it affects its peers in the CA3 and CA1 regions. And in the case of STG, how it affects the CA1 region.'
Dr. B:'Please, tell us about that book. What's it about? Where is it? Why should I read it? I'm not familiar with this book. What is it about?'

Dr. M:'OK. So, this book by Wollenschlager was actually published in 1942. And it was about a nervous system that had been experimentally removed from the crab stomatogastric ganglion. In this experiment, the neuroscientists removed the stomatogastic ganglion by making cuts along the nerves. This allowed the neurons to die and the ganglion to atrophy.'
Dr. B:'How does the brain generate spontaneous activity?'

Dr. M:'Mostly the brain generates motor patterns for feeding and breathing, and there are also important rhythmic patterns that are generated by the nervous system, that are important for muscle movements. All the rhythmic activity is generated in the muscle movement, whereas the neural pattern generator is often separate from the muscle movement.'

Dr. M:'You know, I've been looking into that. There's some pretty interesting ideas that are being published. I'm still kind of, I'm kind of at the stage of not having a clue as to how these things are going to fit into how neural function is going to work. Like, the whole thing is the fact that these networks are all built-up of thousands of interacting neurons, and so you have to get the connectivity right. So, how does it get built?'
Dr. B:'It seems to me that spontaneous activity is the way to go.'
Dr. B:'How many years have we got left? How long do you think we have to figure out how to do this?'

Dr. M:'No. You know, we're thinking there might be several years before we start putting stuff into the body. So, the best time to do it would be after we have, you know, it's just after we have done all the fundamental work, you know, I don't know. But you know, because, so, you know, in our work, you know when I started out, we did some work on how neurons work.'
Dr. B:'The rest is history?'

Dr. B:'That's what you were trying to tell me before, right? What you were trying to say is, is that the best time to figure out how these things are done is after, or after we have already done a lot of work on the fundamental parts of these problems. And so, you know so that in the future, when we can, when we have a lot of work done already, then we can start applying it to the problems.'
Dr. M:'Well, we have, we have a lot more than we can apply now.'

Dr. B:'I'm a bit more optimistic, though. I'm more optimistic. I'm very optimistic, too, but I'm not sure. But I'm very optimistic. Because it's such a difficult problem. Dr. B:'The fundamental unit of information in the brain is the neuron. And, a single neuron generates a very large number of spikes. Dr. M:'So, it's sort of the number of spikes per burst, but the bursts have a characteristic duration. So, it's sorta the number of spikes, the number of spikes times the duration of the burst. So, it looks more like the number of spikes x duration, rather than like the number of bits.'

Dr. B:'Yes. But, this is also the number of spikes a neuron can produce in the time that you would refer to as one oscillation. Dr. M:'Spontaneous neural activity during development? Why? Why?'

Dr. M:'OK, we'll explain it. Spontaneous neural activity means that the nervous system is active without having been externally stimulated. Dr. M:'The role of the nervous system during development of the nervous system is critical for the generation of the brain, so the nervous system is doing all kinds of things, including making sure that neurons develop and become functional, and that circuits become stable, and that circuit activity doesn't disrupt normal development'.
