Is it simply a matter of developing these circuits to the right length? Or is there a more complex issue of how these circuits are wired together, what's the function of the wiring patterns, etc.? Is this an issue we have to worry about? Or do we ignore it until we have to worry?'

Dr. M:'You know, if you really want to understand the brain, and you ask me that question and I'm an experimentalist, I don't really like to talk to people about their dreams. So I think we have to figure out, you know, what the function of the brain is and how it has evolved. I think that's important to realize is that we have a lot of tools to solve that problem.'

Dr. B:'And how did you come to that? Is this what you spent your whole life? Or have you had other interests? Or is this what you're interested in now? If so, is it different than when you first entered the field? Or did you have a specific career goal from the beginning that you thought you might end up on, and then you ended up on it? Or was this just what you fell into, where the path was. So if so, where would you be?'

Dr. B:'But are these the same tools that we have to understand how the circuits are wired together? Is this a question we have to answer? Or do we use the same set of tools to answer the question of the function of wiring patterns?'

Dr. B:'I'm going to pick up on that. What does the brain want to do? What is the brain's function? What is the neural syntax? Is it the same as the syntax in the language? Is it fundamentally different? Are they similar or fundamentally different? We're looking at brain patterns in the same way that we looked at words. We have to understand how the brain is organized in order to explain how the brain works.'
Dr. M:'I study the function of neural activity, its function in normal animals, because neural activity during development is quite different from activity in adult animals.'
Dr. B:'What are the differences in neural activity between adult and embryonic development? If there are such differences, I would like to learn more about them.'

Dr. M:'A lot of work has been done on embryonic development. The first thing to think about is that the neural circuits develop in the embryo in a completely different way. For example, neural circuits in the embryo can be quite small and simple. In fact, they have a tendency to be small and simple and often have very simple dynamics. And they may not have all the neurons in them that later become functional in the adult.'
Dr. B:'How does it change with age? In other words, how does the brain grow from the point of view of the developing brain? How does a baby's brain grow?'
Dr. B:'Are there any other differences in the early development of neural activity? If so, what are they?'

Dr. M:'It has to be tuned, but it also has to be maintained. The brain has to have a set of properties during development that makes it useful for cognition in the adult. It is possible that the properties of the brain change over time, during development. This is what makes them different from other animals in the world. They may lose some of the properties of their brain during development, and they may gain new ones.'
Dr. B:'What makes the brain different from other animals? Why is it special? How did you get interested in neuroscience?'
Dr. B:'But it's the new ones that are important for cognition.'

Dr. M:'Yes. Yes. Yes. The new ones are important for cognition. It is important for the neural circuits to be in a state that makes them robust, that they maintain their function over time. This makes me think about the function of neuromodulation.'
Dr. B:'Well, this is the part of the story that you want to tell. Can you explain that?'

Dr. B:'Well, you mentioned it in your answer, but what are these new circuits that are important? It's not clear. Can you tell us, for instance, why the hippocampus is so important for memory? It's not really clear. What do you think is the function of the hippocampus? How is this a new circuit? Or are there other circuits? Or do you think there are new circuits that are specifically useful for cognition? It's not exactly clear.'
Dr. B:'I was wondering how the brain's initial conditions affect how its function changes when the brain develops.'

Dr. M:'If you start your system with a fixed set of parameters, I would imagine that those parameters would stay fixed, because all the biochemical processes that depend on those parameters would be very tightly regulated. And the parameters would be fixed by synaptic connections and by hormonal connections. The brain would be like any other organ, in the sense that it would not be perfectly tuned. And the regulation of these parameters would be critical to maintaining normal activity.'

Dr. B:'Can you give me examples that would illustrate the idea that synaptic connections and hormonal changes affect the regulation of neuronal activity? How would these parameters change when the brain develops?'

Dr. M:'Well, for example, in the pacemaker network that is responsible for maintaining the rhythmic firing of the two pacemaker cells in the pyloric rhythm, for example, changes in the activity of the pyloric neurons during development may alter the regulation of the pacemaker cells, and lead to different patterns of pyloric firing, which in turn can lead to changes in the functional output of the network.'
Dr. B:'Do we know the initial conditions that are responsible for the changes in synaptic connections and hormones? What would they be?'

Dr. M:'One of the most general mechanisms for regulating synaptic output is homeostatic regulation, which is driven by feedback from synaptic output. When I talk to people, I find that they have this picture in their mind, and this picture is not correct, because we don't see these homeostatic mechanisms.'

Dr. B:'But how would you suggest that a homeostatic mechanism operates? What would be its mechanism? Would it be like in the brain where there are lots of connections and we can find and eliminate them? Or would it be more like in the heart, where we have two levels of regulation? What are the two levels of regulation, and what is the mechanism by which they work?'

Dr. M:'Right, and it turns out that these two levels, and these two are in fact the only ones that are important, the two main regulatory mechanisms that are responsible for regulating synaptic output. So that the first mechanism is a synaptic mechanism, which involves inhibitory connections from the neurons onto the pacemaker cells. And this is a fast, almost instant process.'

Dr. B:'It is also possible that the properties are constant, and what happens to the organism is the brain's response to the change in the environment. This is what I want to learn more about. Can you give me an example from an animal with which you are working that shows the influence of the internal dynamics of the brain on how the organism behaves?'

Dr. M:'Yes. The crab,  Cancer borealis, has many different neurons, and some are electrically coupled. Each of these different types of neurons is electrically coupled to the others, and there is a cascade of activity, a cascade of neurons that are all firing together.'
Dr. B:'How many neurons are there in the cascade?'
Dr. M:'Two or three, I guess.'
Dr. B:'Do we know how many different types of neurons there are in the cortex of the brain?'

Dr. M:'There are 26 different neurons, and they fire sequentially and together. We can determine which neurons are active because we can see the activity of the other neurons. We can see the activity in the lateral gastric neuron because it is connected to the STG, which sends out axons, which are visible. We can tell which neurons are active by watching the activity in the motor neuron.'

Dr. M:'Well, there are examples that come from work done on a small network of neurons in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion. The stomatogaster is actually a very small ganglion, so it's basically two neurons, the 2nd and 3rd neurons, that are responsible for chewing, and for maintaining the mastication rhythm of the animal. They can be thought of as the pyloric and gastric mill neurons.'

Dr. M:'Well, the first phase of development, you want your cells to be quiet because they're very important to the differentiation of tissues and the formation of patterns of circuits. In the second phase, you want them to be very quiet, because that's when the circuits have to become active, and they need to become reliable, and that means they have to have the kind of robustness and reliability that you would see in circuits of neurons that you use every day.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function of the first phase? What is the function of that phase? What is...'

Dr. M:'I mean, the function of that first phase is to make sure that the cells are very reliable during that transition from the first phase to the second phase. Because the networks that will form in the second phase are going to be highly regulated, and highly regulated because you want the circuits that you're forming to be reliable.'
Dr. B:'But what is the function during that transition phase? What is it good for? Or what is it good for?'

Dr. M:'So it's good for cell differentiation. It's good for cell development, because the differentiation has to occur during that transition. That transition occurs over weeks, and months, and years. And so by allowing neurons to fire spontaneously in that transition period between those two phases, you know, we're not asking them to fire for a certain length of time.'
Dr. M:'Well, as you can see in the stomatogastric nervous system of  C. borealis, and other invertebrates, these networks are very dynamic.'
Dr. B:'So, this is a simple network? What are some functions it performs?'
Dr. M:'It produces rhythmic motor patterns.'
Dr. B:'Is this a good idea? Do these brain systems just evolve for this purpose, or does some brain system use it for this purpose? What are some other functions it performs?'

Dr. M:'Oh, many other functions. As you can imagine with a nervous system as complex as ours, there are many functional reasons for the network to be active. I mean, neurons, neurons and circuits have to maintain a certain level of activity. You know, neurons are supposed to fire over a certain range of activity, and they want to keep that activity.'

Dr. B:'So how would you characterize these spontaneous patterns? For instance, the stomatocarpic ganglion, which is a very simple system, has just one main central neuron which responds to food and one other cell that responds to vibrations in the brain. But, these other neurons can give rise to a lot of activity, but their sole function is to transmit action potentials to their targets.'

Dr. M:'But in the stomato-carpic ganglION, we found that the neuron in the stomatorca ganglION, which responded to vibrations in the  brain, also had activity in the stomatosac. So the neural circuit had a dual function of responding to food and also responding to sensory stimulation of the brain. So these networks can be quite flexible.'

Dr. B:'Can I ask you one question? What are the advantages of a dynamic network over an unchanging static one? I mean, we are a bit of an engineering term. What is your engineering solution? What would you design for a system that has perpetual activity? The advantage of activity would be that the brain would be able to be able to learn and adapt to changes in the environment. It's a bit like a stock market or any system where there is an adaptation to external influences.'

Dr. M:'Yes, exactly, and also because the circuit is very important in development, because if you think about your nervous system, it's got to have a variety of behaviors, for example, a variety of synaptic transmission rates, and there's no set rates, you need to be able to change those rates, you need a variety of conductance densities, all of which must be consistent. So it's got to be really rigid.'

Dr. B:'You know, you've brought up an interesting point. I have been interested in the ability to move neural circuits and I have been interested, or in the ability to create new circuits for a long time, but, um, it's been very difficult. I mean, a few things have been tried, but they have been very difficult to scale up, but now we have the technology that allows the modification of circuit structure. It's becoming a reality.'
Dr. M:'And so you can change the synaptic connectivity or the synaptic conductances, the membrane conductances. So you can change a circuit.'

Dr. B:'Well, of course, and it's a question that I am really looking forward to answering. So it's a question with a huge engineering, computational solution. So the question is how can we change a circuit, and, and we'll answer that. So that's the question that I'm looking forward to answering in a little bit, and then we can have a discussion about it.'

Dr. M:'So, for instance, if you look at the network of the central pacemaker neuron of the pyloric circuit in the STNS, the pacemaker kernel is surrounded by many neurons that have a little bit of independent function, but the pacemaker kernel itself generates the action potentials that it responds to. And we're studying these neurons as well, as you can imagine.'

Dr. B:'How important are these mechanisms to cognition? And in particular, how much do you think they contribute to cognition? Is it possible that the brain generates a large repertoire of sequences from a very small repertoire of genetic instructions, and that these sequences are used for the construction of the neural syntax? Or do you prefer the second approach, where the brain is not a syntactical device, but a physical system that generates an ever-changing repertoire of sequences that are used to represent a particular percept or construct?'

Dr. M:'In a way, it depends on whether you're a mathematician or a physicist. When you're a mathematician, you like to think of the brain as an entity that generates a repertoire of sequences of numbers that are used to construct different kinds of functions, so that that kind of a sequence generator is useful. But if you're a physicist, you like to study the laws that govern the behavior of systems, so you tend to be more interested in how systems work, and how things in nature work.'

Dr. B:'And I think that there's a fundamental difference in this. You just said that this is a sequence generator, right? But what if you just say that the brain is a sequence generator? Is it the case that the brains ability to generate sequences is just as useful as a sequence generator? And what are the functions of the brain, and what are the sequences that it generates? Is there a special role of the sequence generator? Or does the sequence generator make any special contribution at all?'

Dr. M:'It has been documented that during development of the nervous system, neurons are active in the absence of inhibitory neuromodulation. That is part of the normal growth of the system, the normal maturation of the nervous system. It is known that during development of sensory neurons and during maturation of motor neurons, as the nervous system is growing and developing, there is a series of changes in their membrane properties, changes in their patterns of synaptic connectivity.'
Dr. B:'What is the function then of spontaneous activity during development?'

Dr. M:'We would like to think that that would be just something that would allow the neurons to grow and develop in their correct connectivity, but if we found that, it might be important that it is part of the mechanisms that allow neuronal circuits to develop properly.'
Dr. M:'Well, it's kind of obvious, isn't it? It's that neurons in the early stages of development have a set of intrinsic excitability properties that allow them to respond to a variety of stimuli.'
Dr. B:'And do those responses continue throughout life?'
Dr. M:'Absolutely. The problem is that all of those underlying, innate, excitable properties of neurons can be altered by different modulatory inputs.'
Dr. B:'So what is the main function of spontaneous activity of the cortex in early life, and the function of activity at adulthood, if any?'

Dr. M:'Yeah, most of the neural circuits that are present in adults—they're either present during development and they're there throughout life, or they were not present during development and you have to add them on top later on. For example, in the cortex of a developing heart, most of the neurons are present, but there are neurons that have to be recruited to drive rhythmic movements.'

Dr. M:'Well, we have learned that these rhythms, these oscillations, are the function of the central pattern generating networks of many neurons. It's a set of circuits with different properties that work together to generate the rhythmic activity that is seen in many neurons.'
Dr. B:'Is there a special reason why these rhythms are so critical for brain development? Or could it just be some chance that it happened to be this way?'

Dr. M:'I don't think so, because these are the very early networks that arise in developing animals. The rhythmic nature of these networks gives them the capacity to change, to grow, to respond to many modulators that become available at different times in the animal's lifetime. It gives them the capacity for learning, for making new associations, for understanding and then understanding others.'
Dr. B:'If so, why are they not just simply a byproduct? And what is the function? And what is a byproduct? Because they are there, they are doing something, or they are not.'

Dr. M:'They're doing something. They're giving rise to the functional circuits that we have in the brain. So, the brain is a circuit of circuits. So we're talking about neurons, synapses, circuits. There are circuits for chewing, circuits for swallowing, for digestion, for processing information, circuits for storing information, circuits for understanding and then, and understanding others.'

Dr. B:'But it can be a byproduct of the other functions. And, and what other functions are those? And what happens when the function is severed? So what would be the consequences? And what are the consequences of disconnecting these circuits? We can't afford to have this happen.'
Dr. M:'Okay, so disconnecting circuits, the consequences are bad. And this has been seen with different systems in the past.'
Dr. B:'So it is not a case that this is a random activity that occurs, but that in fact, it is organized. This is important because the brain doesn't do things that are not useful.'

Dr. M:'Well, we know that animals develop, and that development depends on neural activity. But we also know that development does not depend entirely on the activity of one single neuron, but depends on the interactions of multiple neurons. So my work has focused on examining the function of neural activity in development, and it has also focused on the interactions between multiple neurons and the effects of neuromodulators.'

Dr. M:'I'm going to answer that by showing you some experimental results, from which you can see, and it's kind of obvious when you just look at this data, that it's a fundamental question that we should be asking ourselves. Because you're saying, you know, we all look at ourselves as adults, and we talk about things that matter, and what's important, and it sounds like you're asking me to be the adult.'

Dr. M:'It's thought that the developing network becomes a self-regulating regulator of neural circuit structure. This may involve cell death or regulation of connectivity among neurons and circuits. You see, when you develop the neurons, it's thought that they will always be in their correct synaptic connectivity, and that they will be active at their proper frequency. And you know, they also must be active in the appropriate pattern of activity, and this is very different from when you're studying a network in vitro.'

Dr. B:'Is it possible that some of these activity patterns, in which we're very familiar with, that's what we see when we're studying the brains of humans and other animals, are actually critical in allowing the brain to function, and we have to study these events in a way that really allows us to observe how they affect and interact with the activity patterns that we observe in the intact brain?'

Dr. M:'The function of neural activity during development is to produce a stereotyped brain architecture. It's also a way to control development. Neural activity provides a reliable way to synchronize neurons and to establish network relationships in developing neurons. In adults, neural activity is very important for sensory and motor functions. Neural activity is important for memory and synaptic function. Neural activity is critical for maintaining appropriate behavior. It's a fact that during development the frequency of many brain oscillations goes up or down.'

Dr. B:'What is the function for neural activity in adult organisms? What are the benefits of the brain's spontaneous activity? I'm not a doctor, so I'm not asking a real question, but it's important because this is where we have to make a judgment of the usefulness of our work to others. The first reason why I would like to know is what is the purpose of the neural activity? So, you're looking at the brains in a developing brain and there are many oscillations.'

Dr. M:'When we were doing experimental work with the crab,  Cancer borealis, which has a pacemaker kernel that we studied for many years, and you were saying something about using electrical stimulation, this is something we tried to do. And one of the things you have to do in an experiment is you have to be able to control the frequency of the brain oscillations. We wanted to understand how the pacemaker kernel works.'

Dr. B:'What's the advantage of this organization? What are some disadvantages? And what are the advantages of different types of organized activity? What is the function of these neural activities in the adult brain?'

Dr. M:'If you ask the animal, 'What are you doing with all of these rhythmic neural activity?' I think they'll say, 'I'm trying to produce a reliable nervous system for myself.' I think it will be hard for the animal to explain why it is different from other animals. There's a number of different advantages. There's a lot of variability between animals. There are several advantages to having a certain pattern of neural activity, but some of the disadvantages you may ask.'

Dr. B:'In terms of function, what's the advantage of neural activity during learning? How does activity in the brain during learning lead to a reliable behavioral response? Do we have a theory that can describe that? What do we know about that?'

Dr. M:'It turns out that activity is good at some times, bad at others. Activity is good at times when we are learning, when we're starting to learn and when we're doing things that we're trying to learn. That's when the neural activity is good.'

Dr. M:'During development the neural systems must change as they develop and this can involve not only their morphology, but also their physiological properties. It's well known that changes in the neuromodulatory system can cause changes in neural network properties. And there are examples of neural systems that are completely or nearly completely dependent on neuromodulation and that show a great deal of change over the lifetime of a nervous system.'
Dr. B:'How would such a change in properties of a neural network be accomplished?'

Dr. M:'You could imagine, for example, a change that's similar to the changes that occur in a mature nervous system. Because in a mature nervous it's quite common that a neuron shows a ton of activity at one point in time but then at a particular time of its lifetime it suddenly shows almost no activity. And that might be part of a larger change. That a neuron's properties, in many cases, could change by many different routes.'

Dr. B:'Do these changes in properties occur for the sake of development or are they for some other purpose? And would these changes have any implications for what happens to the brain when we're adults?'

Dr. M:'Oh, I think this will have implications for our brains, for our brains' function. This is obviously because our brains develop differently as adults than children. So there'll be changes that occur, that might be quite different from how things are in an adult.'

Dr. M:'Some of the changes can have deleterious consequences. I've never seen a study that actually looked at what happens when you start altering a neuron's properties in adulthood, but I'm pretty sure that neurons that are not functional as adults are likely to be dead, at least partly. I know we studied the effects of altering the properties of a cell on the properties of a different cell and that caused it to go through multiple states.'

Dr. B:'What was the nature of these changes? Did the new neuron show an increase in excitability? Did it have less response to inputs? What was the effect on its firing patterns? Does the new neuron have an effect on its neighbors? What was the change in its ability to interact with its neighbors and how did the changes affect its ability to interact across networks? What was the impact on the overall properties of the network?'

Dr. M:'The biggest change, I think, that's associated with developmental changes is that at the cellular level these neurons and networks behave in ways that are different from the way they behave when they're mature, and they probably also behave in ways that would be different when they're adult. But I can't think of specific changes that would alter the effect of these networks on the rest of the system, I don't know that.'
Dr. B:'What's the function of spontaneous activity in adult brains?'

Dr. M:'So, to me, the most important thing is, as we say, that you cannot rely on these networks to maintain stable activity patterns. So that they're intrinsically oscillatory, and so that you want to find a stable network of activity patterns, and I think the same applies for animals, the same thing in animals. So you want to find stable networks of behavior, stable networks of motor patterns, stable networks of pyloric circuits, that you have to tune and find and fit.'

Dr. B:'But how do you build a network that can sustain activity? It's a simple question. You say, "I want to make an autonomous system." It's a simple goal. And so you would think that there is a simple way to build a network that will be able to sustain activity in a particular direction.'
Dr. M:'Well, because you have to do this in many different brain regions, and you have to do it with many different sets of neurons.'
Dr. M:'I can tell you that, you will understand better what the role of neuromodulation is when you understand the importance of this activity.'

Dr. B:'How? I mean, how can you explain to a young child the importance of oscillations in the brain? If he/she cannot perceive the importance, how can he/she ever go on to have the insight that there's nothing more important than brain rhythms?'
Dr. B:'Why do I need to know this?'
Dr. B:'What are the mechanisms that support this activity?'

Dr. M:'There are different kinds of neuromodulators that you can study, and we have been studying all of these modulators that come into our brain and they modify our behaviour. It's important that you understand that we don't have a fixed set of mechanisms and they will be different depending on the situation, depending on the animal, and depending on the type of neurons that we have.'
Dr. B:'I'm not interested in the details of the physiological mechanisms. I'm interested in understanding the function of spontaneous activity. What is it?'

Dr. M:'Well, what is it? The role that neural activity plays in development is fundamental to understanding how neuromodulation works. Because we know that, at some point in development, neural activity stops.'

Dr. B:'So the question is whether this activity is there to have some function or whether it is there to serve some function. In that case, how do we know what that function is? And this activity should be there, in your opinion, for a reason. I know that this is the only way that we can understand the functions of the brain is if we have some way of testing what is the reason that this activity is there.'

Dr. M:'In the absence of neuromodulators there are many ways for a neuron to activate a circuit. In a developing animal the neurons will respond to each other. Some of these responses will depend on the activity of all neurons present in the network and these will be the strongest.'
Dr. B:'Which one of the following would you be interested in understanding in further detail?'
Dr. M:'The second one?'
Dr. M:'I would really like to understand what is going on when the whole nervous system, the circuit is active.'
Dr. B:'And why is it important?'

Dr. B:'So, let me ask you a question. What does it mean to be embedded in a circuit? What does it mean that all neurons in the circuit are embedded? What is the function of self-organized activity? What happens to those neurons in the absence of activity? Let me start. What is the function?'

Dr. M:'I would argue that the function is that it is necessary to have a nervous system that is able to respond to all of the environmental changes in the world that we have been finding. We have evolved over tens of thousands of years to be able to respond to changes in environmental temperature and humidity, and to be able to provide temperature compensation. In addition, animals are able to function in all kinds of environments.'
Dr. B:'What does it mean that a brain is embedded in a circuit?'

Dr. M:'The first thing you have to understand is that the nervous system develops in two phases. There's an early phase when neurons start their differentiation and are developing their circuits that produce basic behaviors, and then they enter the mature phase as their networks, their circuits come together and they develop their functions. So it's a two-step process.'
Dr. B:'What are the basic functions of the developing brain?'

Dr. M:'Well, so the most fundamental function is to keep the body going, to make the cells produce and maintain all their cellular functions, and then the nervous system is there to regulate the body and to provide the control. So it's really two phases. So the initial phase, the most fundamental phase, is the body.'

Dr. M:'Well, you've got the basics of motor pattern generating, you've got memory storage, etc. That's why in  The Blind Watchmaker  you've got the story about the pigeon, because he has to remember that he's going to be able to find food, and he's going to remember that he can survive and he's going be able to survive the flight, he's going to do all these things.'

Dr. B:'Is there a basic function of the developing brain for which no mechanism has been proposed, that is the goal? Are there any hypothetical functions? Are there any functions? If not, then is there some reason why you'd like to answer that question differently? Or is there one that you are particularly curious about?'

Dr. B:'So the main functions of the developing mind are to generate behavior and survive? What if you just take a small brain from a developing brain, and say, "What if we just keep it alive?" What would happen?'

Dr. M:'So if you just keep it alive without putting in any extra functionalities, the brain would just go into a kind of steady-state. It wouldn't develop new circuits or new features and it would be, it wouldn't do anything, it wouldn't grow. It wouldn't change, it would just be stable, and then as these circuits were added it would be able to add new features, and it would develop itself.'

Dr. M:'So as you develop your neural circuits you're developing not just your sensory and motor circuits but also your higher-order circuits that govern your behavior, so that you can develop complex behaviors.'

Dr. M:'In a developing brain, as you develop neurons, as circuits develop in these small circuits, you can see how they are electrically coupled, and they can play a role in the modulation of other neurons, and they can be regulated by neuromodulators and hormones. So we really believe that there are different modulators and different hormones that are important for the development of circuits, and the modulation of networks and the development of behaviors.'
Dr. B:'Do we know what those specific functions are?'
Dr. B:' What is the function of theta oscillations during the early phase of development?'

Dr. M:'So the theta oscillations are a part of neural activity in the developing brain. There's different cells, different neurons that all have similar firing properties in these small networks that fire with an alternation between the two, a similar, well, rhythmic firing, as it were. So they're a feature of neural activity during development, and I believe it's been studied, but I know it's been studied. I've studied it in the crab and in the lobster.'

Dr. M:'Well, it is critical that the nervous system be functional when a baby is born, and as the circuits become more complex during development, it is important that those circuits be maintained and supported.'
Dr. B:'What do we know about this topic?'

Dr. M:'There's a lot of work on this topic, but I'll start with a summary of some of the main issues. There's been a great deal of work in the past 40 years on the role of rhythmic neural activity during development, both in model systems in which the rhythms were studied and in the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system, where the stomatogastic ganglion was dissected away from the rest of the nervous system.'
Dr. B:'Why is it important?'

Dr. M:'It's important because it provides the basic rules for neuronal and network assembly during development. For instance, it is the rule of connectivity, which is the way neurons connect with each other. All neurons of the same type in the nervous system connect with each other, and those connections are conserved throughout development. Neuronal type is not fixed, and neurons can change over time, but the connectivity rules that dictate network activity and circuit formation are conserved.'
Dr. B:'I'm not going to interrupt you, but why is it so important that this rule be maintained? How could a malfunctioning network result in a developmental disability?'

Dr. M:'We know that many neurons and circuits have been characterized, and they can be categorized into many different functional groups, and the neural systems are relatively consistent across species.'
Dr. B:'So how does this lead to a useful answer for what's the function of spontaneous activity?'
Dr. M:'By definition, you are trying to understand the function of neural circuits. And to do that, you have to understand what the properties of neural circuits are.'
Dr. B:'Well, I'd like to say something, then, from the perspective of spontaneous activity. I am a long-time practitioner, and I have had a lot of success and failures with spontaneous activity.'

Dr. M:' Well, I think this helps you to find the function of activity, because if you look at the data, you find that many of the neurons are doing the same tasks, and often many of the circuits are doing the same task, and therefore this gives you an insight into the functional connectivity of the circuit, and then you start to understand the function of activity by finding out the relationship between neurons and networks, and that's a big part of what we are studying.'
Dr. M:'Well, we see that there are two sets of neurons: one set that's bursting in the frequency range you see in adults and one set that is bursting in a much more limited range in juveniles.'

Dr. M:'I'm working on that, and so many neurons. I mean, when you look at an example of a single neuron, you know, it can't be independent, but in networks, there are many neurons that are independently active, but they all have their roles and they interact. So you kind of have to have a good idea of how they interact and how they do it.'

Dr. B:'Yeah, that's been known for years. But I mean, what is the function? Is it a byproduct of the wiring or the wiring a byproduct of function? Or is it simply a result of some sort of a random noise?'
Dr. M:'Well, I'm working on that.'

Dr. B:'So what happens if you suppress all spontaneous activity? Do we get something different? I mean, that's, the brain can't be just silent. There's no such thing as just silence. There's not enough silence to be useful. We're talking about spontaneous activity here.'

Dr. M:' The function of neural activity during development is that it provides feedback for the regulation of synaptic transmission, because during development the synapses are not yet present and are regulated by the nervous system. In the mature nervous system, spontaneous neural activity provides feedback to the synapse-forming neurons. There are no direct changes to synaptic transmission during development because the synaptic connections are still present.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for spontaneous activity during the development of neuronal circuits?'

Dr. M:' During the development of neuronal networks, the neurons are 'prepared' to send out the synaptic connections and their intrinsic properties. They acquire their electrical properties and ionic currents that are required for their function in networks. In most preparations, during early stages of development, the cells have tonic activity that is relatively high. Then during the late stages of development, activity of the neurons tends to become more sporadic.'
Dr. B:' What is the function of sponta-neous activity in the adult brain?'

Dr. M:' Well, as I said, activity in the adult nervous system is not spontaneous, but instead it is governed by synaptic inputs. But if you look at activity in the adult network in the sense that we all have cell phones. We all have little gadgets. It is a much lower activity than it is during the development and juvenile phases. And these two phases are absolutely critical for the way that neurons and synapses are regulated.'

Dr. M:'Well, I mean there are really two different approaches to how you develop a brain. First of all, you start out with a fully-functional brain, and you grow from there. So I know many, many nervous systems, where the nerves are intact, but the circuits that are produced are not fully-functional. And the brain's architecture is very fixed. And you kind of develop this network, and these circuits develop, and the brain develops as you do.'

Dr. M:'Well, we are born with an incomplete brain. In fact, many, many, many neurons are missing. Dr. M:'There are two functions of spontaneous activity during development of a neuronal circuit. One is regulation of synaptic transmission because the synapses are immature. As an example, as I described, the network of the pacemaker of the lobster, Stomatogastric ganglion, can change during development.'

Dr. M:'So, I think there's two different ways of looking at it. And then the other one is the functional requirement. So, the fact that neurons fire is necessary to produce functional neurons.'

Dr. B:'Now, if you have a neuron which is capable of responding to a given input and firing at a given time, and that is the only input, then what is the output? This is where I put in a challenge because a single neuron only ever produces a single output. The output of that neuron is determined by its upstream input, the other neurons. Is that correct? What do you have in mind?'

Dr. M:'And that's a funny question. So I have to do experiments on these cells because the neural activity is a little bit like, if you're a bird, and you're sitting on a branch and you see a worm on the branch. You've got to be able to find the worm. You don't want to move it because if you move it, it'll eat the worm. So the activity has to be regulated.'
Dr. B:'So the question is whether the brain is in control of spontaneous activity or vice versa, as some people would suggest.'

Dr. M:'That is a very good question, and I think I am going to discuss it in a different context, but I would first say that, because it is known that many of the intrinsic properties of neural activity in animals change as they grow and develop. So the answer is that it is important to measure all of the properties of neural activity. One of the properties of the neural activity is that you can detect changes in the frequency of the spikes and their phase relationships.'

Dr. B:'Okay. What is the functional significance of the oscillation? Is it good? Is it good for memory? Is it good to enhance? Is it good or bad to block? Is it good because it's important? Is it important because it's a big wave?'
Dr. M:'Well it's obviously necessary for the maturation of the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'In order to answer that, we would have to know a lot about the maturation process of the nervous system, and what are the consequences of different maturation phases. That would be very difficult to answer because the brain is a complicated system, composed of many cells with diverse functions, but the maturation process is a simple process. The brain is developed from a single cell to a full blown system.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'Now, what is the function of the maturation process? This may be easy to answer. It's very useful to remember a few things about the maturation of any system. The most important thing is that the system that emerges from its immature phase is stable, and the system that emerges when it is matured is also stable. Now, let me ask this, what's the function of the immature brain?'
Dr. B:'What makes it so crucial? Is there any such thing as'spontaneous activity'?'

Dr. M:'Well, the function of activity is one of feedback. The idea is that you are always trying to produce an appropriate set of physiological properties to your brain.' So, the way that neural activity develops depends on the activity that your brain is experiencing, and also on the feedback that you are receiving from neurons and neuromodulators, which provide a variety of feedbacks about the environment that the brain is living in.'

Dr. B:'Do neurons have a default pattern for activity? If you look at how a pyramidal cell behaves, it's very different from the how a nonpyramidal neuron behaves. So, the question is how this process, that occurs throughout the life of the brain, that produces a pattern that makes sense of the data that we have, and whether that's a default pattern or whether it can be changed.'

Dr. M:'You are talking about neural activity patterns. So, the answer to your question depends on what pattern of activity your brain is living in. If your brain is living with its friends the pylons in a crowded, noisy, noisy environment, then the neurons may be firing all kinds of other neurons, and there are many ways that the brain can compensate for this and that it might be quite likely that the neurons will change the activity pattern, because that would be adaptive.'

Dr. B:'How about in the absence of the external influences, which is to say in a very well isolated and closed system where activity can just occur. What patterns of activity would emerge? In fact, the answer to that question is the same as the answer to the question for development.'

Dr. M:'Okay, let's look at the question for development. This is a very fascinating part of neuroscience that we have talked about before, because we think, of course, that if you are a cell, if you are a neuron, that you just know what you need to do.'

Dr. B:'What would it do? What would it do? So, the answer is the same as it is for the absence of external influences: that the activity would remain at the same level of the activity as the external influences because that would be very adaptive for the brain. But the pattern of activity in the absence of external effects is that the activity would be a very long and boring, because that would not be of any use to the brain and they would fire spikes randomly.'

Dr. B:'So the activity of a neuron in a developing brain is shaped by the patterns that it is exposed to during development. In fact, the activity pattern that a neuron fires at a given point in time is a function of its pattern at the very beginning of life, when it is born. It is not a function of its current state. So, the activity pattern of a neuron at a given point of time in life is a result of the previous activity, which is a result of its previous activity.'

Dr. M:'Oh, absolutely. The question that you ask there is really, well it doesn't depend on the activity, but it depends on the type of cell that you are producing that determines whether it can be controlled, but it also depends on the pattern of the neural activity that it receives. So, the answer is, yes, absolutely. It has to be that way.'

Dr. B:'What are the advantages of this feedback? It's a positive feedback? What advantages does this offer? What does this offer? I'm asking this from a perspective that would be a benefit, rather than just a disadvantage. What advantage does this offer? There are two issues that are being addressed by this feedback.'

Dr. B:'So, would you say that the same pattern of activity from a pyramidal neuron can be controlled, or it has to be controlled by something? Is it a one-way process? Is it a hard-wired, or is it a plastic, variable pattern? Does it have a default pattern, and if it does, then what is the mechanism? What is the mechanism to change the activity of a neuron from a default pattern? I have an idea here.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, I have an idea. I'm going to put my hands up and tell you. I'm going tell you an idea of a mechanism. It's a very good one, because this is something that we are trying to figure out. What is the mechanism of changing the activity of neurons from a default pattern to a different pattern? And also how does that mechanism arise in the developing brain. So, the same principle applies here. I'm going make my hands up.'
Dr. B:'When you receive a message in your brain, what happens?'

Dr. M:'You can think about it as a filter, or as a gate that passes your messages to the right place. Your brain is a sort of gate that allows your neurons to talk to you about the world and to tell you about the world, and your neurons also have a variety of other functions in the world. So, your neurons can tell you about other sensory features that you are seeing with your eyes.'

Dr. B:'And so it's all in the feedback. For example, there are a number of developmental processes, such as the appearance of eye movements in babies and the first crawling movement, that occur before these changes are reflected in the brain. There are other processes that develop from this very early stage. What is the role of these spontaneous processes in these developmental processes? For example, during these early development processes, I'm not asking, "What is the role of sleep in sleep?'

Dr. M:'The role of the brain is one of feedback, because these processes are critical for development. They are critical for understanding what the environment is. And there are, and this is also one of the questions that people have been studying, whether you know in the past decades in the 1960s, when people realized that the nervous system was different and had to be studied as a brain.'
Dr. B:'I'm asking that the role of these processes be explored. What role do these spontaneous processes have in these developmental processes?'

Dr. M:'Yes. For example, it's possible that during early development, the motor pattern of the brain was generated by spontaneous neural activity, and these spontaneous neural activity patterns played some role in the development of the brain. And it's also possible that these neural activity patterns were, in fact, important for the development of the nervous system.'
Dr. M:'And what is the function of neurons and neural activity in development?'

Dr. B:'So, I'm saying that this is the brain's attempt to understand the environment. So the brain is the best organ that we have to understand our world. We know that there is this world out there that is filled with all kinds of interesting things to be understood. The brain has a big advantage. It has a huge advantage because the things out there are in our world. You may have noticed that a lot of what the world does out there is about the same.'

Dr. M:'It's actually very difficult to know what the function of neural activity is at any stage, because neural circuits are always interacting with the outside world. As you grow up, you're interacting with a world of motor patterns and sensory stimuli and hormones and you know, you interact with the world and you're constantly exposed to environmental stimuli, but as you grow up, the neuronal circuits start to interact with the rest of the world. So what is the function of neural circuit activity during development?'

Dr. B:'In the hippocampus, hippocampal ripples serve as a mechanism for encoding memories. So that is an example of the way that the neuronal circuits become more active during development. The hippocampus and the subiculum are the first areas that show hippocampal ripples during the postnatal development. The hippocampus is the structure that has the most recurrent system in the brain.'

Dr. M:'Right, right, right. I'm thinking about a related issue, which is the possibility that, you know, when you're an infant, you're completely dependent on your mother for survival, and so you know, you've got to be close, close to the mother because you can't, you can't do it yourself.'
Dr. B:'You can't. That's right. And so the mother is actually teaching you how to be in the world, teaching you how to find food and water in the world.'

Dr. B:'So this is actually a difficult question, because there are many stages of development that occur, and all these are accompanied by different functions of neural circuit activity. So the activity of cortical circuits during development could be very different at different stages of development and in different structures of the brain. So what I have to say is just a short list of things that would be interesting to think about.'

Dr. M:'Well, to generate the neural circuitry that is required for function, for neuronal circuits that are required for cognition, and for a host of things in the brain, and to maintain and to be reliable, and so these are fundamental functions that we want to have neurons fulfill.'

Dr. B:'And these are what I call "neural syntax" functions. But how are the brain circuits organized to support these functions? What I mean is that I have seen some of the earliest models that you have constructed over the years, and they were, uh, perhaps a bit oversimplified, but it was clear to me at least that they can work. And then I began to look at the brain.'
Dr. M:'The brain! The brain!'

Dr. B:'I have begun to observe how the wiring of the brain and the activities of its various rhythms support the many of these functions, which I had always thought were a mystery. And my question is how do you begin to look at the wiring? How do you figure out how wiring supports function?'

Dr. M:'We've known since the first work on neuromodulation by Marder and Weimann. And the first experiments with neuromodulation were done by injecting neuromodulators into the brain. So Marder and the Weimann group went first. But when you look at how the brain develops, it is not as a fixed set of circuits that are fixed. So you're going to have changes in neural circuitry as you develop, as your nervous system develops.'
Dr. B:'Well, that's why in this series I'm asking you two questions, which you answer, and then I'm going to answer.'
Dr. M:'Sure.'

Dr. B:'Okay. Okay. The question is how are circuits formed and how are they developed? The answer is that is, of course, it depends on the circuit. But if we look at circuits at the right time and right place, and that circuit is already formed and already there, and then we can study what are the functions that are performed by that circuit and we can see how they are formed.'

Dr. B:'So how do you have the fundamental functional changes? And, and what is the role of self-generated activity that we have in the brain? And then you'll have changes in activity during development. What are these functions that are supported by the self-generated?activity? And what are the self-generated functions? And then you're going to start with the fundamental neural syntax, and look for how the brain works to support those self-generated functions. So that's what I mean.'

Dr. M:'So we're all used to the idea that when we talk about neuromodulation or neuromodulators, we talk about them being released in very small, discrete units. In small amounts. And we talk about the neuromodulators that are released from the STNS (stomatogastric nervous system) being released as small amounts of substances and then diffusing to the periphery, to the whole nervous system.'

Dr. M:'In the developing nervous system, there is always a balance between growth, maintenance, and adaptation, and that balance has to be maintained in adults. For example, when the animal is growing, the neuromodulators that would be released and have their effects must be regulated, otherwise the animal would be unable to grow properly. Therefore, there has to be homeostatic regulation in neural activity.'

Dr. B:'So homeostatic regulation is achieved by neural activity, and homeostatic regulation can occur in two different ways. One is by balancing the excitatory and inhibitory networks and the other is to reduce synaptic weights of synapses that are not active.'

Dr. B:'We are talking about the brain that was born in the womb and during the first postnatal days? What is the function of the spontaneous activity in this brain? I'm asking a somewhat similar question: What is the function? of spontaneous activity of the developing nervous system? How does it help to organize the information in neuronal networks?'

Dr. M:'Well, in general, it is believed that, first of all, there is a large tonic component to that activity. And then, on top of that, there is a rhythmic component. And then, there is a component that is transient, and that comes in at high frequencies, and that is thought to be necessary for neuronal development and synaptic integration.'
Dr. B:'What is it about spontaneous activity that allows for that kind of sequence? Can you describe that? Do you have examples?'

Dr. M:'Yes. I mean, one of the examples that we used, again, with the axons and with the muscles, was that they develop their muscles at the periphery of the nervous system, that they develop the muscles on their nerves. So, they develop their muscles early in development and then move them off the nerves. The muscles then grow, and they grow in their musculature and then get bigger and bigger. Then, the muscles get the most of the synaptic input.'

Dr. B:'And so, at some point, then you need to stop them? What is it? What is the critical moment? What is the key thing that happens? What is the necessary thing? What is it that's necessary? What is it about the timing that is necessary?'

Dr. M:'I think, it depends on the context. I mean, some of the other points that you've been making. I think the critical point, though, in terms of neurons is that they have this ability to stop growing. You mentioned that neurons, neurons do not just go around, and you know, eat and eat and eat and just make tons and tons and tons of new material. So, they have this ability. I mean, neurons that are larger have this ability.'
Dr. B:'So what would be the most critical component in terms of stopping the growing? What is it, this component that would be the most important to stop growth?'

Dr. B:'So, when we are young, we start out as having a body like that and then we learn that, in reality, the world is more complicated than that. How are we expected to navigate this complex world? What is the function of the spontaneous activity? Could you say a few words about it? It's just so fascinating. I'm fascinated by it and so many things are just, are just inexplicable by my brain.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, it has been shown that if a neuron, which we will describe as a single compartment model, has a tonic synaptic current in the absence of stimulation and a tonic synaptic conductance that is regulated by modulators or other chemical substances, it will continue to produce a tonic current, even though the synaptic conductance is very small. And the other way around is also true.'
Dr. B:'How about during development? What is it about spontaneous neural activity, or spontaneous spiking activity, that allows for that?'

Dr. M:'So you would want to make a point of having a high level of tonic activity, and then having a high level transient activity. Because it will be very important that the neuronal network is sufficiently dynamic to allow the other components to come into play.'

Dr. B:'Why is that the case? What does the brain need from the perspective of neural syntax, as I call it, for that activity? Why does that need to happen? How does that happen? Does that have an impact on our understanding of neural syntax? Or on our understanding of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Yes, I think there are a couple of different views that can be taken of that question. You know, I think that one is that that activity can be a byproduct of other processes that are going on. That neurons may fire at a high frequency without being part of a circuit, because they are just firing because they are already in the circuit and then they fire at a high rate.'

Dr. B:'I don't have a problem with that. But why is it so? What is the impact? What's the impact? How can the brain take advantage of the fact that activity in the brain can be generated by the brain, and how does that influence our understanding of neural syntactic rules? Is there a need for activity to go on in the brain even if it is just a result of the brain's self-generated activity?'

Dr. M:'There are many, many different potential roles for high frequency activity, and there are lots of interesting roles that have been studied, in general, by my colleagues, who have studied how activity is important to the brain and to synaptic integration.'

Dr. B:'And the second view is that activity may be necessary for the generation of circuits and neuronal syntax, which then becomes a byproduct of activity that is happening for a different purpose and not in parallel, and that that is then the question, what is the function of that activity? So, that's two ways of answering the question.'
Dr. B:'So that's what you're saying is that there's no functional component for spontaneous activity? Just a tonic component, a rhythmic component, and a transient component?'

Dr. M:'Yes, yes, right. So, you know, I guess the simplest way of thinking of the function of neural activity is that the neurons that are not under control are doing all kinds of stuff and are being used to generate behavior and to generate function. And the neurons that are behaving properly are behaving appropriately to give rise to behavior.'
Dr. B:'And these are the neurons that are developing right? So there's no functional role for the spontaneous activity?'

Dr. B:'And, you know, I'm, I'm, this is all very interesting. And I'm wondering what is it, what's this component that can actually have a function? What is it, what can be its function? And I'm, and, you know, the tonic component, I'm, uh, I'm, that would be, uh, the main focus of your research.'

Dr. M:'I, well, I think that this is, this is interesting because I think that a lot of the work that we did in the first phase of our work focused on the role of rhythmicity in, in nervous systems, and that the importance of rhythmicity was revealed by the fact that it is not a function of a set of rules or laws but it's actually the result of the evolution of evolution of the nervous system.'

Dr. B:'Okay. So what is the role of, uh, the second component? What's this component, the, uh, what's the rhythmic component? What is it? What does it actually do? What does it do? What does this component do?'

Dr. M:'When the embryonic nervous system becomes functional, it requires neuromodulation to make the correct connections and to maintain their proper connectivity over time. As you get older, you lose that ability to use neuromodulation, and you develop the ability to respond to neuromodulation. That's probably why many people find neuromodulators are useful for restoring function in the elderly.'
Dr. B:'Where does the nervous system store that information?'
Dr. M:'You store that information on different ion channel types in the different cell types, in a set of neurotransmitters, and their receptors on receptors in the membrane.'
Dr. M:'When the neurons grow up, we don't usually ask them, what their function is, we just ask them to fire in a specific pattern.'
Dr. B:'The interesting thing is that we don't know which pattern they would choose, the same pattern that was given to them as a solution to the problem or whatever.'

Dr. M:'Exactly. Because we've always assumed that a solution that can be found in nature is the correct solution and that's why the biological evolution has converged on the solution that we are using today, which is a solution that has some of the same features. But it's certainly not identical with the solution that we have today.'

Dr. B:'I would say that the spontaneous activity is a good way to find out what the functions would be in the brain. It's the same as if you would like to understand what it is, like a movie, like the music, the way that we see things today and how they can be put together.'
Dr. M:'Right. You know, it would be interesting to see how you could do a computational model that has this very feature and then try to understand it.'
Dr. M:'No, I think you're right.'
Dr. B:'What is the spontaneous activity in the network then?'

Dr. M:'I think the only thing that happens is that the neurons grow up and they realize that they have a lot of freedom. They can move around in the brain, they can make new synaptic connections, and they can change how they react to certain stimuli.'
Dr. M:'They'll use any pattern that is convenient for them because the neurons have the same pattern of intrinsic excitability.'

Dr. B:'And there's another interesting thing, which is that the brains that grow up with the most developed pattern of spontaneous activity are the brains that give rise to the most complex behaviors of the organisms, but they still use the same spontaneous pattern of activity in the same way. It looks like there's a fundamental and universal function of the spontaneous activity, which is, perhaps, the solution to the problem of brain complexity.'

Dr. M:'Maybe that's true. I mean, you could say that the brain is always looking for a good enough solution and that neurons use the simplest possible pattern of activity, like some kind of optimization, if you will.'
Dr. B:'So you just make them fire in a specific sequence? So that they can be stimulated in a predictable manner. So the function of the sequences is... what exactly is it's use-ful for?'
Dr. M:'Well, it depends. There are some things that we don't quite know what they are. They are just part of the system.'

Dr. B:'What are these? What are these sequences? I mean, we are talking about a specific pattern. I know what the pattern is. It's something like this:  N 1 -N2,N3-N4. Now, where I come from, this is the typical format of the sequences for the brain. I think it is a fundamental mechanism for the brain. What are these sequences that you're talking about?'
Dr. B:'The thing is when the neurons are excited. So if it happens to produce something useful, why not use it? If that's the reason, it should be very clear.'

Dr. M:'Well, the primary function of the nervous system is to maintain control over the rhythmic processing of sensory inputs, which is a critical component of a number of higher brain functions, including cognition. So the nervous system must have the capacity to express rhythmic rhythms. And then, the neural circuits must be robust to perturbation.'

Dr. B:'So the question is, what is the mechanism of rhythm generation? What are the building blocks? Are we looking for the same building blocks as in chemistry, physics, and engineering? How do you think we can make progress here?'
Dr. B:'Okay, what is the function of rhythms in the brain? Are there different functions for different brain rhythms?'
Dr. M:'Yes, yes.'

Dr. B:'And can you give me a few examples? I'm listening, but then I want to make sure I'm hearing you right. I'm hearing about functions, and we are discussing whether the brain is a blank slate to be written on, or is it already a pretty decent computer with all of these circuits, in which case, what are the functions of the brain circuits? And then it's written, and that should provide clues for the functions.'
Dr. M:'So, first of all, this idea of a blank slate, if you like, and a blank slate is sort of the opposite of how biology operates.'
Dr. B:'I'm curious about that. Are you going to explain that to me?'

Dr. M:'No, I'm not going to go into why I feel that way, but why it's the opposite of how life works. I have been trying to answer this question for years, decades. I think if you asked any scientist, or anyone who has studied neuroscience, this question is going to come up repeatedly, the answer is going to come from decades of neuroscience. The answer is going to be something about how the circuits develop in early life.'
Dr. M:'Right, and if you look, you will see that many systems have two or more networks with different properties that come into play during behavior and in the brain.'
Dr. B:'What about the brainstem and spinal cord? Are there any rhythms in the brainstem and the spinal cord that are useful for cognition and behavior?'
Dr. M:'Yes, indeed, so that is a critical component, but the brainstem and then the spinal cord, and the circuits that connect the brainstem to the motor system, also produce rhythmic activity.'

Dr. B:'So are there any brain rhythms that are unique to the cortex and hippocampus? What about theta, delta, slow-wave, alpha, beta, and gamma oscillations? Are there any brain rhythms unique to the hippocampus? What are some of the potential functions that the different rhythms of the brain can perform? What are some potential mechanisms of those functions? Is there a function for each brain rhythm? What is the mechanism by which the brain uses these rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Well, the brain has many, many mechanisms. The brain has many, thousands of neurons, and there are neurons and networks and synapses that contribute to every one of these rhythms, including the rhythms in the spinal cord. The spinal cord is also part of the network.'

Dr. M:'The first function of the central nervous system in the animal is to maintain homeostasis. This is how animals grow and develop and maintain their identity. It is also critical for their function, but it is not directly relevant to our understanding of how the brain develops and what it is going to do once you are adult. The question then comes, how does this maintenance of homeostasis in the brain affect behavior?'

Dr. B:'If you can answer this question, then the second question becomes irrelevant. However, if you ask this question to the wrong people, then you will get all the wrong answers. It is an ill-posed question. The first question is the interesting one to answer because the answer depends upon what you consider the 'brain's role in the animal. It is more like a "brain's role in life" or "brain's role on the planet".'

Dr. M:'Then you can get all kinds of answers that are wrong. It is a very difficult question, so I don't have an answer for you. I think that the first question you can answer is whether it is important that a neuron should always maintain the same phenotype. I think the answer is yes. I mean, I can think of neurons that are not always doing the same thing that we are interested in.'

Dr. B:'How do you know that it is always doing the same things? If you consider brain oscillations as one example of a phenotype, then what is it doing? What is a phenotype in the brain? Let me give you some examples that I like. One is sleep rhythms. It is an example of spontaneous neural activity. Neurons in the hippocampus can predict sleep time with great accuracy (just watch the movie on YouTube), and this is not a behavior that the brain is trained to do.'
Dr. M:'You just have to watch them. The animal is not doing anything; it is just sleeping.'

Dr. B:'So when it is a question about whether it is important to maintain a neural activity during development, the answer is that is it is very important. So then you can go from there and ask about the consequences of this maintenance on behavior. If you ask the same question to the wrong kind of person, then they can give you all kinds of answers. But the only question that should be asked is: how does this maintenance contribute to an animal's function and behavior?'

Dr. M:'Exactly, because all the different aspects of brain development are relevant and then the development of the brain is relevant. So, if you look at the development of a neuronal circuit, then you can figure out what the role of the nervous system is going to be. Then the development of the nervous system will be critical to understanding how the nervous system functions.'

Dr. B:'The first function is the maintenance of homeostatic function, which is what is so fascinating about the neurobiology of the brain, is that how the brain maintains its self-regulation in spite of what it is surrounded by. For example, the neurobiology of food consumption and its interaction with hunger and energy, as a self-regulation process is so complex and fascinating. The brain is not an exception.'

Dr. M:'If you are asking, how does the brain maintain its homeostatic function in the adult animal, then that's a good question because then you can see, you can then understand the role of neuromodulation and the role of neural activity during development and the role of the neurons. That is also important to consider because in some cases the nervous system may be quite different in the adult animal than in the developing animal.'

Dr. B:'The question is, can you tell me how? I can tell you that this function would be an important thing for the central nervous system to achieve. But to answer it, one has to look at how is it maintained in the brain after it develops? How does this function stay? This is not as simple as we think because it's a system of networks and we know that brain activity is not an isolated phenomenon. There is a competition between neuronal systems which are competing with each other.'

Dr. M:'So we have to consider how all this competition is maintained and how the neuromodulatory systems are regulated because these are not independent neurons and neurons that exist within the nervous system. So they are very intricately regulated so they are subject to the same mechanisms that keep them in balance.'

Dr. B:'This is an interesting thing. If you think about it, it's almost as if the function of the brain is to make it last for a long time, to maintain a stable environment. In the end, you can use the brain for very many different things but it is not the brain that makes up those functions. The brain is a mechanism that does a thing. When you use a particular mechanism to achieve something, then you have to use it in a particular way.'

Dr. M:'The brain is a highly sophisticated mechanism which must be controlled. It is controlled by both intrinsic and extrinsic factors. The most obvious example of this is that the brain contains a large number of different ion channels and receptors which are regulated by neuromodulators. But there are other examples, and so the brain is a highly regulated mechanism. In this case, you can see why the brain, for example, is not an ideal place to carry out a complicated calculation.'

Dr. M:'So, you can imagine that in the nervous system there is a competition between neurons, and each neuron has a tendency to increase its output as the neurons try to keep their homeostatic function. So, that competition creates a tonic sort of pressure to increase their activity.'

Dr. B:'What can this system do? What are the solutions? We know that this function would not be easy to achieve, but if you understand how to maintain the function of this network then you can see how this network can sustain activity as it is required to maintain homeostatic function for many years.'

Dr. B:'This tension may result in a change in their activity, for example, in synaptic strength. That is, that pressure will cause a change in activity in neuronal networks and it will be visible in their electrical activity. And this is why it is a brain-wide activity and it has a huge impact on all parts of the brain, and it's a fundamental process in the brain.'

Dr. M:'But, I think you have to ask a better question. The question is: if we are thinking about a homeostatic neuron, can a neuron with a tonic membrane current generate a different activity from another neuron that does not have a tonic current? And the answer to that is yes, yes, that depends on the membrane currents that that neuron has.'

Dr. B:'Well, if you can give me a couple of examples of homeostatic mechanisms that maintain function in the adult brain, then I will ask whether those mechanisms have the same function in the brain of a developing organism, and that way we can start talking about how the brain maintains its identity, the core of the brain. Let's just think about the neurons for a minute.'

Dr. M:' Spontaneous neural activity plays multiple roles during development, such as keeping neuronal structures small, making neurons functional, allowing neurons to respond to neuromodulators, and maintaining brain activity during sleep and wake. We now understand that some neurons are functional because they have synaptic connections, and that synaptic connections are often regulated by neuromodulators. In some cases, the regulation is regulated by homeostatic mechanisms that maintain target activity in a target range.'

Dr. B:'What are the physiological mechanisms of this homeostatic regulation? Does the system have a fixed target range, and if so, what happens when the range is exceeded? Is the system hard-wired in this target range, and what happens when the target range is exceeded? What are the consequences of this homeostat regulation when it fails?'

Dr. M:'It is important to realize that homeostatic regulation may occur in neurons that don't have synaptic connections, such as electrically coupled pacemaker cells, and that the regulation may occur at many levels of activity, including the level of a neuron's voltage. In the case of electrically coupled pacemakers in the STG, the regulation occurs during the activity of the individual neurons, but the level of regulation is coordinated by the activity of the network as a whole.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of spontaneous activity during learning?'
Dr. M:'It plays a role in all learning, in learning during development, in learning in adulthood, and in learning in response to changing environments and in response to changes in mood.'
Dr. B:'Is there a brain rhythm that can serve a role for both brain development and learning?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. The only known example is the pyloric pacemaker. We're now learning that the mammalian cardiac ganglion, with its seven pacemaker neurons, can generate rhythmic rhythms for both cardiac and gastric mill function. We're beginning to understand that neural networks may have many pacemaker neurons, so it's not so much whether it's one or many pacemaker neurons. It's the degree to which they are regulated, and their connectivity.'
Dr. B:'Does spontaneous activity contribute to a memory function? What is the role of learning in neural syntax?'

Dr. M:'That's a very important question. I think the role of memory in neural syntax is that, just as the role of memory is to store information, it's the role of synaptic interactions to store memory, and then memory to store that synaptic interaction. It's like that role of memory in storing synaptic interactions.'

Dr. B:'Why are the hippocampus and associated structures involved in this process? Are there particular sequences in the hippocampus that are responsible for this process? Are hippocampal networks critical to memory? Does the hippocampus contribute to memory in a similar manner to the way that it stores information? In other words, are there certain sequences in the hippocampus for memory and learning that can be perturbed or disrupted? How does the hippocampus contribute to learning and memory?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are actually several experiments that look at the role of the hippocampus. We understand very well that the synaptic interactions between neurons in a network can be altered by a variety of neuromodulators, and that these neurons can change their synaptic connectivity over time, so in one experiment we used this approach to examine the changes in synaptic connectivity in the hippocampus as it develops. In this experiment, we used genetically identified  C.'
Dr. M:'We think that it plays a role in learning, and the more I study it the more I think that it does.'

Dr. B:'How did spontaneous activity get its name? What is the relationship between spontaneous and spontaneous activity? If you think about it from a broader context, spontaneous activity is the activity that occurs before a stimulus is delivered to the brain. For example, a very strong stimulus can induce seizures, but the seizures occur without any additional input. This is often referred to as the first-degree seizure or an epileptic event. So is this the same as the activity that occurs in the absence of any external influence?'

Dr. M:'Yes, in some sense it is. What we learned as neuroscientists is that in general the way in which neurons and networks work is really determined by interactions among neurons, and these interactions can be either intrinsic or synaptic, and they are differentially regulated. So there are a number of ways in which you can regulate the interactions between neurons.'

Dr. M:'The term was actually coined by experimentalists who were studying sensory neurons in the spinal cord, and it was thought that these neurons were firing spontaneously. And this was thought to be a consequence of the synaptic connections in the network. And so I suppose the origin of the term is similar to many other terms that have come into neuroscience, like the terms for neurons that are active because of synaptic release from other neurons.'

Dr. B:'Do we know how spontaneous activity is organized and how to control it? Are there simple mechanisms, such as inhibition or other simple mechanisms, that can control the amount of activity? Are there multiple mechanisms, and are they mutually exclusive? What are the relationships between spontaneous activity and sleep, waking, and stimulation? Are there simple rules, like the rule between stimulus-response? Are there complex mechanisms? What is the contribution of different neurotransmitters? Does the contribution vary depending on brain state,?'

Dr. B:'Does neuronal activity depend on a particular gene that determines the function of that cell? Is it possible that some of these functions are influenced by the timing of activity? Does it matter how the activity of the cell is triggered?'

Dr. M:'Yes.
