The role of spontaneous neural activity is regulated by homeopatic mechanisms, so this means that neurons are able to change their own membrane properties in response to neuromodulator, and in response to activity itself. In this context, homeopatic regulation is called intrinsic regulation, because the intrinsic properties of the neuron determine the regulation rules that determine the shape of the function of that neuron.'

Dr. B:'Is it important to understand that the function of the cell depends on how that neuron is activated? Is it possible to understand how a function emerges through a different sequence of activities? Are these different sequences important for understanding the functions of different circuits?'

Dr. M:'They are certainly important for understanding the way that neurons are regulated during development. There are so many neurons that are important in developing the nervous system, and it is possible that some of the same mechanisms are regulated during development to produce a particular circuit function.'

Dr. B:'I think it is important to understand that a function of a neuron is determined by the neuron's ability to respond to external inputs. If the neuron is inactive at a time when it is naturally expected to be active, is this not a good opportunity to look at the circuits that are connected to the neuron to determine what may be going wrong? I don't mean to be taking the perspective of a parent. I'm just looking from a different perspective as a mentor of a graduate student.'

Dr. M:'Exactly! The problem with the biological neurons is that the nervous system is always at work, always changing. There is always ongoing work on new molecular entities, which will influence the activity of the biological neuron. It is impossible to keep track of all the modifications that are being made, and we certainly don't want to know all the modifications, but it is important to know the ones that are relevant.'

Dr. M:'The function is to allow the development of the circuits. As the system becomes more complex, we want to allow the function to be optimized, so that there are many different sets of synaptic inputs that can produce all the behaviors. So that the neurons, as they're developing, become able to do whatever they need to do to produce the appropriate behavior, and then the circuit can be optimized for that behavior. And so it's not so that we can get rid of it.'

Dr. B:'You can say, well, it's a necessary part of brain development, but we want to optimize it. So what I mean by optimizing it is allowing the development of the circuit so that it will, in fact, do that kind of thing, but it will do it with a little more efficiency, a little more speed. That's what optimization would mean in this context. So in that sense, there is a function for the spontaneous activity, but that is an optimal state for developing circuits.'
Dr. M:'And for development.'
Dr. B:'Yes.'

Dr. M:'We see, actually, some interesting functions. Like, for example, during development, we see the networks get more robust to environmental perturbations. So, you know, you're talking about, you're talking that in terms of developmental parameters.'

Dr. B:'I'm going to talk about the stability and stability of neuronal circuits. It would be a very hard thing to achieve because of the development of the networks, but we do have, for example, in humans, the ability to make such stability and stability changes. And that has to do with the development of the brain and the stability and stability changes of the brain that can occur through the different, uh, and that have to do with the developmental parameters. We've already identified a set of parameters.'
Dr. M:'A set of parameters.'  Dr. B: 'Right.'

Dr. M:'Which are responsible for such development of the brain. For example, in the case of humans, it has to do with temperature. And so, you know, as you're growing, your body temperature fluctuates a certain amount and there has to be a balance between temperature regulation and keeping your temperature within a certain range. So that has to do, that has to do—and it has to do also with your synaptic connections.'

Dr. B:'Well, I'm not going to talk about a set of parameters that's responsible for such development, and this is what I'm looking at. Now, I'm looking at a whole set of functions that arise out of neural syntax. So it's the rules, the syntax that allows for a neural syntax to be read out. So what's a syntax that allows for this neural syntax to be understood by the reader? Is it, is it fixed or is it flexible?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think there's, in principle, there's two kinds of optimizing this kind of thing, one is to keep the activity at a specific level that will be appropriate for the development of the system, so that it can learn as it grows. So the activity of the system is important for development, and that's what's required. But the other thing is to try to get the system to behave in a fashion that's appropriate for the behavior it's going to be performing.'

Dr. M:'There is not only a function. There's a goal to the development of the brain that we don't know exactly how we want it to end. And in a very general sense, I think the goal is to allow the brain to develop itself, and to have that develop a set of rules by which to interact with itself. So in a very general way, this could go any number of ways.'

Dr. M:'I think it's really important in order to find out how the network grows, but we don't actually know that much about the way the network grows, because we can't actually manipulate the network until it's completely mature. The nervous system has an amazing plasticity. We can put in neuromodulatory substances, which change how a network is built, but we don know when the network is going to mature, so we have to put them in at the end.'

Dr. B:'So you would like to have a more complete understanding of how the brain functions in terms of its network dynamics. What are the areas where we are missing the data? What are the things we don't know? What is the field that we are trying to understand? In a broader sense, what do we want to know? What is there not enough data on, but the field we're trying to understand? What are the areas in which we need more data?'

Dr. M:'I suppose the first answer would be: it's a matter of ensuring that the circuits are correct. This is not really a function, because you always know the output of a circuit, and it's easy to determine if a given neural circuit is correct. So it's a matter more of keeping the circuit intact, so that the neural circuit is active in the correct time and that it produces the appropriate patterns of activity during development.'

Dr. B:'So I think you're looking for two things, right, in order to answer this question. You're looking for a function that is inborn and then a function that is formed by experience. So I would be looking for these two types of functions, that is, functions that are inborn, and then functions that are formed by experience. Let's start with the inborn function.'

Dr. M:'Well, then the function is that the nervous system grows, or evolves, and then the neurons grow in number and their properties are regulated and that these are regulated by neuromodulation. So the function of neurons is to be regulated during development. So it doesn't have to be regulated during adulthood.'

Dr. B:'This, that's one side of the issue. So then the other side is, that is, the side that it does have to be regulated is the activity of the neurons. So, uh, the other side of the issue is the function that it does have in terms of the activity of the circuits.'
Dr. M:'Mhmm.'
Dr. B:'But what is the circuit? What is the circuit? Is it a single neuron or multiple neurons? How do you define the circuit?'

Dr. M:'So if you want to define a circuit you can choose any three or four neurons to form it, and you can build the circuit based on their interactions. But I think this has to be defined in a way that is a little bit more abstract. So I suppose the circuit could be a single neuron, it could be a group of neurons. It could be a bunch of neurons, as you say.'

Dr. B:'Do you think that it's a mistake for neuroscientists to work too much with single neurons? Or is it more important to work with neuronal circuits? I mean, this is the reason that I asked that question. It's because it's the thing to be understood. So is it a mistake to work with neurons? Is it more important to deal with circuits? Are there other important things to work on?'

Dr. M:'Well, it might be possible to work with individual neurons and look at how they contribute, but I think there are probably good reasons to work with more than one cell, and to define circuits as collections of cells, because the way neurons interact together depends on how they are linked together. So to my mind, the circuit is defined, it has some neurons and some interactions among the neurons. The circuit has some neurons that are coupled by chemical synapses and electrically coupled.'

Dr. B:'So would it be helpful to see a circuit for a simple motor reaction? So, let's say you're trying to get from the middle of your foot to the toe and then back to the middle. You're trying to get to the toe. The first thing you have to do is make a motor command, a movement command. So, where in your brain are you making the commands? How many neurons are required?'

Dr. B:'If so, this is in line with previous observations, including the observations that if you give a piece of neural syntax to a cell in isolation, or put the cell into the brain of an adult, it's possible to see how that syntax operates. What happens in isolation? What happens to the cell in the brain? What happens when the brain is put into the neural syntax? Do we get different outputs? Different outcomes? Different behavioral outcomes? What do we see?'
Dr. M:'You can see that the neuron responds in different ways when it is put into different environments.'

Dr. M:'Well, the first function is that it allows the development of the nervous system, of the circuits in the nervous system, but it also enables the maturation of the sensory inputs. The brain becomes more complex as it goes through development. In a sense, that is necessary. So the first function of spontaneous neural output during development is that it provides feedback to the nervous system that allows it to become more complicated.'
Dr. B:'What is the main goal of spontaneous activity?'
Dr. M:'I think the first thing that comes into my mind is understanding how circuits work.'

Dr. B:'Who is in charge of this activity? Is it the parents, or is it the brain? Is it a random event or is it an organised event? Is it a 'neural syntax' or is it simply the 'brain activity'? How is the activity transmitted from sender to receiver? Is the activity of neural circuits a consequence of the structure of the sender, or is the structure of the sent messages determined by the receiver?'

Dr. M:'It is a question that is not so well studied and is still not fully understood. The work on  Drosophila  showed that neuronal development is critically dependent on the presence of modulatory input during development. These data suggested that neuromodulatory inputs, as well as electrical synapses, may be important for network development.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of  in-vitro  stimulation of brain slices in developing a brain network?'

Dr. M:'I don't think the actual role is really being studied. The work is done using slices of brain from different animals. So there are different networks used in different studies. I don't think the same network is used for each individual. So, the actual network being studied is not the actual network in vivo. So, I don't know if we really can draw conclusions about whether they are functioning normally.'
Dr. B:'How can one tell when an artificially developed network is ready to be studied in  in-vivo  experiments? Does the network reach a critical state or something? If so, what is it?'

Dr. M:'There is actually a very good paper in the literature that studied networks where the output of the network was measured as the strength of the synaptic input from each of the neurons in the network. This study was done using the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion.'
Dr. B:'I have read this submission. I believe that I have an appropriate level of expertise to confirm that it is of an acceptable scientific standard.'

Dr. B:'Diversity of input can be critical for the emergence of a system with the ability to produce a diverse output. How does the brain develop the ability to produce such a variety of outputs? What is the role of spontaneous activity, and what is the role of input that can affect spontaneous activity in the developing brain? How do the various brain rhythms interact with each other in the course of development? How are various brain rhythms influenced by the developing environment?'

Dr. M:'We don't know the function of the neural activity during development because we didn't have the technology, the tools, to measure the neural activity during these very early phases of development. And so therefore it was impossible to know the function of neural activity during development.'
Dr. B:'Is it impossible to know the role of the hippocampus and what you call the 'default mode network'? Is it possible to measure these phenomena today?'

Dr. M:'It can be very important, because during the embryonic stages, during development, all neurons have to be fully integrated into the circuit. There's a number of things that are necessary for development, such as providing the feedback to the network, so that you can keep it synchronous, in a well regulated fashion. Then, there are things that are also necessary for the correct wiring, and then, for things that are necessary just for development, like, for example, cell proliferation.'
Dr. B:'What are those things that are not always critical for development?'
Dr. B:'What is the role of spontaneous activity during early development?'

Dr. B:'What is the role of inhibition? Is the inhibition necessary for the development? Is there any role for inhibition, or is it sufficient, or is there any role that inhibition plays in the network? How much role do various brain rhythms play in the development of the brain?'
Dr. M:'There are a lot of rhythmic events that play a role in development.'

Dr. B:'Is the role of these brain rhythms too specific? Are they responsible for a particular type of function, and if so, is it the same type of function for every brain rhythm? How much is each rhythm responsible for, or does each rhythm play a different role in the development of brain activity?'
Dr. B:'Do you have a particular example of a critical function that is not fulfilled by the network, or are you just taking a random example and trying to think of a mechanism?'

Dr. M:'I think maybe more of a mechanism of how development works is actually helpful, because there are other mechanisms, as well, that we understand a bit more. We know that there are hormones that play a role during development, and also that there are other mechanisms. And so, I think it's kind of hard to think of a specific example, but there are so many examples that I think come to mind, of how neural activity plays a role during development.'

Dr. B:'So, the thing that is missing at the moment, is a good description of what happens during the postnatal period, and what I'm looking for is a good description what happens during development. And, I don't need to say a lot about the postnatal period. It's a very interesting period. And it has to be studied by different tools. And those tools should be very appropriate for the questions that we are asking.'

Dr. M:'I'm not so sure that the questions that you're asking are appropriate, because I'm kind of suspicious of the phrase, "the function of spontaneous neural expression during development". I'm curious, and this is one of the things that I'm thinking about because this is really interesting, when you're talking about a function of neural activity and you're trying to describe, I don't know what it is, but maybe a function of neural output. I guess, what does that mean?'

Dr. B:'Well, it means that the function of the activity during development, in other words, the function of the spontaneous neural activity during that period, is the development of the network, because if you have a single neuron in the hippocampus, which would produce no output and no noise, and if you would train it for a very long time, it would become very noisy. But the important thing is what we learn about the pattern of activity that emerges without any training, or training, and no experience.'
Dr. M:'And, it's also interesting because the pattern of activity, the activity, the pattern of neural activity during development will also give you the information about what happens later.'

Dr. B:'What later? What happens later? What happens next? What's the next thing? In other words, what do we know about it? What's the information about? What's the function? What's the role of the activity at a particular point in time, but at the same time, there's a pattern of activity that can give you the information that you will ask later.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. M:'This was studied by the French neurobiologist, Jean-Pierre Marder, and it was shown that the activity of the pacemaker neurons is responsible for the determination of many properties of the developing brain. The neural activity is very important, but we are also learning that it's the time in between those activities that's critical.'
Dr. B:'But what is the function of the spontaneous activity during the post-developmental time?'

Dr. M:'That is a good question. You know, the activity in adult neurons isn't critical for neural circuits to work properly because all of the connections have been made by the time the neural circuit is active in adult animals. It's the interplay between those two different time scales that makes all this stuff work, and it's the interplay of the two time scales.'
Dr. B:'So what is the function then of spontaneous activity during the development? Is there a role for it, or does it just serve as a way to get us away from that hard-wired idea?'

Dr. M:' The activity that develops in nervous systems during development must occur spontaneously, without the influence of neuromodulators, for this is the only way to ensure that the neural activity that develops is consistent with the way the nervous system operates.'
Dr. B:' In what way does the brain develop spontaneously? Does it have a 'default state'?'

Dr. M:' In many cases it does. For example, we develop the muscle system of our forearms over time and without conscious effort, as a result of repetitive muscle movements and the strengthening of muscles. There is also a very important process called homeostatic regulation that allows neurons to reach target firing frequencies that produce appropriate muscle movements.'
Dr. B:' What is homeostatic regulation? What are the mechanisms that provide this regulation? What is the function of homeostatic regulation?'

Dr. M:' This has been studied very extensively, particularly the regulation of membrane voltage in neurons, and it is critical to homeostatic regulation of firing frequency because it ensures that neurons reach target firing frequencies when they are isolated and can fire without any influences from other neurons. This regulation ensures that neurons that fire in a stereotyped manner can also maintain their target firing frequency.'

Dr. B:' How do neurons maintain their firing frequency? Can you illustrate this with an example? Can you explain this in a simple way? Can you give me an example? Can we see a homeostatic mechanism? Can you make it up? Can you make up an example of what happens to the neuron when it reaches this target firing frequency? What is the mechanism? Is it the same thing when the neuron is not isolated? What is the difference? What is the regulation? Can we see it?'

Dr. M:' No, this regulation of firing frequency depends on the presence of some very important physiological regulators, that include the pacemaker kernel, the neuromuscular junction, the membrane excitability and the synaptic excitability. This regulation depends on the interaction of all of these systems. The pacemaker kernel is activated by temperature, by changes in pH, by changes in intracellular Ca 2+  concentration, and by neuromodulators.'

Dr. B:' Where is the neuromodulator? Where is the neuroma? Where is the membrane excitability? Where is the synaptic excitability? Where are these things? Where are the things that change when neurons reach this target firing frequency and keep the neuron firing? Can you make these things up? Are these things the same? Are these things identical? Are these things similar? Can we see an example that illustrates what happens to the membrane when it reaches this firing frequency? What changes?'

Dr. B:' The most important function of this regulation is to ensure that a neuron that is active at a higher frequency can maintain its firing frequency in the long-term. I assume that this function is related to some fundamental mechanisms and that this fundamental mechanism is what we are looking for when we are trying to understand the brain and its functions. What is this mechanism? What is the fundamental mechanism of this homeostatic regulation to maintain a given firing frequency in the brain?'

Dr. M:'No, but it does develop. So, if you look at animals of the same age that you're asking questions about, even if you just look at animals of an identical genetic make-up, you find out that some are 'laggards', and some have more features and some have more neurons, some have more synapses in their circuits, and some develop to different extents. You find that the same genetic make-up doesn't always give rise to the same physiological output.'
Dr. B:' How is this spontaneous activity related to the activity that occurs after birth in humans?'

Dr. M:'Well, you see, in humans, we've always been nervous systems that have evolved to cope with a certain range of activity, whether it's our bodies, or whatever else we might deal with, so our nervous systems evolved to be able to deal with different kinds of activity, so it's really that they sort of came to be this way.'
Dr. B:' What kind of activity is not supported by the brain, and what kind of activity is?'

Dr. M:'We had two questions that were asked this afternoon, and I wanted to ask about the function of neural activity during development. One is how the brain is wired during development, but we had one interesting observation, is that when the brain grows older, the neural activity becomes more robust. We know that many of the synapses in the brain change their properties as we get older.'
Dr. B:'How would you define that? What is that? Is that the same in different species, in different animals?'
Dr. M:'Yes. Yes.'
Dr. B:'Is that the same in the developing brain as in the adult brain?'
Dr. M:'So that is how the brain changes, the activity becomes more robust and more stable.'
Dr. B:'So, it would mean that at the onset of the wiring stage, the brain is less prone to change that way as we get older. Is that a fair way of explaining it? Do you see it that way?'

Dr. M:'But it changes. Right. We know that as we get older, many of the synapsies that we use change, either because of changes in voltage-gated conductances in the synapse, and changes in synaptic efficacy, and also, many times, the synaptic conductance is different, the synaptic strength changes, the electrical synapses change, the gap junctions change. And so it is possible for the brain to change when we are young.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, we found that this happens for many neurons and many networks, this sort of a switch, so that as the brain gets older, many of the circuits switch back and forth from one to another. So, what we've been studying is, we've been studying that for many years, this switch-like switch in some brain circuits, as we get older, and this switch-like change of brain circuits, not only as you get older, but also as your brain changes.'

Dr. B:'The second question is, how do these switches or changes in brain circuits manifest? How does this switch become active? Is it activated when you're in a particular mood? Or is it activated when you have a particular goal in mind? Is it activated by different types of learning? Are they different? Is it activated for different types of memories? Is it activated, we know it changes, but how does it change? We don't know how the circuits change.'

Dr. M:'That is a great question. In a sense, I think, you know, there is a sort of, you know, I think, there's a bit of an illusion, that somehow that the brain stays the same throughout life, but it's not true. I mean, even with muscles you know, muscles get bigger and stronger and it becomes more effective, but they change.'

Dr. M:'Well, we can ask the same question about the function of muscle movement. In the nervous system there are networks of oscillating neurons that are important for the correct performance of all brain functions, but are not critical for the brain functioning. For example, the cardiac and pyloric circuits. They produce cardiac and pylori rhythms, and these rhythms are important for the breathing process, for the chewing process, for the swallowing process, but they are not critical for all other brain functions.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for these rhythms? What are they good for?'
Dr. M:'They're good for keeping the heart alive, keeping the lungs alive, they're good for eating, they're good, they're good to the brain.'
Dr. M:'So, the function of these rhythms is, as far as I know, for maintaining body temperature, maintaining homeostasis. The function of muscle movement in the stomach is for eating.'
Dr. B:'Now, in the brain, are there oscillators? What is their function?'

Dr. M:'There is not only oscillators, but a ton of different oscillators. The best-known ones are the cardiac and pilar muscles. And there is the soma in the center of the brain, where there are several neurons. We know that these oscillators provide pacemaker function, and that they influence many brain functions.'
Dr. B:'Is there any physiological mechanism for the maintenance of body temperature without the brain? What is the mechanism?'

Dr. M:'No, I think not. I think the mechanism is the brain is just a part of it. It's probably just a mechanism. It's a mechanism that has evolved over millions of years to be robust, so it can maintain body temperature, because temperature changes all of the biological processes in the body, in the nervous system, the muscles, all of the processes in the body. They all depend on temperature.'

Dr. M:'The first thing that is learned by the brain is not necessarily about consciousness, which may be something entirely different, but it is about function. In the same way that muscles and bones are growing and different muscle fibers are growing in the brain, there are distinct neuron types. And in the same way that different types of muscles are used to move different types of animals, neurons, in the brain, are used to move animals in different ways.'

Dr. B:'If I was to pick one neuron that is most critical for cognition, that would be an interesting question, and in fact, there are some neuron types, such as interneurons and fast-spiking neurons that are used for such purposes. There are even some in the brain, such as in the hippocampus, where these specific neuron types are used as a map and are necessary for the formation of certain memories. What is the function of these neuron types?'
Dr. M:'What are their functions?'

Dr. M:'Right, exactly. So you can think of it as sort of a wiring diagram, but it's not a hard-wired wiring diagram. It's a wiring diagram that will allow you to move in the world, if you don't have vision, or if you are blind. In the same vein, if your eyes are damaged, your brain will allow you to see and to navigate the world.'

Dr. M:'You know, it's funny, I often say that you know it's kind of these mysteries in neuroscience that you really can't figure out, you can try to, you know, figure out your way around it and do experiments, but you can't, you know, you can't really, you know, come to understand it.'

Dr. B:'What is the, I don't know that the thing is actually in our hands. What are we actually asking? Is that really a good question? There's many different things one could say is that the function of spontaneous activity during development is this or that, is a, is an interesting question to answer.'

Dr. M:'But you can't, it really can't because there's a lot of these mysteries and I think most people don't, you know the most people don't know. Like I mean there's the function of neuronal circuits is really important but you know, there's a lot, I think one of the problems is, you know, is we really don't know how, I mean the function of a neuronal circuit, the function of a neural circuit, is really important.'

Dr. B:'There are a lot of, uh, possibilities. And to me it's just so funny that I don't know what to say because one of the possibilities could be that there is, uh, there is a lot of freedom in the brain, but then there's still a lot of, um, constraints, or limitations.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, yeah I mean there's a lot. There's a lot of constraints, there's a big constraint. Right.'

Dr. B:'And then there's a limitation. And then there are the limitations. And then there's a limitations. I mean, this is where we have to go, you know, and there's a limitation in your research that there's a limitation that we need to go and we know. There's a limit, but the question is how to overcome these limitations and limitations. And, uh, that's where I'm at.'
Dr. M:'Okay, I'm at.'
Dr. B:'I'm at.'

Dr. M:'I'm at a point right now where I, I have a few, uh, limitations, and it's actually very hard to think how to get beyond them, because you've really got to think about how you do that, how you think about this. Because this is where you really need to get to the point where you know you need to think about, uh, thinking about things that aren't constrained.'

Dr. B:'So why is the neural syntax so complicated? It's hard to figure out what's the function of it, because it really is a big thing to be taken apart and put together again into some kind of a function.'

Dr. M:'I mean, I'm very interested in how neurons, brain neurons are built and how synaptic inputs from the rest of the brain are regulated and how that all gets regulated. So you know, I'm very much looking at the underlying mechanisms of how neurons get regulated. How synapses are regulated. But it also I mean, you know, so I look at synaptic depression.'

Dr. B:'But the function of the synapse, which is really an electrical process and the way it communicates between two cells. This is the thing that I'm not sure that we have in our hands. There's a large, uh, space in our hand. There's a huge amount of work to do to understand how the brain is built, and how the circuit can be put together, but the really important issue is the function of the circuit. What is the function of a circuit?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'And I look at synaptic potentiation, which, uh, I can call them the same thing, you know, the same thing. But the mechanism of synapse, how does it get back to a state of baseline is what the function of this is, it is this. The synaptic function is the function of the synapse.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, and I remember the first time we saw each other we were in the park in Cambridge, we were doing this kind of, you know, sitting in the park and we went back home and my mother asked me when we were first meeting, did we meet, was it a big meeting? And I said it wasn't really a meeting.'

Dr. B:'And, and my, and it just didn't really click at first that was a big meeting. It was a small meeting, and then we just talked, and I knew, and then a few months later I realized that my lab and, uh, the lab where I would meet Marder was, and there was a, there was a connection.'
Dr. M:'That is really interesting.'

Dr. B:'I mean, I mean, it's, uh, it is, it is interesting, it's interesting how those of us who, uh, who do very different fields in neuroscience connect to each other, but it also makes it, uh, and there's, there's something in common as well.'
Dr. M:'So, um, and then, but it is, it's kind of a mystery that you just, that you just can't figure out.'

Dr. B:'I think, yeah, that the big, or at least the big question is what is the function of spontaneous? activity during development, and it's very complicated, and it's always interesting how one works it through. And then there's other questions as well, the function of sleep, and there are other questions. There are, there are a lot of different questions that you can ask, and it's not an easy problem to solve, but it's a very interesting one to ask.'

Dr. M:'And there's different answers to different questions. But you know, because there's so much more known about the brain, the nervous system, how it works during development than how it works during adult. Right?'

Dr. B:'So when you say spontaneous activity during development, does that mean that it, it's a function of how the system works? Is that what you're asking, is that your question? Is that what we're asking?'

Dr. M:'The early embryo is all kind of chaotic, the first few days are like the early days of the nervous system. But the important thing to focus on is then how it develops and the processes of neuromodulation that begin to regulate the processes of circuit function at the level of the circuit.'
Dr. B:' What are the most important functions of spontaneous activity? I'm thinking about gamma frequency rhythms. What does this do?'

Dr. B:'If you look at the literature, and you find the first systematic reviews on these questions, the answers are mostly 'it's an important problem to be solved because it is related to a cognitive function or a mental function, or it is a phenomenon that is important to understand'.'

Dr. B:'How do neuronal networks become organized? Do they have a natural organization or do they require training? Do they have natural connectivity or do they require learning? Does the brain grow up with this organization or do we develop that? What mechanisms are in place to regulate the stability of this organization in the absence of environmental or body-derived inputs? Are these mechanisms learned or inherited?'

Dr. M:'So you ask me the most fundamental question of all: how do we develop a sense of self and how do we create a sense of ourselves and how we relate to others in the world? The answer to that is probably going to have to come from a combination of both.'
Dr. B:'And the combination that you think is needed? What is that combination?'

Dr. M:'Well, I think we have this idea that this is really a unique way of being and to some extent we are unique. I think we also have this notion that you know all of these processes are necessary for us and they don't happen because of magic, they don't happen by some magic.'

Dr. M:'I think we learn them as we grow up because then we can take advantage of our experiences and learn more from our personal experience than other people. And I think in general, I have seen most of the neuroscientists who are the same age and who started graduate school a little bit earlier than me to be very different from me, and the brain is one of the most sensitive things that you can train yourself to do, and it has to be regulated, and we learn how to do it.'

Dr. B:'What is the relationship between brain dynamics and cognition? What is the relationship between connectivity and computation? Do we know what is going on in circuits, and what makes them go? Or do we just assume the brain 'wires up' into a set of circuits that make it a brain that 'does something' and what? Does that mean anything to us, even if we know how it is wired up?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's hard to think about this in a simplistic way, because one of the things that people find really difficult about understanding neural circuits is that they have this amazing ability to self-assemble and they do this on the basis of interactions with environmental inputs. So one of the things we find ourselves thinking about is this issue of 'how do neurons interact in the absence of environmental input?'
Dr. B:'Do they have an intrinsic ability to generate spontaneous activity, or are they just waiting for something in their network to push them over the edge?'

Dr. M:'I'm a bit perplexed, because at some point in time, these patterns are just going to be there and you don't necessarily know whether you're going to use them. If you're going to develop a particular function of the brain, then these networks, these networks of neurons are going to develop anyway. You're going to develop your network of neurons.'

Dr. B:'But this network is going to be very well prepared. In fact, the pattern is just going to be waiting for you and waiting for you to use it, and it's going to be prepared because you have to do something with it. You have to do something useful with it. I mean, it's a network, but it's also a device that you can learn, because it's already there. So I would like to know whether the brain is more like a machine or a network.'
Dr. M:'Well, I would say it's both because you can't build a machine and a machine doesn't build itself.'

Dr. M:'The function of neural activity during development is still a mystery. We have no good idea why neural activity is different in some animals and not in others, as we would like to know, because many of the features of neural activity are developmentally determined. So, how does that come about? It would be nice to know what the underlying principles are that determine how animals develop, in terms of brain and behavior and all of the components of their nervous system.'

Dr. B:'We have a lot of evidence to suggest that the brain is programmed to self-organize. That is, that it has self-organized dynamics at every scale from single cells, to neurons, to the large cerebral cortex, and that it functions this way because it is most adaptive. It is most adaptive when it is able to generate an output, in the form of behavior.'

Dr. M:'Yes. Well, in some way. Because we want to know the mechanisms by which behavior occurs. We want to know what neural mechanisms are responsible for behavior. So, it is very interesting to think about the role of brain activity in development and its role in behavior. Of course, when you think about it in some general terms, the neurons in the brain are going to be more active in some animals than they are in others.'
Dr. B:'What is the role of spontaneous neural activity in the development of the brain?'

Dr. M:'It is still a mystery how neural activity develops into mature brain behavior. I mean, obviously, the brain has to be mature. So, we are looking at mature brain behavior. We are looking at animals that are mature. So, I mean, I look at the lobster  Cancer borealis  as an example of this. The lobster is not that young. The lobster is almost mature.'

Dr. M:'It is very well documented that the development of animals, the maturation of neurons is extremely variable, and that a neuron can be produced, in one type of animal, and not in other animals, as the result of different underlying mechanisms. There are also lots of examples where animals of the same species can behave very differently, or even exhibit different behaviors.'

Dr. B:'Yes, that's true. But, and the point that I am trying to make is that it is possible to learn a lot about how development occurs from the knowledge that self-organized dynamics are the default state of the system, because the system always comes up with self-organized patterns, that the brain can use. So, the brain can learn a lot about development from the very simple, but very fundamental, principles that underlie the spontaneous dynamics of the system.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's essential that the central pattern generating system that controls activity in the pyloric circuit of the stomatogastric ganglion in the lobster,  Panulirus interruptus, during development is properly maintained in adult preparations.'

Dr. B:'I would like to ask your question from a slightly different perspective. What is the function of spontaneously occurring activity in the brain? This question could be as informative as you ask from the point of view of a very specific system. The brains ability to generate self-organized activity is what gives rise to my answer. In terms of the brain as a system, what is the function of self-organized activity? The self-organized activity of the brain is a fundamental feature of neural systems.'

Dr. B:'When the experimenters, Marder and her colleagues at New York University, were preparing the tissue culture, they observed some spontaneous activity from the first day in culture. They identified these 'patterns' as neuronal aggregates that they would call 'neural syntax'. They wrote a paper with the results and called it 'neural syntax' in the journal 'Neuron'.'

Dr. M:'Now, as we develop this study of neural syntax, we want to study how brain systems deal with sensory inputs, including the senses of taste and smell, and how they deal with hormonal inputs. We want to understand neural mechanisms that can be used for maintaining brain homeostasis, and that's the point at which it becomes very important to understand how neural syntax is regulated.'

Dr. B:'In particular, we want to ask about how it is maintained, because in many cases, it's maintained by external sensory inputs or externally driven hormones. And, when those inputs are withdrawn or, when those hormones are suppressed or eliminated, the activity patterns of neural syntax are altered, and that's where things get very interesting. What we'll see is a lot of neural syntax activity in the absence of the environmental control that would maintain the same activity patterns.'

Dr. M:'That's right. It's interesting because if you go back to work that was done with  Aplysia, a very small, simple nervous system, and you look at neural coding there, if you just take those data and put them in a little model that's similar to a neural network you'd think, 'Hey, that doesn't look anything like a brain.' It looks like a bunch of neurons that are connected by electrical synapses and by modulatory synapses to each other.'

Dr. B:'But then you go back to the experiments done with  Panulirus,  and you realize that there are a few neurons, but their activity patterns are very distinct and, if you look at these patterns and look at these, I'm sure you can tell that there are similarities, but there's enough differences between these patterns to make it clear that these patterns, although they can be used as a reference mechanism for thinking about neural syntax, they are not the neural syntax.'
Dr. M:'So you're talking about a form of homeostatic regulation that is central to nervous system function, that ensures that neurons and networks remain the same.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's not exactly clear, it may be important for patterning, you know, neural network construction, or synaptic transmission, or homeostatic mechanisms, which are very important during development. There are very good studies on this in the stomatogastric ganglion in crustaceans, where there's very good data on how this nervous system grows and develops and what sort of neural patterns emerge and change over time.'

Dr. M:' The first thing I'd say is, if I had the time to read all of the papers I want to, but, it would be that, for example, neural activity is crucial for development. This activity must be rhythmic, and this rhythmic activity is really important, because when you're developing the nervous system, you're developing all the circuit function. So I think the best study would be to show the function of the nervous system, if the nervous system is intact, during development.'
Dr. B:' I'm interested in this, because I have long believed in the importance of activity in neural development. My first question is, is that a real study, or just another wish?'
Dr. M:'No.'
Dr. B:'Is it a study, or a mere desire?'
Dr. M:'Oh, this is a study.'
Dr. B:'I'm a little confused here. Can you walk me through what your study is? I'm really curious about the content of it.'

Dr. M:'Well, it's a study of activity in neural networks, and it's a study from the first part, the part that you're interested in, because I'm really interested in neural syntax as it relates to neural circuit function, and how neural circuits develop. We studied the stomatogastric nervous system of crabs, where, for instance, the brain, the brain consists of two lobes, and there are motor neurons that project into muscles.'

Dr. B:'Well, what we're going to look at is the development of the visual system in the rabbit. The rabbit is a well-known species, and this is a well-characterized animal. There are a number of well-understood experiments in the rabbit. There's a long list of well-understanded experiments. I'm not going to talk about any specific experiments because those are all readily available.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, no.'

Dr. M:'If you could ask a single biological neuron, "what do you do during development?" you would get an answer that you would be surprised. What do neurons do during development? I guess there's two things. One is, the brain becomes very complex and starts to have multiple neurons. So, you have many neurons firing at many times during development, and I guess these neurons develop a set of intrinsic properties that, then, enable them to become good working neurons for the adult brain.'

Dr. B:'And what about the brain that is very simple and has a single neuron? The development of the brain as it moves from this simple to the complex form is what we're interested in. The most fundamental difference between the brains that evolved in the simple environment and brains that evolved in complex environments are that simple brains have many fewer cell types compared to complex brains.'

Dr. M:'It's important because it's the first time that there is a chance to see how different neurons and circuits of neurons are organized in the nervous system. For example, my grandmother was a neuroscientist and studied the electrical activity of neurons in the spinal cord in the 1920s and 30s and she found that some of these neurons were present as single neurons, while others are present as groups of neurons. And that, in her time, was quite interesting.'

Dr. B:'It was very important because there was a need to find a proper function to such a neuronal activity. It was not possible to define its function, so we said, let's call it a reflex, it has two components, one is an ascending activity and the second one is a descending activity that are coordinated to form a loop, which is called the central pattern generator.'
Dr. M:'So we had this model of the pyloric circuit and it has two neurons, one of them is the pacemaker neuron and one of them is one of the oscillatory cells.'

Dr. B:'So the oscillator neuron is what made us happy because it behaved as we thought, it was a perfect oscillator. And in our initial experiments, we saw that the loop that we defined is indeed closed. There are no open-loop components in the central pattern generator. It works in a complete loop. There are only two places of possible failures: the central pattern generator and the pacemaker neuron.'
Dr. M:'Exactly, the pacemaker and the oscillator were connected, and there were a number of tests to make sure that there would be no interference between the two neurons.'

Dr. B:'Exactly. So it was a very nice discovery. But it took time. And, it is also important because we did not know how to find the pacemaker. There was no good answer. Because the central pattern generator is closed and there is only one place of possible failure: the pacemaker. And we could not find the pacemaker neuron until, uh, I wrote the book "The Gamma Buzz".'
Dr. M:'I mean, how many ways can you search for the pacemaker neuron?'

Dr. B:'Well, there are two. I can either find the neuron in a random search and I have to know the circuit beforehand, but this would not be a very efficient way. Or I could find the neuron first, because there is only one neuron. Then I would find it pretty fast. So when I realized that the model was closed, I used a particular method that we do not use in my laboratory.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'We use a very specific search method, which is called a 'blind search', which is, uh, the idea that the neuron should be the only neuron and should have no connection to other neurons. It is like if you want to find the hidden message in a sentence, or the hidden number in a number sequence, or, uh, the hidden place in a picture, and so on. Well, the blind search is the most efficient way to find hidden information in any system.'
Dr. M:'Spontaneous neural activity is critical for establishing and maintaining the activity-dependent features of nervous systems.'
Dr. B:'And, what is activity dependent? Are there different modes of activity?'
Dr. M:'Well, yeah, there are different modes of activity, as the brain develops.'

Dr. B:'What are these different modes? Do we know which of these states will become the default state of the brain, and why? What are the reasons for this? Are we born with one set of patterns? Are we born to experience and become self-motivated, or are we born with self-generated patterns?'
Dr. B:'What kind of activity is the default activity?'

Dr. M:'The function of the neural network is to provide the neural circuit for the appropriate behavior. And the role of the neural activity is to develop the appropriate nervous system, to produce appropriate behavior in the animal. So, the neural activity is a major determinant of the appropriate behavior. So, neural activity is important for development of the nervous system, and then for function of the nervous system. And then also for evolution of nervous systems.'

Dr. B:'Is it ever important to have spontaneous activity in the adult brain? I mean, when we discuss the importance of spontaneous activity during development, it is in terms of neural syntax. In terms of brain-behavior. And this has been debated by generations of neuroscientists, and you're the two neuroscientists who have addressed this issue most clearly, both of you. Do we ever need spontaneous activity in the brain? What are the pros and cons?'
Dr. M:'Well, it helps establish the circuit, you know. It helps establish the circuits, the synaptic connections between neurons.'

Dr. B:'And then you can do things with them. There's always a time that activity occurs when the circuits have established themselves that is beneficial for the organism to do something with, in terms of that. The circuit is already set. Now it's not a random noise. It's a structure. So there is no 'random' in this world. What is random is to take something out of a structure that it's a random thing and look at the consequences.'
Dr. M:'Randomly, you're going to lose the structure, because you're going to start doing things with it. And the structure will go away, the wiring will go away.'

Dr. B:'I know. The random is a brain. I mean, it's always a brain. The brain is a structure and there are many structures and there are many functions. I would like to know how to think about those. And when we are thinking about those, what are we doing? What is it doing? How are we doing this? How are we thinking about those? Is that random? Or is it structured? We know it's a brain. And what is it doing?'

Dr. M:' It is important that a neuron can respond to the environmental perturbations it will be exposed to during development. So it is important that, when a neuron is not active, that it can respond to perturbations of its activity. One of the key examples of how the function of the nervous system is regulated by modulators is the case of synaptic modulation of the synaptic transmission of muscle fibers. There is some evidence that this is important in development of the nervous system.'

Dr. B:' What is the impact of the developmental process on neural activity? How does the brain disengage from the environment? Does the brain have a 'default state'? How would the default state be characterized by the experimenters? What is the default pattern in terms of the distribution of activity of neuronal groups and their relationship to each other?'

Dr. M:' The key is in the word 'default'. So the default state is the state that will occur most of the time, so that the neurons are not in a constant state of activity. This will be different for neurons that are part of networks, and the networks will be different for each individual brain.'

Dr. B:' So what is the impact of this default state on the brains ability to represent the external world? Are there differences between how a developing brain and an adult brain represents the world and the surrounding environment? How is the default state characterized in terms of the distributions of activity of neuronal populations and their relationship to, each other? What is the role of sleep in the default state? What is the impact on sleep? Is there a role for sleep? What is the function of sleep?'

Dr. M:' So the key point is that neural systems have to be regulated, so they can respond to environmental perturbations. So it's important that a neuron is always active, but also has a time when it is sleeping when the environment is not perturbing. So that you have some sort of balance between the two.'

Dr. B:' This is very important for the brain because there are times when the system does not need to be as active, but it is there, but it doesn't have much to do with anything. It is not useful to the brain. So these are those conditions that the brain has to deal with when it disengages from its environment, and it can disengage for a long time before it starts getting back into the default state again. And these are those processes that are going on in the brain.'

Dr. M:' We would characterize that by measures of activity, of firing rates, of activity patterns, of the time of activity for each neuron, of the frequency of the activity patterns in the network and so forth. So we have done many experiments in animals of various species that showed that the brain can reconfigure itself.'

Dr. B:' How do neurons engage and disengage from each other? How does this process evolve as the brain matures? What is the relationship between the patterns of activity during the development process and the patterns of activity in adults? Is there a 'default state' of neural activity? Do the patterns in adults correspond to patterns in the early developmental period?'

Dr. M:' There's certainly a set of patterns that we think of as 'core'. So, for example, neurons like the ones that are responsible for the circadian rhythm are active throughout all of our lives. Neurons like the ones that control chewing are only active when chewing food, and we think of these as being core pattern neurons. Neurons that are active in many different brain regions during the lifetime of an animal are core pattern neurons.'

Dr. B:' Can the activity patterns in an adult reflect the sequence of activity patterns during development? Do the patterns at different ages correspond to the pattern in a newborn, adult, or older child? What do the adult activity patterns have to do with the early stages of the developmental process? Is there a default state of neural activity? How do we know if an adult state corresponds to the default state of activity when the animal is a newborn?'

Dr. M:' The adult state corresponds to a particular pattern of activity. A default state is not a pattern. So, if you think of an oscillator, if you want to characterize a cell like a neuron that will oscillate, an oscillator that will be active throughout your lifetime and so forth, you can use frequency of oscillations, duty cycle, and amplitude as the parameters.'

Dr. B:' I would also add that a pattern corresponds to a pattern that is associated with a behavioral output. It's one pattern that could be described with one parameter. So if you want to know how that one pattern is characterized as an adult, as a mature brain, or as an older brain, it would be useful to know how that pattern is characterized as a child. And, in fact, we have done a lot of studies with rats, but I don't have a particular rodent to focus on.'

Dr. B:' In other words, the default state in adult life would be characterized by a set of neurons and the activity patterns of those neurons that can't be altered by any external perturbations or conditions. It would be characterized by patterns that would be consistent in both development and adulthood. Is there such a core state? Are there core patterns? What is the impact on the core patterns by the developmental process? What are the implications of the developmental process for the core patterns?'

Dr. M:' In the first few days of life, the brain is not yet sufficiently developed to be able to control every physiological function of the body. So it will take some time for the brain to discover which functions it can control. So we can speculate that the initial phase of development will be critical, because during development the brain will be learning to control these functions. And it will also be learning that, OK, these other physiological systems may also be important.'
Dr. B:' Do we know how this process can be investigated experimentally?'

Dr. M:' Right. One thing that I've done a lot of work on is looking at the developmental expression patterns of neural systems in different animals. So we use this technique of looking at the expression levels of different genes in different neurons or different brain regions, and we study the relationships between these neurons or different brain region in different animals, and in different species. So we study the relationships and we study the connections that exist between different neurons, and also the connectivity between different brain regions.'

Dr. B:' Would there be any changes in the brain during development? Would the default state change in any way? Does the brain disengage itself from the environment? What would be a good test for the default state? What is the best example of the state of the brain at any given point? Does the brain 'default' to a particular pattern? Is there a default pattern? What would a default pattern be like?'

Dr. B:'So the function is that it is necessary that a neuron can be activated, and it is not necessary that it is activated by the environmental perturbation. What is the function of development is not the environment. The environment is only a set of possibilities to choose from. It's the result of previous experience, which is already there, and then the brain chooses from these possibilities.'

Dr. M:'The most important thing is that it is possible to change the output of neurons. So the role of the environment is really important, as it gives a set of possibilities and allows the brain to choose from them, and to choose an appropriate response.'

Dr. B:'What is the importance of spontaneous activity during development? It is just as important, but not as specific. The brain is just a set of possibilities. The most important thing is to choose from these possibilities, which is what gives rise to the brain's output, which is the action of the body.'
Dr. M:'That's right. The function of the nervous network is really to do the appropriate action of the muscles.'

Dr. M:'It is the way that neural activity becomes self-organized, in that case, because there are synaptic modifications as neural networks are forming, and as they are developing, and they are just, there is a process of choosing, in that case. It is not, it is not 'there is a fixed function'.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for the brain of self-organized neuronal activity? And what is the role of self-organized activity in development?'

Dr. M:'So, for the brain of the animal it is necessary that neurons can form the brain. There are three different ways in which this can be achieved, which we will discuss in a moment. The first is a purely genetic mechanism, so that neurons can express ion channel and receptor genes that give them a specific voltage dependence. This is an example of hard-wired behavior that occurs at all times in the animal's life. We will discuss this mechanism in a moment.'

Dr. B:'I'd like to discuss how development creates a particular assembly pattern of neurons in the brain. So you have the genetic blueprint, which is the genome. And the genetic blueprint is there to determine how the network is organized, and then you have to choose from that a particular set of possibilities that the brain chooses from and then you have a pattern. So, we have the pattern as a blueprint, and we have to choose from all possible options, which is the selection mechanism.'
Dr. M:'Spontaneous neural activity during development is important because it helps neurons find their place in the nervous system.'
Dr. B:'How did you study this phenomenon?'

Dr. M:'Well, for years we'd be looking at the neural circuit in the nervous system and finding correlations that were meaningful, but we were unable to understand the function of these correlations, because there was no function we could associate them with.'
Dr. B:'In other words, how do you know when the neurons will turn off their spontaneous activity and start firing in response to an appropriate input?'
Dr. B:'I know, but what do they actually do in the brain?'

Dr. M:'It is well-known that neural networks, at least in the cortex, are highly active during embryonic development, and that they can become silent or exhibit different activity patterns during subsequent stages of development.'
Dr. B:'Could you explain these observations? If you have a moment.'

Dr. M:'The first observation comes from the fact that many of the genes that code for neuronal proteins, such as ion channel subunits and neurotransmitter receptors, are turned on and off during development, so we have some idea of which neurons are in an active state when the network is developing, and the timing and the phase of the switches that are used to activate these genes. The next observation is that we also have some idea of how the activity is changing during development.'

Dr. B:'And what would be the function of such a pattern? Do you have an example? How does this pattern benefit from the brain of an adult? Are we aware of any, any function of this pattern? Is it a special thing that happens when this pattern is in place? What is the function of this pattern?'

Dr. M:'There are many, many examples of such behavior. And I will tell you that, that it is very important to see how it develops during embryonic development, because then you know how it is that these neural circuits develop to be able to perform all of their function, to be able to interact with the rest of the nervous system, to be part of a complex brain, and to be part of behaviour, and cognition and emotion.'
Dr. B:'I would like to, uh, follow up on that.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'

Dr. M:'So that's a good question. So let's take a couple of examples, you know, a very simple example is a spiking network that has only three neurons, and these are three of the five neurons that are in the network. These are three oscillators, you know, oscillators. I don't know if you've studied this, this model. This is very simple, I know it sounds.'

Dr. B:'I have studied this network. I studied this network and its various configurations. The most interesting thing I found out is that the system can have two different kinds of behaviors, one is the default behavior, where the three neurons fire each in phase with each other. They fire together at one frequency, but they don't have a special relationship among themselves.'

Dr. M:'And then the other kind of behavior occurs when a single neuron fires out of phase, but the two other neurons are phase locked to that single neuron. In other words, one of the other two neurons stops firing and is silent during a particular phase. In other words you can have the same frequency but different relationships among these neurons.'

Dr. B:'What is the function and mechanism of the self-organized activity, which is present in the developing brain, the adult brain, and throughout the life cycle? Where are these patterns? How should they be explored?'

Dr. M:'You're talking about the activity of the central pattern generating networks, which are responsible for all rhythmic movement in the brain. They are responsible for maintaining the balance between muscle contraction and muscle relaxation, for generating the pyloric rhythm in the pyloric network of the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion (STG) and for producing the rhythmic movements associated with speech.'

Dr. B:'How can this self-organized activity be exploited or used in order to understand and learn about how these complex functions are realized by neural networks? Do we have a good understanding of what are the mechanisms that give rise to the self-organized patterns? Is it possible to manipulate these patterns and learn how to create synthetic activity patterns in the brains of developing animals so that we understand how these network patterns are generated?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. We're now exploring the mechanisms and how these self-organized patterns are generated. We now have the technology to manipulate the self-organized brain activity in many animals, both in the laboratory and in the intact brain. There are many different brain regions that produce distinct activity patterns during development. For example, the retina produces stereotyped and very precisely stereotyped patterns during embryonic development. However, during development, many neural networks can become silenced, or show different patterns of activity.'

Dr. B:'Does it matter where the perturbation occurs? Can one make perturbations that are important for particular regions of the brain but perhaps not for the function of the whole brain? Are there particular regions of the cortex that can be perturbed or activated in a way that is important for the understanding of the function of the cortex in general, or the specific function of a particular structure in a way that has long-term consequences? I'm interested in the patterns that are present during development.'

Dr. M:'Yes, of course. In this case, it is important that these perturbations occur in very early development and in developmentally-critical neurons. In this case you have a very specific area that is affected by these manipulations. In other cases, these manipulations can occur in neurons that are not essential for normal brain function.'

Dr. B:'Where do these networks reside, or is it possible that the network and the perturbation occur independently? In this case, if one can learn about the structure and function of the network by using imaging, one can perturb or activate these network patterns in the appropriate manner in the appropriate brain structure.'
Dr. M:'It is important, because these neural circuits provide a kind of scaffold for development, to make neurons and synapses more sensitive to neuromodulators.'
Dr. B:'But it is also important to train the brain in order to activate circuits that can make neurons and synapse more sensitive to neurotransmitters.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. For example, the development of motor neurons. It is very important that as neurons grow and develop they should be able to activate circuits, and they should be activated in ways that are beneficial. So for example, the pyloric network in the foregut, you want to make the neural activity during development in the foreguts different from the adult.'

Dr. B:'What is the function for sleep in the foregts? It is important to train the cortex for a specific purpose. But if the goal is to train the cortex to be sensitive to neurotransmitter inputs, it is also important that this training does not affect other functions of the brain.'

Dr. M:'But the training does. That is a big problem, because if you train for one specific function you are going to change the other features of the brain, because they all have to fit together. And so, if you take the cortex and you take a neuron, you can say, "Okay, I'm going to put this neuron into the cortex, because it is one part of the brain", but you are going to have to change a lot of other features of the circuit.'

Dr. B:'You are going to have less neurons in the cortex, which is very important. But this is what we should train. And that is what we train for, for example, the motor cortex. We want to train the movement system for specific functions, so you can then turn the circuit into one that is responsive to neuromodulatory inputs and can respond to neuromodulation in a different way.'

Dr. M:'So when you think about your whole nervous system, because I was trained as a neuroanatomist, and so I thought, okay, we have this neural circuit, we have these neurons, we have these synapses, we have these neurotransmitters, and now I think it's a lot more complicated than that. Because a neuron has many different subtypes. There are different versions of the same neuron. There are different populations of neurons, different species of neurons.'
Dr. B:'What is the function, during adult development, of spontaneous activity? Can you explain?'

Dr. M:'I think I answered the first question by saying it is essential for development. We have been very careful to maintain the homeostatic control of neural activity, by not injecting current into these circuits in adult neurons, so there has been an important function for activity-dependent processes. When you get neurons that fire in response to a variety of different inputs that will provide homeostatic control, it provides the feedback mechanism that will enable neural networks to reconfigure themselves.'
Dr. B:'How would that be done? How can we maintain the homeostasis? What is the feedback mechanism? What can we do to maintain a network in a homeostatic state?'

Dr. M:'The first thing is that there is a variety of potential perturbations and then there are compensations that occur in a network. Some of these perturbations can be permanent, some of them can be very transient. So, the first important thing is that there are compensations. This is one of the most important points, I think, of understanding neural systems, that neurons are always working with their environment, and compensations occur in the brains of all species.'

Dr. B:'Could you talk a little bit about the process of compensation? Please. What is it? What is the mechanism? What is the sequence? What can we put together? How can we build a sequence? What are the components? What are the mechanisms? How can we understand? What are the requirements? What is the explanation? What are the experiments? Please.'

Dr. M:'So, a very important function of homeostasis is to provide feedback for the circuits. And one of the most fundamental aspects of that is that there are sets of proteins, membrane-bound ion channels, that are turned over, their synthesis is controlled by different mechanisms, and some of those can be quite rapid.'

Dr. M:'Well, we have been studying neural compensations for many years. We first started studying the pyloric network of the pyloric brain of the crayfish. And one of the features of the pyloro system is that the frequency of the network oscillator is controlled by the rhythmic action of three neurons. These neurons are called 'pacemaker' neurons. They have electrical and chemical synapses.'
Dr. B:'If neurons in these circuits are already sensitive to neuromuscular control, what advantage do the spontaneous activity of the circuit serve?'
Dr. M:'Well, if neurons already are sensitive to neuromotion, then the brain is going to have some mechanisms to compensate for them.'

Dr. M:'There are numerous physiological consequences to the presence of spontaneous neural activity, as you know. They're used to establish and maintain cell identity. They're used as a control to control the brain in certain behaviours, as you know, or even for control of muscle movements. I mean, you know, muscle movements, you know, the contraction of muscles that give you that sort of breathing during the night that you do.'

Dr. B:'But the most important use is to establish the neuronal syntax that will allow you to build the brain of the animal. To learn from experience, to build up the brain and the brain networks of the animals and use that to build the brains of the humans.'

Dr. M:'Right. Right. Right. And I mean, the most important function is to, um, to maintain control of the brain during times when it's not behaving properly. So the activity patterns you use, you use for long periods of time. You know, the patterns you use during the night when you sleep and then you can't, you can't remember your dreams. The patterns you use when you're awake and then you're having a conversation. Right?'

Dr. B:'So this is important in terms of how you, um, how you build up the brain, how you build it. How can we understand how we do that? How could we build up a brain? I mean, how would you approach this? You know, I mean, it is something like this, but in the reverse direction. So you know, the brain is a preexisting system.'
Dr. M:'Oh, yeah. Right. Right, right.'

Dr. B:'And in both cases, you can't control them. You can't modify them. You can not just decide, uh, that's the way I want to build it. I'm a neuroscientist, and I'm, uh, interested in neural syntax, so I want to build up these patterns, these brains.'

Dr. M:'I think it is pretty clear that it is important that the developing nervous system is flexible enough to allow it to change as it learns, as it builds neural circuits. We have seen that in the case of the cortex of the nervous system, where we were able to make different animals by changing the level of modulation of the neuromodulatory inputs.'

Dr. B:'I'm not sure what makes the cortex different from other parts of the brain. For instance, in the thalamus, it is not so easy to change the level of inhibition and gain control, as in the cortex. It seems like it is much more important in the cortex to change the level.'

Dr. M:'Absolutely. I mean, so many other neurons are going to be connected to the cortex of an animal, and this is where you make the connections, so it is important that you have a lot of flexibility, but this is not necessarily the case.'

Dr. B:'So what kind of flexibility does the cortex have? We're going to be discussing how we develop a computer model to try to figure out the function of spontaneous activity during development. What are some of the mechanisms that allow the cortex to be flexible during development? What can we look for in the brain that might allow for such flexibility? How are the circuits built? How are the connections made? How do we develop? What are the mechanisms? What are the functions? What are the inputs?'

Dr. M:'So this is all very much work on the theory of circuit formation. There is some work that says that there may be some important features that can arise from the properties of neurons that may be conserved throughout development, but other work shows that if you have neurons with a ton of different voltage-dependent properties, you are going to get a variety of behaviours and a variety of different patterns of behaviour in development.'

Dr. B:'Now, how would it change the dynamics of the brain? How are the rhythms built? Are the rhythms generated or brought in? If you have a computer model that can make a model of how it works, how would it make a difference if it were to have a very different pattern of connectivity? How does connectivity change, and what are some of the rules?'

Dr. M:'I'm going to be talking about a variety of different questions. So let me give you an example of the way this plays out. We are trying to study how neurons interact with each other, how neurons interact with sensory inputs. So we have done a lot of studies where we have been using electrical coupling of neurons, but also electrical synapses of neurons in an isolated network, in the absence of other neurons.'

Dr. B:'It seems like, so many other things in the brain could be modulated, but it doesn't. It doesn't work that way. So, it is like, when you are a neuroscientist, you are interested in how the brain works, or how it works at any point in time. So how could it be? So what is the function of, so on and so forth?'

Dr. M:'So you are going to change the strength of the connections of the neurons. It doesn't have to be as simple as that. So you know, we have learned, we are going to learn about changing synaptic transmission, we are going learn how to control synaptic transmission in the adult brain.'

Dr. B:'So are you going to be able to show me, like, the exact changes that you are going to make, when you get to the adulthood of the brain, how will you connect neurons? I know, like, there are many connections of the cortex that are already in place, but what will be new?'

Dr. M:'No, actually, the connections we are going to be making are going to be new. So it is a little bit different, like, this is a little bit more of a change of what you think that is important, because the networks we are going to have are going to be a little bit different. But it is not going to be changing all the parameters that are important.'

Dr. B:'Okay. So what is important is that they don't change the parameters that are used by the brain to generate the same output. So that is what is important. So we want to generate the same outcome from a brain network, and they are going to change their ability to do this.'
Dr. M:'Absolutely. Okay, okay, I'm sorry, I think you are going to be surprised. We are going to be really surprised, I'm really hoping.'

Dr. B:'But it doesn't have to have such a simple function, because when you look at the very small, or small circuits, small circuits that make up the brain, how could they do such complicated things? And the answer is that they don't. So they don't have that capacity. But as soon as you connect it to the large neocortex, or the large neocortex in the adult brain, it can be a very complicated task, and it can be very difficult.'

Dr. M:'Yeah. I mean, I don't know if there is a good analogy to that, you know, in the human brain, but we know when we are babies, you know, we learn to control and play with our bodies. We learn to control our bodies. You know, and, you know, so that, you know that that is the kind of starting point for how we learn to control our brains.'

Dr. M:'I think the same thing. Like, there are so many other things that can be regulated. Like for instance, you know, if a neuron is silent, and you want to wake it up, you know, there are all kinds of neuromodulators that are going to be released. So, I think the same thing, the way that it is regulated depends on how you want it to be regulated.'
Dr. M:'Because the synaptic transmission is not, it is not as simple as we think that it is.'

Dr. M:'But it is important to understand that there are neurons that play an important role in the regulation of neuronal activity. Neurons that produce modulatory substances, and neurons that receive inputs from outside the circuit, that all of these neurons are important to have flexible enough circuits.'
