Dr. B:'How do these neurons interact in the developing brain? How do they form neural circuits? If you want to answer that question, please talk about my question, too, that is how are these neurons organized during development? I'm sure that the brain is already complicated, so we don't have to be inventing new things every day. But to understand the relationship between the building blocks and the way they work together, is really important.'
Dr. B:'How important is this flexibility? And how important is the ability to adapt to new stimuli as the brain builds circuits?'

Dr. M:'It seems to me that the nervous system is always being challenged with new challenges because the nervous system itself changes as circuits change. And it has to be flexible enough to allow the circuits to change.'

Dr. B:'Are there any recent studies that you've worked on that have made progress? Are there some topics that have been particularly interesting to you? What are your current interests and future plans? What would you like to know about how neuroscientists do research? Are there some things we know that we do not? What should we be looking for? How do we build a team? How do we work together? How do we make progress in our field? And what do we need?'

Dr. B:'But it is very important to make a distinction between neurons that are embedded in circuits that support their own dynamic and plasticity, and neurons that are embedded, say in the thalamic reticular nucleus, and in the cerebellum. In these structures, there is no plasticity, and it is very hard to change the level modulation of these neurons. It is not so easy, because there is not a strong enough excitatory drive.'
Dr. M:'Right, but they all rely on each other, so they all need to be tuned together to work together.'
Dr. B:'Exactly. So it seems that there are circuits that are different and have different dynamics, but those circuits are interdependent in an important way, and can work together.'

Dr. M:'So as you study these circuits, you find neurons with the same membrane potential that don't necessarily have the same behavior. It seems like the only time that you hear about someone who has had, say, the same voltage as another is when their activity is very different. So it is kind of like a puzzle how these neurons interact, and how these circuits work.'

Dr. B:'There is one way that it is done in the hippocampus. A few years ago, we reported that the firing patterns of a small subset of hippocampal pyramidal cells showed an extraordinary dependence on ongoing local networks of cells. What we call spontaneous ripples. So many of these neurons had the same firing pattern during spontaneous ripples, and they fired in sync with other neurons in the same network.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, yeah, yeah.'

Dr. B:'And what is the advantage of the brain to have such flexible circuits? What benefits are there to not have rigid circuits? How is it possible that neurons, which produce such substances, should have rigid circuits? The fact is that, without those rigid circuits, it is not possible to get rid of modulatory substances and gain control without affecting other elements of the circuit, as we have seen it in other parts of the cortex and the thalamus. What makes the cortex different?'

Dr. B:'Is it important to study how the different types of neurons interact with each other in the circuit? It seems like it could be an important function of the nervous system to build circuit where there are different types of neurons. For example, in the thalamocortical system, we can make a variety of different types of neurons in the different thalamic nuclei.'

Dr. M:'So it is really important to build networks in response to a particular stimulus that you need to respond to, I mean it is very important for an animal that you are going to respond to a particular stimulus to be flexible enough to be able to respond to that stimulus. It's very, very important.'

Dr. M:'We are trying to understand the principles that allow the brain to make itself. The brain's behavior, which has to do with perception, emotion, cognition, motor control, etc., all of these things depend on a whole complex of underlying neural mechanisms that have to be put in place early in development, when the brain is growing and making connections.'

Dr. B:'If the brain's spontaneous activity is an important part of the developmental process, what is the best explanation we have so far for this process? How does the brain's self-generated activity become organized? How does the self-generated activity lead to the formation of these connections in the early part of life, and then what happens in later development? Is there a particular event that leads to this organization? And then, if there is, how does this occur?'

Dr. M:'Oh, it's a really long story. We don't really understand how exactly this happens. So, in the case of the pyloric circuit that has its different neurons that interact with the same circuit, and the circuit is reconfigured during different processes of development, so the synaptic strength is changed and you know, and the synaptic interactions themselves are modified.'

Dr. M:'A good answer to that question was given by another neuroscientist, and a great scientist,  David H. Haensch. You know, he said, "Think of the developing brain as a developing animal." Because the behavior of the animal has to be put in order and the behavior of the brain has to be put together." But, that still doesn't answer all the questions. So, there are two major aspects. One is, you know, you have a growing brain.'

Dr. M:'I think that it's really important to understand this, because the neurons of an adult have to have a set of specific functions. The neurons that are developing have to have different kinds of functions. So if you take the example of the retina, when you're developing your retina, you are not going to want to use it for reading. But as you're learning to use your retina for reading, it has to develop a kind of robustness to it.'

Dr. B:'That's right. So how do you know what is the best thing to do in this kind of a developmental phase? Is it a set of experiments that would have a certain outcome? Or do you know, or maybe you don't know. So I think, the way the brain works is that you know, it's a complicated system with lots of things going on. So you make a guess at the output and look at the consequences.'

Dr. M:'That's right, it's a guess. So, I mean, we knew that the nervous system is robust. When we started studying the brain, we thought we would find this 'Aha!' moment where we would come up with a simple principle that explains how brains work. But we're finding that's not the case. Because we now know that there are lots of different solutions.'

Dr. B:'Well, it's not always easy to pick the optimal solution in the context of many different options. But that's the reason why the brain is not a hard-wired system. It's a complicated system, but the way you have to think about it is in terms of the outputs that we want to accomplish in order to evaluate the alternatives. Because if you make a wrong decision or do it the wrong way, it's like a car, and then the consequences are very unpredictable.'
Dr. B:'What's your answer? Why do we need to understand the activity of neurons in the brain during development?'

Dr. M:'Because I don't think we do that. You know, so that's an example of a case where the brain is reconfiguring itself and you don't want to make changes that you don't understand. You know, and I think it's a little bit like when you get into your car and you just want it to work, and then you get your first little bump and then you go 'oh I didn't think that would happen'.'
Dr. B:'But we are seeing a variety of studies, but how many of them have to be published for the sake of our collective understanding?'
Dr. M:'Exactly. So the main thing is, we have to understand how robust brain development is, and the brain is quite robust.'

Dr. M:'Well, we are beginning to understand what is critical for development and brain development. Because there are very, very many neurons that come together in the brain and that have specific tasks during development, and they need to function as they mature. They need to develop their abilities to change. So I mean, you have to understand the function of the neuron to really understand how the network develops. It would be the same as a brain-cell, if you have to understand how your brain cells develop.'
Dr. B:'So why is it so important to understand how we develop these functions?'

Dr. M:'Because I think a lot of people look at how neurons grow and how they fire, and they ask, "Why are they doing it?" So they're asking, "Why is this neuron going to fire spikes in a specific frequency? Or why is this neuron firing bursts of action potentials in a specific order?" And why is this neuron going be bursting when it has no function? Or why is it going to fire spikes when it has no motor function? Why are the neurons doing this?'

Dr. M:'Because as we do experiments, as we do experiments with the neurons of different types of animals, we begin to realise how robust the brain is to the changes in neuronal circuits that can occur.'
Dr. B:'In what way can you describe the function of the brain's spontaneous activity during development?'

Dr. M:'There is the interesting point that development is happening in multiple time scales. There are changes that happen very quickly, like, you know, a fetus will be developing in less than a month, but if you are talking about the development of a nervous system that is going to have to function, you know, to the extent that it is, I think the brain has to develop for a lifetime, it has to be robust to the variability of the internal and external environments.'

Dr. M:'I guess it's to sort of to give you the initial structure and then it might not be very functional initially, but it might be there to ensure that you have the initial structure and it might be there in case you change, like you find something interesting, and it might be useful.'

Dr. B:'Well, it is a very interesting question. There are different ways to go about it, and it may very well be that in the case of your brain, the initial structure is a very bad idea. There are many things we can't put together at birth. There are a lot of interesting things in our brain that are not there, even though these things might look very useful and maybe very useful in the future.'
Dr. M:'Yeah.'

Dr. B:'So in the case of the hippocampus, what I think is very exciting is the possibility of the hippocampal system in the absence of any sensory stimuli and, or memories and, or the experience of a specific event, how it might give rise to a completely novel structure. This is what I'm talking about, that it's a very interesting thing to ask. What is the function of self-generated activity? Is it beneficial? Can it be useful? Or can it be dangerous?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, so I would say that it may very well turn out that you just have this structure, you really can't ever change it. You're going to be doing interesting things like learning, reading, writing, and speaking, and so you'll just kind of get it wrong because it's really going to be wrong.'

Dr. B:'I don't have that much of an idea that there are things that we shouldn't put together at a very young age. What is there that we shouldn't? What's the evidence? I don't have that many things that I'm afraid of, but I don't have a list either. I'm not that good a scientist. I'm actually not a very good scientist at all. What is there? I don't know.'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, I think it is also interesting that you don't know that you should be afraid of, and I just want to mention this, that when we take a mouse, for example, which is like a two-month-old mouse and we take that and we freeze it, we do a whole bunch of experiments on it, and then we take it back out and we keep it alive.'
Dr. B:'So would you be open to the idea that spontaneous activity is not the only function of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely, that's a totally different, that's a different idea, that's a really interesting idea and so the other thing is, is it just kind of like a structure, or it's going to be a structure with no function, and then function comes from the external world?'
Dr. B:'It might be a structure with lots of function, as opposed to a structure with no initial function but there is function after some experience?'

Dr. M:'Exactly, so that's another way of asking the same question. So you say it's like a building is there's going to be function after you build it, and I think you're saying when you build your building and it's going to have functions or you're building your house and it's going be functional but you're not building it in order to function, you're building it to survive, right, and it's going through life and it's going have a life.'

Dr. B:'The spontaneous activity gives you an idea about how the wiring is organized in the brain, which is not the only way to understand how the wiring is organised. That is, it is also important to look at the wiring that is done in the lab and see how it connects to what is there, and see how that compares with what you are looking at to see how the wiring is organizing.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, so it is, it has always been there. It's there in the brain, but if you look at it you can see the connections are all different.'

Dr. B:'Yes, but there is a lot of variability in that spontaneous activity. It can be in different places in the brain depending on the development stage. It can be different, so that can have a profound effect on the way the brain develops. And it can have a profound impact on the way that it connects to what's there.'

Dr. B:'I'm interested in spontaneous activity during the initial phase of development, I'm interested in how the brain gives you the initial structure to sort of make it functional and then it may change in response to new information, but there has to be a balance between those two aspects, so that there is a stable structure. For example, a tree is very stable, but it has a big open structure that can be used for a lot of different purposes.'

Dr. M:'So there has to be some kind of balance between the need for stability, and the flexibility to respond to changing information, like new information about what the environment is going to be like.'

Dr. B:'Yes, exactly. Exactly, that's exactly. So this is the balance that I'm interested in. What does it look like? How can you use the initial structure that is there to make it very functional and responsive? So this is the, this is the balance we are interested in. We are interested in a balance between the needs for stability, and for responsiveness.'

Dr. M:'But you can also see that with the balance between stability and responsiveness, I'm interested as well in how networks are regulated. So I'm interested in the mechanisms, so not only in the mechanism that causes a tree to grow, but also in the mechanism that allows a tree to respond to changing conditions.'

Dr. B:'So the brain's always looking for a balance. We are looking for a balance between the stability and responsiveness aspects of brain activity. The balance of this has to be very important. It has to be very carefully maintained.'

Dr. B:'Why is it very important that the brain gets engaged in some spontaneous activity during development? I mean, if you take the idea that the cortex is a single neuron that is not attached to anything, it does not have a function. The idea that it has a function is that it starts with spontaneous activity. And as you know, we know from a lot of data that there is spontaneous activity in the brain, but what happens to it is not always very useful.'

Dr. M:'Right, well, we know that the activity during development might be important. We know that the activity after maturation is really important, but the activity during development, because it is a time of plasticity and I think the way we think about developing neurons is very different.'

Dr. B:'If you go to a brain research laboratory and you put in a piece of wire, it has a function for a long time. So it will be very interesting to see what the brain does. And I would like to know what the brain does in its own time. Do I have to wait until you are in a white lab to ask you what the brain does? If you want to know what the internal mechanisms are, what sort of thing are the people studying? Is that correct?'
Dr. M:'You are supposed to ask me what the brain does and not what your laboratory does, and so that is a little bit of a problem. Right?'

Dr. B:'Yes, well, that is a very serious issue that you have to look at, whether it's the brain or your laboratory. But if we're talking about development, and development is not about the brain, but it's about the wiring, then, well, the wiring is what the brain does, right. It builds the wiring before it's got a function, which is what it's built for, to have a function.'

Dr. B:'Yeah, it's very different when we use that terminology because, that, the only thing you can, I think there is one thing we can do with the brain, is to stimulate it. And it is not very useful, but, but it's very useful. So I think that's what you are saying about the activity during development? Is that the brain can do it, or can't do it, and it would be good to know which? And then you can go from that.'
Dr. M:'The function of spontaneous neural activation during development is to sculpt the circuits of the brain that control behavior.'
Dr. B:'What are the principles of neural syntax?'

Dr. M:'We know that in the same network different kinds of neurons can be coactivated, and that if you have the same neuron that fires multiple times over a period of time the neuron becomes a sort of oscillator.'
Dr. B:'How does the brain make an oscillator?'

Dr. M:'It's important to remember that neurons in the brain are not active in isolation. They're not firing in isolation from the rest of the circuits of the nervous system. So in the case of the single cell, there is a ton of regulatory inputs that alter the properties of the neurons. In the case of the larger networks, many different substances are released at various times, and the nervous system has to deal with all of that.'

Dr. B:'Where is the place for understanding spontaneous activity? Is it the hippocampus? Is it the prefrontal cortex? What about other areas of the brain? What do we know about these brain states? Where does it stand? Is it just about recording the activity of neurons and determining whether the brain is in an active state? Is it necessary to understand how the brain produces an output? Is it necessary that we understand how the brain is embedded in its environment?'

Dr. B:'The importance of such spontaneous activity can be observed in the observation that there is no real difference in function between the developing brain and the mature brain. The brains response to the same inputs is essentially the same, and its performance remains stable over time, even though many, many orders of magnitude of time are covered by the life of an animal. The only difference is that during development there are no sensory constraints imposed on the brain and no external influence.'

Dr. M:'Yes, that is one of the reasons why we think that it is important to study this, but I'm also interested in what the mechanisms are that are responsible for this and what the functions of these neural circuits are during development.'

Dr. B:'Neuronal circuits are not there to do anything. They are just there to get used. They are there to get used by their host structures. In fact, in the case of circuits, they are the host structures. They have a huge impact on the circuits they're embedded in, so one can argue that the circuit-based definition of the functions of the brain and the functions of the circuits are more important than the "activity-based" definition of the brain.'

Dr. M:'We certainly do need to study this in the mature brain, but I'm trying to understand how neural activity during development affects neural circuits, and we believe that this is an area that we can study relatively unambiguously because the differences between the developing and mature brain are fairly unambiguous. You can see that these circuits are not just stable, but they are not even identical, right?'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, it's really fascinating. Because we can look at a circuit with an oscillator in the middle, and you can see how the oscillator can synchronize with other neurons. And we can look at neurons that don't respond the same way, and we can say, oh, this is the same cell with the same synaptic connectivity, but it's responding differentially, or its responding with different properties.'

Dr. B:'Well, what is the developmental role? How does it work? What are the mechanisms? Can you give an example? What is the circuit in the brain that would respond differentially when you use different patterns of activity to drive it? We can make a circuit, where a simple network of neurons, we can show the circuit how it would work.'
Dr. M:'Well, you know, I mean, you know, it's clear that spontaneous neural activity has an enormous influence on development.'

Dr. B:'Yes. So what I mean, what I mean is the effect, not the mechanism. It's, uh, the effect of activity of the activity that is in the brain on brain development, uh, as well as on behavior and cognitive processes that are important to the brain. I mean, I want to talk about that, uh, but it comes with an enormous risk: the risk that is, uh, the, uh, spontaneous activity is not a phenomenon we understand the mechanism of.'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'And what is it's contribution?'

Dr. M:'I think one of the things that we find from our work with other systems is that the same processes that cause changes in behavior can cause changes in the underlying features of the neurons themselves and their interconnection patterns and that's one of the ways that, you know, we have come to see that it is possible to change neuronal activity from one type to another.'

Dr. M:'Well, you know, it was originally thought that the development of the nervous system was the consequence of the development of the muscles and the muscles that supported the nervous system, but we now know that there are neural activity that is going on in the nervous system during development that plays important roles for the normal development of the nervous network.'

Dr. B:'Well, there are different mechanisms at work in different periods of development, and one of them is the emergence of the first spontaneous activity, in the early developmental stages of the brain. We know that spontaneous activity emerges from the time when the nervous system emerges in the body of the embryo and in the spinal cord, that is, in the first post-natal week, and lasts until the third trimester of pregnancy.'
Dr. M:'Yeah, and there are three periods of time, you know, when the brain really develops.'

Dr. B:'The first time is at the end of the first trimester, right, because, at this point, there are already three basic neural mechanisms in the brain, and at this point they can already communicate with each other via some synapses, and their interactions form the basis of our first experience and our first language.'
Dr. M:'Right, the first language.'
Dr. M:'I don't think it is important to understand the function of neural activity during development, but it's important to know how neural systems change as they mature.'
Dr. B:'The reason is because those circuits are what will be used in the adult. We don't want to damage them now.'
Dr. M:'So if a circuit is going to be used for many hours or many days or many years you really want to be sure that the network is reliable and resilient to perturbations.'

Dr. B:'We know from animal experiments that there are a lot of things that can change the patterns of the system, including synaptic strength, circuit connectivity, neurotransmitter release, synaptic release, and even changes in the local environment. And the brain is complex enough that it can recover from those changes. But we don't know what the limits are and what the perturbations are. And it's very important that we understand what it is and what it is not.'

Dr. M:'And there's a real danger of damaging the network and getting it wrong because there are so many other systems that are also important. And it could be very costly to have the brain be wrong for years or months or even days.'

Dr. B:'If you know, I just can't see it, but I can see the potential danger. I just can't seem to think of the consequences. And I just can't believe it. But the same system with the same inputs can lead to very different results because it has a very different state. The reason is because of what's happening at the right and the left parts of the brain.'

Dr. B:'So if you look at how hippocampal activity develops in the rat, there's an early period in the newborn animal when neurons are spiking irregularly, and they are called "rapid eye movement" or REM sleep. This is a state in which most of the brain's energy consumption is devoted to synaptic activity and not to spiking. In this early period, the firing rates of neurons are very low.'

Dr. M:'So as the animal grows and develops, there's another transition when it transitions into a state where most of its neuronal activity is devoted to spiking and there's a lot of regulation of neurons and synapses. And so, these transitions are important and have been studied experimentally and the transitions can be driven by neuromodulators.'

Dr. B:'Neuronal activity of the hippocampus is also driven by a strong oscillatory pattern called theta. And, in this particular case, it's theta that is the driver. Neurons, of course, can fire under the influence of theta without being driven by it, but that happens in very rare cases.'
Dr. B:'How should we understand the function of spontaneous activity?'

Dr. M:'It's important to understand how neural systems change over time in the context of how those systems are behaving in a particular setting. So if you are trying to understand the function in a brain, it's important to understand the environment in which the brain is behaving. So a very important issue in studying function is trying to understand how the brain changes over the lifetime. So that would be the first question I would ask you: how the brain changes?'
Dr. B:'I would ask you about that in a different way: how do the brains of the developing brain and how those developing systems change over time?'
Dr. M:'We would like to know the effect of modulators in all animals.'
Dr. B:'What is the difference between the effect of NMDA and AMPA receptors?'

Dr. M:'NMDA receptors are voltage-dependent whereas AMPA receptors are not. NMDA receptors have been studied extensively, and are well characterized. We don't have any evidence of AMPA receptor activity yet. This is still a new phenomenon in neuroscience. We know what they are, but we have to know what they are doing and see whether or not they play a role in controlling the animal's behavior.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible that NMDA and AMPAR receptors are mixed in the hippocampus, and this makes it difficult to separate their function?'

Dr. M:'A variety of things, including neuronal identity, synaptic connectivity and network performance. I think it will be interesting to see whether neural activity changes as we move from the juvenile to the adult brain. I also think that understanding how neuronal circuits change as they mature is a particularly exciting area.'
Dr. B:'What is the function for spontaneous activity in the adult brain?'

Dr. M:'Oh yeah, you know the function of adult activity. We know a lot of things about adult activity that we should know about juvenile activity. We know things about the regulation of synaptic transmission in the adult brain. But when you are growing up, it's about growing up, so all you want to know is how you get up on your bike and go down the street. The brain is different and there are also other things to know and it's not so easy.'

Dr. B:'What is the function, in your opinion, of brain rhythms? Are they simply epiphenomena? Are they a necessary component? Are they useful in a scientific sense? What is their function? Do they perform a computational function? What does it mean to 'understand' brain rhythms?'

Dr. M:'Yes, I think brain rhythms are important in many ways. I think the most important is that the brain is able to make rhythms, and this is important for understanding how the brain works. As far as the computational function of rhythms, I think it is important in many ways for understanding how neural systems work, because they have to take into account that you have different time constants for different processes.'

Dr. B:'If we look at a different time scale, in the same sense as the computational aspect, one can ask whether the temporal organization of neurons is related to what the network performs, which is a function, or whether this is simply a relationship of the network to a function, which could be useful, and could be useful to learn. Are the rhythms a necessary component of the function, and are they useful in a practical sense?'

Dr. M:'I think you are raising a really interesting point. I think that the most important is to understand how neural circuits function, which is what we are all interested in. And I also think that brain rhythms are useful for understanding how the human brain works, because you can ask yourself how you are responding to some stimulus, or how you are responding, not just to a simple question, but how you are responding in a complicated context. You can also look at the dynamics of brain rhythms.'

Dr. B:'Can we explain the computational and scientific advantages of brain rhythms? Can we explain why oscillations can perform a specific function? And I'm going to ask you to take a couple of minutes with me in each case, and to talk about it, and maybe give some examples that you can illustrate, and I will try to take a stab at this.'
Dr. B:'What is the function or role of brain rhythms?'
Dr. M:'The brain is not silent. There are always many different rhythms occurring in the brain.'

Dr. M:'One of the most important features of the brain is that it has a large number of rhythmic, or oscillatory, motor patterns. For example, the heartbeat depends on coordinated action between the pacemaker neurons, the two pyloric dilator (PD) neurons and the one single anterior gastric (AG) neuron.'
Dr. B:'Are there different types of oscillations? For example, in mammals, perhaps there are some types of alpha waves, others gamma rhythms, and so on?'

Dr. M:'Well, that's one of the issues that we're trying to figure out. One of the things that we've been thinking about for a long time is how we can distinguish among different types of oscillators in the adult brain.'

Dr. M:'Well, in my mind, it's very clear. It has to do with circuit function. The function of spontaneous neural firing in the developing nervous system is that the neurons have to learn how to function within a network. They have to learn how the system works, and that means that they have to be able to coordinate activity with other members of the network, not just with themselves. That means that their neurons have to be able, as adults, to coordinate with each other.'
Dr. B:'Can you give an example? For instance, can you give some examples of how that's happening?'

Dr. M:'Absolutely! Absolutely! In the development of the heart, for example, there's a very strong coupling between cardiac and gastric mill activity, and you can see when the heart starts to form how the gastric mill rhythm and the cardiac rhythm become coupled to each other, because they have to work together. The gastric mill rhythm is a rhythm that has to keep the gastric mill muscles going as the heart grows, so they become coupled.'

Dr. B:'Are you a parent, or are you a mentor to children who have nervous systems? If so, how do you talk to them about the importance of the relationship between the developing and the mature brain and spontaneous activity? What do you tell them about how the self-organized activity in the developing brain will serve to organize itself later on? How do you talk to kids about this? Are you able to give us examples that you are able to talk about with your children?'
Dr. B:'Can you give an example of how that works in the brain?'
Dr. B:'It's not a hard-wired system but it's flexible enough that it will bend if you touch it.'
Dr. M:'During development, neural activity is generated, and we have seen that this can be regulated to produce a variety in the nervous system.'
Dr. B:'What are some of the consequences of these findings? For example, what does it mean for the treatment of epilepsy?'

Dr. M:'Epilepsy is a fascinating problem, as we know. We can use electrical activity of the cortex as a guide to find the neural circuits underlying different behaviors. So that's a direct application. It would be wonderful to be able to record neural activity and then apply neuromodulators to change the underlying neural structure.'
Dr. B:'Is it a random thing, or is it not?'
Dr. M:'I'm sure it's regulated. And when it's regulated to produce a certain kind of neural activity, then we can understand how the nervous system works.'
Dr. B:'Could you elaborate on that?'
Dr. M:'So the randomness arises from the intrinsic properties of the neurons in the network. And those properties determine the patterns of activity.'

Dr. M:'Well, the initial generation of networks is done by the neurons and their interactions with each other. The initial synaptic transmission is probably important for some developmental purposes and it does change over time as we learn, as a brain learns. But there's a second, probably equally important factor, the electrical coupling between cells and the role that electrical coupling plays in determining how neural systems come to be.'
Dr. B:'The second factor you mentioned is the connectivity and wiring. What are the mechanisms that determine the wiring patterns and connectivity of neurons?'

Dr. M:'We don't know the rules, but we find the rules that are appropriate for particular neurons, and then we build the rules of connectivity. For example, the neuronal connectivity in the retina and retina nerves is done very stereotypically. We have two different cell classes, the pacemaker neurons, and the rest of the retina network, and that is how the retina forms. And these two cell classes don't have any connectivity between them because they are two cells with different electrical properties.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible that these two neuron types are connected via chemical synapses and not electrically?'

Dr. M:'No, the electrical synapses are the dominant mechanism for the formation of retina, and they also are an important mechanism for the formation and function of the retina. And I'm telling you, there is always going to be a balance between the electrical coupling and the chemical coupling. You can't ever have one, and if you start trying to create a network with only one of them you will fail. So the rules of connectivity are always going to be balanced.'

Dr. B:'That said, how does a brain create a wiring system? How does a brain create connectivity? I'm asking the general question, and I'm just looking for an example, just so that I can be able to imagine. Can you just give me an example? How does a cortex create a wiring system for connectivity? What happens? What happens? How does it go? Can you tell us what happens, or what happens? How does a system?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are multiple factors that determine the wiring system. I mean, I think when you're studying in the laboratory you would find one factor. It's going to be very important that when you're studying neurons that you understand that multiple factors influence your circuit and that you are always looking at multiple components. You're looking at multiple factors, because different synaptic conductances that might be important. And then you might look at cell type, and so forth.'

Dr. M:'It's certainly possible, but you're talking about very specific cell types. If you want to talk about general principles, the rules that govern the formation of synaptic connections are likely to be general rules, and we're trying to understand the rules that govern network formation, so we have an ongoing project to figure out, you know, the rules that would govern, like, for example, the wiring of an animal.'

Dr. B:'But there is no question, in general, what the rules of wiring and connectivity are? You know, when you look at neurons, it's pretty clear. And those are the rules. And those are not necessarily good enough to explain how a network forms.'

Dr. M:'Well, yeah, there's no question that you're talking about. There's a lot of rules that govern network development. And we know that most network circuits are highly plastic, so it's also important to think about those rules of connectivity in terms of developmental rules. So there are rules that govern how you build a network, rules that govern how it behaves, and rules that govern synaptic plasticity. So it's interesting to think about how you could build a network.'

Dr. B:'What if we could take a network like the hippocampus and, for example, say that we know how to make a very large number of connections between hippocampal neurons in a way that could look like a single hippocampal system and then how to make many, many connections between those neurons, but the connection rules are different. Would that mean that we could make a network, or an animal, which looked like a hippocampus but had much stronger connections, stronger wiring?'

Dr. B:'If you had to give a short answer to the question, 'What is the meaning of connectivity?' would you say that the brain is not a giant connected graph but a large number of interconnected loops with mostly local connectivity.'

Dr. M:'That is correct. That is an example of connectivity and not of wiring. Because wiring is the building of the connections between the parts of a circuit, not the circuit itself. So it is connectivity which will be the most important factor, probably, to consider when we study nervous systems, in general.'

Dr. M:'Well, during development, when you're a developing neuron, you have a relatively high level of activity, because your neurons are developing in response to many, many different inputs, and so you have a relatively large, high level of synaptic inputs that are acting on you.'
Dr. B:'But then what? There should be a mechanism to eliminate that.'

Dr. M:'And there are mechanisms to eliminate it, and one of them is by synaptic depression, and the other one is by synaptic depression. The mechanisms for synaptic depression work so that during development, your network is always at low frequency, and that way you can develop your networks at high rates, because if your network is oscillating at high frequencies, then you don't have time for synaptic depression to come and be effective.'
Dr. B:'Do these mechanisms disappear, or are they permanent?'

Dr. M:'Yes, these mechanisms can be permanent. Of course, if there is enough synaptic depression during development, then there are mechanisms that can maintain a low frequency indefinitely, but then it can also be quite possible that the mechanisms that would produce that low-frequency activity might be disabled, because then they would be unnecessary, and so it's a dynamic balance between the need to have this robustness and this flexibility.'

Dr. B:'What would it take for an adult network to do what you're talking about? What are the conditions that would need to be met? What are the requirements that would need to happen? What would it take?'

Dr. M:'Well, as I said, there are two mechanisms, two different mechanisms that you could use to change your network's frequency. One of them is a synaptic-driven mechanism, and the other mechanism is a homeostatic mechanism. A synaptic-driven mechanism would involve synaptic conductance, synaptic transmission properties, and synaptic strength, and then you would have to have a network of neurons to activate the synaptic mechanisms and then to turn the synaptic conductance back on.'

Dr. B:'So would this require a specific brain state? What is the state that would need to occur? Is it an internal or an external process? How does it take place? Is there a timeline that it would require? What would it require to make it happen? What is the mechanism for synaptic depression? Is there a time limit that this would have? Is there a threshold, and if so, is there a time when that threshold needs to be exceeded?'
Dr. B:'What about in the adult, where the networks are mostly stable, for instance? Does it come back? Does it go away?'

Dr. B:'The role of spontaneous activity is also very important for the timing of the action potential generation. What about that? We know that during development there is a relatively large population of spontaneously active neurons, which are driven by many, many different kinds of inputs, but they still need to have a mechanism to eliminate these inputs in order to give rise to action potentials. Then why would they be able to generate action potentials? What is the mechanism that allows them to do that?'

Dr. M:'Right. That's right. They must have mechanisms to reduce that activity and develop into adult networks, in a way that allows for the functional interactions that are necessary. And they are always developing and they're always changing, because the network, the brain, is constantly changing.'

Dr. B:'Now, there are many things that are different in the hippocampus versus neocortex. The hippocampal region is a different structure from the neocortex. The reason why you can get a big brain in a small package is due to the special structure of the hippocampus.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, to get rid of that. And there is. There are mechanisms. But as you grow older, and as you reach adulthood, and you start to function, you begin to take over some of the roles that the neurons have always done, and you start using your neurons for your own use, as neurons and as individuals.'
Dr. B:'So it's like a brain becomes self-determined. In other words, it's autonomous. It's autonomous?'

Dr. M:'I think that's a wonderful idea. I like that. That's a great idea,'self-determined'. So it starts to use its own nervous system, and it starts to do things that are not necessarily necessary, but it's doing things that it's supposed to do, and so it develops a kind of homeostatic mechanism, which makes it a very complex, very robust system.'
Dr. B:'Do you think that there should be another mechanism to provide a balance between these functions?'

Dr. B:'Well, this is very interesting. I know this from my own personal experience as a young person, when I was a student at the University of Pcs, Hungary. I was very enthusiastic about everything, and so I was very active in a variety of extracurricular activities, which is what you have to do when you're a teenager, and my first thought was how much I wanted to be a professor and a scientist.'

Dr. M:'And, you know, you're like 18 or 19, and you're just excited about everything and thinking about the future and then suddenly you go to graduate school, and so you're going to graduate school with your fellow students, your colleagues, and then you're going to start graduate school. And you know, it's like everything changes.'
Dr. B:'Is that the function of the spontaneous activity during development?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, the function of the spiking during development is to allow the neurons to develop.'
Dr. B:'But when you are a young adult, what is the function of activity during development?' Do you have any idea?'

Dr. M:'I think it plays a role in the growth and development of all of the neurons and all of the circuits. But not as a single unit. The function of neural activity during development is to prepare the circuits for the life of the animal. So it's not a passive process by which the circuits are simply growing. It is a process in which the networks are responding to the inputs that are coming into the network. And the networks are responding very actively to changing inputs.'
Dr. B:'What about sleep and its role in the development of the brain?'
Dr. M:'Well, there is no data about sleep because it's not something that is recorded in any biological animal. So we don't really know the role of sleep in development.'
Dr. B:'How is sleep different from wake?'

Dr. M:'Wake is something that occurs over hours and hours. So if we're looking for the role of sleep, it's certainly not the same as the role of wake. In fact, the data that we have on sleep is really the first data that I have looked at that reveals the role of an important regulator of the network and how important a regulator of the network. So we know about sleep because it has been studied for years in all animals. So in most animals, sleep has been studied.'

Dr. B:'I'm interested in what's going on in the brain during sleep, when you are actually asleep, not when you're waking. So, we know that the patterns of the brain are different during sleep and wake. Now we have to see what happens when you're actually in sleep. Now it's not clear what kind of patterns we're going to be seeing.'

Dr. M:'I mean, we don't know yet. But we're going to have to look at that. And, so there are some animal models, of course, that have been studied and have been shown to respond well to a number of different manipulations.'

Dr. B:'But in some animals, like in particular in humans, it is not well studied and we need to look at sleep, but we need to understand how sleep is fundamentally different from wake. And that, at least, would be a major contribution to understanding how we can use sleep for some purpose in a manner that has nothing to do with the way that sleep is defined in humans.'
Dr. B:'Are these responses driven by genetic program or is it the result of a genetic program?'

Dr. M:'No, this is very much a product of the interactions of neurons and the interactions of neurons with their environment. And as the network is developing, all of the neurons are responding very actively. And then, in an evolutionary sense, the evolutionary pressures on these circuits as they develop are, then, driving their responses to changes in their environments.'
Dr. B:'How important is it for the brain to learn how to sense and understand its environment? How important is it to learn how to respond to those changes in the environment?'

Dr. M:'Very important. Because it means that the network has a tool by which it can respond to the changing environmental conditions. So, in some sense it is really important for all animals to learn how to behave, to understand their environments, and to respond appropriately. And also I think that neural circuits, all of the cells that are present in these circuits are also learning to respond appropriately, so that when changes in the environment occur, or when changes occur in a neuron or a neuron responds appropriately.'

Dr. B:'When an animal learns to change its behavior as a response to changing environments, this is a very different experience than when one is trained to respond in a situation where the animal is just exposed to the same conditions but without any feedback. It is an experience. The learning process, therefore, has different features than the response of the circuits. And those differences are what makes this process an experience. So it is important to make this distinction.'

Dr. M:'Because it is also a very, very different, it is a very different sort of learning when you are learning how to make yourself behave in the world, rather than how to make yourself do what someone else wants you to do. Right?'

Dr. B:'Yes. I agree with this. In fact, I would like to take this a step further. So if the brain doesn't learn about the consequences of its actions, there is no experience, there is no learning and there is no cognition. Because it is simply a function of the environment and the organism's response to that environment. I mean, we've discussed this in different ways, but in the end it comes down to the same point. And the, the answer is quite simple.'

Dr. M:'It is very important. You're right. I mean, I think learning how to live is an evolutionary process. Because as you get older, your responses to environmental changes are not fixed. It is easy to think that as you get older you don't respond the same way, but it is not the case.'
Dr. B:'Is it important to learn how to think about the environment, not how to behave? I mean, if we can learn how to live, we may not need to learn how to look at the world.'

Dr. B:'So it's a big advantage to be able to learn new ways of thinking, new ways of responding to situations that we encounter. That's what allows our species to prosper. And as humans prosper, as the human species prospeers, the needs for these circuits change. And the circuit is, then, responding to these changing needs.'

Dr. B:'And it's not only in the cerebral cortex but in the spinal cord as well. And even in the brainstem. So that's another important issue to address. What are the functions that can be produced by spontaneous activity during development? And what are the functions that cannot be produced by spontaneous, non-invasive activity, and what should be the function of the activity?'

Dr. M:'Right, right. Well, there are some networks that we think can not be produced by a spontaneous process. There are networks that are not produced by a spontaneous physiological process. But you're absolutely right. So it has to be a balance, that you're going to be able to produce a spontaneous rhythm during development because that's what you want to get.'
Dr. B:'Is it true that you need a single input to generate spontaneous activity in the brain? And what would that be?'

Dr. M:'Oh, I think that's true. But when the network is growing, you will have the synaptic and intrinsic currents that are required. I mean, this is why we think of the pyloric network as being one compartment. It's a single compartment, you know. And then you're going to get the activity, but the synaptic and intrinsic activity. But it is true, you know, you're going to need a single input.'

Dr. M:'That's right. So that's one of the fundamental principles of the system, the same principle that we think applies to all of the other biological systems. So the biological systems always have multiple components, neurons and neurons and neurons that can be electrically coupled and they can all be part of the same circuit, and then the inputs to the circuit can be multiple and varied and different.'

Dr. B:'So that the circuits can be produced by multiple inputs from many parts of the network without the input always being the same. So can you explain to us why? What's that principle? Is it something you're known to be interested in? Is it something that you want to pursue in research?'

Dr. M:'So we studied this in the crab. We studied this very well in the lobster and in the shrimp. So we used to call it the lobster trap network. That's when we used to go to the coast. There's a beach at the end of the pier where the lobster is there. The lobster are there. We'd go there and we would wait for the lobsters and the lobster would come and they'd have food in their stomachs.'

Dr. B:'And they'd have a high probability of walking down and getting food. We can call it, uh, a feed-forward circuit. There are a bunch of inputs into the circuit that are varied and different. The inputs are multiple and vary from circuit to circuit, and they are connected to many different neurons. Now we have a second circuit which is called the lobster trap circuit. We have some very strong, uh, recurrent connections in the circuit but the input is very similar.'

Dr. B:'So the main reason why I think so many of the problems in the brain have to be explained by multiple mechanisms is the single cell doctrine. So the neuron is a single cell with multiple connections, that the same neuron has a single output. So when I talk about the same thing in a different way in terms of the circuit, then it is different, but this is the fundamental principle that has to be there.'

Dr. M:'So it's interesting. I mean, what you say is something that I thought about in the context of the network, which is that it's not just that the neuron is a cell that fires in a single way. And that's something that a lot of people forget. Because we talk about neural circuits and neural networks, but the neuron is only a cell that fires one way. It doesn't matter what the other cells are doing. It's only that one cell.'
Dr. M:'Yes, well, it has to be, so that is a really interesting observation, and you said that, and I was thinking about this, because we have thought about this for a long time. But we did a study.'

Dr. B:'Yeah, that's very interesting. What is the interesting part of this? So we just look at the same neuron, because this was the neuron that you mentioned, the single neuron in question, we just ask what input can generate spontaneous activity? What input can produce a spontaneous activity? So this was an experiment where we looked at this one neuron, the single neuron, and it has two synapses, two inputs to it, and it can generate a spontaneous firing in the network.'
Dr. M:'And you can look at that in many different ways.'

Dr. B:'So, in addition to the input that brings about activity from the body and environment, such as the electrical activity of the brain, what kind of signals are important to be considered in developing the brain? Do we need to consider what comes to the brain through the sensory system and what comes to the network through the motor system? Does the answer include the emotional system? Does it include the limbic system? Does it includes the brainstem? What does it include?'

Dr. M:'It includes all of the inputs that you would imagine that the animal is going to respond to over its lifetime. So it includes inputs from the senses and the motor systems. It includes input from the sensory system. We know that the brain must respond to chemical, electrical, and other sensory inputs. So it includes all of the chemical, electrical, other sensory inputs.'

Dr. B:'So what do you think about the role of oscillations in the brain? And in particular, what do you think the role of theta oscillations? Is it important to your study? Is it absolutely critical? What do you think the function of theta oscillation is? If you had to describe a single network, would it be theta? What do you believe to be the role of oscillation? What do you predict its role to be?'

Dr. M:'So, well, I'm more interested in the function of all of the networks and all of the neurons, and I think the role of oscillatory activity, the importance of oscillatory activity. So I would say that, you know, theta is important because it is a key component in the regulation of the networks.'
Dr. M:'Well, I think it's pretty clear that neural activity plays a role in the maturation of circuits during development.'
Dr. B:'I think it's more controversial whether that role is good or bad, and I will address those points today.'
Dr. M:'I don't think it's bad. I think that if you don't pay attention to neural activity during development, that the nervous system becomes sort of a victim of its own properties.'

Dr. B:'So what is the alternative to not paying attention? Do we know it? How would we do this if it's not important? What happens if the system can do nothing else besides its default patterns? What do we get? Would we get a nervous system with a much different wiring, a nervous system that's much better equipped to do something else? What happens if it's not possible to move the system forward to do something else, it's just stuck to its default pattern?'

Dr. M:'Oh, I think that it could take us back and make things worse. You can go forward, but it can take you back, because if you don't check the neural activity then you end up with a nervous system that, as a consequence of having been left alone to develop in a way that might not have been optimum, then you're going to end up with a system that's just going to behave like its default.'
Dr. B:'So that it will turn into something that you can't control.'
Dr. B:'How would you define this role? What would be the physiological consequences of a change in activity from zero to the network level?'
Dr. M:'I don't think we know yet.'

Dr. B:'What are the main physiological functions of activity? Are there special categories of activity that are the most critical? What are the main physiological consequences of a different activity level? What are the physiological mechanisms of such activity?'
Dr. M:'Yes, absolutely.'

Dr. B:'There are two things that are critical, as I see it. One is that we develop the right number of neurons, in this case in a developing brain. The other is that the activity that is brought about should be of the right type and in the right time window. How we would go about doing this, I don't know, but we can say that there are specific consequences and physiological consequences.'

Dr. M:'So it's too early to say. I think there are many ways in which neural activity is regulated, and it's hard to know which way is best, but I would say that the way it is regulated is really important.'

Dr. M:'It would be interesting to know, but if we assume it has a role in development and we try to alter it, we will see. We're really interested in the role of synaptic and intrinsic conductances, and how neural activity changes as a consequence of different kinds of synaptic and intrinsic excitability changes.'
Dr. B:'When would this occur? Where are these synapses? What is the intrinsic excitability? What would be a consequence of a change in synaptic connectivity?'

Dr. M:'There is evidence that spontaneous neural activity is present during development of the nervous system. The neural circuits are not fixed because neural cells are themselves modulators. So there is this sort of interplay between the activity of neural cells and their target neurons. So this was initially demonstrated in  C. borealis  crabs. They have a relatively large number of neurons. So the brain of the crab has a large number of neurons, including sensory and motor neurons.'
Dr. B:'What is the function, of course, of the spontaneous neural activity in the developing brain? What is the function of the spontaneous neural patterns during development?'

Dr. M:'Well, you know that neural networks themselves develop, so when you're developing a network, you want to make sure that you're developing a robust network. And the first thing that you want to do is to make sure that all of your neurons are firing correctly, so you want to make all of your neurons fire in concert, or you want to make them fire with appropriate temporal and spatial patterns.'
Dr. B:'There is also evidence that spontaneous activity is not necessary for the development of the neural circuits but is it critical?'

Dr. M:'Well the initial work that we did was to demonstrate that, for example, the pyloric network had no activity, and it didn't matter whether it was silent or whether it was tonic. So we wanted to establish that this was not a case where you can make a model of something that doesn't exist. We wanted to demonstrate that you can make a well-defined brain by changing the properties of the neuronal cells.'
Dr. B:'Can you tell us why it is so critical? I mean, if you had to make up a sentence for it, what would it be?'

Dr. M:'I'm just trying to think of a way to put it, because it really boils down to that interplay between the cell type properties of the neurons and the properties of their connections. So, we had to find a way to put this into a little more general sense, that, in the end, it boils down to this interplay between the properties of the cells and the properties of the connections between the cells.'

Dr. B:'Is there a relationship between neuronal activity and behavior in these models? For example, the crab has sensory receptors in its shell and muscles to move, but in this model system, the motor neuron activity is not being activated. Is that correct? If so, is it a matter of a missing link? Is it a missing link, or is it a missing link? If so, then what is missing? Is it a matter of the timing or what? What is missing?'

Dr. M:'I think the biggest missing link is the biological link between these oscillations. This is the missing link between this neural architecture, this neural circuit architecture that has all of these different neurons and their circuits, and how they relate to behavior, to behavior at the cellular level. We want to understand how it is that these neurons work together. And it's that connectivity that is essential to understanding how these circuits work together.'

Dr. B:'Are there things that the circuit can do without oscillations? For example, in the brain, when you go to sleep, when the activity of these neurons decrease, there's no behavior to it at all. And there's no reason for them to move. It doesn't mean that we don't have to move and that there's no reason to move, but there is a huge difference in the energy of these cells when you move in the network and when you don't.'

Dr. M:'What happens is, for example, if you have a muscle with a ton of receptors, which is activated when you move and which fires as you move. Then you're generating movement that may not be very efficient. The neurons are active, they're firing, but they're firing in a very constrained fashion.'

Dr. B:'The energy that these neurons use is much larger when they are firing in a very restricted manner. In fact, the more they fire, the more they use up a lot of energy. Now it seems that there's an energy source, a lot of energy, but we have a different problem that we want to understand: how is it that these neurons work with each other, how they connect with each other and how the circuit is organized?'

Dr. B:'So the neuron responds to its inputs, but it does not move in a controlled manner. And I guess what you're asking is, is there some specific input that can generate a movement that is not constrained to the activity of the network? I'm sorry. I'm asking what happens, when you don't move, that's not the right question.'

Dr. M:'Well, it is probably important to start with an understanding of how neural circuits develop. When you do experiments with developing animals, you can ask questions that have to do with the processes of neural circuit development and learning, the kind of questions you can ask in developing animals. I mean, obviously, we have a lot of work on the effects of neuromodulators on neurons, on circuits, so that would be a very good example.'
Dr. B:'I'm going to try to list out three questions that you could ask that would probably tell us something useful about the function of spontaneous neuronal activity during development.'
Dr. M:'Okay.'

Dr. B:'The first question would be: what is the role of inhibition? What is the role of inhibitory neurons? What are the roles of interneurons? What is the roles of inhibition in neural circuit development? What is the importance of inhibition? If you ask these questions and you would get good answers, then it would mean that you have a good knowledge of how inhibition works as a mechanism of neural circuit development. The second question would be, what is the role for spontaneous neural activity?'

Dr. B:'What is the role of electrical activity in neuronal development? Is it really necessary to use electricity in this process? Can we simply ask animals to behave differently, or are their brains not going to be fine as a result of doing that? Is it essential to use artificial patterns that are similar to what the brain generates, or are the artificial patterns necessary?'

Dr. M:'I don't think it is necessarily. I think that this was one of the first indications that it might not be necessary, because if you think back to what you hear in terms of how the nervous system works, it is really a network, right? It has different cells, it has synapses, but it has some electrical activity.'

Dr. B:'Are there any particular cells that can be studied, or a system that can be studied to understand the role of network activity? Is it a particular layer or region of the brain or is it not as simple as that? Is it actually the role of specific cells? For example, what are the specific roles of hippocampal pyramidal cells? What is the role of hippocampal interneurons? Is it specific to a particular layer, or does it extend to different layers of the brain?'

Dr. M:'Yeah. There is a lot of work from different systems, I mean, it really depends on the system you're studying, because every nervous system is different. The stomatogastric system of the lobster (?) has a lot of interneuron cells that were very well studied, and they had all kinds of different properties.'

Dr. M:'I think what is essential, you know, when you start with the nervous system, is to understand what the role of different currents, different types of conductance, is in normal neural circuit activity, in normal neural circuit functioning.'
Dr. B:'How important are synaptic communication and learning?'

Dr. M:'How important are neural synapses? Absolutely. When you are building any kind of circuit, and you know, this is obvious, I mean you build a circuit to get food from the stomach, you know, to eat, and then you build a circuit in the brain to control that stomach, you know?'

Dr. B:'So when you are building a circuit in the mind, what are the types of inputs, or synapses and what are the types or the function of outputs? What are the types of the circuit that is built in the brain to accomplish that? What is the function of the output? What is the goal of that circuit? How does that circuit interact with other circuits to accomplish something useful for the brain?'

Dr. M:'I think that it's quite hard to talk about the function of neural activity during development, but it has to do with the fact that neurons, as you said, are kind of the core constituents of circuit structures. So there has to be some way in which neurons are regulated during development, in a way that maintains the behavior of the circuits throughout development and throughout evolution.'
Dr. B:'How would we know what is a good time to manipulate those circuits?'
Dr. M:'Yeah, that's a really hard question, I mean, we don't know.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible to identify the mechanisms by which these circuits would regulate the activity of their constituent neurons?'

Dr. M:'It is essential to development, because in fact all nervous systems depend on neural activity, for their function to develop. In fact, there are many functions for neural activity during development. One function is to stimulate circuits of neural activity to ensure circuit development and maintain function, because that is how these circuits are designed to work, so we want to keep them active during development, because that is important to maintain network function and network development.'

Dr. M:'The spontaneous activity of many neurons during development of the nervous system plays a crucial role in the organization of neural circuits, both structurally and functionally. In developing circuits, neurons must interact with other neurons to produce appropriate actions. In the STNS of the lobster, the pyloric circuits are established in the first three weeks of development, and then maintained for the remainder of the animal's life, with minimal perturbations.'

Dr. B:'If you go to the central ganglion, the STNS, and compare it with the cerebral ganglion, which is an anterior ganglion of the cerebral nerve, and the central ganglium, which is an olfactory ganglion, then you see a remarkable similarity of wiring and how connectivity is established. So, when we look at that circuit, we have to ask, what is the role of spontaneous activity? What is the function of the circuits?'

Dr. M:'Of course, the first question to ask is, 'Why does this network have to have so many connections?' Why not use fewer connections? We know that, in all biological systems, electrical coupling creates network flexibility, and we know that you want to use a relatively small number of synaptic connections to do different kinds of things, to provide a rich diversity of potential outcomes, and we all know that many biological neurons and biological circuits can have a few different output patterns.'

Dr. B:'So, I have no doubt, that it is better for the brain to have many connectivity options than to have only one option. However, in biological systems, the number of connections is limited by various factors, including cost. So, this is a good question to ask. What is the function? What is the brain doing here? In the STNS, there are only 25 connections. In the cerebral ganglium, there are 50 connections. What is the advantage of this organization?'

Dr. M:'I've known many, many, many brain researchers who have told me that a crucial thing is to make the connectivity choices, that they're made consciously, that you should only make connections in a way that is beneficial for the brain. And so, in biological systems like the brain, you want to make connections that can be turned on and off. So, the function of the brain is to maintain its functional integrity.'

Dr. B:'What is the mechanism of the maintenance of functional integrity? What is the fundamental organization of connectivity in the cerebral ganglial circuit? This is the one thing that I want to know.'

Dr. M:'So, I don't know exactly what the answers will be. I don't have all the answers to this question, but I'll do some of them. And I think the first thing we should know is that, because we're interested in learning about the brain, we should know the mechanisms that allow brain circuits to function. So, if you look at the cerebral ganglionic circuit, as a model system, it is a small network. It has only about 25 neurons.'

Dr. M:'So, if we go back to my colleagues and I, for example, we studied the pyloric networks in the STNS. And when we studied the pyrite networks, which are part of the STNS, we used to do experimental work, we would look at these networks as models, and we would study their function, and we would try to understand how these circuits work, and try to understand how nervous systems work, and we did lots of studies on these networks.'

Dr. B:'Then, when it comes to the cerebral ganglioside and I would ask the question differently. What is the brain's role? What is the circuits doing? We know that in the cerebral gangliolite, there are 30 connections, in the cerebral ganglia, there are 70 connections, and there are even more connections in the cerebral gangliome. What is the difference? And the answer to this is simple.'

Dr. B:'So, in order to do what is needed for the nervous system, I'm going to ask what is the function of such a rich connectivity as seen in the STNS, which has so many wiring connections. So I'm going to go through the wiring and see what the network is actually doing.'

Dr. M:'The activity during development has long been studied and is seen as a necessary precursor to network activity during development. In my own experiments in the crab  Cancer borealis  ( B ) during development, we saw very strong evidence that, as animals get larger, they lose some of the very strong, stereotyped rhythms they exhibited during development ( C ).'

Dr. B:'Are there any examples of how such changes in activity contribute to the emergence of adult neural activity? For instance, in the cortex of developing ferrets, activity during development is dominated by very strong stereotyped rhythms at about 5-12 Hz, followed by the emergence of activity at theta and spindle frequency bands at later developmental stages. Are these the same rhythms that dominate activity in the brain of adult animals? If so, what causes these rhythms to shift and emerge? Is it development?'

Dr. M:'Yes. I think there are many examples. Let me take an example from our experiments with the crab,  C. borealis, where we were studying the role of neuromodulators in maintaining stable network performance during development. As animals grow, they start to exhibit rhythmic activity at the same frequency, but they lose that robust rhythm when they become larger.'

Dr. B:'Would these be the same rhythms that we will find in the brain in adults? What if, for example, we find a rhythm that is different in the brains of adult animals? Would that be useful in terms of understanding the function and importance of such rhythm? Does the brain contain many rhythms that are not observed in other species? Or are there a few key oscillations that dominate the evolution of neural activity? If so, how does the brain manage and maintain the rhythm?'

Dr. M:'I think we're going to find a huge diversity. There's many different rhythms that I think will appear. There's likely to be a tremendous amount of variation, I think, that we're going to discover, and that we're going try to understand, as we start to collect all these data.'

Dr. M:'Developmental changes, or changes during development are accompanied by changes in activity because the activity itself changes. There are many studies which demonstrate that the activity during development is highly stereotyped ( D ). A particularly well-studied example is the activity of the heart, which is very well-regulated in adult animals. In heart muscles of developing animals, the heart exhibits rhythmic movements, at a characteristic frequency.'

Dr. B:'Is there anything special about the activity of the brain during development? In other words, is there a 'default state' that neurons in the brain tend to be in? Is there an activity pattern that we can call the default state? If there is, is it unique to a particular brain state? If not, what is it? Is there a general default state of activity? If not, where does the default state come from?'

Dr. M:'We would tend to think that the default state is one that is consistent with the general patterns of behaviour. Thus, it is likely that most of the neurons in the brain during development are active in a similar pattern of activity. Of course, the pattern may change as animals grow. If it changes significantly, that could be problematic for the appropriate behavioural patterns to emerge.'

Dr. M:'There are examples of how changing activity in the nervous system contributes to changes in the neural circuitry that we don't understand completely. One example comes from the fact that, even when animals get as big as we are, their neuronal circuits never reach adult-like performance. And I'm wondering now, as you point out, because I used to think that when animals get bigger they would lose all the features of their circuits, and that this was essential for the stability of behavior.'

Dr. B:'It's actually a very difficult question to answer because, as you point, there is no way to tell what is going to happen when the circuitry is developing, and what will happen when the circuitry becomes adult. What we can see and can predict from the point of view of the activity during development is that this kind of activity is very critical, but it does not tell us what will happen.'
Dr. M:'Right, right.'

Dr. B:'How do we have to change the activity during development so that it reaches adult-like patterns? What do we have to do? And if we fail to do this, it means that in the future, this adult-like activity will not be there, which is why, when we grow up, we have so many problems and issues to face.'
Dr. M:'Spontaneous neural activity is very important, but has a lot of interesting functions as it comes into being.'

Dr. B:'I have several questions for you. One of them is how does the brain produce spontaneous activity? The second one is how does the developing brain use spontaneous activity to form and refine the circuits that are necessary to perform simple reflexes, as well as more complex functions? The third one is how does this activity continue to serve functions that arise later in life? The last one is what is the relationship between neuronal activity and cognition?'

Dr. M:'These three aspects are all interrelated. We're going to get into that later on. All of them have to do with how the circuit is set up, how it is regulated, and then how it uses that activity to do its many, many different functions in the adult. So all three of them are related.'
Dr. B:'What are some of the functions of the spontaneous activity in the developing brain? And what are some of the mechanisms of spontaneous activity generation?'

Dr. M:'Well, there are two models for how this network comes into being. So one is called the genetic model, that's been thought about, that you've talked about, that the neurons are born, the networks are born. But we've developed the model that takes into account synaptic input during development.'

Dr. B:'And we know that there are many, many synapses on developing cortical neurons, what are the main functions of synaptic activity in the developing human brain? And what mechanism would be responsible for the generation of the synaptic responses in the developing brain, which would be similar to those observed in the adult brain? The third question, of course, would be how to go from the early-born networks to networks that are similar to those in the adult.'

Dr. M:'There's a very general answer to this, and it's been shown that these rhythms can play an important role in development. One, during development we have to take advantage of the strengths of our neural networks. So if they're not active and we have to build things we need to use the strength of the synaptic connections, if they're not working well we might find it difficult to build things.'
Dr. B:'What are the advantages of this process?'

Dr. M:'Well, it's a good question. One of the advantages of these processes is that during development it allows us to take advantage of strengths that exist within the networks that we build. One of the reasons why this is important during development is that there's a lot of developmental variability in many of the underlying parameters of neural activity, and there can be differences in the strengths of the synapses and changes in the electrical properties of the neurons.'

Dr. B:'Are the changes that occur from this variability important for how neural circuits work? If so, how do we deal with them? How would you go about trying to understand the nature of these changes from a neurophysiological perspective?'

Dr. M:'So one is that, when you're developing a new brain, you have to use the strengths of the nervous system and you have to make use of the strengths of neural connectivity, and so it provides advantages.'
Dr. B:'How can we control the activity of these rhythms?'
Dr. B:'And what happens if we don't have the ability to control these rhythms?'
Dr. M:'If we don't have them we'll have to figure out other ways of regulating ourselves.'
Dr. B:'What is it that these rhythms do? What is the function that they do?'
Dr. M:'They provide flexibility to circuits.'
Dr. B:'So they are like a scaffold on which neurons can build and, and flexibly connect to each other.'
Dr. M:'Yes, that's exactly right.'
