Dr. B:'That would explain how, that you can have very large synaptic space, but it's a rigid structure where the connectivity can be reconfigured very effectively.'

Dr. B:'There's another way of going about this, which is to train the networks to do something, and then use them later in life to drive behavior. There are many different ways to train a network to do something, but I will only use two: either reinforcement or punishment. These are simple ways, and I will also argue that training with either of these two methods is fundamentally similar.'

Dr. M:'You may ask me this question when we start the formal study of how neurons develop. But what is important to ask you is about the role of neural activity in development and maintenance of complex behaviour. And that is not necessarily the same, but related, to asking you about how neurons develop. And you may answer this, but I think you can answer this question about development, and maintenance, and modulation of neural activity that has to do with the role of neural systems in developing neural circuits.'

Dr. B:'What is the best way to start with the neural syntax and to look at the role of neural networks in the development of brain rhythms that are in a state of change or transition? Where is the best source of neural syntax?'

Dr. M:'Well, it seems to me that there are really four different questions here. There is an important question about neural activity during development and how neurons can maintain their function as a circuit, and you mentioned the question about how neural activity contributes to developing neuronal networks. So it seems to me you are asking about four separate questions. So the best way to address all of them is to start with what is most difficult to understand.'
Dr. B:'Okay, let's start with the first question.'
Dr. M:'The best way to start is with the simplest possible example and then you can ask yourself questions like: How would a single neuron contribute to the development of an entire brain network?'

Dr. B:'Good idea. I'm going to start with a single neuron from the brainstem, which is a very small piece of brain that we can understand the most. It's a very simple network of a few principal cells and a very few inhibitory interneurons that are all connected via two types of synapses, gap junctions and chemical synapses. And then the first question is: What would be the consequence of the activity of this network in developing a neural circuit?'

Dr. M:'I'd like to ask you the same question, and we're going to see exactly how the same sort of neural activity can be used to drive different cognitive and behavioural patterns. But the most important point is this. There are many, many kinds of neural networks, and there are many, many networks that can be found within any single organism.'

Dr. B:'So I'm not really sure what kind of question you are going to ask me? If I know the specific, the brain's response to the input of a specific sensory input, I might be able to tell you which brain state it would lead to. The brain doesn't respond to inputs in a vacuum. There is a context. And it depends on the organism how to act. The context is what is important. We're looking at how to do it.'
Dr. M:'Right. So I'm going to ask you a question, and you tell me.'

Dr. B:'That's exactly what I asked. What kind of network are you looking for? How many types of circuits do you want to see? Do you want to see the brain use a special set of connections? If so, what are they? Or are you more interested in looking at how neurons and systems can be arranged to give rise to a particular behavior or output, and this is what they do? Then what is it that you're looking for?'
Dr. M:'They're all part of the same network.'

Dr. B:'So that's what we are talking about is the wiring of neural networks, right? The wiring of these networks that are found within a single organism to carry out different functions or processing stages? What are the particular functions of the network that has the particular kind of wiring you're talking about?'

Dr. M:'I don't know, we were thinking that if you were born at any random point in time you would have a similar brain. So we thought that the purpose of this was to build a new neuron that could be a good enough brain for you to work with until you could control your body, because if you had no body control you would just have to rely on the brain.'

Dr. B:'I don't want to be too radical, but I have to ask. I have to ask a question from every single one of you that you've ever met: What is the function of the brain? I'm just wondering what we do when we walk around, or talk about the same stuff, or I don't know, but the same things that we are talking about.'

Dr. M:'Well, I was thinking of the last example you gave me, the brain has to build a neuron. If you have no body control you have to build a neuron and somehow maintain your brain. You have to get oxygen and you have to feed yourself and all these other things.'

Dr. M:'Development of the nervous system of an organism is always accompanied by activity. This activity is intrinsic and part of the brain circuit, but the activity of the nervous system during development is different from that of adults. When an individual develops, the frequency of the brain circuits is relatively high during the initial stage of development, and then it falls as the animal reaches maturity. We have to understand how this transition from high frequency to low frequency is accomplished during development.'

Dr. M:'Well, you could, you could ask that question at any age, and the answer would be, I think, very different, and the answer to that question would be really important to understand why, to understand, you know, why neural activity is important during development and why neural activity isn't important when you're an adult.'
Dr. B:'So you can answer it, can you? I mean, the answer is, uh, is there no answer that is right, is there no good answer to that question?'
Dr. B:'How do I know what's important? How do I know what you're interested in, what you're trying to figure out?'

Dr. B:'What is the function, the physiological function of neuronal activity? You know, what is the function? And, and if you understand that, and then if you understand why, then you can go to the next level and then, then maybe you can understand how to improve. What is the function? We have to start from the very beginning to try to make progress in understanding how this brain, this nervous system operates. What are its physiological function? What are its effects?'

Dr. M:'The effects are obvious, the effects, of course, that all you've learned are obvious. And, I mean, that, that's, that's what everybody, people talk about. They talk about like, like, how the nervous system changes with age, and how the effects of the nervous system change, and, and the effects of the effects of the brain change, the effects of drugs on the nervous system change as you, as people age.'
Dr. B:'It's important because it's an important mechanism. How to understand that is really important. So what is that mechanism?'

Dr. M:'And, and I think the mechanism is really important, is that I think, one of the things that I think is really important is that, when you think about, you know, a developmental system, as the nervous system develops, you know, the nervous system develops as a set of circuits and as a set of neurons that can perform a specific kind of behaviour.'
Dr. B:'So what is the behavior that you're looking at?'

Dr. M:'Right. So this is part of this, part of this, you know, as the nervous systems develops is that the nervous system develops into a set of circuits that can behave as a set of functional units in, in a set of circuits. So you have to ask yourself: Why?'
Dr. B:'Is that just the set of circuits are there, and they do something? Are there rules? What are the rules? What are you looking at?'

Dr. M:'So, you know, you see, you see, I think that the behavior that we're looking at is behavior that you're, that you're observing is behavior that you can observe, you can observe in an animal. So, you can observe, and so, you know, we have to, and we have to observe how these circuits that are, that are developing behave.'
Dr. B:'I'm going to tell you the history of how brain activity came to be important. And then you can talk to us about what it would take to understand its, uh, its function for us.'
Dr. M:'Um, so, when, uh, neural activity started getting studied in the early 1970s, the question that was studied was, how can the brain, the, uh, the function of the brain be described?'
Dr. B:'The answer was, uh, that a, that a, uh, a system has two components, the hardware and the software, and that you have to build up the hardware to understand the software, right?'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'So, to understand the brain, the first thing you do is build up the hardware. So, so this is, uh, what I call, uh, the hardware? So, uh, what happens to be the hardware of the brain? Now, what happens to become the hardware of the brains is the emergence of, uh, and the assembly of neurons and the firing of the neurons that generates the behavior.'

Dr. B:'So the answer that came up at the time was, the answer was to use a phrase, "I will give it a, uh, and then you can understand it." So the answer to the question of, how will you give it a name is that that's the question of the problem. But, uh, that question, uh, wasn't really ever answered because we didn't have a way of how to describe what was in front of us.'

Dr. M:'You know, I mean we have a general view of what the brain does in adult life, but the question you raise is what does it do in terms of building neurons and building synaptic connections and building circuits during development?'
Dr. B:'If we take a look at the brain, then it's important for a long time. And there's not much to ask about it, is there?'

Dr. M:'No. It would just be too boring. So what is it that happens that occurs during development of the brain, that occurs during development is that it produces circuits of neurons, so you know, and you could ask that same question, well, is there a neural network of neurons, that is there, during development, and I think there's certainly networks, you know, the cortex is a network. So it's certainly network-like during development, but it's not as network-like.'

Dr. B:'I mean, I'm asking about a particular kind of function that is generated by the brain during development, but the question could also be, is there a particular kind of, and how does this function emerge? It might be different. And I'm talking about how the brain does something with the information it has available to it. But how does it create that function? And there might be more answers to that.'

Dr. M:'Right, but my problem is that we don't know what these neurons are doing in the brain, during development. So we can't ask this question. So we can ask this question, why is neural activity important during development, but we can't ask it because we don't know, we don't know the answer to it.'

Dr. B:'We don't know. Okay, what is the question that you would like to ask? That was a question you put to the audience, that's actually a question that I would like to ask, too, that could perhaps help us get a better answer than the ones we already have, but also to get a more comprehensive understanding of the development of the brain. So here's the question: what is the fundamental role of neurons in the development of the nervous system?'
Dr. M:'That's an important question, but you see, and it's the thing that is really, you know, why is neural input important during development?'

Dr. M:'No, there's very little to ask about it. There is very little we can ask about it until the brain stops growing, and then we'll get some, you know, we'll get some clues to why neural activity is so important for growth and for keeping, keeping the brain functioning correctly in the adult.'
Dr. B:'Do you have some of that data? Do you have some of the data where you take a look at a, at a brain in the adult stage, and then you can ask that question?'

Dr. M:'No, and I mean, this is a big thing, this is a huge thing, because it comes back to this is a real, it's a real problem, because we know that neural activity is an important thing when you're an older animal, an adult animal.'

Dr. B:'We know that when you're younger you can, I can do a lot more than I could when I'm an adult. That's the argument. In that case, there's a lot of, uh, that's the case when you look at development, which is that there's a lot less to ask about, uh, what is it doing? What is this? What is it doing? And in a way it is the big problem.'
Dr. M:'Right.'

Dr. B:'Right, and the big issue is how those neurons, those circuits that are so important to the development, how they grow and how they stabilize and how they're maintained are being exploited by the brain, and it's a, it's a big problem. And it's a problem, but we have very little evidence about how those systems that are so important in development are being exploited by, by the brain.'

Dr. B:'Well, in a way that you can expand on that, I would say that perhaps, maybe we don't understand what the function is of activity in the brain at this point. We have some good data on the functions of activity in the thalamus, but that's largely in an adult brain, not the very first days of life, not, not the time when, when neuronal activity comes to life, or to continue to come to life.'

Dr. M:'I'm not going to expand on that answer, I'm just going to say that this is an important, this is an important area of research, and as you were mentioning, we're doing some experiments, we've been doing experiments on that as well, to try and determine how these neurons behave, how these neurons behave during development and then as you start to age and then as we, as we age.'

Dr. M:'Well it is not obvious in the development of every circuit. However, during development there are a number of important cellular processes that require continuous and coordinated activity of neural circuits. The process of muscle development, for example, requires coordinated activity of a large number of neurons. Similarly, the process of generating synaptic connections, the process of cell cycle regulation, requires coordination of a large number neurons that are active during specific periods of time.'

Dr. B:'I think it would be a very important advance to understand, at least at a conceptual level, how spontaneous activity is generated and what it does, especially given the fact that there are large differences between circuits in the cortex. I am very much interested in how the brain generates self-organized neuronal activity, and how it transforms this self-organized activity into functions.'

Dr. M:'Right, I think that is the big difference. Because you see, what we are interested in is the behavior of the system. In the brain, it is very difficult to isolate all the underlying mechanisms of how behavior develops. I mean, if we put a probe in the cortex and we looked at the synaptic transmission, or the intrinsic membrane properties, then we might be able to understand how behavior develops. We might understand how the brain is wired to behave.'

Dr. B:'Well, that is a very interesting question, because there are a number, I suppose a couple dozen mechanisms by which self-organized activity emerges. I know that you will ask that question several times, but do you have an answer for it? Or do you think that, like, what are some, or just a handful of, or a couple of key mechanisms, which you have thought about and you are looking for in the laboratory?'

Dr. M:'I guess that is the big question that is always coming back to us, and I think that that is why this is important for people to do, because there is a huge, and I think very complicated, set of questions, but one of the problems in neuroscience is that we have to answer that question by making measurements of neurons and we have to measure circuits and we have to understand how these circuits interact.'

Dr. B:'This is a great argument in favor of our interest in this whole area of research. That is, that the research itself is not a matter of, "What are the mechanisms?" but a matter of, how we can understand, how do the mechanisms give rise to a function that we want to understand?'
Dr. M:'Oh, right. Right. It is a matter of how do we understand how the brain develops? So that is one.'

Dr. B:'Right. There are two other mechanisms. I will list those as a couple, and if you come up with a new one that I did not mention, I will add it to the list. What do you mean by that? What, a couple of mechanisms, I mean, what would be an example of the two mechanisms that you are interested in?'

Dr. M:'Well, I don't know. A couple of mechanisms? A couple of examples would be a small network that has two neurons. That would be a simple model. So one of our favorite models is a model that we made of two oscillators, one being pacemaker activity, the other being sensory-transmitter-dependent, so both are sensory-transmitter dependent.'

Dr. M:'Yeah, and I think people should look into that a little bit more. In general, I think we should really be interested in understanding how nervous systems interact with the rest of the world, and understanding how we are wired to interact with the world.'

Dr. M:'A lot of it is the development of synapses, it's the development of the activity, that develops the rhythm. And the development of synaptic strength and synaptic transmission. Because if you want to develop synaptic transmission, you have to develop the activity. If you want to develop the strength of a synapse, you have to allow for that activity to occur.'
Dr. B:'And you can have the activity without synapses? What is the function of the activity without synapse?'
Dr. M:'Well, it has no function because when you take out the synapses and just the synaptic activity that is produced, there is no way to make it produce a different type of activity.'
Dr. B:'So if I'm understanding correctly, spontaneous activity without synapses is simply activity?'
Dr. M:'Yes.'
Dr. B:'What is activity? What is a synapse? Is there a synapse in the brain? Do I have to go and invent one or look at the brains output?'
Dr. M:'No, the synapses that you find in the brain are the ones that have been used in the past in the nervous system.'
Dr. M:'Right, the activity that is produced is just activity.'
Dr. B:'How does one make synapses? What are the ingredients? What are the components that you need? I'm trying to understand how the synapse comes about.'
Dr. B:'Is it possible to make the activity that is produced without synapse become synapse-dependent? What would that mean?'

Dr. B:'We can take the experience that we've got from the hippocampus in the hippocampus and from the neocortex in the neocortex, and then we will go into a much deeper level and ask a more specific question. What are the brain rhythms? And we will say, well, we've got one that, we have one that is going to be critical to synaptic transmission, to synapse strength. We have another one that will be critical to synaptic communication, to synaptic transmission and synapse strength.'

Dr. M:'Okay, so that is the development of synaptic transmission, that develops synapse strength. The development of synaptic transmission that produces synapse strength, the development of synaptic connectivity, that leads to the development of the network itself. And then, then we will talk about how the network develops. How the network develops as a network.'

Dr. B:'This, this process can go backwards or forward. We can have a very, very specific question now. And we can say, well, what is the critical point, the point where the network is capable of transmitting information? Is that too early? Is that too late? Is that a too fast? Is that a slow, slow? Is that a fast, fast? And then we can go back and see how the process actually develops.'

Dr. M:'Theoretical studies of neural activity show that it can be very variable across preparations and brain regions, both because of the underlying biological parameters and because of the ongoing interaction of neural circuits with their modulatory inputs. Theoretical studies suggest that this variability is an important part of learning in developing nervous systems, because neuronal circuits can be modified in response to neuromodulators, and these processes can create changes in circuit behaviour.'
